 There are changes in the way bonus points are earned in the millennial revision of the County Championship.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

Bonus points are now reckoned on the score in the first 130 overs, not 120 overs as in recent seasons.

Batting: now 5 pts can be earned (4 last year)

200 -249 runs (1pt);

250-299 (2);

300-349 (3);

350-399 (4);

400 or over (5)

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4)

three-five wickets (1);

six-eight wickets (2);

nine-ten (3).

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

*Note: in a draw where the scores finish level , the side batting in the fourth innings earn 6 points their opponents 4, plus bonus points.

fields.headline: Trescothick ready for call
fields.standfirst: Somerset 290-5 v Kent
fields.trailText: Somerset 290-5 v Kent.
fields.body:
Eye-catching performances at this level often suggest a player has the talent to play for England, only for him to be exposed under Test cricket's unforgiving spotlight. But if things continue to go wrong at the top of England's order the selectors might do worse than turn to Marcus Trescothick.

He made 90 against a moderate attack and on a placid pitch, but showed such power and control that he threatened to score a century before lunch. When he was out in the eighth over of the afternoon session, the third wicket to fall with the total on 146, the day lost its lustre, despite a thoroughly professional unbeaten century from Peter Bowler.

Trescothick even middled the ball that dismissed him. He aimed to smash Min Patel through the leg side for his 14th boundary but Martin Saggers clung on two-handed at square leg.

Trescothick, 24, is not far from international recognition. After being selected for last winter's A tour, he was introduced to the atmosphere of test cricket when he was summoned for 12th-man duties against Zimbabwe at Trent Bridge this month. He is tall, left-handed and good against the short ball, which might help his cause as the summer progresses.

Patel, the left-arm spinner who got a brief chance with England four years ago, did his best to keep Somerset in check after Trescothick's fluent assault. Bowling unchanged between lunch and tea, he had Piran Holloway caught behind and persuaded Keith Parsons to leave a ball which knocked back his off stump.

Bowler controlled the final session, reaching his century 10 minutes before the close. It was his 33rd in all but his first this season. He batted like a man who felt it would be foolish to miss out on such a surface.

It was a surprise, therefore, to see Jamie Cox fail. The Somerset captain has not yet reproduced last season's form, when he finished fourth in the national averages. Two sweet boundaries suggested a player intent on making amends, but he was then leg-before to a full-length delivery from Saggers that struck him on the boot. Having to watch rather than bat all day must have been a frustrating experience.

Trescothick, 24, is not far from international recognition. After being selected for last winter's A tour, he was introduced to the atmosphere of test cricket when he was summoned for 12th-man duties against Zimbabwe at Trent Bridge this month. He is tall, left-handed and good against the short ball, which might help his cause as the summer progresses. Patel, the left-arm spinner who got a brief chance with England four years ago, did his best to keep Somerset in check after Trescothick's fluent assault. Bowling unchanged between lunch and tea, he had Piran Holloway caught behind and persuaded Keith Parsons to leave a ball which knocked back his off stump. Bowler controlled the final session, reaching his century 10 minutes before the close. It was his 33rd in all but his first this season. He batted like a man who felt it would be foolish to miss out on such a surface. It was a surprise, therefore, to see Jamie Cox fail. The Somerset captain has not yet reproduced last season's form, when he finished fourth in the national averages. Two sweet boundaries suggested a player intent on making amends, but he was then leg-before to a full-length delivery from Saggers that struck him on the boot. Having to watch rather than bat all day must have been a frustrating experience.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Kim Barnett frustrated the Second Division leaders Warwickshire, and the returning Allan Donald, at Edgbaston to take Gloucestershire past 300 for the first time this season.
fields.body:
Kim Barnett frustrated the Second Division leaders Warwickshire, and the returning Allan Donald, at Edgbaston to take Gloucestershire past 300 for the first time this season.

Donald had two early wickets in his first match since damaging ribs eight weeks ago, but Barnett responded with the 56th century of his career. Jack Russell, captaining Gloucestershire because Mark Alleyne is injured, ended unbeaten on 67 with his team 316 for six.

 Worcestershire, joint top with their Midlands rivals at start of play, enjoyed a better day at Swansea as three more wickets for Glenn McGrath, including his Australia team-mate Matthew Elliott lbw for 62, helped to dismiss bottom-of-the-table Glamorgan for 218.

 Essex also maintained their promotion push with Peter Such taking out his frustrations on Middlesex in Chelmsford. Such, who had claimed two wickets so far this season, took five for 51 as Middlesex limped to 222, but Essex's batting can be equally fragile and Angus Fraser capitalised, taking three for 40.

 Durham and Derbyshire are in danger of coming down the other way but another fine performance by Melvyn Betts ensured that the home side had the better of the first day in Darlington. Betts claimed seven for 30 to make it 27 championship wickets for the season as Derbyshire collapsed from 84 for two to 151 all out. Durham reached 88 for two before rain forced an early close.

fields.headline: Captain contained
fields.standfirst: England taught me discipline, Jimmy Adams tells  Paul Weaver
fields.trailText: England taught me discipline, Jimmy Adams tells Paul Weaver.
fields.body:
England supporters might need a divining rod and an indomitable faith to search for positives after the first Test drubbing at Edgbaston, but here is one happy thought: England did play a considerable role in shaping the singular cricketer that is Jimmy Adams, the West Indies captain.

In his dedication and self-discipline, his thoughtful introversion and humility, his determination to make the most of relatively modest talent and place team ethos above everything else, there is the distant echo of an old-fashioned English professional.

This is no coincidence. He played only one season of county cricket, for Nottinghamshire in 1994 when he was 26. But he had five seasons as professional at Eppleton in the Durham Senior League and spent other summers playing club cricket in Scotland, Shropshire and Surrey. England, a poet might say, shaped, made aware, gave, once her flowers to love, her ways to roam...

"I've played all over the place in Britain, the whole length of the M1 and way beyond. I appreciate the conditions here. I also felt at home here on my many visits. I felt settled for the first time, even though I thought I'd never get used to the weather.

"In the West Indies I am living out of a suitcase and rushing for different planes. Being away from home, being labelled the professional in the side, does create a sense of responsibility. To be recognised and respected I had to be consistent, to match the standards set by other professionals, week in, week out.

"It shaped my attitude. I had to take care of myself. I was responsible for my own performances. There was no captain or coach pushing me.

"Whatever the weather, I had to go out knowing that if I didn't do a job it wouldn't get done. I used to knock it around like any Caribbean player, but here I learned to discipline myself and that to play too many shots was to place the side in danger."

Off the field, too, he widened his character. "I hated being indoors during the day. So I would do any job to get me out. I got a job valeting cars and another making snooker tables. I also had to carry washing machines up tall apartment blocks with no lifts in Edinburgh, which put two inches on my shoulders."

But this very serious-looking Bible reader says he came to love this job, along with all the others, including leading a rabble of a test team out of the international wilderness.

As a player Adams, the ruminative son of a Jamaican doctor and his Canadian wife, was never a natural at this level. His parents, so the story goes, never trusted cricket and tried to push him towards university and medicine. This he dismisses. "It's just a good bit of PR that has come out of the Caribbean. I'm happy to go along with it but it's not really the truth. They were perfectly happy that I should do whatever I wanted provided I was earning a living."

Because of his all-round skills - he also bowls slow left-arm and fields well anywhere, including behind the stumps - he used to be known as Jimmy the Cricket. He first played for Jamaica in 1985 but had to wait six seasons for his maiden first-class century, one of the slowest scored in the Caribbean, and until 1992 for his first test cap.

Carl Hooper, who is such an extravagantly gifted but unfulfilled cricketer that he could almost be Adams's alter ego, has played a significant if unwitting part in the other's promotion. It was Hooper's chipped finger which gave Adams his debut in that historic match in Bridgetown in April 1992 when South Africa returned to test cricket, Hooper's bad back which let Adams in for a good series against England in 1994, and, last year, family illness which resulted in Adams replacing him as vice-captain against Australia. In that memorable series the Jamaican was at the other end while Brian Lara played his match-winning innings in Kingston and Bridgetown.

Adams took over the captaincy after West Indies had 10 overseas test defeats in a row, failing to win one first-class match on tours of Pakistan, South Africa and New Zealand.

In his first test in charge, in Trinidad this year, Zimbabwe needed only 99 to win on the last day. But thanks to Adams the pressure on the batsmen never relented and they were bowled out for 63.

Then, at home at Sabina Park, Adams scored his first century for four years to set up a 10-wicket win. And, under intense pressure, his unbeaten 49 carried his side to victory in the deciding test against Pakistan.

His performance against England in Birmingham two weeks ago was typical of the cricketer and the man: last out after steering his side from 136 for four to a tally of 397.

"The players know me very well. I captained some of the younger ones on an A tour. They know what I stand for. They know what I'm going to ask for. I'm not going to rant and rave but I do expect standards to be met and, if I have to, I can put a point across strongly."

Adams, however, is a consensus captain, one who is constantly seeking and measuring the opinions of others. "I try to involve everyone, with their individual strengths, as much as possible. It's one thing to ask a player to do something. But it's better if we both agree to do something. I have to make decisions but I want everyone to be involved.

"Now, after Birmingham, we have something to build on. I feel we've been rewarded for putting some things in place. It would not have been the end of the world if we had lost that test against Zimbabwe, or the series against Pakistan, because personal experience has told me that you learn your biggest lessons when you fall down.

"But I'm thankful for those results and the one at Edgbaston. And the thing that really pleased me about my 98 there was that there were decent partnerships with Franklyn Rose, Curtly Ambrose, Reon King and Courtney Walsh. That showed me that we had kept the spirit we showed in the last test against Pakistan."

All we have to do now is convince ourselves that Courtney, Curtly, Sherwin, Brian and Franklyn would all be complete duffers if they had not polished their skills in county cricket and the summer might have consolations after all.

webTitle: England look to get bungee jump on West Indies

fields.headline: England look to get bungee jump on West Indies
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey previews the second Test against West Indies at Lord's and finds England quite capable of bouncing back.
fields.body:
For the Marylebone Cricket Club and its members the 100th Test match at Lord's is a cause for celebration, with some of the choicest contributors from the previous 99 matches in official attendance. To Alec Stewart, the former captain reinstated pro tem , on the other hand, it is "just another match" and his side intend to "take each game as it comes".

Well, Stewart said it would be back to the good old cliches and he did not disappoint. Whether it can be followed by a return to the good old winning ways as well, we shall see. England are the bungee jumpers of international cricket, plunging to the bottom of the heap only to bounce back up again, and they are more than capable of doing so this time.

If they have doubts, they need only recall the heady days of 1995. Coming, as now, to Lord's on the back of a nine-wicket defeat by West Indies in the first Test at Headingley, England won an uplifting victory by 72 runs thanks to the spectacular debut of Dominic Cork, whose seven for 43 in the second innings were the best figures on England debut for more than a century.

So the return of Cork to the squad after a 19-month absence has a totemistic quality to it. Nothing gains the respect of the opposition like success against them, and Cork, even if his career tailed off against other opposition, has that from West Indies.

The back injury to Andy Flintoff has pretty much guaranteed that Craig White will play, despite figuring only in one-day games since his bizarre black-out. The chances are also that Cork will renew his Caribbean acquaintances, and very likely slip comfortably into his role as irritant-in-chief to the opposition.

Ed Giddins must have gazed wistfully across the ground when he was released from the England squad last night to wonder how a man-of-the- match award here barely a month ago against Zimbabwe could so quickly translate to being given the elbow.

Yorkshire's prospective 23-year-old debutant Matthew Hoggard will play if the selectors - Stewart included, for this match - decide to leave Robert Croft out of the side and go with a handful of seamers and no spinner.

Nasser Hussain stresses how he dislikes not having bowling options, and Stewart would probably agree with that. Against that, the great Michael Holding argues that you select all bowlers on the premise that they are capable of taking five wickets in an innings, and Croft no longer comes into that category.

England's batting line-up has been disrupted by the enforced absence of Hussain, even though he has had a pitiful summer at the crease so far, but at least it enables Michael Vaughan to re-establish himself, in Hussain's No3 position but keeping half an eye on Mark Ramprakash's opening spot.

Ramprakash ought to be good enough to make big runs but the fates have conspired so that what might be his biggest test of character should be at a venue, albeit his home ground, where he has scored only 79 Test runs from eight innings including a pair in that famous victory five years ago .

West Indies may yet name an unchanged side, although the elbow injury to Shivnarine Chanderpaul, their most prolific batsman on this tour, makes it unlikely. His place may be taken by Ramnaresh Sarwan, who turned 20 only last Friday. The Guyanese is a right-hander to counterpoint all those lefties, and good judges predict a sensational future for him.

In the spirit of making the opposition feel at home, this and subsequent Tests will see the end of the traditional marching band at lunch and the introduction of live and loud reggae from Jamaican bands such as Third World and The Wailers, some drum-and-bass, God help us, from Beenie Man and earplugs for the pavilion.

England retaliate with Jools Holland, who will sing Sunny Afternoon. If ever there was a guarantee of a downpour...

England (from): *A Stewart, M Atherton, M Ramprakash, M Vaughan, G Hick, N Knight, R Croft, A Caddick, D Gough, D Cork, C White, M Hoggard.

West Indies (from): *J Adams, S Campbell, C Gayle, W Hinds, B Lara, S Chanderpaul, R Jacobs, F Rose, C Ambrose, C Walsh, R King, R Sarwan, A Griffith.

fields.headline: Zoff looks sharp in grey
fields.standfirst:
He is not flamboyant and he is not excitable but he suits Italy just fine. Richard Williams reports
Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: He is not flamboyant and he is not excitable but he suits Italy just fine. Richard Williams reports from the Italian camp.
fields.body:
When Francesco Totti scored Italy's first goal against Romania last Saturday, many observers noted that Dino Zoff seemed disinclined to join the celebrations. Why? "Because it was just one goal," Italy's 58-year-old coach replied, "and that's all it was. I don't like excessive enthusiasm."

Zoff comes from the Friuli region in the north-east corner of Italy, a long way from la dolce vita . Up there the sky is often as grey as the goalkeeper's jersey in which he not only won a World Cup winner's medal but also kept a clean sheet for 1,143 consecutive minutes of play - still an international record. He is famous, in fact, for giving nothing away. Even so, his legendary dourness sometimes seems as though it must be an elaborate joke. Maybe, underneath it all, he is the Buster Keaton of the game.

Or maybe not. The self-same Totti, asked recently about the coach's dislike of talking too much, remarked: "When he takes you to one side, it's to tell you there's something he's not happy with. So that's why I'm content for him never to say anything at all."

Yet Zoff, a man who habitually looks as though he carries not just the fate of the national team on his shoulders but the national debt as well, has already achieved something close to a miracle. After a morale-lowering season in which no Serie A club made it as far as the semi-finals of the Champions League, he has helped to restore the self-image of Italian football. Even reaching the last four of Euro 2000 was more than most fans dared to hope for after a build-up featuring a series of undistinguished results.

Despite his reputation for taciturnity, he seems to have brought it off principally by rekindling the spirit of the team. "Inside the dressing room we've made a pact," his striker Filippo Inzaghi said the other day. "And with that state of mind we can go a long way."

The main secret of Italy's success, according to Alberto Cerruti of La Gazzetta Dello Sport, is the squad's internal harmony. "And in everybody's opinion, from the players to the masseurs, the person responsible for that is Zoff."

His first good move, Cerruti said, was to ease the tensions between the players from Juventus and Lazio, who had just finished fighting each other for the championship. It may have helped that he has coached both clubs, won six league titles as a player with the former and will eventually take over as president of the latter.

The second was to allow the players to choose their own shirt numbers. And the third was to give them plenty of freedom during the preparations, reducing tactical lectures to a minimum and letting them spend time with their families.

Ivan Carminati, their chief physio, devised training routines that are entertaining as well as rigorous. Ciro Ferrara and Angelo di Livio, senior players assigned to the bench, entertain their team-mates with songs and stories.

But beyond making the players feel comfortable, Zoff gave them the means with which to dispel self-doubt, to rise above the babble of criticism and to win matches. He has done this by refusing to moan about the last-minute loss through injuries of his most intimidating forward, Christian Vieri, and his No1 goalkeeper, Gianluigi Buffon, and by adopting tactics that maximise the talents of a group long on professional skills but short on genius. Through rehabilitating certain long-established virtues of the Italian game, he has also given the squad a powerful sense of national identity.

So far, his judgment has been subtler than that of his predecessor, Cesare Maldini, who abandoned the 4-4-2 preferred by Arrigo Sacchi and tried to take Italy straight back to the days of catenaccio . Zoff's insistence on efficient defending is reflected in the fact that Italy have conceded only two goals in the tournament so far, but his three-man central module is quite flexible and is flanked by wing-backs who are available to join or initiate attacks, in the modern manner. He listens to his players, too: the selection of Mark Iuliano and the deployment of Paolo Maldini, the captain, wide on the left was apparently suggested by Demetrio Albertini.

Lacking a playmaker of the classic type, Zoff has created a midfield unit based on speed and accuracy of interpassing - which also helps promote the sense of ego-less endeavour. He chooses players, assigns them functions that fit their abilities and then demonstrates his faith in them, which must be why Albertini, for instance, has looked twice the player he was in a Milan shirt last season. And Zoff's wild card, Stefano Fiore, a hard-working left-sided midfield man from unfashionable Udinese, has been a particular success, delivering one of the finest goals of the tournament against Belgium.

The forwards work as hard as the rest of the team, refusing to drop their heads when a chance goes begging. These players show modesty and humility in their efforts - not least Inzaghi, whose achievements with Juventus have made him a superstar but who remains the most wholehearted of team men.

Crucially, Zoff has also handled the peculiarly Italian phenomenon known as la staffetta - the relay - with outstanding wisdom and tact. This feature occurs when two outstanding creative players are deemed unable to play together, either because they are too much alike or too dissimilar. The task defeated two World Cup coaches - Ferruccio Valcareggi, who had to choose between Gianni Rivera and Sandro Mazzola in 1970, and Cesare Maldini, whose dilemma in 1998 involved Roberto Baggio and Alessandro del Piero.

This time Del Piero is in competition with Totti, but Zoff has managed to give Totti the starting berth in every game without upsetting either the most highly paid player in the Italian game or the reporters from the Turin papers who favour him. Even when Del Piero comes on only for the last 20 minutes, Zoff makes him look and feel integral to the team.

A man with 112 caps hardly needs to bother about PR, and the benefit of Zoff's refusal to play the usual games should not be underestimated. From Turin to Palermo, the Italian in the street did not find himself approaching Euro 2000 buoyed up by exuberant predictions of glory.

Zoff's view before the tournament started was straightforward. "I believe we can do well," he said, putting a damper on unrealistic expectations. But why, after a victory as important as the one against Romania, does he continue to sound so downbeat? "Because the most important game is the one that you have to play next. It may sound banal, but that's how it is." And he declined an invitation to raise his earlier assessment of his side's performance, continuing to mark them at seven out of 10. "There's more to come," he promised.

So far, seven out of 10 has not produced a style of play that pleases anyone, but public criticism from Sacchi, in particular, may have served to strengthen the squad's collective spirit.

Even the players who also worked under Sacchi at Milan were upset by his comments after the quarter-final. "It wasn't a pretty game," Sacchi said, "but then our team didn't take risks. This isn't a team characterised by adventurousness or courage. It has patience and concentration, and it's well organised in all departments. Up front, its play is exclusively based on counterattacking, on long balls or on individual bursts. It's a kind of pragmatism that breeds cynicism."

The reaction from within the squad was heated. "Whenever I see Sacchi on the television I change channels," Albertini remarked, and Maldini had a particularly neat riposte. "I'm happy to be spending my 32nd birthday with the squad," he said. "I can remember four years ago, when the championship was held in England and I was back home in time for the celebrations. That was with Sacchi's Italy."

Zoff's own response was thoughtful and incisive and said a lot about the attitude of the players Holland will have to overcome tonight. "People who talk about cynicism aren't watching," he said. "Or at least they're looking at it in partial way. Cynicism implies coldness. Ours is a team with heart, which also happens to have other qualities."

fields.bodyText: When Francesco Totti scored Italy's first goal against Romania last Saturday, many observers noted that Dino Zoff seemed disinclined to join the celebrations. Why? "Because it was just one goal," Italy's 58-year-old coach replied, "and that's all it was. I don't like excessive enthusiasm." Zoff comes from the Friuli region in the north-east corner of Italy, a long way from la dolce vita . Up there the sky is often as grey as the goalkeeper's jersey in which he not only won a World Cup winner's medal but also kept a clean sheet for 1,143 consecutive minutes of play - still an international record. He is famous, in fact, for giving nothing away. Even so, his legendary dourness sometimes seems as though it must be an elaborate joke. Maybe, underneath it all, he is the Buster Keaton of the game. Or maybe not. The self-same Totti, asked recently about the coach's dislike of talking too much, remarked: "When he takes you to one side, it's to tell you there's something he's not happy with. So that's why I'm content for him never to say anything at all." Yet Zoff, a man who habitually looks as though he carries not just the fate of the national team on his shoulders but the national debt as well, has already achieved something close to a miracle. After a morale-lowering season in which no Serie A club made it as far as the semi-finals of the Champions League, he has helped to restore the self-image of Italian football. Even reaching the last four of Euro 2000 was more than most fans dared to hope for after a build-up featuring a series of undistinguished results. Despite his reputation for taciturnity, he seems to have brought it off principally by rekindling the spirit of the team. "Inside the dressing room we've made a pact," his striker Filippo Inzaghi said the other day. "And with that state of mind we can go a long way." The main secret of Italy's success, according to Alberto Cerruti of La Gazzetta Dello Sport, is the squad's internal harmony. "And in everybody's opinion, from the players to the masseurs, the person responsible for that is Zoff." His first good move, Cerruti said, was to ease the tensions between the players from Juventus and Lazio, who had just finished fighting each other for the championship. It may have helped that he has coached both clubs, won six league titles as a player with the former and will eventually take over as president of the latter. The second was to allow the players to choose their own shirt numbers. And the third was to give them plenty of freedom during the preparations, reducing tactical lectures to a minimum and letting them spend time with their families. Ivan Carminati, their chief physio, devised training routines that are entertaining as well as rigorous. Ciro Ferrara and Angelo di Livio, senior players assigned to the bench, entertain their team-mates with songs and stories. But beyond making the players feel comfortable, Zoff gave them the means with which to dispel self-doubt, to rise above the babble of criticism and to win matches. He has done this by refusing to moan about the last-minute loss through injuries of his most intimidating forward, Christian Vieri, and his No1 goalkeeper, Gianluigi Buffon, and by adopting tactics that maximise the talents of a group long on professional skills but short on genius. Through rehabilitating certain long-established virtues of the Italian game, he has also given the squad a powerful sense of national identity. So far, his judgment has been subtler than that of his predecessor, Cesare Maldini, who abandoned the 4-4-2 preferred by Arrigo Sacchi and tried to take Italy straight back to the days of catenaccio . Zoff's insistence on efficient defending is reflected in the fact that Italy have conceded only two goals in the tournament so far, but his three-man central module is quite flexible and is flanked by wing-backs who are available to join or initiate attacks, in the modern manner. He listens to his players, too: the selection of Mark Iuliano and the deployment of Paolo Maldini, the captain, wide on the left was apparently suggested by Demetrio Albertini. Lacking a playmaker of the classic type, Zoff has created a midfield unit based on speed and accuracy of interpassing - which also helps promote the sense of ego-less endeavour. He chooses players, assigns them functions that fit their abilities and then demonstrates his faith in them, which must be why Albertini, for instance, has looked twice the player he was in a Milan shirt last season. And Zoff's wild card, Stefano Fiore, a hard-working left-sided midfield man from unfashionable Udinese, has been a particular success, delivering one of the finest goals of the tournament against Belgium. The forwards work as hard as the rest of the team, refusing to drop their heads when a chance goes begging. These players show modesty and humility in their efforts - not least Inzaghi, whose achievements with Juventus have made him a superstar but who remains the most wholehearted of team men. Crucially, Zoff has also handled the peculiarly Italian phenomenon known as la staffetta - the relay - with outstanding wisdom and tact. This feature occurs when two outstanding creative players are deemed unable to play together, either because they are too much alike or too dissimilar. The task defeated two World Cup coaches - Ferruccio Valcareggi, who had to choose between Gianni Rivera and Sandro Mazzola in 1970, and Cesare Maldini, whose dilemma in 1998 involved Roberto Baggio and Alessandro del Piero. This time Del Piero is in competition with Totti, but Zoff has managed to give Totti the starting berth in every game without upsetting either the most highly paid player in the Italian game or the reporters from the Turin papers who favour him. Even when Del Piero comes on only for the last 20 minutes, Zoff makes him look and feel integral to the team. A man with 112 caps hardly needs to bother about PR, and the benefit of Zoff's refusal to play the usual games should not be underestimated. From Turin to Palermo, the Italian in the street did not find himself approaching Euro 2000 buoyed up by exuberant predictions of glory. Zoff's view before the tournament started was straightforward. "I believe we can do well," he said, putting a damper on unrealistic expectations. But why, after a victory as important as the one against Romania, does he continue to sound so downbeat? "Because the most important game is the one that you have to play next. It may sound banal, but that's how it is." And he declined an invitation to raise his earlier assessment of his side's performance, continuing to mark them at seven out of 10. "There's more to come," he promised. So far, seven out of 10 has not produced a style of play that pleases anyone, but public criticism from Sacchi, in particular, may have served to strengthen the squad's collective spirit. Even the players who also worked under Sacchi at Milan were upset by his comments after the quarter-final. "It wasn't a pretty game," Sacchi said, "but then our team didn't take risks. This isn't a team characterised by adventurousness or courage. It has patience and concentration, and it's well organised in all departments. Up front, its play is exclusively based on counterattacking, on long balls or on individual bursts. It's a kind of pragmatism that breeds cynicism." The reaction from within the squad was heated. "Whenever I see Sacchi on the television I change channels," Albertini remarked, and Maldini had a particularly neat riposte. "I'm happy to be spending my 32nd birthday with the squad," he said. "I can remember four years ago, when the championship was held in England and I was back home in time for the celebrations. That was with Sacchi's Italy." Zoff's own response was thoughtful and incisive and said a lot about the attitude of the players Holland will have to overcome tonight. "People who talk about cynicism aren't watching," he said. "Or at least they're looking at it in partial way. Cynicism implies coldness. Ours is a team with heart, which also happens to have other qualities." fields.headline: Banks sound ATM retreat
fields.standfirst:
HSBC and NatWest decide to scrap cash machine fees, leaving Barclays isolated
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: HSBC and NatWest are to scrap all charges for withdrawing money from cash machines, reviving the furore over Barclays' plan to charge as much as £1 for using its network.
fields.body:
HSBC and NatWest are to scrap all charges for withdrawing money from cash machines, reviving the furore over Barclays' plan to charge as much as £1 for using its network.

The move by the two big clearing banks, which are expected to make announcements about the decisions next week, will pile further pressure on Barclays to rethink its charging strategy.

Earlier this year members of the Link cash machine network engaged in a lengthy public row over a plan promoted by Barclays to alter the charging system for cash withdrawals.

Instead of levying a "disloyalty fee" on its own customers when they used rivals' machines, Barclays wanted to move to a regime of levying a surcharge on rivals' customers using its machines.

While that proposal initially led to concern that bank and building society customers faced the prospect of a double charge - from their own card issuers and the owners of the machines they used - the trend now appears to be swinging back towards free use of hole in the wall machines.

After a series of heated meetings, Link members agreed that surcharges could be introduced from next year. But peer pressure in the industry, ignited by Halifax last month,now appears to leave Barclays and Lloyds TSB as the only two big banks prepared to impose surcharges.

Lloyds appeared to soften its line when it told a committee of MPs that its planned sur charge would be restricted to 50p, a view it maintained last night.

Some players, such as Woolwich and Alliance & Leicester, are already levying surcharges on machines in "convenience" locations, such as remote areas or shops.

By making the decision to scrap all charges from next year, HSBC, which levies a £1 disloyalty fee, becomes one of the biggest players yet to throw its weight behind last month's decision by Halifax, which was the first bank to drop a disloyalty fee after the Link decision.

A spokesman for HSBC would not confirm the plan to drop the fee but said: "We are reviewing our charges."

After some confusion last week about its intentions, NatWest confirmed last night that it, too, was poised to stop charging customers disloyalty fees from next year and would not introduce surcharges next year either.

Peer pressure appears to be the main reason behind the moves, with Abbey National also joining the non-charging bandwagon. It also means that banks and building societies which had not been charging are less likely to start.

Barclays has yet to say at what level its charge will be set but during the protracted battle earlier this year has cited a figure of £1.

The plan by Barclays to levy a surcharge was initially prevented by the threat of legal action by Nationwide building society, which along with the Co-op Bank has refrained from charging customers. After a series of often acrimonious meetings of members of the Link network, the banks and building societies agreed that surcharges could be levied from January next year.

In the past the banks have claimed they need to charge customers for cash withdrawals to recoup the cost of running their networks, estimated to be £80m a year for some of the bigger players.

The industry's move to allow surcharging has also encouraged some of the first non-banks and building societies to introduce cash machines. Securicor last week said it would install machines in villages, convenience stores, hospitals, petrol stations, bars and nightclubs, levying a charge expected to be set at £1.

fields.headline: Intimate moves
fields.trailText:
Royal Ballet New Works***
Linbury Studio Theatre, London
fields.body:
Royal Ballet New Works***
Linbury Studio Theatre, London

Given the title of the Royal's New Works season, it may sound perverse to find the dancers more interesting than the choreography. But the intimate scale of the Linbury puts us in rare and revealing proximity with the performers (as if we were watching in a studio rather than a theatre), while the programme gives us an unusually democratic view of the company, with star principals cast right next to lowly juniors.

Tuesday evening was a long overdue chance to see more of Alina Cojocaru, who made such a stunning debut in Symphonic Variations earlier this season. She took the the lead in Vanessa Fenton's romantic trio Ad infinitum, and if the piece itself was slight, the grandeur and detail of Cojocaru's dancing marked her emphatically as the great ballerina of her generation. Fenton's piece shows lots of craft for a new choreographer, but her take on classicism (and on the dynamics beween men and women) is disappointingly timid.

William Tuckett's 3:4, by contrast, puts its dancers in a teasing, combative relation both with each other and with the music (Schubert's Death and the Maiden), the choreo-graphy working reverently within the music, then deviating away in search of its own phrasing and grammar. Zenaida Yanowksy is wonderful close up - her brain seems to work as vividly as her body - while Carlos Acosta practically rocks us back in our seats with the aftershock of his enormous jumps.

Jacopo Godani's Aeon's Run is a disappointingly anonymous essay in the Frankfurt school of classicism, its toughly virtuoso manoeuvres looking slightly less exciting than a class, despite the passionately intent performances of dancers such as Jenny Tattersall. The most substantial piece of the programme is unquestionably Christopher Wheeldon's There Where She Loves, contrasting images of romance from songs by Chopin and Kurt Weill. The piece starts out looking mimsy (pastel-coloured steps and emotions) but it rapidly grows in complexity with a riveting central duet for Darcey Bussell and Jonathon Cope. This shows Bussell in a rare strop, resisting an unwanted lover; in the tight defensiveness of her timing and the urgent scale of her dancing she looks willful, beautiful and intriguing. A grown-up dance for grown-up dancers.

 Until July 2. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Fresh floats signal hi-tech revival
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The resurgent investor interest in hi-tech flotations was in further evidence yesterday with two more technology companies announcing plans to list on the main market.
fields.body:
The resurgent investor interest in hi-tech flotations was in further evidence yesterday with two more technology companies announcing plans to list on the main market.

IFX Power, a company that makes the hardware needed to operate electronic gadgets for the power industry, said it had raised £30.6m before expenses and would command a valuation of around £117m when its shares are expected to start trading on July 5.

Database software company Alterion plans to raise £20m and will be valued at around £60m.

The float announcements came as shares in internet software firm Orchestream jumped 74% on their first day of trading, just a few weeks after several technology, media and telecom floats were postponed due to market turbulence.

Letsbuyit.com, Yes Television, Filmgroup and Chello were among high-profile new technology-based companies reassessing fundraising plans on the public markets in recent weeks.

IFX Power's European managing director, James Peters, and chief executive Larry Tracey have decided to use the float to cash in £3.4m worth of shares each. Broker Investec Henderson Crosthwaite said both had served the British business of IFX for several years and it was not unusual for key directors to sell shares at the time of a float. "They still retain large stakes," an adviser said.

IFX Power is made up of two power solution firm subsidiaries: a British company called XP and US-based firm called Foresight. Around £10.3m of the money raised will be used to fund the costs of acquiring IPS, another American company.

The group recorded turnover of £58m and pre-tax profits of £3.6m last year.

"What we are looking for from the IPO is to give the group visibility in the market and the opportunity to expand geographically," Mr Peters said.

Alterion, which manufactures software enabling companies to make better use of their customer databases, expects to be capitalised at around £60m if it completes a successful flotation on the main market later in the summer.

Investec Henderson Crosthwaite hopes to raise around £20m to help fund new Alterion offices in the US and Europe, as well as sales, marketing and development costs.

A former WH Smith finance director, Keith Hamill, is non-executive chairman of the group

In the year to March 31, Alterion recorded sales of £1.01m and pre-tax earnings of £12,000, compared to a loss of £255,000 in the previous equivalent period.

fields.headline: I drifted away
fields.trailText:
Festival of Drifting*
City Varieties, Leeds
fields.body:
Festival of Drifting*
City Varieties, Leeds

Rather than awarding medals for endeavour to people who rescue canoeists from fast-moving rapids or take on the Luftwaffe armed with a catapult, the Queen should bestow honours on anyone who manages to sit through the Festival of Drifting. Officially a touring gathering of various strands of ambient and post-rock, it is actually a festival of droning that appeals to people so desperate to be hip that they will not only tolerate Bruce Gilbert, guitarist in Wire, playing (as DJ) what sounds like the amplified traffic from the M62, but will actively applaud it. But less about the good bits.

Because of the mysterious non-appearance of Pole (who decided that the PA wasn't up to scratch), the first "act" (I use the term loosely, as there is no performance involved) was Robin Guthrie. Yes, Robin Guthrie, from the Cocteau Twins. He used to be good. Dammit, he used to be great. Sadly, minus his Liz, this Hugh Grant of indie hasbeendom waddled on with a guitar, played what sounded like the Durutti Column minus any melodies, had some technical problems and grinned. He was perhaps amazed that peo ple will pay good money to see a bad Cocteaus soundcheck.

David Pajo (usually of Papa M) has obviously decided that what the world really needs are the sounds of a tractor tangling with a pylon, and demonstrated them with a guitar for at least 20 minutes. Still, he has a sense of humour; he ended with a bizarre, hilarious Dylanesque song (yes, song) about the minority-interest indie scene. But sadly Pissing in the Wind was lost on a crowd too busy discussing Nick Drake's relationship with John Martyn and record label "imprints".

Icelanders Sigur Ros were like Aled Jones singing with a hopeless Joy Division tribute band covering 40s death- tribute marches. They have the stage presence of four gnats. Heads bowed (rightly so!), black-clad and playing guitars with a violin bow, they were staggeringly precious, ridiculously cacophonous and about as "ambient" as a bassoon up an angry rhinoceros's backside.

In fact, all of this stuff has somehow taken Brian Eno's conception of ambient - innocuously beautiful music - as a licence for anally retentive, insular, naval-gazing pretentiousness of the most unbearable order. By the time I had heard the sub-Tangerine Dream/Fast Show's "Jazz Club" dronings of Labradford, I'd had enough. Festival of Drifting? They should bury it in snow.

 At the Arts Centre, Colchester, tonight. Box office: 01206 500 900.

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB has never felt quite so unloved; its shares are languishing and analysts are less than optimistic after their round of meetings with the bank's management before its results next month.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB has never felt quite so unloved; its shares are languishing and analysts are less than optimistic after their round of meetings with the bank's management before its results next month.

Renowned for its acquisition record, investors and analysts alike are now waiting for chief executive Peter Ellwood to pull off his next deal. Yesterday though, in an interview with the Reuters press agency, he was playing for time, blaming the Don Cruickshank investigation into banking competition as a reason for holding back on any major banking deals in Britain.

"I still think there's scope for further consolidation in the UK. But the chances of very big organisations coming together post-Cruickshank are more difficult I think," Mr Ellwood said.

He ignited speculation that Lloyds TSB might still be able to buy a mortgage bank, essentially one of the former building societies, without running into regulatory barriers.

Mr Ellwood said: "We're looking at a wide range of potential opportunities."

Whether these include Abbey National, the first building society to convert to a bank, or Fortis, the Belgian-Dutch financial conglomerate, two names which feature regularly on the rumour mill, was no clearer.

What is apparent, is that Mr Ellwood needs to prove to the shareholders that the firm can keep the momentum in the business going, even if it fails to find a suitable acquisition target. He will receive support for caution about making a hasty acquisition - but be attacked for failing to keep profits pumping out without one.

What is apparent, is that Mr Ellwood needs to prove to the shareholders that the firm can keep the momentum in the business going, even if it fails to find a suitable acquisition target. He will receive support for caution about making a hasty acquisition - but be attacked for failing to keep profits pumping out without one.

fields.headline: Southern discomfort
fields.trailText:
Orpheus Descending ***
Donmar Warehouse, London
fields.body:
Orpheus Descending ***
Donmar Warehouse, London

Anyone who still doubts that Tennessee Williams was a deeply political writer should see Orpheus Descending. This is a portrait of the American south as hell, a place beset with racism, bigotry and violence. The pity of it is that Williams's undeniable passion is almost buried under the deafening sound of clashing symbols. Myths are clearly in the air. We are in a southern dry goods store ruled over by the Sicilian, Lady Torrance. Her husband, Jabe, is a dying relic whom we discover was involved in the burning of her father's wine garden on the grounds that he sold liquor to black customers.

Enter Val Xavier, an itinerant guitar player in a snakeskin jacket who takes a job in the store, offers Lady the southern comfort she has been sorely missing, and excites the anger of the local rednecks who are baying for blood in the bayou.

Nowhere else does Williams offer such a vicious portrait of the American south. Against this he sets his ageing Eurydice, the Orpheus-like visitor who sympathises with the desperate cries of a chain-gang fugitive and a wayward local beauty who laments the loss of "a wild sort of sweetness" in a land that is sick with neon.

As so often with Williams, the free-spirited confront a world of brute materialism and go down fighting. At its best, in the tender encounters between Lady and Val, the play has a singing poetry. But the exposition is laborious in the extreme and the symbolism becomes top heavy. Val turns into a mixture of Orpheus and Christ.

Written in 1957, the play offers a curious mix of Williams at his best and worst. But Nicholas Hytner's coolly intelligent production is worth seeing for the acting alone. Helen Mirren's Lady Torrance is an exemplary study of an immigrant woman who has acquired a patina of resilient toughness but who slowly acknowledges her sensuality. Stuart Townsend, lean and capable of a poised stillness, is no less compelling and avoids all the cliches of the drifting Don Juan. Saskia Reeves as the isolated local temptress, Richard Durden as Lady's death-stricken husband, and William Hootkins as the burly sheriff add to the sense that we are encountering a community.

Some productions swathe the play in atmosphere. But Hytner has uncovered it and revealed a work that, for all its imperfections, is filled with Williams's hatred of oppression.

 Until August 19. Box office: 020- 7369 1732. This review appeared in some editions yesterday.

fields.headline: $1bn Priceline heads for Europe
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Priceline, the US e-commerce company that enables buyers to name the price they are prepared to pay for goods they want to buy, announced plans yesterday to launch a European operation in the autumn.
fields.body:
Priceline, the US e-commerce company that enables buyers to name the price they are prepared to pay for goods they want to buy, announced plans yesterday to launch a European operation in the autumn.

The new firm, Priceline.com Europe, will be headed by Denis Malamatinas, who last weekresigned as chief executive of the fast-food chain Burger King.

Priceline claims to be the best-known internet company in America after Amazon.com. Its large-scale advertising campaign has featured the actor William Shatner - Captain Kirk in Star Trek- and this year the business expects to turnover $1bn (£660m).

Users of Priceline name the price they are prepared to pay for goods ranging from flight tickets and new cars to groceries and fuel. Sellers then have to match those prices if they can.

Mr Malamatinas, who takes up his new post on September 1, said he had been made an irresistible offer to run the new operation by Priceline's founder, Jay Walker, when the two first met in March.

"The sheer intrigue of building a leading e-commerce brand in Europe was too tempting to turn down," Mr Malamatinas said. "I've spent my entire career building brands and Priceline is a very powerful proposition.

"For the first time buyers and sellers are able to connect directly. Consumers can regularly save 30-40%. We believe Europeans will respond favourably and quickly to this pricing model."

Priceline Europe.com will be a joint venture between Priceline Inc, which is listed on Nasdaq, and General Atlantic Partners, one of its original venture capital backers. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

The initial European launch will be in the UK, moving into Germany, France and Benelux in the following months.

It will offer customers the opportunity to name their price for telephone calls, airline tickets, hotel rooms and car rentals. A reply is promised within one hour. Priceline is expected to spend heavily on advertising in the UK and, as in the US, this may also involve Mr Shatner

Tim Brier, co-founder of Priceline in the US, is moving to Europe to chair the new company. He believes that flights will be one of Priceline's most popular lines.

"There are 450,000 empty seats on planes flying around Europe every day," he said. "It's like 900 planes floating around the skies with no-one onboard. Airlines are desperate to fill those seats."

Some analysts expect Priceline's arrival to put the squeeze on internet flight specialists such as Lastminute.com and E-bookers. But Lastminute said that the two companies had different business models that could peacefully co-exist with one another. Priceline also had a strategic 1.5% investment in Lastminute.

Since the service began in April 1998 more than 5.3m people have used Priceline, generating revenues of $313m (£207m) in the first quarter of this year. Analysts are forecasting revenues of $1bn in 2000 and expect the company to make a profit by the end of 2000 or first quarter of 2001.

Priceline claims that two-thirds of American adults are aware of its brand. It has already announced moves into the Far East and Australasia.

Mr Malamatinas, 45, was chief executive of Burger King, part of the Diageo drinks group, for two years. He has previously worked for IDV, Pepsico and Procter & Gamble.

Amazon

webTitle: Ford 'leads the race' for Korea's Daewoo

fields.headline: Ford 'leads the race' for Korea's Daewoo
fields.trailText: Ford last night was reported to have taken pole position in the race to buy the South Korean car maker Daewoo Motor. The US group has been selected as a favoured bidder, according to a local television station, YTN.
fields.body:
Ford last night was reported to have taken pole position in the race to buy the South Korean car maker Daewoo Motor. The US group has been selected as a favoured bidder, according to a local television station, YTN.

Ford refused to comment on the report. "There has not been an official announcement by the restructuring committee," said a spokesman at the company's world headquarters in Dearborn, Michigan.

Ford is competing with two joint bids, one from DaimlerChrysler with Hyundai and the other from General Motors with Fiat.

A decision on which bids will go into a second round is expected tomorrow.

Daewoo has the capacity to produce some 2m cars a year with plants in eastern Europe as well as in South Korea, where it sold some 340,000 cars last year.

The car business is being sold as part of the dismantling of the main Daewoo group - once South Korea's second biggest conglomerate - which ran into financial problems in the wake of the crisis which swept through many Asian economies in 1997.

The sale of Daewoo Motor has attracted bids from all three of the big US automotive manufacturers - but it is seen as a particularly good fit for Ford which is eager to expand its presence in Asian markets where sales are expected to grow faster than in Europe and the US. Ã

fields.headline: Running scared
fields.trailText: 29 June: Last year I got a final written, then I was ill. I am worried I will get the sack but I'm too frightened to ask advice from personnel as they disciplined me in the first place.
fields.body:
The problem

Last year I was given a final written warning after one of my staff had stolen some money and I had not noticed. In the meantime I had already moved to a lower-paid, part-time position, due to ill health. My problem is now that I am terrified I will get the sack as even a trivial misdemeanor will mean dismissal.

I've had a few weeks off sick this year and I am also frightened that this will go against me. And I'm too frightened to ask advice from personnel as they disciplined me in the first place. How can I regain my confidence and self-esteem?

The solution

Relationships between employer and employee are often irrevocably damaged by the time a final written warning is delivered. You will probably already have had at least one verbal warning as well as another written warning. A final written warning often leads to the employee leaving, either voluntarily or not.

That is not to say that an employee so disciplined cannot claw their way back into the grace and favour of their boss. But, a bad reputation is notoriously hard to turn around and to do so will require a great deal of effort, self-analysis and honesty on your part.

The first thing to do is to examine what is going wrong. Were these warnings deserved? Is the quality of your work suffering because of your health? Can things improve?

If you feel that you can turn over a new leaf and deserve a chance to prove yourself again, I suggest you sit down with your boss and explain why things have gone so wrong. Explain how you are going to implement changes in your work so as to ensure that your performance is improved. And, you are will have to take extra care over all your work, checking and double-checking, perhaps working longer hours, just to be sure that there is no cause for complaint.

As far as getting advice is concerned, if you are a member of a union, ask them. If not (and it is too late to join and get help with this issue now) you could try ACAS (number in your phone book) or your local Citizen's Advice Bureau.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Petit in frame for France
fields.trailText: Emmanuel Petit has declared himself fit for semi-final duty against Portugal in Brussels this evening after recovering from the knee-ligament injury that forced him to miss France's last two games.
fields.body:
Emmanuel Petit has declared himself fit for semi-final duty against Portugal in Brussels this evening after recovering from the knee-ligament injury that forced him to miss France's last two games.

The World Cup holders were also lifted by news that Christophe Dugarry is available for selection despite his broken nose. "Petit is fit and so is Dugarry," said Roger Lemerre, the coach. "All 22 players are operational. Petit's availability gives me another possible solution."

Petit picked up his injury in the win over the Czech Republic, and Dugarry sustained his in a clash of heads with a Spanish defender during the quarter-final, though he played on with cotton wool in his nostrils.

But Holland, who face Italy tomorrow, suffered a blow when it was confirmed that the full-back Arthur Numan, who ruptured a muscle in his right foot during the 6-1 defeat of Yugoslavia, is out of the tournament. "The doctor said the chances I could play for Thursday was nil," the Rangers defender said. "And it's almost impossible I can play the final."

Numan will be replaced by his Ibrox club-mate Giovanni van Bronckhorst, but will stay with the squad. "Hopefully I'll be there on Sunday and hopefully Monday and Tuesday for the celebrations if we win."

Italy's Paolo Maldini should be fit despite problems with a thigh muscle in his left leg. The captain resumed light training yesterday but Fabio Cannavaro dropped out of the session because of a right-knee problem. "It's an inflammation I've had for a couple of days; it was hurting so I stopped." Asked whether it was likely to sideline him, the Parma defender replied: "I don't think so."

webTitle: Feast calls for French and Dutch treat

fields.headline: Feast calls for French and Dutch treat
fields.standfirst:
David Lacey on the final that the purists are demanding
Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: Portugal and Italy could yet upset the apple cart, but a Holland-France final could become an all-time classic.
fields.body:
Europe is about to discover if its first football championship of the new century will surpass the best of the last. In other words can Euro 2000, already the best-looking tournament of its kind since 1984, provide an even better finale than 1976, the all-time classic?

Certainly the ingredients are mouth-watering. Tonight, in the first of the semi-finals, France and Portugal meet in Brussels in a reprise of the 1984 semi-final in Marseille, which produced one of the most spellbinding international games ever played before the French won narrowly in extra-time.

Tomorrow evening, in the Amsterdam Arena, Holland play Italy in what will be the biggest match between them since they faced each other in Buenos Aires in the later stages of the 1978 World Cup. That was when Enzo Bearzot, Italy's coach, fatefully took off his best forward, Franco Causio, when he thought he had the game won. He duly lost it 2-1 and the Dutch went on to reach the final.

Victories for France and Holland over the next 48 hours would satisfy most tastes for Sunday's final and vindicate the majority of forecasts. France, since the start, and Holland, more gradually but with equal standards of excellence, have confirmed what was suspected all along, that they are the most accomplished national teams operating in Europe, with only Brazil and Argentina able to give them a serious argument elsewhere.

For the moment the dissenting voices belong to Portugal and Italy, who in style and character bear some resemblance, respectively, to the Brazilians and the Argentines.

The Portuguese, though conforming to the contemporary demands of the team ethic, are still willing to express themselves in the exceptional individualism of Luis Figo or Rui Costa. The Italians combine speed with technique, power with vision, and rate pace and mobility in defence as highly as they do in attack.

Both are capable of denying the tournament its logical final; both have the means to punish lapses of concentration on the part of French or Dutch.

A meeting of minds between Zinedine Zidane and Dennis Bergkamp in the Feyenoord stadium on Sunday might be the footballing equivalent of Freud bumping into Jung, but first Zidane has to out-think Rui Costa in the King Baudouin stadium and then Bergkamp has to outwit whatever strategy Dino Zoff has devised to restrict his influence in Amsterdam.

It would be wrong, however, to depict either semi-final purely as a cerebral conflict involving outstanding individuals. If this tournament has reminded football of nothing else it is that one player's achievement is indivisible from the collective efforts of those around him.

Zidane catches the eye because he appears to saunter between the lines of battle like a neutral taking notes. When he does deliver a pass it is often with the nonchalance of someone giving the kids their ball back. There is an air of you-might-as-well-have-this-I-don't-want-it about his distribution which disguises some of the most cunning angles the game has yet seen.

Yet initially France will look as much to the intelligence of Patrick Vieira and Didier Deschamps in providing a base for their movements of sufficient flexibility to prevent Figo, Rui Costa and Joao Pinto getting hold of the play between the penalty areas. If Figo finds space on the right similar to that enjoyed by Spain's Pedro Munitis on the left when he gave Lilian Thuram a hard time in the quarter-finals, Portuguese hopes will soar.

Tomorrow night all Holland will await the renewal of the almost telepathic link between Bergkamp and Patrick Kluivert which in the quarter-finals found Yugoslavia's arboreal defence suffering from a bad outbreak of Dutch elm disease. Yet before this can happen Philip Cocu and the loquacious Edgar Davids will surely have to impose themselves on an Italian midfield packed with strength and sinew even in the absence of Antonio Conte.

France and Italy have the best central defenders and the most reliable goalkeepers. Marcel Desailly has been a man revived and Francesco Toldo is an omnipotent presence behind Fabio Cannavaro and Alessandro Nesta.

Holland look stronger at the back than Portugal, who might have paid heavily for allowing David Beckham so much space in their opening match had a tactical ingenue not been in charge of England. The Dutch, however, can be undone by final passes and crosses of a sort which have yet to find the French or the Italians seriously wanting.

One of the reasons for expecting the semi-finals to go with form and forecast is that France have the means both to keep Portugal out and pen them in, and Holland have begun to take a higher proportion of their chances than Italy, for whom Filippo Inzaghi is Imre Varadi with a pedigree.

To have reached this stage without having to resort to golden goals or penalty shoot-outs is a feat in itself. Such artifices would demean a tournament which has set such high standards of open football, helped in equal measure by sensible refereeing and co-operation from the players.

Whoever gets to the final the most encouraging thought is that Sunday's conclusion in Rotterdam can hardly fail to provide a spectacle of skill and entertainment. Most non-committed spectators would settle for Holland and France. They should get their wish.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: Deschamps stands down, Trezeguet moves on, England are in the clear.
fields.body:
 Didier Deschamps has decided to retire from international football after Euro 2000, according to reports in the French press.

The 31-year-old France captain is expected to win his 100th cap in today's semi-final against Portugal and was reported in Le Parisien to have told close friends and team-mates of his decision.

"He's marvellous, fabulous," said the Chelsea defender Marcel Desailly when asked to comment on the future once Deschamps does decide to hang up his boots. "Nobody will do the job quite like him."

 The French striker David Trezeguet has joined Juventus from Monaco in a £16.5m deal. The 22-year-old will be replaced by the £13m Burundian forward Shabani Nonda, who has signed from Rennes.

 Uefa will not impose a further European ban on English football despite the violent scenes in Charleroi and Brussels at Euro 2000.

Over 900 supporters were arrested in the two cities, but the Uefa general secretary Gerhard Aigner has ruled out a similar ban to that imposed after the Heysel disaster in 1985. "We must not exclude English clubs because when there is an international competition held in England there is never the slightest problem," he said.

"We can't just continue making idle threats. Rather we must work in depth with the FA and the English government. We must give ourselves the means of eradicating hooliganism."

 Portugal's coach Homberto Coelho is not even guaranteed the support of his wife in this afternoon's semi-final against France - she is French and has yet to decide who she will be cheering on.

"You'll have to ask her, but I think she'll be for Portugal," he admitted. The France midfielder Robert Pires has his own family problems as his father is Portuguese.

webTitle: Djorkaeff ready to provide that little bit extra

fields.headline: Djorkaeff ready to provide that little bit extra
fields.trailText: Roy Collins previews the first semi-final as France 2000 aim to replace France 1984 as the greatest national side ever.
fields.body:
Youri Djorkaeff was a wide-eyed 16-year-old on the terraces of Marseille's Stade Velodrome when France last played Portugal in a European Championship semi-final in 1984. And when he taps into the emotions of that memorable evening, the words still tumble out in the vocabulary of an impressionable teenager. "It was a fantastic experience," he says, "one of the greatest nights of my life."

Tonight, in the King Baudouin stadium, he and his team-mates intend to repeat that victory, though they will be hoping for a less dramatic finish than 16 years ago. Then, the heavily fancied French rescued themselves with a Spanish-style comeback, turning a 1-2 deficit into a 3-2 triumph with a 118th-minute winner from Michel Platini when the referee was already pondering which end the penalties should be taken from.

France went on to beat Spain 2-0 in the final and, though Djorkaeff talks of repeating that success, victory in Euro 2000 would represent not so much emulation as obliteration of the side always hailed as the greatest in France's history. The 1998 World Cup win was undoubtedly a greater achievement but French fans are no different from any others in refusing to acknowledge greatness until it is in encased in mothballs.

This French team still carry scars from the back-stabbing over their style of play in France 98, when they were constantly compared unfavourably with the holy midfield trinity of Platini, Alain Giresse and Jean Tigana in 1984. So if they see off the talented Portuguese tonight and then lift the trophy on Sunday they will have earned the right to insist that critics think twice before launching an attack.

Djorkaeff also remembers the inspiring effect the 1984 win had on the French nation. "That match meant so much to French football," he says, aware that tonight's means no less to expectant supporters who have become so used to victory that they are unlikely, like fans of old, to respond to underachievement with a Gallic shrug.

Zinedine Zidane believes the team have ripened since 1998, and their performance against Spain in Sunday's semi-final certainly endorsed his words. Part of the secret might be the eclectic experience garnered by the players. Djorkaeff, who capped an outstanding display with the winner, plays in Germany with Kaiserslautern; Zidane, Laurent Blanc and Lilian Thuram play in Italy; Patrick Vieira, Thierry Henry and Deschamps in the Premiership; and Nicolas Anelka in Spain, with Premiership previous. Christophe Dugarry is back in the French league after spells in Italy and Spain.

Djorkaeff says: "I knew I was going to score that goal against Spain the moment I brought the ball under control. I could just feel it. It is the kind of feeling that only comes from having a lot of confidence in the squad."

It is also a feeling that only comes when a player is at the peak of his fitness and form, and France's coach Roger Lemerre will surely retain Djorkaeff in the midfield tonight, even though Emmanuel Petit is fit again.

Portugal can expect to win the support of neutrals because of the mesmeric performances of such players as Luis Figo and Rui Costa which have helped to make them most people's favourite second team. Yet despite the impression that the French are too arrogant to warrant popularity, the sheer majesty of their football would win them plenty of votes in a beauty contest.

Close as Spain took them in the quarter-final, there was a conviction on and off the pitch that whereas the Spaniards at times seemed to be running close to empty, France always had some juice sloshing away in the reserve tank.

That is one of the privileges of World Cup winners, insists Djorkaeff, saying: "We are champions and we feel like champions. And champions, of course, always feel strong and have that little bit more to offer when it is necessary." They may need to prove that again tonight.

Venue King Baudouin stadium,

Brussels

Kick-off 7.45pm BST

Referee Günter Benkö

(Austria)

Head-to-head

France: 13 wins

Portugal: 5 wins

Draws: 1

Television

Live on ITV from 7.30pm

Replayed on BBC1 at 12.55am

Radio

Live on Radio 5 Live from 7.30pm
