fields.headline: Portugal 1 - 2 France
fields.standfirst: Refresh this page for the latest action
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

France: Barthez, Thuram, Desailly, Blanc, Lizarazu, Vieira, Deschamps, Petit, Zidane, Henry, Anelka. Subs: Lama, Rame, Candela, Djorkaeff, Pires, Wiltord, Micoud, Leboeuf, Karembeu, Dugarry, Trezeguet.

Portugal: Baia, Xavier, Couto, Costa, Dimas, Conceicao, Vidigal, Rui Costa, Costinha, Figo, Gomes. Subs: Bento, Beto, Capucho, Espinha, Jorge, Pauleta, Pinto, Quim, Sa Pinto, Sousa, Secretario.

Referee: G Benko (Austria)

1 Portugal kick-off as they bid to avenge their semi-final defeat at the hands of France in 1984. They immediately pass back to Baia and he hoofs the ball upfield.
2 A very cautious start for Portugal as they again pass back to Baia. France nearly caught out when a back-pass to Barthez almost sells him short.
3 Still nothing much to speak of as both teams seek to find their feet.
4 Portugal free-kick wide on the right just fails to release Rui Costa on a run.
5 Thuram sets off down the right for France, tries a one-two with Anelka; France win a free-kick - Petit takes from wide on the right, 40 yards out, but Vieira is penalised for wrestling with Vidigal in the area.
7 Henry gets up on the left and crosses from the byline but it is easy for Baia.
8 Portugal free-kick after Gomes is brought down by Vieira near the left touchline. Comes to nothing. Rare poor control by Zidane 30 yards out almost allows Rui Costa to get away into space but Baia charges out to cover.
11 Still no real rhythm to the game as France win a free-kick 25 yards out, square-on to goal. Zidane takes and tries to lift the ball over to top to the advancing Blanc near the right-hand upright but it runs out of play.
13 Zidane is finding life difficult up against Xavier who has most definitely got his tackling head on tonight.
15 Deschamps finds Anelka on the right but the ball is cleared for a throw.
16 Things have suddenly picked up as Henry is tackled on the left byline by the omni-present Xavier. France free-kick, but it goes for a France throw on the right. Cleared by Portugal.
18 Thuram and Zidane exchange passes to the right of the area, but Portugal hold firm and neither can find space in which to pass. Then Vieira does just that and races away on the right, crosses for Petit on the far side of the area but he cannot get in a shot.
19 GOAL! Portugal 1 - 0 France From nothing this one. Conceicao picks up possession to the right of the France area from a Xavier pass, does well to keep hold of the ball as he cuts inside and then finds Gomes 20 yards out. Gomes strikes first time with his left foot to leave Barthez stranded as the ball flies to his right for the opener.
23 Booking Vieira for hacking down Figo.
25 France pick up the pace and Baia is forced to gather a cross from the right to his near post.
26 France free-kick 35 yards out. Petit takes it quickly, over the top, but Baia gets there first.
27 Gomes races away on the right for Portugal and finds Figo ahead of him, but his cross from the byline is easy for Barthez.
29 Anelka picks up possession to the left of the France area, runs across the face of goal and shoots from the right but Baia claims. Portugal break, Figo beats Blanc 25 yards out but his right-foot shot from the edge of the area is blocked by Desailly; Barthez claims the wildly looping delfection.
33 France come alive as Zidane plays superb one-touch football with Henry to the right of the Portugal area. The ball goes wide to Thuram, then back in for Henry to snatch at his shot from distance.
36 Dimas and Rui Costa play a lovely one-two on the right which sees Rui Costa away to the byline, but his cross comes to nothing.
37 Portugal finding most of the space at the moment, particularly down the right as Rui Costa is brought down near the touchline - no foul.
38 France push up - Henry races to the byline and dives right on the edge of the area; nothing given.
40 Booking Desailly for a tackle on Rui Costa 30 yards out. Conceicao blasts the free-kick straight at the wall.
42 France starting to look frustrated as more and more of their passes are failing to reacsh the target.
43 Conceicao gets away on the right and launches the ball into space for Rui Costa to chase but Barthez commits himself early and clears.
44 Henry agains finds space on the right of the area and pulls the ball back for Vieira to shot over the bar.
45 The half draws to a close with France on the attack. Zidane shimmies around the edge of the area and unleashes a shot into the crowd. Portugal win a free-kick on the touchline, to the right of the area, after Desailly barges Rui Costa of the ball and into the linesman. Figo takes and France clear. Half-time. Not the exhibition match that many had hoped for and probably not the scoreline that many would have predicted either, but Portugal deserve their lead nonetheless.

46 France kick-off the second half. Anelka fails to get in an early cross from the left byline.
47 Henry fails to get around Costa on the edge of the area before Vieira is pulled up for a foul.
50 France get up numbers but Portugal again hold firm and clear.
51 GOAL! Portugal 1 - 1 France France free-kick square to Petit; he plays it in but Portugal clear. France play it back in again straight away and find Anelka on the right byline. He pulls it back for Henry to shoot to the far post for the equaliser.
54 The pace of the game now bears no comparison to the first half.
55 Anelka is brought down right on the edge of the penalty area by Costa, and he earns a booking...
56... Petit takes the free-kick but Dimas blocks well. Portugal break with Figo down the left but his cross into the area is headed away for a corner by Lizarazu. France clear.
58 Rui Costa sprays the ball wide to Conceicao on the right but France cover well.
59 France corner from the right. Petit takes to the far post, but Desailly can only get his shoulder to the ball and direct it wide.
61 Bento on for Vidigal.
62 Good work by Portugal around the France area allows Rui Costa to get in a shot. Booking Dimas for a challenge on Henry.
64 Portugal win a corner after more good work on the right by Costinha. Comes to nothing.
65 Vieira tries to break through the middle but is obstructed.
67 Henry goes down after a challenge from Xavier, but after a quick rest he his back on his feet.
68 Zidane rides three challenges in midfield with some fancy footwork but is undone by the fourth and loses possession when he could have played back for safety.
70 A great pass by Zidane on the edge of the centre circle finds Anelka in space to the left of the area, but his delayed shot is blocked.
71 More great work by Zidane he controls the ball with chest and foot before finding Anelka in the area, but Anelka loses his footing and the ball goes for a free-kick.
72 Substitution Wiltord on for Anelka.
74 Vieira plays in Wiltord on the right and France win a corner. Desailly again the target man and again he fails to get to the ball.
76 France corner on the right. Petit takes but Baia punches clear.
77 Lizarazu plays the ball in; it comes out for Petit to shoot from the edge of the area - Baia forces the ball wide. Unlucky for France.
78 Substitution Joao Pinto on.
82 Frantic stuff now as both teams seek to avoid extra time and the golden goal scenario.
83 Petit just fails to find Henry running into the area.
85 Portugal continue to push up but have had few chances on goal in this half. France are packing the penalty area whenever Portugal cross the half-way line.
86 Figo tries to find Conceicao on the right but Barthez beats him to it at the corner flag.
87 Gomes' header from a looping centre is saved by Barthez. Substitution Pires on for Petit.
88 Thuram pulls the ball back from the byline but there is no one there to meet it and Portugal clear. France corner.
89 Zidane takes but it comes to nothing.
90 Desperate times now. Can Portugal pull a late goal out of the dying minutes of this match? Portugal free-kick. Figo takes from 40 yards out and finds Xavier who heads well for Barthez to make a great save. Terrific chance for Portugal. Two minutes extra to play. Henry in the six-yard box pulls the ball back, but again there is no one there for France as Portugal pack out the area. Full-time. Extra-time to follow - golden goal applies!

1 France kick-off the first do-or-die session of the tounament. France almost wrap it up in the first minute when Zidane's header from a deep cross goes over.
2 Figo is chopped down, and it looks as though malice was indeed a forethought as there appears no reason for such a rash challenge.
4 Portugal free-kick. Bento takes and Portugal try to work through from midfield - to no avail.
5 An increasingly frustrated-looking Zidane's cross is charged down by Bento near the left touchline.
6 Henry works his way into the area is run out for a corner by Bento when he should have laid the ball back to the man over...
7...Pires takes and Blanc heads over. Blanc goes down injured, but gets up when the referee tries to prod him on to Uefa's hospitality stretcher.
8 Conceicao now goes down injured after attempting a cross from the right.
10 Conceicao is sretchered off. And then returns almost immediately.
11 Pires tries to get around the back on the left and wins a corner - Portugal clear. Zidane shimmies around on the left of the area before being brought down by Xavier for a free-kick four yards to the left of the area...
12... Zidane swings it in to the near post but Portugal clear.
13 France having the best of the possession and the chances, but Portugal are certainly not being overrun.
14 Figo finds Conceicao on the right but becomes isolated when trying a long route into space behind the defenders.
15 Wiltord tries a one-two with Zidane on the edge of the area, but fails to pick up the return. SubstitutionTrezeguet on for Henry. Wiltord wins a corner on the right after Portugal crowd him out. Pires takes and the ball comes to Wiltord on the left of the area - offside. Half-time.

16 Portugal kick-off the second period with France looking the more likely to score.
17 Booking Joao Pinto. Zidane tries a shot from distance - no chance as the ball rolls lamely wide.
18 Gomes tries to loop the bll over the top to Figo but he is caught offside. Close, but good, call.
19 France come close but Wiltord in the area is thwarted by the offside flag.
20 Joao Pinto shoots from just inside the area and beats Barthez but the ball goes a foot wide of the far post.
23 France break with Zidane; he takes the ball 30 yards before being stopped by Rui Jorge.
24 Penalty! Xavier is deemed to have saved with his hand from Wiltord at the near post when Baia became stranded after a probing run by Trezeguet. Long delay as the referee consults again with the linesman...
27... Zidane takes and scores the winner as the Portugese players surround the referee. Rui Jorge looks as though he is about to head-butt the ref. But it is all over to boos from the crowd. Portugal 1 - 2 France.

Blanc goes down injured, but gets up when the referee tries to prod him on to Uefa's hospitality stretcher. 8 Conceicao now goes down injured after attempting a cross from the right. 10 Conceicao is sretchered off. And then returns almost immediately. 11 Pires tries to get around the back on the left and wins a corner - Portugal clear. Zidane shimmies around on the left of the area before being brought down by Xavier for a free-kick four yards to the left of the area... 12... Zidane swings it in to the near post but Portugal clear. 13 France having the best of the possession and the chances, but Portugal are certainly not being overrun. 14 Figo finds Conceicao on the right but becomes isolated when trying a long route into space behind the defenders. 15 Wiltord tries a one-two with Zidane on the edge of the area, but fails to pick up the return. SubstitutionTrezeguet on for Henry. Wiltord wins a corner on the right after Portugal crowd him out. Pires takes and the ball comes to Wiltord on the left of the area - offside. Half-time. 16 Portugal kick-off the second period with France looking the more likely to score. 17 Booking Joao Pinto. Zidane tries a shot from distance - no chance as the ball rolls lamely wide. 18 Gomes tries to loop the bll over the top to Figo but he is caught offside. Close, but good, call. 19 France come close but Wiltord in the area is thwarted by the offside flag. 20 Joao Pinto shoots from just inside the area and beats Barthez but the ball goes a foot wide of the far post. 23 France break with Zidane; he takes the ball 30 yards before being stopped by Rui Jorge. 24 Penalty! Xavier is deemed to have saved with his hand from Wiltord at the near post when Baia became stranded after a probing run by Trezeguet. Long delay as the referee consults again with the linesman... 27... Zidane takes and scores the winner as the Portugese players surround the referee. Rui Jorge looks as though he is about to head-butt the ref. But it is all over to boos from the crowd. Portugal 1 - 2 France.

webTitle: Flintoff ruled out as White steps in

fields.headline: Flintoff ruled out as White steps in
fields.trailText: Craig White will return to England Test duty against West Indies at Lord's tomorrow only a month after his inexplicable loss of consciousness in a Scarborough sidestreet.
fields.body:
Craig White will return to England Test duty against West Indies at Lord's tomorrow only a month after his inexplicable loss of consciousness in a Scarborough sidestreet.

The Yorkshireman's opportunity comes because Andrew Flintoff, the hulking Lancashire all-rounder, was ruled unfit yesterday after a recurrence of the back ailment that continues to undermine attempts to transform him into a genuine all-rounder.

For White, the opportunity to add to his eight Test caps is one of the most remarkable stories of recent years. He has played only two first-class matches this season, and since his enforced lay-off he has gingerly returned to action in only three one-day matches.

"It would have been nice to get a bit of match fitness back, but I'd like to think I'm ready for a five-day game," he said. "I've never felt fitter, but you don't black out for no reason. You get a bit paranoid but you have to get on with it."

Flintoff is still no nearer to discovering the source of the back pain that has troubled him intermittently throughout his career. After an abortive net session, he packed his bags for Manchester and a further consultation with Brad Williamson, a spinal surgeon who has also treated Michael Atherton.

Dean Conway, England's physiotherapist, suggested Flintoff's symptoms were "not overly concerning; his back pain is not of the same intensity as in South Africa last winter and no major problems have been revealed by any of the scans in the last few years".

This latest setback will nevertheless encourage further scepticism over the validity of England's attempts to mould Flintoff's unwieldy 17 stone plus into an all-rounder of authentic pace rather than predominantly a middle-order batsman of awesome power.

His pace rivalled that of Darren Gough during England's innings defeat at Edgbaston, but 23 overs, 19 of them on the second day, proved too taxing. Either that or blame a bracing Cleethorpes breeze when he bowled only three overs in Lancashire's NatWest Trophy third-round win against Lincolnshire a week ago.

His tour of South Africa last winter was also fraught with injury worries. Back trouble almost caused him to return home early, with Conway urging regular back-stabilising exercises as a part of a more professional attitude to fitness.

He then fractured his left foot while bowling during the Cape Town test. White was summoned as a replacement from New Zealand, where he had been playing for Central Districts, and acquitted himself well enough to claim one of England's central contracts.

fields.headline: A century of its own
fields.standfirst:
Lord's reaches 100 not out as England try to level the series with West Indies
Lord's facts and figures
fields.trailText: Lord's reaches 100 not out as England try to level the series with West Indies. Nick Mason reviews the highs, lows and frankly contradictory events that have characterised this unique venue.
fields.body:
When Lord Harris, with WG Grace at his side, led his England team on to the Lord's outfield against Australia on July 21 1884, the debutant Test venue was a long way from being the principal cricket arena in the land. The rival establishment across the Thames at Kennington Oval - thanks to high-class organisation and a sharper business acumen - had until earlier that season staged every home Test match, and until the previous year every home football international as well.

By the start of the 20th century, however, the influence, money and patrician style of Marylebone Cricket Club had established Lord's as the most charismatic Test venue in the world. And so it remains on the eve of its 100th Test match: a place where every overseas cricketer dreams of beating England, and where every schoolboy batsman imagines himself acknowledging the applause for his maiden Test century (scored ideally on his 17th birthday, before lunch, against Australia).

Yet the history and reputation of Lord's also offers a mass of contradictions. This tranquil domain of law-abiding MCC members provided, for instance, the unwholesome sight in 1980 of those members, fuelled by drink and frustration at rain delays, roughing up umpires for sticking rigidly to the game's regulations. Lord's can bring a lump to the throat as it rings down the curtain on Dickie Bird's career as master of ceremonies or John Arlott's as master of the microphone, yet it can also rack us with embarrassment at the innate cruelty of cricket, as it did in 1960 when South Africa's Geoff Griffin was no-balled out of the match, and out of Test cricket for ever, for his suspect arm action. It is the very temple of middle-class rectitude, with near-Victorian views on sartorial propriety, yet it was also the stage for the first Test-match streaker in 1975 (fined 20 quid, don't do it again).

It was at Lord's that Ian Botham became the first cricketer to score a century and take eight wickets in an innings in the same Test, and at Lord's that the maestro's reign as England's captain - a reign without a single win - ended ignominiously with a duck in each innings. It is a ground where England have, over the years, performed pretty well (35 Tests won against 24 lost), yet a ground where their decline in the past two decades has been highlighted most emphatically: half of those defeats have come since 1980, but only seven of the victories.

The anomalies do not end there. The Lord's Test match, by tradition, is synonymous with high summer - after Royal Ascot, before the climactic week of Wimbledon - with the sun blazing down to torture the members in their mandatory collars-and-ties. Yet of the 99 Lord's Tests so far, the weather has severely curtailed play, or crucially affected the result, in almost exactly a third.

The biggest anomaly of all is Australia. England won that first Lord's encounter in 1884 emphatically, by an innings; they did the same two years later, and won twice again before the century closed. But since then, through 22 Ashes series played in England (as well as the one-off Centenary Test in 1980) Australia have lost only once, and even then Bill Woodfull's team of 1934 went on to regain the Ashes they had relinquished in the Bodyline series.

Lord's has bestowed spectacular rewards on a few favourites. Bob Massie, for example, was deemed good enough to play for Australia only six times, and ended his Test career with only 31 wickets, yet more than half of those were taken on his debut, when he swung England to defeat at Lord's in 1972. His 16-137, eight wickets in each innings, has never been surpassed at headquarters.

England players have, of course, had more opportunity for success (and failure) and a few have gloried in its special atmosphere. Nobody who was there has ever forgotten the blazing hot day in 1938 when Walter Hammond, regrouping an innings in tatters at 31 for three, scored 70 imperious runs off Australia's finest in each of the three sessions (70 not out at lunch, 140 not out at tea, 210 not out at the close) to end the day with his side safe and in command at 409 for five. Next morning he took his score to 240 and was cheered to the echo until his back had disappeared into the shadows of the Long Room.

It was not, even then, the highest Test innings played at Lord's (Bradman, of course, held that one) and it did not win the match, but it had been a display of courage, power and technique of exceptional resonance. The guv'nor of Lord's, however, was Graham Gooch. He played 21 Tests there between 1975 and 1994 and scored more than 2,000 runs, a good 750 more than any other batsman (though Alec Stewart, who needs two runs in tomorrow's Test match to be second on the list, is still going strong). Gooch scored six Test centuries at Lord's, too, including his 333 against India in 1990, the highest innings ever played there.

Courageous Cowdrey
It is another measure of the fickle nature of Lord's that whereas two more of Gooch's distinguished contemporaries, Geoff Boycott and David Gower, also passed the 1,000-run mark at Lord's, the other high achiever of the era, Mike Atherton, averages only 32 and has never scored a Test century there - though he did run himself out for 99 against Australia in 1993.

Even stranger has been the reluctance of Lord's to get us really excited on the last day. In 99 Tests it has produced only one decisive result tighter than a win by four wickets (Australia beating England in 1985) or by 61 runs (ditto, 97 years earlier). The exception was Pakistan's two-wicket victory engineered by Wasim Akram and Waqar Younis to clinch the most gripping of contests in 1992, which could legitimately stand as the finest Lord's Test of all were it not for the West Indies match of 1963 - Frank Worrell, Wes Hall and a one-armed Colin Cowdrey.

As the last over began of a game whose fortunes had swung back and forth through sunshine and shower-breaks for all five days, England needed eight runs to win with two wickets left. One of those wickets, though, was that of Cowdrey, whose left arm had been broken by a ball from Hall the night before but who was prepared, if it came to the crunch, to face the bowling with one hand holding the bat in a left-hander's stance. Hall, who had bowled unchanged, and very fast, for the past 3 hours, conceded singles off his second and third balls; Derek Shackleton was run out trying to steal a bye off the fourth; and in came Cowdrey, left arm in a sling and mercifully at the non-striker's end. With two balls remaining four results were possible: an England win, a West Indies win, a tie and a draw. David Allen stoutly blocked them both to ensure the draw - and fled before an invasion of spectators delirious with equal measures of excitement, admiration and relief.

There have been 51 Tests at Lord's since that drama. It remains the greatest of Test venues - and it is high time the old lady, 100 Tests old this week, pulled another spine-tingler out of the hat just to prove it.

There have been 99 Test matches played at Lord's to date, including one between Australia and South Africa during the triangular series of 1912...

Yet the history and reputation of Lord's also offers a mass of contradictions. This tranquil domain of law-abiding MCC members provided, for instance, the unwholesome sight in 1980 of those members, fuelled by drink and frustration at rain delays, roughing up umpires for sticking rigidly to the game's regulations. Lord's can bring a lump to the throat as it rings down the curtain on Dickie Bird's career as master of ceremonies or John Arlott's as master of the microphone, yet it can also rack us with embarrassment at the innate cruelty of cricket, as it did in 1960 when South Africa's Geoff Griffin was no-balled out of the match, and out of Test cricket for ever, for his suspect arm action. It is the very temple of middle-class rectitude, with near-Victorian views on sartorial propriety, yet it was also the stage for the first Test-match streaker in 1975 (fined 20 quid, don't do it again). It was at Lord's that Ian Botham became the first cricketer to score a century and take eight wickets in an innings in the same Test, and at Lord's that the maestro's reign as England's captain - a reign without a single win - ended ignominiously with a duck in each innings. It is a ground where England have, over the years, performed pretty well (35 Tests won against 24 lost), yet a ground where their decline in the past two decades has been highlighted most emphatically: half of those defeats have come since 1980, but only seven of the victories. The anomalies do not end there. The Lord's Test match, by tradition, is synonymous with high summer - after Royal Ascot, before the climactic week of Wimbledon - with the sun blazing down to torture the members in their mandatory collars-and-ties. Yet of the 99 Lord's Tests so far, the weather has severely curtailed play, or crucially affected the result, in almost exactly a third. The biggest anomaly of all is Australia. England won that first Lord's encounter in 1884 emphatically, by an innings; they did the same two years later, and won twice again before the century closed. But since then, through 22 Ashes series played in England (as well as the one-off Centenary Test in 1980) Australia have lost only once, and even then Bill Woodfull's team of 1934 went on to regain the Ashes they had relinquished in the Bodyline series. Lord's has bestowed spectacular rewards on a few favourites. Bob Massie, for example, was deemed good enough to play for Australia only six times, and ended his Test career with only 31 wickets, yet more than half of those were taken on his debut, when he swung England to defeat at Lord's in 1972. His 16-137, eight wickets in each innings, has never been surpassed at headquarters. England players have, of course, had more opportunity for success (and failure) and a few have gloried in its special atmosphere. Nobody who was there has ever forgotten the blazing hot day in 1938 when Walter Hammond, regrouping an innings in tatters at 31 for three, scored 70 imperious runs off Australia's finest in each of the three sessions (70 not out at lunch, 140 not out at tea, 210 not out at the close) to end the day with his side safe and in command at 409 for five. Next morning he took his score to 240 and was cheered to the echo until his back had disappeared into the shadows of the Long Room. It was not, even then, the highest Test innings played at Lord's (Bradman, of course, held that one) and it did not win the match, but it had been a display of courage, power and technique of exceptional resonance. The guv'nor of Lord's, however, was Graham Gooch. He played 21 Tests there between 1975 and 1994 and scored more than 2,000 runs, a good 750 more than any other batsman (though Alec Stewart, who needs two runs in tomorrow's Test match to be second on the list, is still going strong). Gooch scored six Test centuries at Lord's, too, including his 333 against India in 1990, the highest innings ever played there. Courageous Cowdrey It is another measure of the fickle nature of Lord's that whereas two more of Gooch's distinguished contemporaries, Geoff Boycott and David Gower, also passed the 1,000-run mark at Lord's, the other high achiever of the era, Mike Atherton, averages only 32 and has never scored a Test century there - though he did run himself out for 99 against Australia in 1993. Even stranger has been the reluctance of Lord's to get us really excited on the last day. In 99 Tests it has produced only one decisive result tighter than a win by four wickets (Australia beating England in 1985) or by 61 runs (ditto, 97 years earlier). The exception was Pakistan's two-wicket victory engineered by Wasim Akram and Waqar Younis to clinch the most gripping of contests in 1992, which could legitimately stand as the finest Lord's Test of all were it not for the West Indies match of 1963 - Frank Worrell, Wes Hall and a one-armed Colin Cowdrey. As the last over began of a game whose fortunes had swung back and forth through sunshine and shower-breaks for all five days, England needed eight runs to win with two wickets left. One of those wickets, though, was that of Cowdrey, whose left arm had been broken by a ball from Hall the night before but who was prepared, if it came to the crunch, to face the bowling with one hand holding the bat in a left-hander's stance. Hall, who had bowled unchanged, and very fast, for the past 3 hours, conceded singles off his second and third balls; Derek Shackleton was run out trying to steal a bye off the fourth; and in came Cowdrey, left arm in a sling and mercifully at the non-striker's end. With two balls remaining four results were possible: an England win, a West Indies win, a tie and a draw. David Allen stoutly blocked them both to ensure the draw - and fled before an invasion of spectators delirious with equal measures of excitement, admiration and relief. There have been 51 Tests at Lord's since that drama. It remains the greatest of Test venues - and it is high time the old lady, 100 Tests old this week, pulled another spine-tingler out of the hat just to prove it. There have been 99 Test matches played at Lord's to date, including one between Australia and South Africa during the triangular series of 1912...

webTitle: The epidemic that cries out for more than one Condon

fields.headline: The epidemic that cries out for more than one Condon
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel The wonder is not that people in cricket are bent, but that some still appear to be straight.
fields.body:
The International Cricket Council announced that it was getting tough on crime by appointing Sir Paul Condon to take charge of match-rigging inquiries. This was a rather New Labour announcement, since it is at least the seventh time we have been told that the ICC is getting serious about corruption, and there is always less to each announcement than meets the eye. In this case, it may take a moment for the unwary to realise that Condon's power is decidedly limited.

The only Blairite aspects missing are that (a) so far no one yet appears to have called Condon "the match-rigging czar", and (b) no one has said that, as well as being tough on crime, the ICC plans to get tough on the causes of crime. This is partly because it ain't getting tough on these at all.

Consider the life of Brian Statham. The coincidence of his sad death this month and the Cronje hearings prompted many comparisons between the disgraced captain and the dead hero ("a real cricketer!"). However, Statham - without having frittered his money on champagne or cocaine - spent most of his later life in financial stress.

In 1957, around the height of his career, the fee for English professionals playing in home Tests leapt from £75 to £100 a match. At the time the average working man was getting close to £1,000 a year, without having to worry much about losing it all in the event of a groin strain.

Most of Statham's best-known contemporaries converted their celebrity into some kind of pension plan: in the City, PR, the media, after-dinner speaking, even (Fred Trueman) a bit of cabaret. Statham - great bowler; nice, shy man - was very un-that.

Since then the money has shot up, but nowhere near as much as the expectations. In 1957, golfers, tennis stars and footballers (maximum wage: £20 a week) earned damn all too. Now cricketers have been left miles behind. Sure, there are fortunes available for Lara, Warne and Tendulkar, as there would be for an English equivalent if one ever appeared. But they get rich by ancillary deals.

Chris Adams, a failure at top level, is said to get £70,000 a year at Sussex, but even that's a pittance by sporting standards, and most get in a year what a Premiership player earns in a week. County players' security hinges on the mad, degrading caprice of the benefit system and whether they can hustle.

Remember too that the UK is about the richest of the 10 Test-playing countries. The Aussie dollar has been weak for years, let alone the rand, the rupee or the Bangladeshi taka. The average pro golfer is richer than everyone else he meets. Yet the money sloshing round the edge of a cricket field is far greater than anything available in the middle. The new £360m (with power to add) world television deal is one sign of that.

Another sign is the number of wealthy people in the pavilion and corporate boxes as the corks pop at Lord's tomorrow. And those are the punters, never mind the bookmakers. Yet when the Pakistani umpire Javed Akhtar disgraced himself in the Headingley Test of 1998 (incompetence being the best interpretation, corruption the worst) he was paid 158 piddling quid, 1/18th the fee of his English partner.

Fringe international players are paid better, but not always by much. The wonder is not that people in cricket are bent, but that some still appear to be straight. To a struggling pro, Statham may seem a more alarming example than Cronje.

Teams get £10,000 for winning a one-day international this summer, £20,000 for a Test, but what's that split 14 or 15 ways compared with what might be on offer from an Indian bookmaker? And all the evidence of the past few years is that the system of endless, pointless, contextless one-day games staged as wallpaper for TV and bookmakers - a system in which a well-rigged game or a contrived incident will never be noticed - is to the corruption epidemic what the San Francisco bath-houses were to Aids.

"The amount of one-day cricket has no bearing on allegations of corruption," said David Richards of the ICC on Monday, bizarrely. It would be interesting to know what Condon thinks after a few months in this cesspit.

fields.headline: Claire Denis - part two
fields.standfirst: Music and soundtracks | Beau Travail | Questions from the audience
fields.trailText: Part two of the Claire Denis interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
JR: How do you think about music when you're writing the script? I know when you wrote Beau Travail, you were listening to the Benjamin Britten opera. So it's really a big part of the whole process for you?

CD: Yes. For instance, Nénette et Boni was completely nourished at the very beginning when we were writing the script by a song by the Tindersticks called 'My sister' In a weird way it was there all the time, but I was lucky enough to be able to ask them to be there, y'know. It's true that music is the origin, it opens free space and I trust that. Music gives an opportunity, even if a scene is soundless or there is dialogue with no music, it could be open and created by music. Like a vision, you know, colours. I don't know, music in film for me is not another part of a soundtrack, it is something that also helps to approach a character, to foresee the type of image, you see what I mean, it's like a part of the process.

JR: Faces, again. You use the same actors again and again, so we see the same faces, we see people getting older, you've worked several times with Alex Descas. Grégoire Colin, who's in this film, we've seen him age from quite a young boy in the short to the legionnaire in this film. Why do you like using the same people? Is it security, to have a family around you? Or is it so that the viewers can see something different with the same people?

CD: No, I think that it's because I am a very slow person. I always feel that when a film is finished it's not enough. It's important to immediately start another one with the same people. A film takes a lot of time, and yet not enough to share with the people you're making the movie with, I think. I didn't consciously create a family. I think it's interesting to always work with the same person because you learn together, you experience things together. I like that very much. Also I think it's a good way to be protected from horrible so-called casting, y'know. I think it's so terrifying that you write a script and now you have to cast - so to prevent that terrible moment, I. . .

JR: Has any producer ever said to you 'Well for this film you have to have a star'?

CD: Yes, for all the films! But all the people I work with are stars to me. They are no better than the people I work with, I think. Denis Lavant, Michel [Subor], I mean to me, they are stars. When we were doing Beau Travail, Denis knows and Michel knows how much I wanted to work with them. I told my producer that without Denis I was not going to make the film.

JR: Let's get on to Beau Travail. This film has a very strange origin, in that it's a film about the desert based on the sea story based on Herman Melville's Billy Budd. How did the story turn into the film?

CD: As I told you, I was proposed by Arté and I thought maybe, as I was myself so ignorant about the Legion, the best way was to create a film about being a foreigner. But the Foreign Legion is like a myth, it's been in movies many times and we had a very, very low budget. So I kind of knew that the group would be a few men and not an army and I realised that again, literature, my knowledge of men together, of discipline, with women separate, was the way Melville described a sailor's life. I keep remembering that from my teens and I thought that maybe it would help me to approach the story about the Legion. Little by little, I realised that in Billy Budd, I didn't like [the character] Billy Budd, I was most interested in Galoup, who was the bad guy and he was going to be the main character. I was less interested in a character that was innocence and purity, to me I understand Claggart better. I don't think he's evil, I think he's really human, opposed to Billy Budd who was the symbol of purity. That's how we started. Little by little, as I worked with Denis Lavant, we find out that what was solid for us was mostly Herman Melville's poetry. More than Billy Budd. That's how we started working with Denis, was with a poem.

JR: Some critics also invoked Jean Genet because like Genet's stories it's a story about men being very physical in a very enclosed male environment. Was that the idea - do you see it as a homoerotic story?

CD: Yes of course. I mean, Billy Budd is almost an icon and I knew of course, I mean I've seen Querelle, I've read Querelle, which is Jean Genet's interpretation of Billy Budd - so of course I knew that. But I think I like Querelle very much, but I think it's difficult to work under the shadow of Billy Budd and Querelle. It was good to choose a free path and knowing that we were in relation to a landscape that would express something to the group of men, maybe a jail after all. Also Galoup's room at the end is like a cell. And the nightclubs with the girls would be like the other side of the world so I think it was better to go free.

JR: OK. And now we welcome on stage the film's stars Denis Lavant and Michel Subor. Michel, first of all, people will recognise you from Godard's Le Petit Soldat - and you have the same name as the character in that film [Bruno Forestier] - is this the same character 40 years on?

MS: Could be (laughs). It could be, yes, definitely. It was the same man who acted, so, it is the same character I guess.

JR: Claire, what is the connection between the two Bruno Forestiers?

CD: Well, I was looking for a commandant and I knew it had to be someone who has a past. A guy who stays so long in the Legion would have a heavy past and in France would have some connection with the Algerian war. I think Le Petit Soldat is the film that I like - more than like - I think it's a part of my life of film-making. Le Petit Soldat is very important. Michel Subor is part of that and I always wanted to work with him. Sometimes I was too shy to ask, but I always wanted this. I saw this was the right moment to ask him to be in it and therefore I wanted him to be called Bruno Forestier, to have the bracelet and to be the same guy. Because at the end of Le Petit Soldat he shoots the guy from the Algerian Secret Service and he has escaped from the French army so he has no place to go . . .

MS: Yes, you quit something to get into something else - that's the reason of the Foreign Legion - you enter a new family, a new life - and he's entering this.

JR: Working with Denis, could you see Galoup already in the character we know from the Leos Carax films?

CD: Well, as I said before, I would not have been able to make the movie without Denis, and Denis doesn't speak English, so he doesn't understand a word of what I am saying [laughter]. He was part of the project from the first day. Also because I knew Denis from Leos Carax movies, and also from the theatre, he works a lot in the theatre. The project was linked to him right from the beginning.

JR: It's a very physical role, Galoup. How did you do the manoeuvres and the dance? Did you practice, you were trained?

DL: Yes, we were trained. Physically, I was already in okay physical condition. You have to be somewhat fit when you work in the theatre - a little bit! Further to this, however, we also worked for a month with a choreographer, Bernardo Montet who made us work like animals to learn the ways of the Legion - not only the drill and the endurance, but also the more difficult - the instinctive choreography. In fact, as I was involved in the theatre, I could not participate fully in rehearsals, if the truth be told. Yet, it was when I actually arrived there, at Djibouti, I had to be 100% in perfect shape in order to play a character who is a legionnaire, who has been there for fifteen years. To be credible I had to become a part of the country, almost. It is this that I disappeared into and it was a pure pleasure throughout the film to completely immerse myself in the culture of Djibouti and in the volcanic rhythms of the film. . . I could go on for hours (laughs). I would like to add something that interests me very much, that Claire mentioned earlier, while we were speaking on the train, about working from another script to rehearse something that is entirely different. For me, I practise juggling to help with the more tedious training - to help keep my head free.

JR: Denis took his juggling material with him to Djibouti to practise, because Claire has the practice of rehearsing not with the scripts that they're actually going to film but with other texts. So he was working on other texts as well, which was his juggling. Let's have some questions because we have time.

Q1: Did you get the scene [in Beau Travail] where they're circling each other from Once upon a Time in the West?

CD: I thought of that when we did the editing. But the thing is, it was a real exercise that you learn doing martial arts - to walk in a circle and always look at the enemy's eyes. So we trained that with Bernardo Montet. After training on that exercise we decided to keep it in the movie. There was a scene in the script where they were facing each other, looking at each other with a fierce look and we so turned it into that, you know. When we were in the editing room I thought 'That's like a Sergio Leone movie'. I was amazed.

Q2: Where is the Lithuanian driving to at the end of J'ai pas Sommeil?

CD: I wanted her to drive back to Vilnius with the money. But I wanted to go and film her driving to Vilnius. But we couldn't make that so we were just able to have her drive off from Paris but that was the main idea, to have her drive back home.

Q3: What does dancing mean to you?

CD: I don't know. Have you never been a teenager dancing in your room? Locked yourself in your room and danced? No, me, I think this is something normal. Dance is something you do, to. . .

Questioner: To survive?

CD: Yeah, exactly. I don't know how to say to survive but I agree with that completely. But it's something you do especially when you're on your own. It has a special meaning, you know. It is a memory of mine, being teenage in my room. But I think, Beau Travail has a different approach, it has something that was part of the discipline of those men together and to approach it with something that was strong enough to create something in the film - was to work with this choreographer, Bernardo [Montet], that Denis mentioned. We never thought we were doing dance, we never pronounced the word dance as we were working - we were doing the training, you know, but it slowly became like a dance, but it was not. . .

JR: And earlier in your career, you also worked with Jerome Savari. . . did that involve dance in any way?

CD: No, but I was doing electrics and things, I was not involved in his work. I was rigging the bulbs.

Q4: [To Denis Lavant] What is it like working with Claire Denis? How is she as a director?

DL: [approximate translation of his reply] For me it was an encounter, because I didn't know Claire at all. I had never seen her films, because I never go to the cinema. It was a great pleasure to work and to communicate on the set - I didn't have an impression of being supervised - how can I explain? She was there in a firm way, in a directive way, providing confidence, a framework, someone to talk to. There was the idea of a character, the thoughts of character that interested me, that existed in the world of Billy Budd - the descriptions of the mental mechanisms of that life of the ghetto - these provided a base. But after there was a framework - some rules of driving - Claire gave me a licence to propose a sense that the character existed. She helped me discover a mode of communication that influenced me greatly. We discovered the poem that helped us with the shooting.

JR: [translating DL's reply] Because there was this mechanism of the characters of Claggart and Galoup in the film with envy and the jealousy, on top of that he had to make the character realistic as a Foreign Legion sergeant but with that there was a great freedom. Also Claire had given him Melville's poems which were very well translated into French. . .

CD: I think that Denis was saying was that it was very mysterious the way I thought Denis would be that Galoup. Denis was mentioning that we communicate through Melville's poem more than through the psychological aspect of this guy full of desire of being perfect and full of envy. I think it's true that we sat down every day, reading poetry before going shooting. We did communicate much more like that - through Melville rather than through explanation of. . . I don't know, it was easier - and also we communicated through the physical effort of being under that sun and in that landscape. To explain to someone to do this, to be Galoup is almost there -

DL: Galoup is a narrator. . .

JR: So Galoup is the narrator of the story - actually Claggart is not the narrator of the Melville story. . .

CD: Galoup is.

JR: So as narrator he is very much directing the story, he is bringing it about - there is a complicity that he feels with the camera.

CD: Yeah, for instance we had always in mind that we would try to look at Galoup as if through the landscape so that we knew that the story was in the past for him.

Q: Can you tell us about working with the director of photography Agnès Godard and the jazz musician Abdullah Ibrahim?

CD: She [Godard] was actually in all my films but one. She started by doing camera operating and became DP afterwards, and we were in the same school. We've been learning to work together, in a way she is a companion of my work, like Jean-Pol [Fargeau] with whom I write the script. Both of them have been a part of my work since I started. Abdullah Ibrahim is different. He's a musician I really like and he was also a friend of Ornette Coleman since the 70s. As he was one of the formidable, interesting musicians of the free jazz experience. When I wrote my first script, I didn't mind his music from South Africa, as he was exiled from South Africa. I saw this music was carrying this sort of regret for a country that he doesn't live in any more. I wrote him a letter and he answered and we collaborated on two films.

Q5: Have ethnographic films - for example directors like Jean Rouch - influenced you in any respect?

CD: In a way I feel obliged to respect Jean Rouch because I am told he is very important. I must say I always felt amazed and almost from a different planet, you know. I like to share something with the people I film. I understand, I've seen all his films and I've always been interested in his films, but it's separate. I don't know. It's hard for me to express what I feel in a Jean Rouch movie, but I feel like the planet is divided into sections - and to me it's not like that - so that's what I can say.

Q6: The creases are very important in Beau Travail

CD: The commandant says that the elegant exterior will create interior elegance - that is why the pleats are important. That sentence I heard from an officer in the Legion and I was completely amazed and I tried to think about it and then I knew, I read and I knew - a shirt - even if you are in a camp in the desert, a shirt should have three folds in the back. When they are in the camp, they should manage themselves. So that's how we wrote that scene where they were ironing. And the laundry was also something I knew exists, but because we were only fifteen - because before ironing you have to wash and dry the laundry - and it was for me the image of the army. We were only fifteen soldiers and I thought the laundry drying on the lines were - so we wrote it like that in the script - that it was the army itself drying on lines as the exercises were to walk also on lines. So we already did that kind of connection in the script. That's why it was easy to make, because everyone felt rehearsed like that.

Q7: What are your influences as a film-maker?

CD: To make my answer short - it's may be by being in the audience as a spectator that films really worked on me for years, like Le Petit Soldat. Working on movies as an assistant director (eg with Rivette or Wim Wenders) was sharing that person's approach. The films we were working on, in a way I don't know these films so well. The relationship is from inside, but it's maybe as part of the audience that I learn from movies more than anything. I think working as an assistant was a part of knowing people who like cinema and to learn from a movie you have to watch it. To me, it's my experience. I learnt more from Le Petit Soldat than from Paris, Texas.

JR: Can you tell us something very quickly about the film that you're finishing at the moment, which is with Vincent Gallo, Trouble Everyday?

CD: The film is called Trouble Everyday and I must say, really that it's really a good title, since we've started. And I wish I could find another title because it is trouble everyday. I don't know, it's still, it has vague shape, but it's not yet a film. It's something that is on its way to being a film. It's true that there is Vincent Gallo and Alex Descas and Beatrice Dalle and Tricia Vessey, but it's not yet a film.

JR: Well it's tantalising. Are the three of you [ie Lavant, Denis and Subor] going to work together again?

CD: I hope, really hope so. I think Denis and I, we have some ideas about working together again - and I think with Michel too.

JR: Well I will always get my shirts ironed by the Foreign Legion in future. Thank you, all three of you for coming tonight.

CD: Thank you very much.

It's true that music is the origin, it opens free space and I trust that. Music gives an opportunity, even if a scene is soundless or there is dialogue with no music, it could be open and created by music. Like a vision, you know, colours. I don't know, music in film for me is not another part of a soundtrack, it is something that also helps to approach a character, to foresee the type of image, you see what I mean, it's like a part of the process. JR: Faces, again. You use the same actors again and again, so we see the same faces, we see people getting older, you've worked several times with Alex Descas. Grégoire Colin, who's in this film, we've seen him age from quite a young boy in the short to the legionnaire in this film. Why do you like using the same people? Is it security, to have a family around you? Or is it so that the viewers can see something different with the same people? CD: No, I think that it's because I am a very slow person. I always feel that when a film is finished it's not enough. It's important to immediately start another one with the same people. A film takes a lot of time, and yet not enough to share with the people you're making the movie with, I think. I didn't consciously create a family. I think it's interesting to always work with the same person because you learn together, you experience things together. I like that very much. Also I think it's a good way to be protected from horrible so-called casting, y'know. I think it's so terrifying that you write a script and now you have to cast - so to prevent that terrible moment, I. . . JR: Has any producer ever said to you 'Well for this film you have to have a star'? CD: Yes, for all the films! But all the people I work with are stars to me. They are no better than the people I work with, I think. Denis Lavant, Michel [Subor], I mean to me, they are stars. When we were doing Beau Travail, Denis knows and Michel knows how much I wanted to work with them. I told my producer that without Denis I was not going to make the film. JR: Let's get on to Beau Travail. This film has a very strange origin, in that it's a film about the desert based on the sea story based on Herman Melville's Billy Budd. How did the story turn into the film? CD: As I told you, I was proposed by Arté and I thought maybe, as I was myself so ignorant about the Legion, the best way was to create a film about being a foreigner. But the Foreign Legion is like a myth, it's been in movies many times and we had a very, very low budget. So I kind of knew that the group would be a few men and not an army and I realised that again, literature, my knowledge of men together, of discipline, with women separate, was the way Melville described a sailor's life. I keep remembering that from my teens and I thought that maybe it would help me to approach the story about the Legion. Little by little, I realised that in Billy Budd, I didn't like [the character] Billy Budd, I was most interested in Galoup, who was the bad guy and he was going to be the main character. I was less interested in a character that was innocence and purity, to me I understand Claggart better. I don't think he's evil, I think he's really human, opposed to Billy Budd who was the symbol of purity. That's how we started. Little by little, as I worked with Denis Lavant, we find out that what was solid for us was mostly Herman Melville's poetry. More than Billy Budd. That's how we started working with Denis, was with a poem. JR: Some critics also invoked Jean Genet because like Genet's stories it's a story about men being very physical in a very enclosed male environment. Was that the idea - do you see it as a homoerotic story? CD: Yes of course. I mean, Billy Budd is almost an icon and I knew of course, I mean I've seen Querelle, I've read Querelle, which is Jean Genet's interpretation of Billy Budd - so of course I knew that. But I think I like Querelle very much, but I think it's difficult to work under the shadow of Billy Budd and Querelle. It was good to choose a free path and knowing that we were in relation to a landscape that would express something to the group of men, maybe a jail after all. Also Galoup's room at the end is like a cell. And the nightclubs with the girls would be like the other side of the world so I think it was better to go free. JR: OK. And now we welcome on stage the film's stars Denis Lavant and Michel Subor. Michel, first of all, people will recognise you from Godard's Le Petit Soldat - and you have the same name as the character in that film [Bruno Forestier] - is this the same character 40 years on? MS: Could be (laughs). It could be, yes, definitely. It was the same man who acted, so, it is the same character I guess. JR: Claire, what is the connection between the two Bruno Forestiers? CD: Well, I was looking for a commandant and I knew it had to be someone who has a past. A guy who stays so long in the Legion would have a heavy past and in France would have some connection with the Algerian war. I think Le Petit Soldat is the film that I like - more than like - I think it's a part of my life of film-making. Le Petit Soldat is very important. Michel Subor is part of that and I always wanted to work with him. Sometimes I was too shy to ask, but I always wanted this. I saw this was the right moment to ask him to be in it and therefore I wanted him to be called Bruno Forestier, to have the bracelet and to be the same guy. Because at the end of Le Petit Soldat he shoots the guy from the Algerian Secret Service and he has escaped from the French army so he has no place to go . . . MS: Yes, you quit something to get into something else - that's the reason of the Foreign Legion - you enter a new family, a new life - and he's entering this. JR: Working with Denis, could you see Galoup already in the character we know from the Leos Carax films? CD: Well, as I said before, I would not have been able to make the movie without Denis, and Denis doesn't speak English, so he doesn't understand a word of what I am saying [laughter]. He was part of the project from the first day. Also because I knew Denis from Leos Carax movies, and also from the theatre, he works a lot in the theatre. The project was linked to him right from the beginning. JR: It's a very physical role, Galoup. How did you do the manoeuvres and the dance? Did you practice, you were trained? DL: Yes, we were trained. Physically, I was already in okay physical condition. You have to be somewhat fit when you work in the theatre - a little bit! Further to this, however, we also worked for a month with a choreographer, Bernardo Montet who made us work like animals to learn the ways of the Legion - not only the drill and the endurance, but also the more difficult - the instinctive choreography. In fact, as I was involved in the theatre, I could not participate fully in rehearsals, if the truth be told. Yet, it was when I actually arrived there, at Djibouti, I had to be 100% in perfect shape in order to play a character who is a legionnaire, who has been there for fifteen years. To be credible I had to become a part of the country, almost. It is this that I disappeared into and it was a pure pleasure throughout the film to completely immerse myself in the culture of Djibouti and in the volcanic rhythms of the film. . . I could go on for hours (laughs). I would like to add something that interests me very much, that Claire mentioned earlier, while we were speaking on the train, about working from another script to rehearse something that is entirely different. For me, I practise juggling to help with the more tedious training - to help keep my head free. JR: Denis took his juggling material with him to Djibouti to practise, because Claire has the practice of rehearsing not with the scripts that they're actually going to film but with other texts. So he was working on other texts as well, which was his juggling. Let's have some questions because we have time. Q1: Did you get the scene [in Beau Travail] where they're circling each other from Once upon a Time in the West? CD: I thought of that when we did the editing. But the thing is, it was a real exercise that you learn doing martial arts - to walk in a circle and always look at the enemy's eyes. So we trained that with Bernardo Montet. After training on that exercise we decided to keep it in the movie. There was a scene in the script where they were facing each other, looking at each other with a fierce look and we so turned it into that, you know. When we were in the editing room I thought 'That's like a Sergio Leone movie'. I was amazed. Q2: Where is the Lithuanian driving to at the end of J'ai pas Sommeil? CD: I wanted her to drive back to Vilnius with the money. But I wanted to go and film her driving to Vilnius. But we couldn't make that so we were just able to have her drive off from Paris but that was the main idea, to have her drive back home. Q3: What does dancing mean to you? CD: I don't know. Have you never been a teenager dancing in your room? Locked yourself in your room and danced? No, me, I think this is something normal. Dance is something you do, to. . . Questioner: To survive? CD: Yeah, exactly. I don't know how to say to survive but I agree with that completely. But it's something you do especially when you're on your own. It has a special meaning, you know. It is a memory of mine, being teenage in my room. But I think, Beau Travail has a different approach, it has something that was part of the discipline of those men together and to approach it with something that was strong enough to create something in the film - was to work with this choreographer, Bernardo [Montet], that Denis mentioned. We never thought we were doing dance, we never pronounced the word dance as we were working - we were doing the training, you know, but it slowly became like a dance, but it was not. . . JR: And earlier in your career, you also worked with Jerome Savari. . . did that involve dance in any way? CD: No, but I was doing electrics and things, I was not involved in his work. I was rigging the bulbs. Q4: [To Denis Lavant] What is it like working with Claire Denis? How is she as a director? DL: [approximate translation of his reply] For me it was an encounter, because I didn't know Claire at all. I had never seen her films, because I never go to the cinema. It was a great pleasure to work and to communicate on the set - I didn't have an impression of being supervised - how can I explain? She was there in a firm way, in a directive way, providing confidence, a framework, someone to talk to. There was the idea of a character, the thoughts of character that interested me, that existed in the world of Billy Budd - the descriptions of the mental mechanisms of that life of the ghetto - these provided a base. But after there was a framework - some rules of driving - Claire gave me a licence to propose a sense that the character existed. She helped me discover a mode of communication that influenced me greatly. We discovered the poem that helped us with the shooting. JR: [translating DL's reply] Because there was this mechanism of the characters of Claggart and Galoup in the film with envy and the jealousy, on top of that he had to make the character realistic as a Foreign Legion sergeant but with that there was a great freedom. Also Claire had given him Melville's poems which were very well translated into French. . . CD: I think that Denis was saying was that it was very mysterious the way I thought Denis would be that Galoup. Denis was mentioning that we communicate through Melville's poem more than through the psychological aspect of this guy full of desire of being perfect and full of envy. I think it's true that we sat down every day, reading poetry before going shooting. We did communicate much more like that - through Melville rather than through explanation of. . . I don't know, it was easier - and also we communicated through the physical effort of being under that sun and in that landscape. To explain to someone to do this, to be Galoup is almost there - DL: Galoup is a narrator. . . JR: So Galoup is the narrator of the story - actually Claggart is not the narrator of the Melville story. . . CD: Galoup is. JR: So as narrator he is very much directing the story, he is bringing it about - there is a complicity that he feels with the camera. CD: Yeah, for instance we had always in mind that we would try to look at Galoup as if through the landscape so that we knew that the story was in the past for him. Q: Can you tell us about working with the director of photography Agnès Godard and the jazz musician Abdullah Ibrahim? CD: She [Godard] was actually in all my films but one. She started by doing camera operating and became DP afterwards, and we were in the same school. We've been learning to work together, in a way she is a companion of my work, like Jean-Pol [Fargeau] with whom I write the script. Both of them have been a part of my work since I started. Abdullah Ibrahim is different. He's a musician I really like and he was also a friend of Ornette Coleman since the 70s. As he was one of the formidable, interesting musicians of the free jazz experience. When I wrote my first script, I didn't mind his music from South Africa, as he was exiled from South Africa. I saw this music was carrying this sort of regret for a country that he doesn't live in any more. I wrote him a letter and he answered and we collaborated on two films. Q5: Have ethnographic films - for example directors like Jean Rouch - influenced you in any respect? CD: In a way I feel obliged to respect Jean Rouch because I am told he is very important. I must say I always felt amazed and almost from a different planet, you know. I like to share something with the people I film. I understand, I've seen all his films and I've always been interested in his films, but it's separate. I don't know. It's hard for me to express what I feel in a Jean Rouch movie, but I feel like the planet is divided into sections - and to me it's not like that - so that's what I can say. Q6: The creases are very important in Beau Travail CD: The commandant says that the elegant exterior will create interior elegance - that is why the pleats are important. That sentence I heard from an officer in the Legion and I was completely amazed and I tried to think about it and then I knew, I read and I knew - a shirt - even if you are in a camp in the desert, a shirt should have three folds in the back. When they are in the camp, they should manage themselves. So that's how we wrote that scene where they were ironing. And the laundry was also something I knew exists, but because we were only fifteen - because before ironing you have to wash and dry the laundry - and it was for me the image of the army. We were only fifteen soldiers and I thought the laundry drying on the lines were - so we wrote it like that in the script - that it was the army itself drying on lines as the exercises were to walk also on lines. So we already did that kind of connection in the script. That's why it was easy to make, because everyone felt rehearsed like that. Q7: What are your influences as a film-maker? CD: To make my answer short - it's may be by being in the audience as a spectator that films really worked on me for years, like Le Petit Soldat. Working on movies as an assistant director (eg with Rivette or Wim Wenders) was sharing that person's approach. The films we were working on, in a way I don't know these films so well. The relationship is from inside, but it's maybe as part of the audience that I learn from movies more than anything. I think working as an assistant was a part of knowing people who like cinema and to learn from a movie you have to watch it. To me, it's my experience. I learnt more from Le Petit Soldat than from Paris, Texas. JR: Can you tell us something very quickly about the film that you're finishing at the moment, which is with Vincent Gallo, Trouble Everyday? CD: The film is called Trouble Everyday and I must say, really that it's really a good title, since we've started. And I wish I could find another title because it is trouble everyday. I don't know, it's still, it has vague shape, but it's not yet a film. It's something that is on its way to being a film. It's true that there is Vincent Gallo and Alex Descas and Beatrice Dalle and Tricia Vessey, but it's not yet a film. JR: Well it's tantalising. Are the three of you [ie Lavant, Denis and Subor] going to work together again? CD: I hope, really hope so. I think Denis and I, we have some ideas about working together again - and I think with Michel too. JR: Well I will always get my shirts ironed by the Foreign Legion in future. Thank you, all three of you for coming tonight. CD: Thank you very much.

webTitle: Police hold six over Dover deaths

fields.headline: Police hold six over Dover deaths
fields.trailText: Dutch police were today holding six people following the deaths of 58 Chinese immigrants found in the back of a lorry in Dover.
fields.body:
Dutch police were today holding six people following the deaths of 58 Chinese immigrants found in the back of a lorry in Dover.

One of the six is a 24-year-old owner of a transport company.

The arrests follow the discovery by Rotterdam detectives of a harbour-side warehouse used to transport the immigrants.

One suspect was still on the run and an international arrest warrant was issued for him. A 55-year-old suspect was earlier released by police.

Shocked customs officers discovered 58 bodies - and two survivors - in a sealed lorry container at the port in Kent just before midnight on Sunday June 18.

An inquest heard how they had suffocated in the back of the sealed lorry which had its refrigeration unit turned off on one of the hottest days of the year.

A spokesman for the Dutch police said: "The Netherlands and Great Britain have exchanged a number of detectives in order to optimise the effectiveness and efficiency of both investigations.

"Meanwhile, the Dutch police have managed to get a pretty clear picture of the organisation and of the individuals that have been organising the transport as well as the manner in which the suspects may have been involved.

"In broad terms it appears that the organisation has rented a warehouse especially for the purpose of the smuggling operation and has a transport company register in the name of a front man.

"After that an articulated truck and container have been purchased. It seems likely that the Chinese group has been brought to the Waalhaven warehouse on Sunday June 18 and has been transferred into the truck. Then the truck was driven to Zeebrugge and has been shipped to Dover."

Kent detectives are close to identifying most of the victims and hope the arrival of several officers from the Fujian province of China this week will speed up the investigation.

Police said they will not name any of the victims until all 58 bodies have been identified and their families contacted.

A spokesman for Kent police said: "We are aware that further arrests have been made in Holland and have been continually liasing with our Dutch counterparts."

Dutch lorry driver Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, appeared before Folkestone Magistrates on June 24, charged with the manslaughter of the 58 immigrants. He is also accused for illegally bringing two people into Britain and attempting to bring the other 58 through the port.

He was remanded in custody until his next appearance at court on June 30.

fields.headline: Hornby on takeover track
fields.standfirst: Toymaker in talks with potential buyers
fields.trailText: British toymaker Hornby, which is best known for its model trains, is up for sale.
fields.body:
British toymaker Hornby yesterday announced that the 99-year-old company, which is best known for its model trains, is up for sale.

Discussions are under way with a number of potential buyers, but their identities were being kept secret last night.

Hornby, which also makes Scalextric car racing sets and developed both Meccano and Dinky toys in the early 1900s, first announced a strategic review of the business in April.

It has now decided that if the present bid talks fail to produce an acceptable offer Hornby will return all its spare cash to shareholders next year. The news produced a 7.5p gain in the shares to 165p.

The company has been hit by fierce competition from rival childhood pursuits such as computer games, and from larger US rivals such as Mattel and Hasbro.

The traditional model-making and hobbies market has become increasingly cut-throat over recent years, although Hornby was able to announce a slight improvement in year-end figures yesterday.

At the pre-tax level, profits were up from £1.14m to £1.21m in the year to the end of March. Turnover was almost static at £21.8m, and the final dividend is being pegged at 2p.

Hornby was founded in 1901 when Frank Hornby, a Liverpool clerk, invented Meccano. He created the first clockwork train set in 1920, and Scalextric arrived in 1957.

Recent modernisations include a virtual railway which is to be marketed on CD-rom and will enable the user to plan track layouts, buildings and scenery, and run locomotives and rolling stock on computer screens.

fields.headline: Schools watchdog questions LEAs' role
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ofsted, the schools watchdog, said yesterday that 40% of local education authorities had "more weaknesses than strengths", but questioned whether councils had any impact on standards at all.
fields.body:
Ofsted, the schools watchdog, said yesterday that 40% of local education authorities had "more weaknesses than strengths", but questioned whether councils had any impact on standards at all.

In a draft report on its first tranche of 44 local education authority inspections, Ofsted adds fuel to the debate over the future of councils' power in education, which the government, encouraged by head teachers, is keen to limit.

At the presentation of the report at an education conference in London, Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, said: "Our position has always been that the successful school is successful because of the effectiveness of its own management and effective schools should have ... the freedom to manage their own destiny."

Ofsted's report urges a "minimalist" approach by LEAs to improving schools, with fewer and better-paid senior education officials. "Most LEAs now accept that schools are largely autonomous institutions and that the core task of the LEA is to reinforce that autonomy and make it effective," it says.

The report chimes with the views of David Blunkett, the education secretary, who is advocating ring-fencing government money for schools and restricting LEAs' role to core functions such as admissions, school transport, special needs and helping to turn round failing schools.

Mr Woodhead said most LEAs failed because of political problems. "It's a fact that in LEAs that have got the most serious weaknesses a common denominator is a failure of political leadership."

The report says it is too early to expect any evidence that LEAs are leading an overall rise in school standards, as required by the 1998 Education Act. But it adds: "Worryingly ... there is little evidence of any correlation between the quality of an LEA as an organisation and the standards achieved in its schools." The leadership of the headteacher is far more crucial, the report says.

Ofsted is developing a new way of measuring LEA performance, using 46 individual tests ranked 1-7. Inspections have been completed for more than half the 150 LEAs in England.

Warwickshire, Kensington and Chelsea and the Corporation of London - which has only one secondary school - are the only LEAs so far to achieve a 1 grade overall. There was praise from David Singleton, Ofsted's head of inspections, for Tower Hamlets and Manchester, for responding positively to Ofsted reports which found serious weaknesses. Calderdale and Hackney had made some progress, but Southwark and Sandwell had regressed.

The report also sees a "growing polarisation" between well-run and poor LEAs. There was often no more than "lip service" to school autonomy, and "nostalgia for control". It says school visits by LEA officials happen too frequently and are often unnecessary.

Estelle Morris, the schools standards minister, said the disparity in delivery by LEAs was not acceptable. "LEAs must adapt to meet the demands of the changing world and not seek to control schools."

Doug McAvoy, the NUT's general secretary, said: "Ofsted's job is to evaluate but yet again it is overstepping the mark and making recommendations in the political arena."

Well run LEA, and high performing schools: Cornwall, North Somerset, Kingston upon Thames, Bury, Surrey, Rutland, Warwickshire.

Well run LEA, and low performing schools: Barking and Dagenham, Birmingham, Newham, Sunderland, Knowsley, Kingston upon Hull, Kirklees, Newcastle upon Tyne.

LEA with significant weaknesses, and average or high performing schools: Bedfordshire, Calderdale, Kent, Buckinghamshire.

LEA with weaknesses, and low performing schools: Hackney, Manchester, Sandwell, Tower Hamlets, Southwark, Barnsley, Islington, Liverpool, Haringey, Leicester

 Liverpool University is setting up what it claims is Europe's first degree to be available to students only via the internet. The masters in information technology will be available to 20 students a year.

fields.headline: Brown pledges extra cash to revive poorest areas
fields.standfirst: Ministers set targets to win share of £40bn to tackle key problems
fields.trailText: Extra resources to raise standards in health, education and crime prevention in Britain's poorest areas are to be provided by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, next month in a bid to tackle deep-rooted poverty and cut unemployment.
