David Blunkett, Alan Milburn and Jack Straw have all been offered additional resources for the next three years in return for agreeing to set extra targets to raise performance in the most disadvantaged areas of the country.

The move is part of a Treasury blueprint under which ministers will get a share of a £40bn boost to public spending in return for greater cooperation across departments to tackle problems in 13 areas. The spending plans will set "floor targets" for the delivery of key public services in poor parts of the country.

The chancellor, who is blamed by some in the party for excessively tight curbs on spending in the government's first two years, intends to use his comprehensive spending review to kick-start Tony Blair's election campaign.

The government, rattled by loss of support in its heartlands, is convinced votes will be won and lost on the traditional battlegrounds of health, education and the economy rather than on Europe. It will announce plans to supplement the £13bn increase in NHS spending with a £28bn boost to expenditure in other areas.

Final negotiations are underway between spending ministers and the treasury, but Mr Blunkett and John Prescott will get extra cash for schools and transport.

Mr Brown is stressing that the conditions for a return to full employment will depend on combined action across departments.

The number of people out of work and claiming benefit is at a 20-year low following more than eight years of economic growth.

But although some Treasury officials think the jobless total - now 1,109,000 - may have dropped below 1m by the election, the chancellor will stress that full employment will only be achieved by co-ordinating action across Whitehall to tackle social exclusion and Britain's productivity deficit with other industrial nations.

"We have to recognise that the potential for full employment exists, but that means we have to start dealing with much harder cases than has the New Deal," said one government source.

"What you will see is the spending review for the second New Deal."

The bulk of the cross-departmental groups deal with domestic problems such as the 100,000 young people not in school, work, training or claiming benefit.

The government believes a strategy for young people at risk needs to look at jobs, housing, drugs and crime - incorporating the work of the Department for Education and Employment, the Department for Environment, Transport and the Regions, the Home Office and the Department of Health.

The Treasury's influence on Labour's domestic agenda is increased as a result of the changes to be announced next month, with Mr Brown and his team setting targets for cross-departmental initiatives and holding ministers accountable for shared budgets.

The 13 cross-departmental groups are welfare to work, Sure Start and services for the under fives, young people at risk, support for older people, the criminal justice system, drugs, crime reduction, local government finance, government intervention in deprived areas, rural and countryside programmes, science and research, conflict prevention in sub-Saharan Africa, and nuclear safety in the former Soviet Union.

Mr Brown maintained tough curbs on spending inherited from the last Conservative chancellor, Kenneth Clarke but in his first three-year spending plan in 1998 increased spending by 3% overall in real terms and by around 5% on health and education.

webTitle: Universal bank scheme to save rural post offices

fields.headline: Universal bank scheme to save rural post offices
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Ministers today announced plans for a Universal Bank that will halt the closure of rural post offices and offer financial services to the 3.5m people currently without bank accounts.
fields.body:
Ministers today announced plans for a Universal Bank that will halt the closure of rural post offices and offer financial services to the 3.5m people currently without bank accounts.

The service will operate through the country's 19,000 post offices - this will require the Post Office to maintain its rural network and prevent avoidable closures. Post offices are regarded as ideal for the new bank to operate through because of the breadth of the network. Feasibility work is underway.

Sub-postmasters and other campaigners have been warning that the government's plans to pay benefits directly into bank accounts from 2003 threaten to close hundreds of post offices across the country. Now the payments will go into the Universal Bank accounts but will also be collected as before over the counter at post offices.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers launched the rescue package aimed at boosting the postal service. He said the government was introducing the biggest reforms since the 1840s by granting the service greater commercial freedom.

"We are enabling it to adapt to market forces. But we also recognise the role of the Post Office at the heart of our society. I believe the package of measures I am announcing today will provide the certainty the Post Office needs to face the future with confidence," he said.

Other proposals include the setting up of a special fund to improve offices in deprived areas and other financial support but the exact figure will only be announced as part of the government's spending review in July.

New funds to be made available could be used to develop post offices into local shops, as well as increasing security measures in some offices. Postmasters will be trained to teach people how to fill out forms and use the internet, as well as offer advice and information on Government services.

Prime minister Tony Blair said the government accepted a report from the Cabinet Office performance and innovation unit (PIU) which detailed 24 recommendations for modernising the network and creating new businesses.

Mr Blair said the PIU report showed that the organisation had become over-reliant on a few lines of business and not kept pace with technological change.

The PIU report also said that people without bank accounts are at a disadvantage because employers insist on paying salaries directly into bank accounts, and they are unable to pay bills via direct debit.

fields.headline: Keeping the post-office customer satisfied
fields.standfirst: A new role for the ailing rural post office is proving a difficult nut for the government to crack, writes chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour
fields.trailText: A new role for the ailing rural post office is proving a difficult nut for the government to crack, writes chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
The future of the rural post office, once the sleepiest of political issues and of interest only to backwoods Tories, has become, in the past year, one of the most sensitive political issues facing this government.

The debate symbolises the conflict between progress and tradition, and the ability for government to see that conflict. The solution being announced today will come from the cabinet office performance and innovation unit. Ministers know it is one of the big issues filling MPs' post bags. The National Federation of Sub-Postmasters managed to organise one of the largest petitions ever to hit the Commons and Labour MPs in rural marginal constituencies have been pressing ministers for solutions.

Ministers have been privately suggesting that if just half the number of people complaining about the closure of post offices actually shopped there, they would not be in the current mess.

But it is not possible for government simply to say that this is the march of progress and the market. The rural post office and - in inner city areas of deprivation, the urban post office - acts both as a social glue, keeping traditional communities together after the closure of, say, a local school or bank. It is also one of the most visible arms of government in communities. It is one of those issues that requires cross-departmental co-operation, largely because the existing long-term decline had in part deepened as a result of the government's own actions.

The Treasury had, four years ago, wanted to save money. It pressed the department of social security to introduce a new, computerised method of paying benefits, especially pensions, directly into bank accounts. Payments of benefits forms 40 per cent of the income of nearly half of the rural post offices. The DSS was keen on the idea because it would keep some of the savings, and also because of projected savings on fraud in the future. Pensioners would no longer be able to draw their pensions from the post office in cash, which would save on administration.

More than 400 of the 18,000-strong network of post offices closed in the last financial year. Many of them were losing custom, partly due to the growth of out-of-town supermarkets and partly due to local post-office owners bailing out before the new technology was up-and-running.

The widespread introduction of computerised benefit payments meant that as many as 8,000 rural post offices might close. Alan Johnson, the DTI minister responsible for the post office, was handed the task in government of overseeing the crisis, although Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, was given a watching brief over the PIU report. Mr Johnson, a former leader of the Union of Communication Workers, has been thrashing around trying to find some new markets for the local post offices.

Together, they have alighted on three ideas. First, the local post office could become the internet arm of government. Customers could be lured into post offices by the prospect of using the internet to complete their transactions with the state, such as booking train journeys, transferring driving licences or booking hospital appointments. It is a visionary concept, and many post office managers are sceptical that there is a big e-trade waiting to be exploited in the villages.

Secondly, the local post office would become a universal bank, a means by which the nation's poor - traditionally reluctant to open bank accounts - can hold an account. The Universal Bank will not allow its users to run up credit, but it will allow users of others banks, such as Barclays, to make transactions through the Universal Bank.

Thirdly, there should be a large-scale investment in local post offices to make them a more attractive retail operation.

However, it is debatable whether these new markets will generate enough income to cover the losses incurred by the end of pension payments. More importantly there could be a gap between the point at which automation starts and the point at which these new services come on stream. As a result, the government will probably have to provide a subsidy to the network, the size of which ministers have so far refused to disclose.

fields.headline: Livingstone lashes Treasury
fields.trailText: London mayor Ken Livingstone today launched a scathing attack on government control of local councils, saying British town halls have no more independence than the Vichy regime did under the Nazis.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone today launched a scathing attack on government control of local councils, saying British town halls have no more independence than the Vichy regime did under the Nazis.

He accused "aliens" in the Treasury of undermining local government and said they treated democratically-elected people with contempt.

In his most strongly-worded attack since winning the election in May, Mr Livingstone told the local government association's newspaper it was time for councils to fight back.

"From the end of the 1980s on, local government has had no more independence in Britain than the Vichy regime had in France under the Nazis," Mr Livingstone said. "So you just do your best to try and protect your local people as best you can."

Mr Livingstone blamed the Treasury for leading the 20-year attack on local government. "The Treasury has always had a contempt for democratically-elected people in Parliament, let alone local government," he said.

"For years the Treasury has been run by aliens whose objective is the destruction of all life on this planet and they're just starting with local government services."

Mr Livingstone also criticised the government's handling of asylum seekers, saying: "I have never seen the collapse of administration in any local authority that I have witnessed over the last three years in the government's immigration and asylum directorate.

"Literally, no-one in central government is in a position to lecture local government about waste or incompetence or corruption."

His comments about the Treasury could reignite his long-running feud with chancellor Gordon Brown, whose economic policies he has criticised in the past, although Mr Livingstone later said his remarks had been tinged with a "smidgen of humour". They will also scotch hopes that Mr Livingstone was set to take a more conciliatory tone towards the Government since becoming the first directly-elected Mayor of London.

Home secretary Jack Straw took a moderate tone in dismissing Mr Livingstone's remark saying his comments about the Vichy regime were "a bit of Ken extravagance".

Mr Straw said that the government was giving councils new powers such as over the control of pub licensing and more freedoms would follow.

"The balance is going to shift. There will always be tension between central and local government and that is not only necessary but desirable," said Mr Straw.

Chairman of the local government association Sir Jeremy Beecham called the comparison with Vichy "ludicrous" and "counter-productive" but accepted that he would agree with Mr Livingstone on "a lot of the points".

webTitle: Portuguese men of war, Belgian men of words, and London's man of destiny

fields.headline: Portuguese men of war, Belgian men of words, and London's man of destiny
fields.trailText: BLEU IS THE COLOUR
fields.body:
BLEU IS THE COLOUR

The date: 30th November 1807. And an overwhelmingly powerful French army, lead by General Andoche Junot, rolls into Lisbon forcing the flamboyant Portuguese to surrender. The humiliated Portugeezers who are left standing swear they'll take the sweetest of revenges on Napoleon -when those Frenchies least expect it. And so they wait. And they wait some more. Until finally - more than 176 years later - they get their chance. In France. In the semi-final of Euro 84. Perfect! And it's all going perfectly - until, once again, they surrender - this time to the midfield maestro Michel Platini.

No doubt sensing a pattern, Christophe Dugarry seemed particularly keen to stress Gallic superiority ahead of tonight's mouthwatering Euro 2000 semi-final. "Portugal are the masters of dribbling and keeping the ball but they'll have to surrender against us because overall we're much stronger than they are," he boasted earlier today. And his team-mate Marcel Desailly was quick to join in. "They have deserved to get this far. But this is the last step so there is more pressure. It must be even worse for Portugal because they have to play against the world champions." And to think that some people think the French are arrogant!

Only coach Roger Lemerre demurred. "Portugal should be regarded as the favourites against France," he said behind his hand while no-one was looking. "They are in the last four because they have no weaknesses. They reached the semi-finals easily while we had to fight for it." Lemerre won't name his team until an hour before kick-off, but seems likely to bring back He Is Emmanuel Petit, who has recovered from a knee injury. Pat Vieira is - according to most reports - also a certain starter, so either Youri Djorkaeff or Christophe Dugarry is expected to make way.

Meanwhile Portugal coach Humberto Coelho, who is presiding over a much more modest camp ("We have a lot of respect for France but we're going to do our best to try and win" was Dumas's response to a question about tonight's game), is set to make two changes. Salad cream-haired Abel Xavier and midfield hard-man Paulo Sousa are likely to return in place of Costinha and Conceiçao, as Coelho opts for a slightly more defensive line-up. It'll be tense, that's for sure.

Probable line-ups. Portugal: Baía; Xavier, Couto, Costa, Dimas; Bento, Sousa, Rui Costa; Figo, João Pinto; Gomes.

France: Barthez; Thuram, Desailly, Blanc, Lizarazu; Deschamps, Viera, Petit, Djorkaeff, Zidane; Henry.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

REPORT THIS!

It's not been the best of days for Kelvin Koogan. Although how you would prove that it's worse than, say, any day in the last ten is a moot point. So let's start again. Kelvin Koogan has had, not only his tactics, but his trademark enthusiasm slagged off by some Belgian on Uefa's official Euro 2000 website (just the 69m hits a day). Which could quite easily have ruined Kelvin's enjoyment of This Morning this morning.

"For England the lessons of yesterday never seem to impact on the fevered anticipation of tomorrow, and K[oo]gan added to the delusion", said the report, mocking supporters, overpaid sportswriters, and badger-haired supremos alike. The report goes on to assert (quite boldly) that the reason the English were so deluded was because they thought their team was OK when it was in fact rubbish. "Keegan's main complaint was that his players could not pass the ball with any great efficiency," it says, "but, with the exceptions of David Beckham and Paul Scholes, that has been obvious for some time."

Oooooohh. What made these otherwise routine remarks a bit special was that they came without a byline (which means 'name' but is much more sophisticated), leading to the assumption that this was Uefa's official verdict on team Koogan, rather than the rantings of some work experience child from Oost-Vlaanderen. An error which Uefa was naturally determined to clear up. "We are very sorry if it has offended anybody," said spokesman Graham Turner today. "But, having said that, we have to take our share of the blame and say we should have filtered it before it went on." Well it's all very well saying that, but the damage has already been done, hasn't it eh?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'm looking into the possible legal steps I can take. The combination Bergkamp-alcohol is ridiculous as is the combination top sport-alcohol. I feel badly treated by someone who tries to make money off my back." Dennis Bergkamp is not too pleased with the song 'Dennisbier' - which promotes the joys of alcohol.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TEL PLEB 2000

The Fiver's sister publication The Euro (we're awaiting convergence as we speak) this morning took Terry Venables seriously. As far as we are aware, this has not happened since Mark Goldberg sat Tel down in South London with a roll of banknotes and said: "A year's wages up front it is then." You see Tel wants his job back. You know, the impossible job. And he wants our help to get it.

"This is the people's game, let the people decide. If Tony Blair can hold a referendum on the single European currency, why not have one to pick the England coach?" a slightly optimistic Tel told the Daily Mail this morning. Tel gave his wife the credit for coming up with the first ever exercise in footballing democracy, but the Euro, and now the Fiver, believes that forcing Kelvin Koogan into the streets and replacing him with Tel against the FA's wishes is not just a crazy dream.

So - in the finest tradition of those dodgy mails asking you to sign your name to an endless list of people (mostly from Pennsylvania) who want to put an end to the maltreatment of clowns, NOW! - the Fiver proposes that you forward today's mail around to as many people as possible, adding your name to the (short) list below. If you get conflicting lists, add them together, and if you receive a mail with more than 5000 names, yeah ok, 1500 send it to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll get our PR people onto it. Tel Pleb 2000 - it's on.

Yes, I want lovely cuddly Terry Venables back as England boss

Yours truly,

The Fiver (Cyberspace)

Mark Tran (London)

Katie Portwin (Oxford)

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal have confirmed a £6m fee for Brazilian midfielder Edu of Corinthians. "I am flying to London and taking my brother as my adviser", the 22-year-old said today. "It's incredible they are willing to pay so much for me. Even my coaches are surprised at the kind of money the English are prepared to pay."

Steve Watson should complete his £2.5m move to Everton from Aston Villa by the end of the week. Watson met Everton boss Walter Smith and club officials at Goodison Park today to discuss personal terms after the two clubs had agreed a fee.

Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson is confident of luring Don Hutchison and Niclas Alexandersson to Highfield Road. "There's competition on both - and I would hate to say yes, it's definite," he told Coventry's official website. "But I think we've got a reasonable chance of doing something on one or both."

Australian skipper Paul Okon is on his way to Middlesbrough, reports Teamtalk. The defensive midfielder told their contact Down Under, "Training starts on the 14th July, but I actually have an extra week off. Naturally I'm very excited about moving to England, although leaving Italy after four years was a very difficult decision for me to make."

Tottenham are lining up Belgium winger Bart Goor to replace David Ginola.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Mario Stanic has completed his £5.6m move to Chelsea. The Croatian international said: "I spoke via telephone (with Vialli) two times and now everything is finished. I hope to enjoy my holidays and then return to work."

Lucas Radebe has pledged his future to Leeds, despite a £6m offer from Roma. "This is a great time to be at Leeds and I could not be happier," the 31-year-old South African told the club's website. "It is always flattering when a big club shows interest in you. But I have two years left on my contract at Leeds and they could be the most exciting two years in the club's history."

Argentine striker Daniel Cordone has signed a twelve month loan deal with Newcastle United worth £500,000. The 25-year-old has passed a medical and joined on loan with a view to a £2m permanent move. Cordone said: "I am very impressed with the manager and with the club. I am looking forward to proving that I'm worth a long-term contract."

Kenny Dalglish is set to be formally dismissed from his post at Celtic with a pay-off of around £700,000. The club have so far refused to comment, but have said an announcement regarding all staff can be expected shortly.

Holland's Roy Makaay and Arthur Numan have both been ruled out of the rest of Euro 2000 because of injury. Makaay has a damaged ankle, while Numan has broken a bone in his foot.

Former Dundee manager Jocky Scott has been named the new manager of English Second Division side Notts County.

QPR vice-chairman Nick Blackburn has been elected to the Football League board of directors in place of David Sheepshanks, who has departed for the Premier League.

Birmingham have signed full-back David Burrows on a free transfer from Coventry. The 31-year-old former Liverpool defender had rejected the offer of a new two-year deal at Highfield Road.

Sky have announced their first batch of Premiership live games. They are:

fields.bodyText: BLEU IS THE COLOUR The date: 30th November 1807. And an overwhelmingly powerful French army, lead by General Andoche Junot, rolls into Lisbon forcing the flamboyant Portuguese to surrender. The humiliated Portugeezers who are left standing swear they'll take the sweetest of revenges on Napoleon -when those Frenchies least expect it. And so they wait. And they wait some more. Until finally - more than 176 years later - they get their chance. In France. In the semi-final of Euro 84. Perfect! And it's all going perfectly - until, once again, they surrender - this time to the midfield maestro Michel Platini. No doubt sensing a pattern, Christophe Dugarry seemed particularly keen to stress Gallic superiority ahead of tonight's mouthwatering Euro 2000 semi-final. "Portugal are the masters of dribbling and keeping the ball but they'll have to surrender against us because overall we're much stronger than they are," he boasted earlier today. And his team-mate Marcel Desailly was quick to join in. "They have deserved to get this far. But this is the last step so there is more pressure. It must be even worse for Portugal because they have to play against the world champions." And to think that some people think the French are arrogant! Only coach Roger Lemerre demurred. "Portugal should be regarded as the favourites against France," he said behind his hand while no-one was looking. "They are in the last four because they have no weaknesses. They reached the semi-finals easily while we had to fight for it." Lemerre won't name his team until an hour before kick-off, but seems likely to bring back He Is Emmanuel Petit, who has recovered from a knee injury. Pat Vieira is - according to most reports - also a certain starter, so either Youri Djorkaeff or Christophe Dugarry is expected to make way. Meanwhile Portugal coach Humberto Coelho, who is presiding over a much more modest camp ("We have a lot of respect for France but we're going to do our best to try and win" was Dumas's response to a question about tonight's game), is set to make two changes. Salad cream-haired Abel Xavier and midfield hard-man Paulo Sousa are likely to return in place of Costinha and Conceiçao, as Coelho opts for a slightly more defensive line-up. It'll be tense, that's for sure. Probable line-ups. Portugal: Baía; Xavier, Couto, Costa, Dimas; Bento, Sousa, Rui Costa; Figo, João Pinto; Gomes. France: Barthez; Thuram, Desailly, Blanc, Lizarazu; Deschamps, Viera, Petit, Djorkaeff, Zidane; Henry. * * * * * * * * * * * * * REPORT THIS! It's not been the best of days for Kelvin Koogan. Although how you would prove that it's worse than, say, any day in the last ten is a moot point. So let's start again. Kelvin Koogan has had, not only his tactics, but his trademark enthusiasm slagged off by some Belgian on Uefa's official Euro 2000 website (just the 69m hits a day). Which could quite easily have ruined Kelvin's enjoyment of This Morning this morning. "For England the lessons of yesterday never seem to impact on the fevered anticipation of tomorrow, and K[oo]gan added to the delusion", said the report, mocking supporters, overpaid sportswriters, and badger-haired supremos alike. The report goes on to assert (quite boldly) that the reason the English were so deluded was because they thought their team was OK when it was in fact rubbish. "Keegan's main complaint was that his players could not pass the ball with any great efficiency," it says, "but, with the exceptions of David Beckham and Paul Scholes, that has been obvious for some time." Oooooohh. What made these otherwise routine remarks a bit special was that they came without a byline (which means 'name' but is much more sophisticated), leading to the assumption that this was Uefa's official verdict on team Koogan, rather than the rantings of some work experience child from Oost-Vlaanderen. An error which Uefa was naturally determined to clear up. "We are very sorry if it has offended anybody," said spokesman Graham Turner today. "But, having said that, we have to take our share of the blame and say we should have filtered it before it went on." Well it's all very well saying that, but the damage has already been done, hasn't it eh? * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "I'm looking into the possible legal steps I can take. The combination Bergkamp-alcohol is ridiculous as is the combination top sport-alcohol. I feel badly treated by someone who tries to make money off my back." Dennis Bergkamp is not too pleased with the song 'Dennisbier' - which promotes the joys of alcohol. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TEL PLEB 2000 The Fiver's sister publication The Euro (we're awaiting convergence as we speak) this morning took Terry Venables seriously. As far as we are aware, this has not happened since Mark Goldberg sat Tel down in South London with a roll of banknotes and said: "A year's wages up front it is then." You see Tel wants his job back. You know, the impossible job. And he wants our help to get it. "This is the people's game, let the people decide. If Tony Blair can hold a referendum on the single European currency, why not have one to pick the England coach?" a slightly optimistic Tel told the Daily Mail this morning. Tel gave his wife the credit for coming up with the first ever exercise in footballing democracy, but the Euro, and now the Fiver, believes that forcing Kelvin Koogan into the streets and replacing him with Tel against the FA's wishes is not just a crazy dream. So - in the finest tradition of those dodgy mails asking you to sign your name to an endless list of people (mostly from Pennsylvania) who want to put an end to the maltreatment of clowns, NOW! - the Fiver proposes that you forward today's mail around to as many people as possible, adding your name to the (short) list below. If you get conflicting lists, add them together, and if you receive a mail with more than 5000 names, yeah ok, 1500 send it to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll get our PR people onto it. Tel Pleb 2000 - it's on. Yes, I want lovely cuddly Terry Venables back as England boss Yours truly, The Fiver (Cyberspace) Mark Tran (London) Katie Portwin (Oxford) * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Arsenal have confirmed a £6m fee for Brazilian midfielder Edu of Corinthians. "I am flying to London and taking my brother as my adviser", the 22-year-old said today. "It's incredible they are willing to pay so much for me. Even my coaches are surprised at the kind of money the English are prepared to pay." Steve Watson should complete his £2.5m move to Everton from Aston Villa by the end of the week. Watson met Everton boss Walter Smith and club officials at Goodison Park today to discuss personal terms after the two clubs had agreed a fee. Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson is confident of luring Don Hutchison and Niclas Alexandersson to Highfield Road. "There's competition on both - and I would hate to say yes, it's definite," he told Coventry's official website. "But I think we've got a reasonable chance of doing something on one or both." Australian skipper Paul Okon is on his way to Middlesbrough, reports Teamtalk. The defensive midfielder told their contact Down Under, "Training starts on the 14th July, but I actually have an extra week off. Naturally I'm very excited about moving to England, although leaving Italy after four years was a very difficult decision for me to make." Tottenham are lining up Belgium winger Bart Goor to replace David Ginola. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Mario Stanic has completed his £5.6m move to Chelsea. The Croatian international said: "I spoke via telephone (with Vialli) two times and now everything is finished. I hope to enjoy my holidays and then return to work." Lucas Radebe has pledged his future to Leeds, despite a £6m offer from Roma. "This is a great time to be at Leeds and I could not be happier," the 31-year-old South African told the club's website. "It is always flattering when a big club shows interest in you. But I have two years left on my contract at Leeds and they could be the most exciting two years in the club's history." Argentine striker Daniel Cordone has signed a twelve month loan deal with Newcastle United worth £500,000. The 25-year-old has passed a medical and joined on loan with a view to a £2m permanent move. Cordone said: "I am very impressed with the manager and with the club. I am looking forward to proving that I'm worth a long-term contract." Kenny Dalglish is set to be formally dismissed from his post at Celtic with a pay-off of around £700,000. The club have so far refused to comment, but have said an announcement regarding all staff can be expected shortly. Holland's Roy Makaay and Arthur Numan have both been ruled out of the rest of Euro 2000 because of injury. Makaay has a damaged ankle, while Numan has broken a bone in his foot. Former Dundee manager Jocky Scott has been named the new manager of English Second Division side Notts County. QPR vice-chairman Nick Blackburn has been elected to the Football League board of directors in place of David Sheepshanks, who has departed for the Premier League. Birmingham have signed full-back David Burrows on a free transfer from Coventry. The 31-year-old former Liverpool defender had rejected the offer of a new two-year deal at Highfield Road. fields.headline: Hague attacks petrol increases
fields.trailText: The leader of the opposition, William Hague, today used prime minister's questions to launch a blistering attack on the government over the rising price of petrol, predicting that motorists would exact their revenge for the increases at the next general election.
fields.body:
The leader of the opposition, William Hague, today used prime minister's questions to launch a blistering attack on the government over the rising price of petrol, predicting that motorists would exact their revenge for the increases at the next general election.

Mr Hague challenged the prime minister, Tony Blair, on the price of a litre of petrol, which he said had gone up at the pumps by 44% since Labour came to power, 34% of which was due to tax increases.

Petrol rises in the budget were calculated on an inflation rate of 3.4%, whereas pension increases were based on a rate of 1.1%, due to changes introduced by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the Tory leader told the Commons.

"Isn't the time coming when the people who can't afford to run a car will take their revenge on the people who can't manage to run a government?" asked Mr Hague.

The prime minister admitted petrol had gone up by 18p a litre - but of this, only 2p was due to fuel duty. The rest was down to rising oil prices from producer nations, affecting not only Britain, but the rest of the world.

Mr Blair said the government had chosen to spend money on schools, hospitals and paying off the national debt rather than keeping petrol taxes down, saying: "If he [Mr Hague] is now telling us he would cut fuel duty, it would mean that the money we are putting into schools and hospitals is money he would also cut."

Voters would conclude the Tories were worse and "more extreme than ever", the prime minister told the House.

Conservative MP for Billericay Teresa Gorman asked about the role of the prime minister's spokesman, Alistair Campbell's request to government departments that they produce a number of good news stories over the next two months to cheer up the Labour party's image.

Mr Blair replied that Mr Campbell had no need to ask government departments to produce a quota of such stories, in view of the government's numerous successes in areas such as school literacy and unemployment. Mr Campbell "needn't have sent it [the request] out, we can do it ourselves," he said.

webTitle: A bullet in the head for drug dealers in China

fields.headline: A bullet in the head for drug dealers in China
fields.standfirst: Admitting that addiction and trafficking are getting worse, Beijing publicises executions across the country
fields.trailText: China has executed 10 drug traffickers in a synchronised operation to dramatise its seriousness about fighting drug-related crime and to mark International Anti-Drug Day.
fields.body:
China has executed 10 drug traffickers in a synchronised operation to dramatise its seriousness about fighting drug-related crime and to mark International Anti-Drug Day.

Domestic consumption of drugs is becoming "more serious with each passing day", according to an official white paper.

The official news agency yesterday circulated a picture taken on Monday from Quanzhou in Fujian province showing two of the offenders being marched out of a stadium packed with spectators, and off to the execution ground.

The two traffickers, Chen Xinyuan from Taiwan and Tsai Dehui from Hong Kong, had been found guilty of smuggling large quantities of heroin into Taiwan. They lost their final appeal in April.

Details of the case were published on a new website belonging to the Supreme People's Court in Beijing which rejected their appeal.

Elsewhere across the country another eight traffickers were executed on Monday to drive home the lesson. Executions in China are often preceded in serious cases by a "sentencing rally" at which speeches are made denouncing the crime, and the guilty verdicts are read out. The actual execution - by a bullet through the head - takes place privately.

China's policy of exemplary execution has been criticised as "inhumane" by Amnesty International and other human rights organisations, but it finds favour with many Chinese who are alarmed by the growth of crime.

China's government State Council has reinforced the campaign in the white paper, which acknowledges that "the situation is grim for the anti-drug struggle." The document is the latest in a series of increasingly frank statements about the rise in drug use and related problems, including HIV and Aids. UN agencies and other foreign organisations say that Chinese officials are now much more willing to discuss these problems seriously and to take joint action.

The white paper on drugs seeks to suggest that the main problem lies outside China. It says that since the late 1970s when Chinese frontiers became easier to cross, "the illicit international narcotics tide has constantly invaded China, and criminal drug-related activities touched off by transit drug trafficking have re-emerged." The number of registered addicts has risen from 148,000 in 1991 to 681,000 last year.

The State Council appealed to the Chinese people to rekindle the spirit of the 1950s when, after the communist revolution, the use of opium was said to have been wiped out in three years.

In another symbolic action on Monday, large quantities of confiscated heroin and the methamphetamine "ice" were burned at Humen in south China. This is where a national hero, Lin Zexu, burned thousands of boxes of opium belonging to foreign traders in 1839.

Deeming Lin's action illegal, the British government of the day quickly responded and this First Opium War led to Britain annexing Hong Kong.

More efforts to prevent Aids were urged at the weekend in a ministry of health statement. It said that the spread of HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases had become rampant in the past five years.

Most cases were found in rural areas and were spread by the sharing of needles among intravenous drug users. Yunnan province, which lies on the main drug route into China from south-east Asia's "golden triangle", has reported the highest number of HIV cases.

The report said that China has registered 17,316 people infected with HIV to date. But the UN Aids China Programme Office, at a recent workshop on HIV surveillance, estimates the total number infected at half a million.

New cases of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) report ed in 1999 numbered more than 800,000 - a rise of 33% over the previous year, according to Zhang Guocheng, head of China's national centre for STD and leprosy control.

Professor Zhang estimates that there are now more than 8m cases of STD nationwide. These had been virtually eliminated before the 1980s but have spread widely as prostitution has re-emerged and social controls have loosened.

fields.headline: Lord Wakeham's full speech
fields.standfirst: This is the full text of the speech given today by Lord Wakeham, chairman of the press complaints commission, at St Bride Institute, Fleet Street.
fields.trailText: I have always maintained that the strength of the newspaper industry's system of self-regulation lies both in the protection that the code of practice gives to ordinary people and the ability of the press complaints commission to deal quickly and effectively with complaints from members of the public about intrusion and inaccuracy.
fields.body:
I have always maintained that the strength of the newspaper industry's system of self-regulation lies both in the protection that the code of practice gives to ordinary people and the ability of the press complaints commission to deal quickly and effectively with complaints from members of the public about intrusion and inaccuracy.

While it may be complaints from the prime minister and the Prince of Wales, or from celebrities like Paul McCartney and Elton John, that grab the headlines, the real success story lies in the quiet work we do day in and day out to sort out problems brought to us by ordinary people.

And it lies, too, in the unsung success of the editors' code of practice which - over the last 10 years - has slowly and surely, and usually unnoticed by our critics, transformed standards of newspaper reporting.

Ten years ago, simple inaccuracies about people that most of us had never heard of went uncorrected. Intrusions into the private lives of ordinary people by a handful of newspapers were all too common.

Today, we live in a different world - one in which a tough code of practice ensures that most inaccuracies are corrected, that intrusion and harassment are by and large prevented, and that a great deal of protection is given to the most vulnerable members of our society such as the sick, victims of assault and, above all, children.

So that is what the vast bulk of our work is all about. Raising standards of reporting. Sorting out disputes. Serving the public. Protecting the vulnerable.

But while I am acutely aware that most of what we do relates to ordinary people, I am also aware that the success of self regulation rests in many ways on how the press deals with the privacy of public figures - and in turn how the PCC deals with complaints from those individuals when something has gone wrong.

In short, while we always apply the code in equal measure to everyone in the land, ordinary people know it works to protect them if they see it protecting the most famous.

And while we will always treat every complainant equally, ordinary people know the PCC will provide them with commonsense and effective redress when they see us dealing in a quick and sensible manner with high-profile complainants who come to us.

Prince William - the original agreement

That is one of the reasons why, almost exactly five years ago and in this very same room, I set out my thinking on how newspapers should treat Prince William and Prince Harry during their time at school.

I believed it was important for self-regulation, for the industry - and, most important of all, for those young men. You may recall that I argued then that the press had always had a very important role in scrutinising the monarchy and should continue to do so - but that such scrutiny did not mean intruding into the privacy of children.

It was in that speech that I set out the basis of an understanding designed to give the royal princes as much privacy as possible, while at the same time allowing the press and the public - rightly anxious to see the way these two young men were growing up - legitimate access to them.

At the heart of that agreement was the industry's code and its stipulations about the treatment of children. I made clear that the terms of the code related as much to Princes William and Harry as to any other children.

Nobody was asking for extra protection, or less protection - simply the same respect for their privacy. That meant no interviewing or photographing without the consent of the parents or of the school authorities - and it meant no long-lens photos or harassment either.

In turn, recognising the legitimate public interest in the children, the Palace agreed to ensure that photographs and information about the children were from time to time made available to the press and the broadcasters.

It was a balancing act - legitimate privacy and legitimate access: In other words, a commonsense solution based on the terms of a commonsense code of practice.

Of course, a great deal had happened since then - most important of which was the tightening of the industry's code after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.

That added significantly to the protection available to all children - including Prince William and Prince Harry - by adding a stipulation that children should be entitled to complete their time at school without intrusion.

That tightening of the code led to a review of the agreement between the Palace and the press. New guidelines, issued in April 1999, tackled the issue of so-called cumulative intrusion as a result of an accumulation of apparently harmless stories about the princes.

It was, I believe, a practical and commonsense set of changes which have proved very effective over the last year.

Has it worked?

That, then, has been the theory. But how has it all worked out in practice?

The answer, I believe, is that it has been a considerable success story for self-regulation - and highly beneficial for the two young men at the centre of our concerns today.

As far as I am aware, for the best part of five years no unauthorised pictures of either of the boys at school appeared in a British publication - although St James's Palace has registered its concern with me about pictures which appeared in a Sunday newspaper a fortnight ago.

That is a matter into which I am still looking.

I should emphasise that this broad picture of substantial restraint has been all the more admirable given that pictures of the princes appear with monotony abroad - particularly in countries like France, where privacy laws are theoretically supposed to protect the privacy of the individual, but lamentably fail so to do.

Furthermore, there has - as far as I am aware - been no physical intrusion or harassment of the boys at school.

Five years ago, there was a regular crowd of paparazzi at Eton. The success of the code has caused that problem in large part to disappear: paparazzi seldom hang around if there is no market available for their pictures.

Nor has there been any attempt by any publication to interview either of the boys, or - again so far as I am aware - any of their friends, in strict accordance with the code.

That has been a substantial success - and provided the boys with a degree of personal privacy that I suspect none of their forebears received. For that, enormous credit must go to editors of all national and local newspapers and periodicals, and to their reporters as well.

By respecting the privacy of these children, they have shown how the code works, and how importantly editors take the work of the PCC. It has certainly confounded the detractors of self-regulation.

Some of them said that it would never work, that the children would be hounded. They were all wrong.

Of course, it would be surprising if - in five years - there had not been the odd hiccup, but those hiccups have been few and far between.

Twice complaints have been made about individual stories - both of which were amicably resolved, and one of which lead to the publication of the revised guidelines.

And, inevitably, there have been other stories which have not produced complaints - but with which St James's Palace have had informally and privately to deal. But the broad picture has been one of commendable restraint - especially on the use of photographs, and on the issue of physical harassment.

And we have had other hiccups in more recent days. The last fortnight has sadly been marked by a number of controversies relating to the copyrighting and publication of photographs to coincide with Prince William's 18th birthday.

Indeed, it was that controversy which caused me to postpone this speech - which I had intended to deliver a fortnight ago.

Given that my message today is one of great praise for editors, and for the co-operation that has taken place for most of the last five years, this is not the time or the place for a post mortem on these recent events and I do not intend to deliver one.

However, I have to underline one point. Given that the future protection of Prince William's privacy is going to rely to some extent on continued co-operation between Palace and press, I have been monitoring the events of recent weeks with some care - and discussed with St James's Palace the lessons to be learned from them.

I am satisfied from those discussions that the lessons have indeed been learned - and that the Palace is now in a position to be able to deliver the co-operation that is required to make this work.

Photographs

First, then, photographs. The question of what photographs of Prince William will be published is, in many ways, the most important one for editors and for the readers of newspapers.

Over the last few years, relatively few photographs of Prince William - or, indeed, of Prince Harry - have been published because of the tight restrictions in the code. That prohibits photographs taken and published without the consent either of parents or of school authorities.

From tomorrow, he will cease to benefit from that protection - and he can expect to be photographed in public places like any other young adult.

If, therefore, he is playing polo, or shopping in Oxford Street, or sitting outside a pub, then he will from time to time be photographed and those pictures are likely to be published.

That is likely to mean that newspaper readers are going to be seeing somewhat more of him in the future.

There are, of course, caveats to that. The first is that neither I, nor the editors I have discussed this with, can foresee any circumstances in which it will be justifiable to publish pictures of Prince William that have been obtained as a result of intimidation or harassment or persistent pursuit - points I want to talk further about at the end of my remarks.

The second is that - like every other public figure - there should be no publication of snatched pictures of Prince William taken when he is in a private place, that is somewhere where there is a reasonable expectation of privacy.

I have made clear to editors, who agree with me, that they should generally regard pictures of him in private gardens, in restaurants and so on as off limits under the code, except - of course - on those rare occasions when there may be a public interest in doing so.

In other words, there is going to be an important change in this area -bearing in mind the key caveats that I have also made.

Facts

Another area where there is going to be further change is that there will inevitably be more stories written about Prince William.

Again, the code - with its provision that young people should be able to complete their time at school without unnecessary intrusion - has meant that hardly any stories about Prince William during his time at Eton have appeared, and rightly so. It has had the same success as far as other young people are concerned.

But as he becomes, increasingly, a public figures and is away from his school environment, there are going to be more stories written about what he gets up to in public.

As there are likely to be more stories, I think it sensible simply to underline a number of points about factual accuracy.

I think most people in public life grudgingly accept the fact that sometimes things get written about them which are unfair, misleading or downright wrong.

Certainly, I can think of a number of things that have been written about me which bear not even a passing resemblance to the truth. But it happens, usually by accident.

If it is a point of no consequence, most of us let it pass. If it is a serious matter, I always encourage people to take it up with the editors - and, if that fails, take it to the PCC. Most significant inaccuracies are quickly put right that way.

However, while older members of the royal family may themselves from time to time attract a degree of speculation and conjecture in stories about them, a public figure like Prince William who is also a very young man should be entitled to expect that things that are written about him are accurate.

He should not have to read about how he is part of a so-called 'set' that is involved with drugs - when he has never been part of that 'set'.

He should not have to read about family arguments that he is purported to have had when he hasn't had them.

He should not have to read about how he is having a relationship with a girl that he has never met.

Such inaccuracies are in many ways worse than an intrusion into privacy because they create a misleading impression, and - as the old saying goes - mud sticks. In some cases, particularly where other individuals are involved, it can damage more than one person.

To give you an example, in recent weeks the PCC has been involved both formally and informally with investigations relating to two or three newspapers that have run stories about alleged relationships of Prince William.

What has struck me during all these is the potential damage that can be done to the girls concerned, and the embarrassment they may well be caused - let alone how such stories affect Prince William.

In each case, the PCC has reminded editors of the importance of accuracy in these matters, and I take the opportunity to do so again today.

In other words, where newspapers or magazines are writing about Prince William they must take care under the code to ensure the stories are right - which will usually mean not relying simply on the word of those who may well turn out to be troublemakers.

Indeed, I was struck recently by a very salient point made to me - that real friends of Prince William will not be seeking to cause mischief by leaking stories to newspapers.

Those who do may not turn out to know him quite as well as they pretend - landing editors in trouble as a result. This, in turn, also puts an onus on St James's Palace to ensure that they respond constructively to legitimate inquiries about stories relating to Prince William.

Clause three of the code of practice makes clear that everyone is entitled to respect for his or her private life.

That part of the code - drawn from the European Convention on Human Rights - is quite clear. Everyone means everyone.

It is unthinkable that the second in line to the throne should not be treated to the same respect.

But at the same time, we have to recognise - as, indeed, I made clear in my remarks five years ago - that he is different to other people simply because of his position.

That means there will be legitimate public interest in stories about him and pictures of him - but not on the basis of a 'free-for-all'.

 Health

 Personal correspondence

 Telephone conversations

 Space at times of grief and shock

 And (as I made clear earlier) pictures taken in private places.

 No physical intimidation

 And (as I made clear earlier) no photography in private places.

Those, then, are the key issues I want to highlight today. What we are saying, simply, is that Prince William should continue to be allowed a private life and freedom from harassment in the same way as any other public figure.

There will be four winners from that.

One winner will, of course, be Prince William - who will continue to benefit from the protection of the editors' code and therefore be able to complete his education without unnecessary intrusion.

One will be newspapers and magazines - because by continuing to respect his privacy, they will again be demonstrating to the public that the media can act responsibly and sensitively and that self-regulation really works.

One will be the public - which has consistently made clear, as the results of an opinion poll last week underlined, that they want to see Prince William grow up with as much privacy as possible.

And the final one will be the institution of the monarchy itself.

I have always believed that - after many years in which the relationship between press and palaces was fraught and tense - the way that newspapers have respected the privacy of Prince William and Prince Harry has pointed a new, better way forward for the next generation.

From that the monarchy itself is bound to benefit.

And it lies, too, in the unsung success of the editors' code of practice which - over the last 10 years - has slowly and surely, and usually unnoticed by our critics, transformed standards of newspaper reporting. Ten years ago, simple inaccuracies about people that most of us had never heard of went uncorrected. Intrusions into the private lives of ordinary people by a handful of newspapers were all too common. Today, we live in a different world - one in which a tough code of practice ensures that most inaccuracies are corrected, that intrusion and harassment are by and large prevented, and that a great deal of protection is given to the most vulnerable members of our society such as the sick, victims of assault and, above all, children. So that is what the vast bulk of our work is all about. Raising standards of reporting. Sorting out disputes. Serving the public. Protecting the vulnerable. But while I am acutely aware that most of what we do relates to ordinary people, I am also aware that the success of self regulation rests in many ways on how the press deals with the privacy of public figures - and in turn how the PCC deals with complaints from those individuals when something has gone wrong. In short, while we always apply the code in equal measure to everyone in the land, ordinary people know it works to protect them if they see it protecting the most famous. And while we will always treat every complainant equally, ordinary people know the PCC will provide them with commonsense and effective redress when they see us dealing in a quick and sensible manner with high-profile complainants who come to us. One winner will, of course, be Prince William - who will continue to benefit from the protection of the editors' code and therefore be able to complete his education without unnecessary intrusion. One will be newspapers and magazines - because by continuing to respect his privacy, they will again be demonstrating to the public that the media can act responsibly and sensitively and that self-regulation really works. One will be the public - which has consistently made clear, as the results of an opinion poll last week underlined, that they want to see Prince William grow up with as much privacy as possible. And the final one will be the institution of the monarchy itself. I have always believed that - after many years in which the relationship between press and palaces was fraught and tense - the way that newspapers have respected the privacy of Prince William and Prince Harry has pointed a new, better way forward for the next generation. From that the monarchy itself is bound to benefit.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Young people worship bodies not brains, says the influential head of Manchester   Grammar School. True or false?
fields.trailText: The Question: Young people worship bodies not brains, says the influential head of Manchester Grammar School. True or false?
fields.body:
Dr Martin Stephen
Headmaster, Manchester Grammar School

Role models are crucial for young people - and we need more role models who encourage intellectual pursuits. I've got huge admiration for people like Posh and Becks, but we need to add to the list people at the sharp end of academic achievement. There are countless candidates, though only a few household names, such as Stephen Hawking. We live in the age of the instant, so I don't think this is a change that could happen overnight. We have to work at it. But it could do so much: when you show young people it's cool to be clever, they take to learning like ducks to water.
Verdict: True

Lucie Tobin
Editor, Mizz magazine for 10 to 14-year-old girls

Teenagers today are really smart. They don't think celebrity is all there is to life. Nor does it make them think they don't need to bother at school. I meet a lot of teenagers and I find them sweet and caring, interested in green issues and in ending exploitation. They're not just thinking about what they wear and what Posh and Becks are up to. There have always been big stars, and it has never been cool to be clever. But I think today's young can be shallow and deep at the same time. They can deal with the big issues of life and still want a pair of designer shoes.
Verdict: False

Davinder Kalsi, 15
Pupil, Yardley's Secondary School, Birmingham

The only "intellectual" role model I can think of is Bill Gates, and he's not in the papers that often. It's OK for people who want to be footballers and pop stars, because there are plenty of role models around for them. But what about people like me who don't? And what about people who think they can make it as footballers and pop stars who are going to be disappointed when they don't? At school if you're clever you get called a geek - it's always sport that's where it's at. Being bright isn't seen as good, and I think that should change.
Verdict: True

Dr Terri Apter
Social psychologist, University of Cambridge

I think Dr Stephen is confusing two things. The first is anti-intellectualism, which is a real issue in Britain, probably more than anywhere else. But it infects the whole culture, not just young people. There's a gender issue here too - the new lad culture is anti-academic work, but girls tend to see that working hard is a way to fulfil ambitions. The second thing is role models, on which maybe more could be done. But I don't think the situation is so bad. The genome project has shown the value of people going into academia to work on a scientific project.
Verdict: False

Lucy Channon, 15
Pupil, St George Community College, Bristol

I don't think young people look up to celebrities at all. Of course, we read about them and see them on television, but they're not people we can chat to, so I don't think we always want to emulate them. A much more important figure in my life is my mentor, who works in a bank here. She's going to be a far bigger influence on me than any celebrity. As far as getting on with your work is concerned, you do get some stick if you say you're off to revise. But it's more joking than serious. By the time they reach Year 10, as I have, people know they've got to work.
Verdict: False

fields.headline: Let's talk about sex, baby
fields.standfirst: Research shows that children prefer to get sex education from their parents. But what if you are too embarrassed? Kate Hilpern reports
fields.trailText: Research shows that children prefer to get sex education from their parents. But what if you are too embarrassed? Kate Hilpern reports
fields.body:
Three sad facts about sex education in Britain: one, too many of our young people are told too little, too late and what they are told is too biological; two, young people don't want to hear about sex from peers or teachers - they want their parents to tell them; and three, parents are the last people to talk to them about it, particularly sons. Why is it that otherwise conscientious parents are failing their children in this way?

"I didn't want to acknowledge that Greg, who's 15, wasn't a child any more," says Mandy Ashton, 39. "And anyway, I don't know anything about boys and puberty. I'm a single mother with no brothers. When Greg asked me about changes to his genitalia, I didn't know how to answer him. I was so mortified that I asked him not to mention it again."

According to Simon Blake, director of the Sex Education Forum, more than 50% of British parents would like guidance on how to talk to their kids about sex but don't know where to get it. As a result, 10% of girls start menstruating before being told anything about it, young homosexuals rarely get any support, and boys often feel they get the wink, wink, nudge, nudge approach and learn nothing. So what help is out there for parents such as Mandy Ashton, who simply don't know where to start?

The short answer is, not much. If she were a man, she could try the YMCA's Lads and Dads course, aimed at helping fathers to communicate with sons. If she lived in Byker, in north-east England, she could attend the "Let's Talk About Sex" parents' group there. If she lived in Great Yarmouth, she could approach the Women's Group, which runs facilitated groups for parents. And if lucky enough to live in Northern Ireland, she could call SpeakEasy, a project run by the Family Planning Clinic (FPC), which offers a three-day residential course to discuss concerns with other parents and a qualified facilitator. The FPC runs nothing similar on the mainland, although it has put in a bid for lottery money to do so. Despite telephoning every helpline we could think of, these small, local initiatives are all we found for Mandy Ashton.

However, even if the FPC gets its funding, it won't be much use to Mandy Ashton. Like many parents, she is "not into the group thing".

"No way," she says. "Give me a leaflet to ponder over any day."

That is exactly what the National Children's Bureau did. "I read it. It convinced me that by not talking about sex, I was saying it was 'bad'."

But thus converted, Ashton still finds it difficult to put theory into practice. "Phoning Parentline, which was advertised on one of the leaflets, helped a bit. I could talk to someone anonymously, giving real examples of problems kids encounter. But you can't phone up every time or you'd feel useless. In any case, Greg would be wary of me suddenly becoming interested in his puberty issues."

Dr Miriam Stoppard, author of several books on sex education, believes the biggest mistake "suddenly clued-up parents" make is going too abruptly into discussions of sex. "The only way sex education within the family really works is to talk about it from the moment the child is born," she says. "Equally important is picking the right time - meaning their 'ready time' not yours."

Kerry McCall, a 40-year-old mother of five, knows exactly what she means. Unlike Mandy Ashton, McCall does talk to her kids about sex but they don't always listen. "I was telling the 11-year-old some stuff the other day that I'd prepared carefully, and he suddenly asked if I'd got a 'wiggly tuft'. I was horrified, but then I realised he wasn't listening and was talking about Pokémon.

Next month, the Family Planning Association launches a video which, according to spokeswoman Diane Lea, "is meant to improve and encourage open and honest communication and to help parents overcome the feelings of embarrassment, fear and even terror that they experience. In the privacy of their own homes, parents will be helped to reflect upon their own attitudes towards sex before passing them on to their children - and even to brush up on the basics.

Mandy Ashton has already placed her order.

 The Family Planning Association video will be available from July 31. Telephone: 01865 719418. Parentline: 0808 8002222.

fields.headline: We are family... sort of
fields.standfirst: Jerry Hall says she would be happy for her children to meet their half-brother Lucas, Mick Jagger's love child. Would we all be so generous? asks  Sophie Radice
fields.trailText: Jerry Hall says she would be happy for her children to meet their half-brother Lucas, Mick Jagger's love child. Would we all be so generous? asks Sophie Radice
fields.body:
Never mind how Jerry Hall fares playing the deshabillée Mrs Robinson in the West End production of The Graduate, she is currently doing a great job in the role of sanguine ex-wife. It could be that her £7m divorce settlement lends her the luxury of magnanimity, but not only did she say in a recent newspaper interview that she feels sorry for her persistently promiscuous ex-husband, she spoke with extraordinary generosity about his "love child" with the Brazilian model Luciana Morad. With a graciousness that some might think beyond the call of duty, Hall said that she had told Mick "that any time he wanted to introduce the baby to our children, I would be supportive".

In a dignified manner, Hall has brought to the fore a relationship that - as I recently realised when my husband's grandmother struggled to introduce to me her ex-husband's youngest daughter - doesn't even have a name. If you marry someone who already has children, you automatically become a step-parent but if your ex- goes on to reproduce after your split, you have no recognisable relationship with your own children's half-siblings. Nothing is required and, for many, nothing is given.

My ex-husband does better then most. Although awkward around my daughter and always treated by her with a mixture of suspicion and condescension, he does remember to buy her Christmas and birthday presents - the only way he knows of recognising her as his son's half sister. My son and daughter, meanwhile, are being brought up together. They therefore regard themselves - and are seen by others - as full-blooded siblings.

More typical, perhaps, is the experience of Rachel Hartley, 37, whose relationship broke down because her ex-husband decided that he wanted "freedom" and "that family life wasn't really for him after all". Rachel went on to have a baby with her new partner but found her ex-husband's attitude towards him puzzling. "When he came to pick up the two older children to take them out he was happy to sit down and chat and have a cup of tea but he would not look at the baby.

"He completely ignored Ben, which was fine until he grew up into a toddler. Then he started wanting my ex-husband to play and getting confused and calling him daddy like his brothers did.

"One time when my ex came to visit, Ben got on to his lap and he absolutely froze. In that moment I understood that he found Ben repulsive because he was the symbol of his replacement. Even though his sons adored their new brother, he could not get over the fact that I had recovered from the supposedly devastating blow he had dealt me."

Carol Berthram, 30, whose former partner went on to have two children after being what Carol describes as a "rather distant father" to her son Josh, seven, says: "God knows, I try to be neutral, but I can't help feeling really negative about his new children. When Josh goes to stay I want him to get the attention he craves from his father and I know how hard it is to see him with other children. If Josh gets angry about them I know I have to be supportive of him and I am afraid I sometimes end up agreeing with him that they sound like silly spoilt brats."

William Knight, 43, who had two daughters by his first relationship and has two daughters in his current marriage, has the opposite perspective. He shares access but says: "She made it perfectly clear that she didn't want to have anything to do with my new family even though she was per fectly happy to let the girls spend half their time with us.

"This became very awkward when we had to decide which primary school to send the younger girls to. I knew that my new kids would be completely blanked by their sisters' mother at the school gates, even if they rushed up to speak to their older sisters. It would have been really confusing and upsetting for them all, so we decided to send the little ones to a different primary school.

"What makes all these complications worthwhile is that the children are delighted by each other and make a lovely family. I am hoping that my ex will see that it would make life easier for the daughters we share if she were less bloody-minded about the ones we don't."

Of the 12 people I spoke to, only one had managed á la Hall to grasp that if he showed a negative attitude towards his daughter's half-sister it might damage the siblings' relationship with each other. "It is really difficult to believe that I have managed to behave well over this," says Joe Cowan, 39. "Because my ex and I had a really vicious break-up. When I heard she was pregnant with her new boyfriend I thought she was making a huge error.

"What changed it for me was that my daughter stayed with me while the baby was being born and it was me that took her to the hospital to meet her. Seeing my daughter's face when she met her new sister was really moving. Despite the fact that we had messed up and put her through so much, she had got something she had always wanted - a little sister."

Joe now spends birthdays and Christmas with his ex-partner, her boyfriend and the two girls. "It started to seem really odd that Jess always saw me on my own. I was really concerned that I didn't come across as a sad disapproving git on the sidelines. Last week I took both children to the zoo and when someone said to my daughter's sister, 'Isn't your dad lucky having such lovely girls', none of us could be bothered to explain. We just looked at each other and laughed."

fields.headline: Feeding frenzy
fields.standfirst: Screaming, clamping their lips together, turning their heads away and being sick - just some of the weapons toddlers use to avoid eating.  Raekha Prasad  on a new way to bring peace to mealtimes
fields.trailText: Screaming, clamping their lips together, turning their heads away and being sick - just some of the weapons toddlers use to avoid eating. Raekha Prasad on a new way to bring peace to mealtimes
fields.body:
'How much does she weigh?" Unlike "Have you chosen a name yet?" or "How long was the labour?" the second question the parents of a newborn are routinely asked (coming, as it does, straight after "Boy or girl?") is a loaded one. When the baby is newborn, it is a shorthand for, "Is he healthy?" And unlike the others, this question will be asked not once, but a hundred times: by mothers themselves when they visit the clinic, by health visitors clutching graphs, by mothers-in-law who don't think breastfeeding is a good idea.

So when Lewis Baum's weight failed to climb the scales, his mother Joanne felt she had failed, unable to confirm her care through those pounds and ounces. Attempts to wean her son onto solids when he was six months old became the first battle in the war that was to follow. Lewis gagged on food Joanne had made but would happily eat the jarred variety.

Aged one, he wouldn't eat anything but jarred food and although his weight wasn't falling his parents became increasingly anxious. "I ended up in tears every time I tried to feed him," Baum says.

Joanne was referred to Feeding Matters, one of two projects run by the Children's Society, which help parents reach a truce at the dinner table. A project worker visited them at home and filmed Joanne's desperate attempts to get him to eat. By going through the film, the project worker was able to help Joanne understand what was going wrong - and to discover ways that she could break the deadlock.

Lewis's case was a mild one. As many as one in 20 under fives in Britain are said to be suffering from "faltering growth" (aka "failure to thrive") because they are not receiving enough calories. Contrary to previously held perceptions that it was confined to the poorest and most negligent families, research has shown that it can occur in any home. Faltering growth is neither a disease nor the same as faddy eating. The precise cause is unknown, but only 5% of young children with inexplicable poor growth are found to have an illness, and only a minority have faltering growth because of abuse or neglect.

What is clear however, is that parents of children with faltering growth suffer a destructive cycle of self-blame. A report out today from the Children's Society found that these parents feel helpless, unsupported and deeply distressed by the impact the condition has on their baby. They describe how their child refused to eat, which included screaming, crying, clamping their lips together, turning their heads away, pushing the food away, spitting out food and being sick. These confrontations at meal times, the report suggest, are part of a vicious circle: parental anxiety about a child's rejection of food is detected by the child which then compounds the problem.

"There is often no one cause," says Angela Underdown, author of the report and a social policy officer at the Children's Society. "There are often many, many causes and focusing on one makes the tension worse."

Underdown says babies "tell" their parents if they want to eat and when they've had enough. Parent's descriptions of mealtimes indicate that they might have become "out of tune" with their baby's non-verbal cues so that feeding becomes fraught. "It's important that parents listen to their child's body language," she suggests.

But how can parents identify what they are doing wrong? Deborah O'Dell banged on every door she could find to find out why her daughter Rebecca had faltering growth. From the moment she came home from hospital she was refusing milk. She dropped below her birth weight. At three months she was tested for diabetes, leukemia and cystic fibrosis - all of which she did not have. At seven months, a tube was inserted into her stomach through which she was fed artificially. Aged one, she weighed only 14lbs: an average body weight of a six- to nine-month-old baby.

During that time O'Dell had made numerous trips to her GP, and was even referred to Great Ormond Street hospital in London, but the problem continued. Then she read about Feeding Matters in a newspaper and asked them for help.

It was only when O'Dell saw on film how she and her husband were interacting with Rebecca that she began to understand what had been going wrong. "On the video, we're saying 'do you want this Becky? Becky do you want that?' We were obsessed with her eating," O'Dell says. "We saw how we were making things worse, bribing her and forcing her behaviour."

In tandem with regular visits by the project worker, a diet plan, working agreement and regular reviews, Rebecca is beginning to eat more. "We now ignore Rebecca when she doesn't eat and praise her when she does. If she doesn't eat we talk to each other and she gets bored and starts to eat. Our lives are completely different."

Taking pressure off a child to eat is the first step towards solving faltering growth argues Sue Barber, a Feeding Matters practioner in North Tees. "If you give a lot of attention to behaviour you don't want it tends to encourage it," she says. "If mealtimes become a battle the parent will always loose."

For a parent to deal with their child's refusal to eat they must first learn not to take it personally. "Just acting as if you don't care is not good enough. You have to mean it," says Julia Fabricius, director of the Anna Freud Centre which tackles childhood emotional disorder. Fabricius argues that, along with potty-training and dressing, eating is a common battleground because it marks a child's assertion of will.

"Toddlerhood is the very moment when a child battles for autonomy," she says. "For many children their first word is 'no'. They are trying to be their own person."

It was only when Joanne Baum stopped insisting that Lewis eat, that he did. After watching what was going wrong on video and advice from a Feeding Matters worker, two-year-old Lewis is eating more.
