fields.bodyText: 'How much does she weigh?" Unlike "Have you chosen a name yet?" or "How long was the labour?" the second question the parents of a newborn are routinely asked (coming, as it does, straight after "Boy or girl?") is a loaded one. When the baby is newborn, it is a shorthand for, "Is he healthy?" And unlike the others, this question will be asked not once, but a hundred times: by mothers themselves when they visit the clinic, by health visitors clutching graphs, by mothers-in-law who don't think breastfeeding is a good idea. So when Lewis Baum's weight failed to climb the scales, his mother Joanne felt she had failed, unable to confirm her care through those pounds and ounces. Attempts to wean her son onto solids when he was six months old became the first battle in the war that was to follow. Lewis gagged on food Joanne had made but would happily eat the jarred variety. Aged one, he wouldn't eat anything but jarred food and although his weight wasn't falling his parents became increasingly anxious. "I ended up in tears every time I tried to feed him," Baum says. Joanne was referred to Feeding Matters, one of two projects run by the Children's Society, which help parents reach a truce at the dinner table. A project worker visited them at home and filmed Joanne's desperate attempts to get him to eat. By going through the film, the project worker was able to help Joanne understand what was going wrong - and to discover ways that she could break the deadlock. Lewis's case was a mild one. As many as one in 20 under fives in Britain are said to be suffering from "faltering growth" (aka "failure to thrive") because they are not receiving enough calories. Contrary to previously held perceptions that it was confined to the poorest and most negligent families, research has shown that it can occur in any home. Faltering growth is neither a disease nor the same as faddy eating. The precise cause is unknown, but only 5% of young children with inexplicable poor growth are found to have an illness, and only a minority have faltering growth because of abuse or neglect. What is clear however, is that parents of children with faltering growth suffer a destructive cycle of self-blame. A report out today from the Children's Society found that these parents feel helpless, unsupported and deeply distressed by the impact the condition has on their baby. They describe how their child refused to eat, which included screaming, crying, clamping their lips together, turning their heads away, pushing the food away, spitting out food and being sick. These confrontations at meal times, the report suggest, are part of a vicious circle: parental anxiety about a child's rejection of food is detected by the child which then compounds the problem. "There is often no one cause," says Angela Underdown, author of the report and a social policy officer at the Children's Society. "There are often many, many causes and focusing on one makes the tension worse." Underdown says babies "tell" their parents if they want to eat and when they've had enough. Parent's descriptions of mealtimes indicate that they might have become "out of tune" with their baby's non-verbal cues so that feeding becomes fraught. "It's important that parents listen to their child's body language," she suggests. But how can parents identify what they are doing wrong? Deborah O'Dell banged on every door she could find to find out why her daughter Rebecca had faltering growth. From the moment she came home from hospital she was refusing milk. She dropped below her birth weight. At three months she was tested for diabetes, leukemia and cystic fibrosis - all of which she did not have. At seven months, a tube was inserted into her stomach through which she was fed artificially. Aged one, she weighed only 14lbs: an average body weight of a six- to nine-month-old baby. During that time O'Dell had made numerous trips to her GP, and was even referred to Great Ormond Street hospital in London, but the problem continued. Then she read about Feeding Matters in a newspaper and asked them for help. It was only when O'Dell saw on film how she and her husband were interacting with Rebecca that she began to understand what had been going wrong. "On the video, we're saying 'do you want this Becky? Becky do you want that?' We were obsessed with her eating," O'Dell says. "We saw how we were making things worse, bribing her and forcing her behaviour." In tandem with regular visits by the project worker, a diet plan, working agreement and regular reviews, Rebecca is beginning to eat more. "We now ignore Rebecca when she doesn't eat and praise her when she does. If she doesn't eat we talk to each other and she gets bored and starts to eat. Our lives are completely different." Taking pressure off a child to eat is the first step towards solving faltering growth argues Sue Barber, a Feeding Matters practioner in North Tees. "If you give a lot of attention to behaviour you don't want it tends to encourage it," she says. "If mealtimes become a battle the parent will always loose." For a parent to deal with their child's refusal to eat they must first learn not to take it personally. "Just acting as if you don't care is not good enough. You have to mean it," says Julia Fabricius, director of the Anna Freud Centre which tackles childhood emotional disorder. Fabricius argues that, along with potty-training and dressing, eating is a common battleground because it marks a child's assertion of will. "Toddlerhood is the very moment when a child battles for autonomy," she says. "For many children their first word is 'no'. They are trying to be their own person." fields.headline: Joseph, 1, Chris the Pillock, 0
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: The diary of a part-time father
fields.body:
Now where were we? Oh, yes. First, there was me and a gal called Dilys: Dilys Day (whip crackaway, whip crackaway, whip crackaway!). Then there was Gloria (born 24/3/88), Jed (13/8/91) and Billy (2/9/93), and we all lived together in a forbearing kind of way, until Chris came on the scene: Chris the Pillock, man of destiny, powerbook in one hand, copy of Introducing Jung clutched in the other. As a child, Jung concluded that Jesus and the phallus were, in fact, the same thing. The conflation is persuasive where Chris is concerned: he thinks he is God's gift and I think he's a prick.

His effect on Dilys, though, has been quite different: he swept her away to his terracotta cave where he got in touch with his masculine side, and she started baking her own bread. And the children? I looked after them most of the time. At least, I did until Dilys got round to re-asserting the privileges of motherhood and promoting the paternal claims of Chris, "our other dad" as my children are encouraged to describe him. Ha, bloody, ha.

By then Gloria, Jed and Billy had started living part-time lives: half their time in my house, the other half with those I dubbed "The Enemy Without". My spirits started slumping. Then I met Angie, and realised Aretha Franklin had sung those lines for me: "When my heart was in the Lost and Found, you came along and claimed it." Oh, joy. Now we are married and have a baby girl - Estelle, two in September. We also have a battle on our hands.

"Who's winning?" I asked Angie on Sunday evening as we flopped in front of the telly. It was not a reference to France versus Spain.

"We are," Angie replied.

"We are?"

"Because we're not trying to win. We're not treating the children like prizes in a competition, and I believe they know that. Or will do, anyway."

We often have this ritual exchange, when Gloria, Jed and Billy are away for a weekend, leaving Angie, me and Estelle to contemplate the dust in our living room and the state of play in the part-time parenting game. It begins when I own up to feeling unloved and discouraged. This time it was caused by what Jed said about the state of his bedroom: "It's really dirty in here."

"You're only eight," I replied, lightly. "You're not supposed to notice dirt."

He didn't look at me.

"Is your bedroom at the other house cleaner?"

"Mmm. Yeah."

"A lot, lot cleaner?"

"I suppose."

I eyed the spiders spinning on the polystyrene coving as Estelle crumbled biscuits on the carpet and Angie talked the cheerful case

"Look at it this way. Yes, our house is messy. Yes, we don't understand computers and we're bad at fussing over every little cough and cold. We're also bad at being crafty. But we must not forget one thing..."

"I know," I cut in. "The kids aren't daft."

"Gloria in particular's not daft."

There had been a long conversation: stepmother and stepdaughter on the subject of half-sisters and who decides how members of overlapping part-time families are related. Gloria said that she couldn't think of Estelle as half of anything, so why shouldn't she think of Angie as a whole other mother and Chris as a whole other dad? But Angie had replied that it wasn't that simple.

How Gloria felt about Estelle was lovely and completely up to her, but she, Angie, could not accept maternal equality with Dilys where Gloria was concerned. She had insisted, this would be outrageously presumptuous, which is why Dilys had been wrong to award Chris paternal equality with me. "You and your two brothers," Angie had reminded Gloria, with just a hint of steel, "have never been only Dilys's to give away." Gloria had said she would think about it. "She can't admit it yet," Angie assured me, "but she knows I'm right."

And Jed and Billy? "Billy is ridiculously happy. The child is too well-balanced to be true."

"And Jed?" I repeated. "He's the tricky one."

"He watches you all the time."

"Yeah. Watches and disapproves."

"He doesn't watch Chris that way. I know, because Gloria told me. He really loves you. They all really love you. All we have to do is keep on being saintly."

I'm not sure I do saintly. But I suppose I'll have to try.

fields.headline: Saving time
fields.standfirst:
New alliance pushes for penal reform
Crime: special report
fields.trailText: Yesterday an alliance of 40 voluntary organisations involved in the criminal justice system launched a joint manifesto for penal reform dedicated to spreading the message that, for some, "prison is an expensive way of making bad people worse".
fields.body:
The case for halting the growth of Britain's prison population as a way of cutting crime has gone largely unheard since the home secretary, Jack Straw, launched his own version of "prison works". But yesterday an alliance of 40 voluntary organisations involved in the criminal justice system, led by the former Conservative home secretary, Lord Hurd, launched a joint manifesto for penal reform dedicated to spreading the message that, for some, "prison is an expensive way of making bad people worse".

The manifesto, published under the banner of the Penal Affairs Consortium, has the backing of prison governors, chief probation officers and many others. It calls for a reduction in the unnecessary use of imprisonment and an increase in the use of community sentences that have been shown to work. Among its 70 recommendations are:

 Setting up a sentencing council as part of the court of appeal to issue detailed guidance on sentencing designed to reduce the unnecessary use of prison.

 Making sure the full range of community penalties is available to all courts, revising rules on use of sentences to stress the use of non-custodial punishments for minor offences.

 Introducing a new prison rule to stipulate that no jail should hold more inmates than it has places for, with compliance to be achieved over a "realistic" period.

 Providing high quality drug and alcohol prevention and treatment programmes across the criminal justice system.

 Establishing an official inquiry into women's prisons and developing a network of small, close to home, hostel-type units to be used for the majority of female inmates.

 Authorising more generous compensation arrangements for the victims of crime, with immediate payment and, if necessary, later recovery from the offender.

Cedric Fulwood, chairman of the Penal Affairs Consortium, says: "We believe that our proposals provide a blueprint for a penal system which is more effective in cutting crime, rehabilitating offenders and reducing the distress of victims. At the centrepiece of our proposals lies the replacement of unnecessary prison sentences with community supervision programmes based on evidence of what works in reducing offending. This would enable the prison service to provide humane, constructive regimes for a more manageable number of prisoners."

The manifesto is bound to prove influential. Hurd, president of the Prison Reform Trust, recently warned Tory leader William Hague not to regard prisons as "simply wastepaper baskets into which we can toss those of our fellow citizens about whom we wish to hear nothing further".

 A Joint Manifesto for Penal Reform 2000 is available from the Penal Affairs Consortium, 169 Clapham Manor Road, London SW9 0PU.

fields.headline: The cost of caring
fields.standfirst: If two social policy professors find it difficult to ensure their elderly mums gain the care they need, what chance have the rest of us? Town or country, it doesn't seem to make much difference
fields.trailText: If two social policy professors find it difficult to ensure their elderly mums gain the care they need, what chance have the rest of us? Town or country, it doesn't seem to make much difference.
fields.body:
Jane Lewis: the shire county story

The shire county story began three weeks before Christmas. My mother suffered a fall and was admitted to hospital - a small acute unit which is now, on my observation, in effect geriatric. It was an extremely friendly place, my mother felt at home and recovered relatively quickly.

After a couple of weeks, the staff began to talk about a package of care at home, but my mother's memory loss had become severe. Had she eaten? Had she fallen? These were impossible questions for her to answer. But she was, to all intents and purposes, lucid and reasonably mobile.

The social worker had doubts about home care but there seemed to be no problem about a residential option. I drove the requisite 400 miles and visited possible residential homes, all of which had vacancies.

The first showed me a nice room with a toilet and a less nice room without. It was entirely unclear to me which one was on offer and the discussion about money was, to say the least, opaque. The second was more straightforward. My mother was coming in "through social services", so I was shown a room without a toilet.

I finally worked out that I had to say, although my mother has essentially nothing in the bank, she did own her own home. Rooms with toilets were then the order of the day. And what would happen when she has spent all the money from her house (still not actually sold and not likely to raise a great deal)? Well, I was told it was "unlikely" she would be bumped down to an inferior room.

Since my mother moved into a residential home, I have filled in the form for attendance allowance - twice. The social worker was very helpful, but told me that she was not allowed to assist me with the form. But unless one has been co-resident with the person in need of assistance, it is virtually impossible to do. I have also completed income support forms. I have dealt, at length, with the court of protection. In short, I have devoted on average five hours a week to "mother administration".

Different bits of money are being paid by different parts of the social security administration into three different accounts. It seems impossible to rationalise these. I have been told by the extraordinarily nice staff in the residential home how much I must pay out of my mother's "house fund" to meet the balance of their charges (£278 a week). However, recently she needed a new skirt. Somehow, she had managed to live in her own home on an income just below income support levels and had paid for new clothes. It is now impossible. From all her various bits of income from the state, she is allowed to keep a derisory £15.45 a week.

Ruth Lister: the urban community care tale

The inner-city tale started at Christmas itself. It illustrates both the strengths and weaknesses of the community care system. I found my mother, in effect, unable to control the lower half of her body - which meant very limited mobility, a tendency to fall and double incontinence. The result, it turned out, of a minor stroke.

Once Christmas was over, the health and social services systems swung into action with impressive speed and co-ordination, even though it was still officially a public holiday. The rapid response team set up an interim service to help my mother get up in the morning and go to bed at night. The following day, a full care assessment was made. The care manager was extremely helpful and, unlike in the shire county, she saw the arduous task of completing the attendance allowance form as part of her job.

The operation of the quasi-market in domiciliary care was, though, much less satisfactory. The contracted agency was supposed to provide an hour each morning and night in order to get my mother up and to bed, to wash and toilet her and to get her breakfast and a snack supper. I very quickly discovered from neighbours (who were playing their part in the community care scenario with unstinting generosity) that the agency was not fulfilling its contract. Sometimes they were there for only a few minutes; once they didn't turn up at all. The care worker appeared to be ignoring instructions in the contract to "be patient" and reassure my mother that she did not have to rush. Indeed, on one occasion my mother begged a neighbour to get the care worker away, as she was upsetting her so much by hustling her.

My mother very quickly decided she would prefer to be in a nursing home (a decision which has turned out very well). Had she not had independent funds, however, the care manager made it clear she would not have qualified for support in a residential setting - a considerably more restrictive policy than in the shire county.

This short-lived experience of the realities of community care demonstrated to me the weaknesses of contracting out the bulk of domiciliary care to the independent sector without a requirement that the service is monitored and regulated. A degree of regulation of domiciliary care is now proposed, though probably not until 2002. Much will depend on the monitoring and regulatory requirements. But how many frail, elderly women without neighbours and relatives to speak up for them will suffer poor quality care in the meantime? And how can we expect care workers to provide a decent service under the poor conditions and minimal pay typical of the care sector?

Both these stories demonstrate that a package of care at home is not always the best solution. Both our mothers feared leaving their own homes, but were relieved and happier to be in residential care once they arrived. However, negotiating and coping with the financial implications of the decision to go into a home can be little short of a nightmare.

 Jane Lewis and Ruth Lister are professors of social policy at the Universities of Oxford and Loughborough respectively.

fields.headline: Sorry you're leaving
fields.standfirst: Holding on to staff is a real problem for charities.  Liza Ramrayka  reports on how some are beginning to address it
fields.trailText: Holding on to staff is a real problem for charities. Liza Ramrayka reports on how some are beginning to address it.
fields.body:
Charities may be expert in raising money and running headline-grabbing campaigns, but research published today suggests they have a lot to learn as employers. And their often poor staff retention record could be costing them a lot more than the price of a leaving card and farewell do.

A survey of 18 national charities highlights an annual staff turnover rate of 20% - higher than any other sector and it's on the increase. The study calculates that resignations cost the typical larger voluntary organisation £340,000 a year, irrespective of time and money invested in new recruits. Even a small percentage improvement in an organisation's retention rate could release significant resources for direct charitable purposes.

The research report, People Count, is produced by consultancy firm Compass Partnership and is based on its work with the 18 members of the Personnel Forum of National Voluntary Organisations, together employing more than 35,000 staff or 7% of paid voluntary sector workers.

The study compares the charities' practices and performance levels on 165 aspects of human resources, from staff recruitment to training. This approach, known as benchmarking, has been used since the 1980s by the private sector to improve efficiency and productivity by comparing performance.

Absenteeism rates among the charities were found to be low compared to other sectors - 5.9 days for managerial/professional staff, compared to a CBI-estimated average of 8.5 days. Yet three in four of those surveyed admitted that their staff turnover was too high, with one reporting a rate as high as 39%.

Follow-up work with the charities, six months after the survey, found that several had reacted to the find ings. One had increased human resource (HR) support; another had reviewed advertising policy and style; while several had instigated salary reviews. Some members of the forum are now involved in a further study of staff retention, focusing on high turnover.

Keith Smith, a co-author of today's report, says: "What we need to find out is why people are leaving, whether it's the 'push' of dissatisfaction or the 'pull' of greater opportunities in a booming sector."

Respondents to the first survey suggested that the main reasons for high turnover were employees feeling that their career progression had halted and the increase in use of fixed-term contracts, driven in part by funding arrangements.

There could be other explanations. Certain areas of the sector, such as frontline care, are more prone to high turnover because of the level of stress involved in the work. Meanwhile, specific functions such as fundraising are target-based and could result in the employee moving on to take on a new challenge.

The job agency, Charity Recruitment, has witnessed highest levels of turnover in fundraising. "The environment of full employment means that there's probably two or three new job opportunities for every fundraiser," says Olga Johnson, chief executive. "It's now quite acceptable for fundraisers to move on every two or three years, particularly if it's to gain experience of different fundraising techniques."

The Compass survey suggests that training and development could be an under-exploited tool for staff retention. Respondents' average spend was 2% of salary costs, or £230 per head - some 10% lower than the £255 average in all sectors. But the survey did highlight growing use of coaching by line managers and distance learning.

Jill Tombs, HR director at learning disability charity Mencap, believes charity staff expect more par ticipation and less traditional instruction. "We are moving away from the 'bums on seats' approach to training, to mentoring and internal support systems," she says. "I also think technology will have a big impact, with the internet offering wider access to training."

The Voluntary Sector National Training Organisation recently conducted its own research into the sector's training needs. Three-quarters of organisations questioned said they needed to improve one or more management skill. Using IT as an operational tool, forward planning and volunteer management were identified as areas where training was needed most.

Charities may also need to review the pay and benefits packages they offer. Two-thirds of the organisations taking part in the Compass survey thought their pay policies were inappropriate and at least four are now undertaking major reviews. While performance-related pay was used by only one charity, many thought its use would grow.

Children's charity Barnardo's found its staff turnover rate - about 24% - was fairly high compared to other charities taking part in the Compass survey. Most leavers were not in direct children's services, but in areas such as the marketing and communications department. The charity is now reviewing career planning for staff and looking to introduce more family-friendly policies.

"Because we're a charity, we don't have the resources to drive up salaries, but we can look at offering more attractive or flexible employment policies," says Barnardo's head of HR, Philippa Bury.

While almost all the HR directors surveyed said they did regularly attend senior management team meetings, five were not actually members of the team and six thought the HR function was not appropriately represented. This rather begs the question of whether charities regard the function in the same light as "hard hitting" departments such as fundraising or finance.

Smith, associate consultant at Compass, says charities should realise that the human resources department is not there just to keep the personnel records. He says: "HR directors can have a significant impact on the bottom line because if staff turnover rates are low, costs go down and charities have more money for their core activities."

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Street facades
fields.body:
Street facades

Your article on community participation in local government in Brazil (Streets Ahead, June 21) made heartening reading. However, we have a cautionary tale where consultation has been used as a rhetorical cloak to disguise old fashioned "council knows best" attitudes.

There has been concerted public opposition to the siting of a Sainsbury superstore on a massive regeneration site in Brighton. Two previous superstore applications had been rejected before a public inquiry also found against the proposal. Since then, packed public meetings and local petitions have continued to oppose the development. The council then embarked on "consultation" by funding a three-day planning event, attended by 500 people.

Yet again, there was near unanimity against a superstore. Councillors then decided to develop a planning brief by setting up a "consultative" working group in which they decided who should participate, the terms of reference, the final report and even whether dissent could be recorded. A council brief in support of the controversial store has duly emerged.

The council has used the facade of consultation to ignore the consistent demand of the public opinion it expressly sought. Perverse outcomes like these undermine public faith in "consultations" and expose community participation in local democracy as a hollow sham. Unlike Brazil,it is the council which calls the shots here.
Mike Aiken
Brighton Urban Design and Development, Brighton

Sold short by Mencap

Just as a pimp advertises a prostitute with references to willingness, capability and a favourable lasting impression, so we have the charity Mencap helping sell workers with learning difficulties to businesses by pointing out how they take "fewer days off sick", are "more reliable" and provide a "positive impact on a company's image" (Stack of Ability, June 21).

And did I actually read the Mencap campaigns officer, Tom Berry, enthusing how "people with learning disabilities are happy to do repetitive jobs that other members of the workforce wouldn't do", can be "very productive" and businesses are hence "generally very pleased with what they get for their money"?

It is one thing to provide enjoyable work for disabled people, but totally another to endeavour to have them profitably exploited through dead-end, monotonous labour and crafty, consumer-friendly advertising.
Max Hess
Folkestone, Kent

I agree that many day centres do little except contain people with learning disabilities with an endless round of tea and toileting. However, I am surprised that a spokesperson for Mencap is still reinforcing stereotypes about people with learning disabilities' desire for the monotony of repetitive and, as it seems in this case, potentially exploitative, low-paid employment.

It is clear from the tone of the article that the emphasis is too far towards productivity, benefits to business, raised profiles and profit. What about people? When will organisations purportedly supporting individuals with learning disabilities, and society at large, stop dealing in generalisations?

People with learning disabilities are just people like the rest of us: individuals with personalities, skills, dreams and interests. No one would dream of saying that all women should be secretaries, that all black men should be bus drivers or all gay men should be hairdressers. It is time to stop trying to live the lives of people with learning disabilities for them, and to start to educate them by increasing our expectation of them from their early years. This will enable them to make their own choices and have opportunities for something more than stacking shelves.
Simon O'Corra
independent advocate, London

No to NHS control

It is hard to fathom the arrogance of the NHS Confederation - whatever this strange body may be - in suggesting (Solving Riddles, June 14) the commissioning of social services by an NHS which is castigated in the same issue of the Guardian (front page) for doctor's errors costing £2bn a year.

My blood runs cold at the thought of a service which is only just beginning to understand (let alone put into practice) the social model of disability, having control over anything relating to current provision by the social service and voluntary sectors.

Years of careful work to reverse medical model nonsense will be damaged if the NHS is let anywhere near social services. The other way round makes much more sense; how about it?
Sarah Playforth
Seaford, East Sussex

Glastonbury dream fades

George McKay's article on the capitalist festival in Somerset (Party Politics, June 21) was a good read for the solstice, but he failed to point out that the "midsummer night's dream" became a bit of a nightmare in the 1990s. One person was shot and killed at Glastonbury, there were mass fights between travellers and security, the perimeter fence is now patrolled by guards with dogs, and even in the green fields (when I was last there) cars were set on fire and left to burn.

Hardly what you would call eco-friendly. The past sure is tense and this "very English fair" now has more in common with Altamont than Woodstock.
Andrew Aitken
Preston

fields.headline: Pulling the plug
fields.standfirst: How wine consumers threaten forests
fields.trailText: How wine consumers threaten forests.
fields.body:
The four cork strippers paced around the trunk of the Whistler Tree, the 217-year-old cork oak which is the largest in the world. For the first time in nine years, it was to be harvested.

They debated where to begin. Eventually, Custodio removed the curved axe blade from its cork sheath. Gently he made the first incision into the outer bark, taking care not to disturb the inner bark and drawing a line towards the base of the tree, gently prising it away. Alongside him, Luis marked out a parallel line.

The first slab of cork, the size of a door, fell to the ground, revealing the tree's golden beige underbelly. In a few weeks, it will turn burgundy red; in a few months, it will be nut brown, and begin to grow once more, ready to be stripped in another nine years.

The stripping of Quercus suber is a skilled craft that has gone on for hundreds of years in this part of Portugal, producer of more than half the world's natural cork - the vast majority of which is used for bottling wines.

Traditional farming methods provide not only an abundance for people, but food and shelter for some of Europe's most unusual wildlife, including the Iberian lynx - the world's rarest wild cat. The forests and the lynx, however, are now under threat, not from loggers but the plastic stoppers to which British and other supermarkets are turning.

"The cork industry is fundamental to the traditional, sustainable Mediterranean agro-ecosystems," says Helena Freitas, president of the Liga para a Proteccao da Natureza (Nature Conservation League), Portugal's oldest conservation group. "The management of the forests involves a low level of disturbance of the natural environment. If we lose the cork industry, then everything that depends on this system of forest agriculture will go."

At issue is the increasing demand by UK supermarkets for the highly marketable, multi-coloured plastic stoppers to plug wine bottles. One in 20 bottles worldwide now carries a plastic stopper, but in Britain the figure is as high as one in three in some of the cheaper wines. The trend has prompted environmentally-minded shoppers to write to supermarkets to complain - and the replies are prompting outrage in Portugal.

"This is shocking, an absolute lie," says Helena Freitas. She is reading a letter from Marks & Spencer to a customer in Norfolk, which tries to justify its decision to switch to plastic by saying that cork bark is infecting wine with bacteria and that the industry is environmentally unfriendly "by virtue of the need to cut them [the trees] down". Freitas responds: "Only someone who has no idea what they are talking about can say this. The trees are never cut down."

And then there is the letter from Safeway to a customer in Stockport, accusing cork farmers of "greed", adding, "the plastic corks we are using should actually help the environmental preservation of the cork forests" because cork farmers had "driven out the population of wild pigs".

"This is the first time I have ever heard such rubbish," says Dr Luis Palma, a biologist at the Algarve University, who has spent 20 years studying cork forest wildlife. "The only threat to these animals comes from deforestation, which is precisely what will happen if supermarkets continue to use plastic."

So just where are the supermarkets getting their information from?

Portuguese politicians claim that the supermarkets are being duped. "These blatant untruths are part of an ongoing disinformation campaign started by the plastics lobbies," says Lino de Carvalho, an MP whose Evora constituency includes thousands of cork farmers.

"What has kept these forests in place is their economic value for making corks," says Palma. "If demand drops because supermarkets use plastic, they will be replaced with something more profitable. And nothing could replace cork forests which would be environmentally sustainable."

Back at the Whistler Tree, the curved cork sheets were being weighed on a tripod. The result: just short of a metric tonne - enough for 100,000 corks.

Satisfied, Custodio took a thirsty gulp of water from a carved cork spoon, and put the axe-head back in its sheath. "I'll see you back here in nine years," he waved cheerily as I left. "God willing."

fields.headline: People's power
fields.standfirst: British charities are being warned that the Brazilian landless movement they help fund is dangerous and illegal.  Jan Rocha meets one of its leaders
fields.trailText: British charities are being warned that the Brazilian landless movement they help fund is dangerous and illegal. Jan Rocha meets one of its leaders.
fields.body:
They grow and sell organic produce, they are replanting mahogany in the Amazon, they even make jam - but the police treat them like criminals. This is MST, the Movement of Landless Rural Workers, Brazil's largest and most dynamic social movement, whose direct action tactics see them hoisting their red flag over farms, ranches, banks and government offices, demanding land, credits, schools, justice and a share of the wealth they help to create.

For peasant movements and small farmers round the world who believe that agriculture is not just a question of trade, but a political and social issue, and that food sovereignty is more important than food security, the MST has become a reference point, superseding Cuba as a training ground for militants. Its links with like-minded groups now stretch to the Philippines, Thailand, Korea, China, Mexico, and throughout Asia. It is the most quoted group by political and environmental activists in Europe and America and is at the forefront of forging an ideol ogy for the poor in many countries. But what exactly is the Movimento Sem Terra?

MST grew out of the despair of small farmers deprived of land in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul just 20 years ago and has spread to nearly all of Brazil's 27 states. Its red flag flies over hundreds of small rural settlements all over Brazil, pockets of defiance located in the heart of soybean country in the south, lost in the sea of sugar cane in the north-east, or in the midst of miles of cattle grass on the giant ranches in the Amazon basin. Pock ets of family agriculture in a sea of chemically-induced cash crops.

Life in the settlements is hard, but it is still much better than it would be outside for the 600,000 families who live there. Before they joined the MST, most were illiterate rural labourers, poor small farmers, or unemployed shantytown dwellers.

In the settlements, none more than 15 years old, they grow staples such as maize, beans, rice and mandioca (cassava), rear pigs and poultry, and keep milk cows. But they have also set up farm cooperatives to process milk, fruit, flour and other products for sale. They sell to commercial food companies, to farmers' markets, or through their first shop in São Paulo.

Brazil is one of the world's biggest markets for pesticides and chemical fertilizers - Monsanto is building a huge factory there - and most of the settlements still use them, but an increasing number are going over to organic methods, encouraged by the agronomists trained by the MST. Initially, it was a question of cost: they could not afford the pesticides and fertilizers. But increasingly it is because of awareness about the damage caused by the chemicals and the advantages to health and the environment of green farming.

An MST settlement in Baje now produces and markets organic seeds. In São Paulo, MST settlers are planting thousands of saplings produced by a local state forest reserve to counteract the erosion produced by the years of deforestation practised by the ranchers who illegally occupied the land before them.

In the Amazon, where slash and burn agriculture is still the main method of small farmers, the Palmares settlement has begun replanting mahogany and native species such as the jaborandi.

One of the biggest problems remains the government's failure to finance organic farming. Credits are for conventional farming only. MST demands to get funding, for long-term regional fruit production like the Amazon fruits cupuacu or graviola have so far been ignored.

In the south, the MST has organised protests against the GM soya illegally planted by large farmers. The growing environmental awareness of the movement is fostered in the schools found in every settlement. In MST schools, the children are taught with the methods of Paulo Freire, Brazil's internationally-famed educationalist, who was exiled as a subversive by the military regime.

They learn to ask questions. The education process begins in the temporary squatters' camps where families often spend years before winning their plot of land in a settlement. Here the school might be only a rustic shelter thatched with banana leaves and where the children sit on tree trunks.

Many men and women, for whom Brazil's harshly unjust society had no other place than poverty and marginalisation, are now directors of farm or credit cooperatives, managers of meat packing plants, or schoolteachers, because of the MST.

One of them is Jorge Neri, the illiterate son of a maid, now a member of MST's coordinating committee, who has just made a marathon tour of 10 European countries at the invitation of organisations eager to know more about the MST. On the way to meet him in London, I happened to be reading EP Thompson's The Making of the English Working Class, and when we talked I was struck by the similarities between what happened 200 years ago here and what is happening now in Brazil, as Neri described what the MST see as the government's attempt to criminalise them.

"What we're doing is not new - we've been carrying out occupations for 15 years now," he says. "We don't torture, or kill or kidnap. What worries the government is our capacity to organise nationally. They see the MST as a bad example to other social movements because we question government policy, we question the economic model, we propose alternatives. We want society to question the fact that they have no say in government spending, in how their money is spent."

For Neri, it is the government which practises violence, because "they are destroying labour rights, selling off nationalised industries, increasing poverty and unemployment. They want to isolate MST, not because we want land reform, but because it is showing society that it cannot remain quiet, it must react. We've waited 500 years already; we can't wait any longer. What is clear is that this model we have is no use - the country is poorer, there is less education, less health, the people see no future."

The MST, together with other social movements, wants to organise a plebiscite on Brazil's staggering foreign debt, which is now over US$200bn, even though $125bn was repaid between 1995-98 - money that MST says could have gone on education, health and land reform. For Veja, Brazil's mass circulation news magazine, MST uses the pretext of agrarian reform to preach "socialist revolution".

MST has discovered that direct action brings results - three-quarters of today's settlements originated as land occupations - but they are an unarmed movement, unlike the ranchers, hired guns and police who oppose them. The latest MST victim was a middle-aged father of five children, shot dead by police when they intercepted busloads of unarmed protesters near Curitiba in May. Their killers often go unpunished: four years after 19 MST protesters were shot dead in Eldorado do Carajas, 155 policemen accused of their murders still await trial.

Jorge Neri found evidence during his trip to Europe that the Brazilian authorities have also launched a discreet battle to undermine overseas solidarity with the movement. Charities which fund MST activities, including some in the UK, are being warned by their governments that the MST is an organisation that resorts to illegal methods to secure land.

Some MST leaders think MST settlements run as cooperatives could survive by becoming completely self-sufficient, and because they also have their own schools and, sometimes, pharmacies. Others are more pessimistic: they remember that in Brazil peasant movements have a history of being massacred.

Neri is philosophic about the future: "I think we're in for a struggle over a long period. It's not just a fight for land, but for a better form of democracy where people participate, debate, discuss what sort of policies they want. Maybe what we are proposing is an illusion?"

This is MST, the Movement of Landless Rural Workers, Brazil's largest and most dynamic social movement, whose direct action tactics see them hoisting their red flag over farms, ranches, banks and government offices, demanding land, credits, schools, justice and a share of the wealth they help to create. For peasant movements and small farmers round the world who believe that agriculture is not just a question of trade, but a political and social issue, and that food sovereignty is more important than food security, the MST has become a reference point, superseding Cuba as a training ground for militants. Its links with like-minded groups now stretch to the Philippines, Thailand, Korea, China, Mexico, and throughout Asia. It is the most quoted group by political and environmental activists in Europe and America and is at the forefront of forging an ideol ogy for the poor in many countries. Its red flag flies over hundreds of small rural settlements all over Brazil, pockets of defiance located in the heart of soybean country in the south, lost in the sea of sugar cane in the north-east, or in the midst of miles of cattle grass on the giant ranches in the Amazon basin. They sell to commercial food companies, to farmers' markets, or through their first shop in São Paulo. Initially, it was a question of cost: they could not afford the pesticides and fertilizers. fields.headline: Outcome achieved
fields.standfirst: Alcohol Concern wins top spot at Charity Awards 2000
fields.trailText: Alcohol Concern wins top spot at Charity Awards 2000.
fields.body:
Outcome monitoring could be said to have come of age last week when its successful application won the first "charity of the year" award for Alcohol Concern, the leading grantmaker for groups working to counter problem drinking.

The rigid use of outcome monitoring has been regarded with suspicion in much of the voluntary sector. But Alcohol Concern, working with a consultant, came up with a model allowing individual agencies to devise and test outcome measures appropriate to their own user groups and objectives. It also offered advice and training.

The charity's starting point was concern that many agencies seemed unable to demonstrate the effectiveness of their services, either to itself or to statutory funders. Its template, now available outside the alcohol field through A DIY Guide to Implementing Outcome Monitoring, has helped groups clarify their aims and improve their project management.

Alcohol Concern scooped the grantmaking category at Charity Awards 2000, organised by NGO Finance magazine, and was then named overall winner.

Other category winners included disability charity United Response, which topped the disability section for UR in Business - a company it set up to provide jobs for people with learning disabilities. After cutting its teeth at Fulham football club, the company has gone on to win other maintenance contracts at clubs including Manchester City, Leeds and Stockport.

Remaining category winners, each of which receives a £2,500 training bursary funded by the main sponsor of the awards, the Leadership Trust Foundation, were: the West Devon Environmental Network (animals and the environment); the National Trust (arts, culture and heritage); Fair Play Training (children and youth); the Notting Hill Housing Trust (education and training); the Multiple Sclerosis Society (healthcare and medical research); Sense International (international aid and development); Worthing and District Victim Support (research, advice and support); and the Terrence Higgins Trust (social care, welfare and religion).

In the past 18 months, the trust has merged with seven other HIV charities, giving it wider geographical coverage and increasing its size by 50% while reducing duplication of effort. Following the "hard and very radical decisions" of the programme, as the trust puts it, a permanent change management budget has now been put in place.

One further award was made at a presentation dinner at the Savoy in London. Mike Whitlam, one of the best known figures in the voluntary sector, received a lifetime achievement award for his (so far) 26 years' work with charities including offender resettlement group Nacro, Save the Children, the Royal National Institute for Deaf People and the British Red Cross, and for work across the sector in promoting best practice in charity management.

Whitlam, 53, is now chief executive of the Mentor Foundation, a new international charity working to prevent drug abuse among children and young people. It is already involved in 45 countries.

There are plans to make the charity awards an annual event. Although the Guardian runs a well established award scheme for smaller charities in the social welfare field - with nominations for this year closing this week - there has been no general scheme for the voluntary sector as a whole. Paul Winter, chief executive of the Leadership Trust Foundation, says: "The winning entries provide lessons for the wider management community as well as charities."

 A DIY Guide to Implementing Outcome Monitoring is available at £6, post free, from the Information Unit, Alcohol Concern, Waterbridge House, 32-36 Loman Street, London SE1 0EE

webTitle: No run of the mill appointment

fields.headline: No run of the mill appointment
fields.standfirst: Gordon Lishman, the new director general of Age Concern
fields.trailText: Profile: Gordon Lishman, the new director general of Age Concern.
fields.body:
For years, Gordon Lishman's career has been influenced by two powerful women. One is his former boss, whose job as director general of Age Concern England he takes over on Saturday: the newly-ennobled Baroness Sally Greengross. The other is his mother, Florence, the role model for much of his thinking about elderly people.

Neither has dominated him; indeed, Lishman admits he wasn't an ideal deputy for Greengross: "I am in many ways a bad number two; I'm a difficult person to manage." A trait, he says, he gets from his mother: defiantly independent at 80, remaining in her own house, with her dog, but within half a mile of the Lancashire hamlet where her son lives with his family and from which he commutes weekly to Age Concern's London headquarters.

If you weren't in the know, the charity might seem to have made a dull choice for its new leader. Young blood? Certainly not; Lishman's 52. Fresh blood? No way; he's been with the organisation for 27 years. So outsiders, learning of his appointment, might be tempted to mutter: "Buggins' turn."

"Absolutely, absolutely," Lishman accepts, disarmingly. Then why didn't he, a Manchester University graduate with an interest in politics and helping people, move on from the charity which he joined as a field officer? He might have been moving up the organisation's ladder, but he was also locked on to it.

And while London beckoned, he could never afford, "on the salary they were paying", to move further south than Northampton, where he was stuck for several years. It was the late 1970s: his second marriage had broken up, he was a single dad bringing up two young children; coping with his duties as a Liberal on the local county council; and shuttling between scores of Age Concern branches - each with autonomy over local staff, services and funds.

Just when he thought he couldn't run both sides of his life any longer, along came a solution: the charity agreed he should return to Lancashire, where he had relatives who would help with his childcare needs.

It was an ideal arrangement. Back in the mill village where he had grown up, he bought a large terrace house and formed an extended family with his sister and her husband. "We were, for a time, a three-parent, five-children family. By the time I remarried in 1998, with a new stepdaughter, it really wasn't right to uproot everybody and move down to London."

Which brings us back to those two women. Greengross, director general since 1987, was an understanding boss who agreed that Lishman could continue to operate from Lancashire. And living close to his widowed mother - his father had been a rural GP - constantly reminded him of the timeless strengths of settled communities.

There's a good Lancashire phrase, he says. "Stop at home." As he applies it to older people, it's not just about enabling the frail to remain in their familiar, domestic surroundings. It's also about encouraging people to make clear what help and services they specifically need, and for councils and charities to provide them - not to impose others.

"Where I come from, and where I live, that's about being able to take down your net curtains so you can wash them, and give an image to the outer world. In my village, it's about putting Cardinal Red [polish] on the front step."

Homely stuff, but don't write off Lishman just because he doesn't sound like a social policy guru. He knows that, to adapt Philip Larkin's line, some mill-town families are still cobble-close. It's first-hand social observation, sound enough to build policy on.

Yet Lishman knows how to cite the right academic sources: a Maudsley hospital study, say, of depressed, homebound elderly people. "Even one afternoon a fortnight of ordinary, basic, social contact - daycare at a not highly-organised level - helps them greatly. And the longest depressed benefited the most."

But if anything, Age Concern stands accused of having too many policies; it's in danger, critics argue, of sinking under them. Lishman says he'll try to bring more focus. He can match any politician's rhetoric (he's a four-times-failed parliamentary candidate): about pensioner poverty; empowering the elderly; transport; reminding party bosses of the latent power of the grey vote. Sober-suited and stocky, he could easily pass as a Westminster mover and shaker.

But the best aspect of Age Concern England's new boss is the sound common sense veined through his Lancastrian roots, of his belief in self-caring communities. He'll be back in his hamlet, Lane Bottom, again at the weekend. Briefcase full of position papers by staff in one hand, and a holdall with the week's dirty washing in the other.

webTitle: RD Laing: The rise and fall of a radical psychiatrist

fields.headline: RD Laing: The rise and fall of a radical psychiatrist
fields.trailText: Childhood Born in 1927 in Glasgow of Presbyterian parents. His mother regularly burnt his toys while his father and grandfather engaged in what biographer Daniel Burston called "brutal scenes in the parlour". By age 15, Laing was reading Voltaire, Marx, Nietzsche and Freud.
fields.body:
Childhood Born in 1927 in Glasgow of Presbyterian parents. His mother regularly burnt his toys while his father and grandfather engaged in what biographer Daniel Burston called "brutal scenes in the parlour". By age 15, Laing was reading Voltaire, Marx, Nietzsche and Freud.

Career After medical school and the army, he trained as a psychiatrist and joined the Tavistock Clinic in north London, where he trained as a psychoanalyst.

Books The Divided Self, published in 1960, was the first of several best-sellers, including Sanity, Madness and the Family, Knots and The Bird of Paradise (his biggest commercial success, about his experience of LSD).

Clinics Having set up in private practice in Wimpole Street in 1960, at the same time as starting to experiment with drugs, he became clinical director of the Langham Clinic in 1962. In 1965, he opened the Kingsley Hall project, an experimental non-hierarchical community. This was far more anarchic than his previous enterprises - he took LSD regularly with patients. A psychotherapy student remembers him as "drunk by lunchtime, staggeringly rude but still amazingly charismatic".

High point In 1964, he regularly appeared on television, published two books, numerous articles and became famous on both sides of the Atlantic.

Love He had three children by his first wife, Anne Hearne, two by his second, Jutta Werner, and at least one child with one of his students. He co-wrote RD Laing & Me with Roberta Russell, an American chat show host, one of his many lovers.

Downward spiral By the end of the 1960s, his career was in decline: he was depressed and alcoholic. In 1987, he was forced to resign from the medical register after complaints that he had been "intoxicated and unprofessional on two occasions". He died playing tennis in St Tropez with, as Burston put it, "no profession, no fixed address or funds".

fields.headline: It's good to talk
fields.standfirst: Cognitive therapy works. So why aren't people with schizophrenia getting it?  Jane Feinmann  reports
fields.trailText: Cognitive therapy works. So why aren't people with schizophrenia getting it? Jane Feinmann reports
fields.body:
Tasha Diffey was hospitalised four years ago after a diagnosis of schizophrenia. She still suffers delusions and is on anti-psychotic medication, though she has since been diagnosed manic depressive, a label she prefers. Now living with her boyfriend and rediscovering her gift as a musician, she's on the mend at last, a development she ascribes to the cognitive behavioural therapy she has received over the past 18 months. It's kept her alive, she says, and helped her return to emotional health.

"Drugs don't work on their own," insists 25-year-old Diffey. "A severe mental illness means you bottle everything up and though you need anti-psychotic drugs, they numb your brain. You need space to open up, to explore and grow. And probably the best way to do that is through cognitive therapy, which is like having a very supportive friend help with problem solving at every stage of your life."

Tasha's assessment of the value of cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is borne out by recent research. One-to-one CBT has been shown to reduce the severity of symptoms including hearing voices, hallucinations, delusions and other thought disorders. It also cuts the relapse rate impressively - by up to 80% when families are involved. At least one European country, Finland, now routinely provides state-funded individual and family therapy for anyone with a severe mental illness.

Yet in Britain, only two out of every 100 people with schizophrenia get the therapy, according to a report published tomorrow by the British Psychological Society. And political correctness is at least partly blamed for the situation - the bête noire being one of the most charismatic and controversial psychiatrists of the 20th century whose legacy, many believe, continues adversely to skew service provision.

It's 40 years since the publication of RD Laing's book, The Divided Self, which launched the anti-psychiatry movement of the 1960s. Laing's startling vision was that of psychosis being rooted in experiences with others, most frequently in a family where relationship boundaries were blurred and messages confusing and contradictory. Falling ill was the first step towards recovery or, rather, a self-cure that acknowledged the "mad" person as an active agent in the creation and perpetuation of his or her own misery. Treatment, he said, should never be electro-convulsive therapy (ECT) or incarceration in a mental hospital, nor should it be drugs - at least of the prescription variety.

Hailed as a guru of the sixties generation, Laing's message soon became brutally simplified to the callous phrase: families cause schizophrenia.

"After all these years, we still hear of parents being asked by their GP if they argue a lot or when they last had sex - at a time when they're seeking help, trying to cope with the fact that their child has been diagnosed with schizophrenia," says Marjorie Wallace, director of the schizophrenia charity Sane, set up 15 years ago at least partly to defend beleaguered relatives. "They have this double burden of suddenly finding that someone they love has become strange and hostile, and then they're told it's all their fault."

By the early 1990s, the influence of Sane and the promise of pharmaceutical therapies meant that Laing was widely seen as an irrelevance. Schizophrenia, said distinguished American psychotherapist Michael Robbins in 1993, "is now generally believed to be an organic disease like diabetes or cancer and the psychotherapeutic models are looked on as relics of antiquity, even of the age of magic and witchcraft".

A few years on, however, the growing mound of evidence has brought at least a reluctant acknowledgement from most psychiatrists that family relationships, as well as genetics, play a role in schizophrenia. As media personality Raj Persaud, consultant psychiatrist at the Maudsley hospital, south London, puts it: "Schizophrenia is largely genetic - you have to have genetic predisposition in order to develop it. But if you grow up in a supportive family, it's entirely possible that events that precipitate the onset of schizophrenia may not occur."

"The truth," says Peter Kinderman, an academic clinical psychologist and one of the authors of tomorrow's report, Recent Advances in Understanding Mental Illness and Psychotic Experiences, "is that genetic and biochemical research has hardly moved in the last 10 years, whereas there's growing evidence of the benefits of a psychological approach".

Whether or not difficult family relationships cause schizophrenia in some instances will never be known, he says. "But what seems certain is that the family's attitude has a major impact on the recovery of a person with psychotic experiences. On the one hand, people may become critical or actively hostile to someone whose psychotic experiences are possibly embarrassing or disruptive. Or families may become emotionally over-involved, treating the ill person as if they were a child. Both attitudes are known to increase the risk of relapse."

Kinderman, reader in clinical psychology at Liverpool university, says most relatives have stopped worrying about whether they are being blamed for their loved one's schizophrenia, all they want is to get the best possible treatment. "In my experience, parents want their children with schizophrenia to receive cognitive behavioural therapy, and usually they'll say: 'Are there any ways in which we were responsible and if so, what can we do about it?'"

More surprisingly, Sane is now also campaigning for more family counselling. "I've actually watched how families can cause a relapse because they know or fear that person is becoming ill and they get desperate and panic, and that's a recipe for disaster," says Wallace.

So is it political correctness on the part of funding authorities that is preventing this proven, and apparently vital, service from becoming widely available? The real reason, argues Persaud, is that psychologists - just like Laing - don't really want to get involved. "RD Laing chose not to become a consultant psychiatrist, seeing people with schizophrenia every day as I do. Instead, he set up in private practice in Wimpole Street, where there isn't a great deal of schizophrenia. It is a very difficult condition to treat and lots of psychologists today prefer to work with less challenging, middle-class angst rather than taking responsibility for unpredictable patients."

Of the 2,000 clinical psychologists currently working in this country, Kinderman admits only a fraction are working in the field of schizophrenia. "That number won't increase until psychiatry, as well as psychology, acknowledges the role of talking therapies in treating mental illness," he says. "The training required is considerable and the NHS needs to acknowledge what research has already proven."

She still suffers delusions and is on anti-psychotic medication, though she has since been diagnosed manic depressive, a label she prefers. Now living with her boyfriend and rediscovering her gift as a musician, she's on the mend at last, a development she ascribes to the cognitive behavioural therapy she has received over the past 18 months. It's kept her alive, she says, and helped her return to emotional health. "Drugs don't work on their own," insists 25-year-old Diffey. "A severe mental illness means you bottle everything up and though you need anti-psychotic drugs, they numb your brain. You need space to open up, to explore and grow. And probably the best way to do that is through cognitive therapy, which is like having a very supportive friend help with problem solving at every stage of your life." Tasha's assessment of the value of cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is borne out by recent research. One-to-one CBT has been shown to reduce the severity of symptoms including hearing voices, hallucinations, delusions and other thought disorders. It also cuts the relapse rate impressively - by up to 80% when families are involved. At least one European country, Finland, now routinely provides state-funded individual and family therapy for anyone with a severe mental illness. Agents of change

An estate agent in Bath is offering to donate £100 to a homelessness charity from each property sold.
Western Daily Press, 5.6.00 (Francis Harvey, Exeter)

Sworn to silence
Members of a rock band have complained that a Christian company that supplied the PA system for a carnival in Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffs, turned down the sound when they were playing because some of their songs contained bad language.
The Sentinel, 1.6.00 (D Cameron, Stoke-on-Trent)

Delivery sweet
Midwives at a maternity hospital in Glasgow discovered a nest containing eight ducklings outside the delivery suite.

Daily Record, 12.6.00 (Janet Nixon, Edinburgh)

High Court
A judge ordered an Ipswich court room to be cleared because of the fumes from a £1m haul of cannabis presented in evidence.
News North West, 14.6.00 (Jon Booth, Stockport)

Deeply fashionable
Pairs of 600-year-old woollen underpants similar in style to modern boxer shorts, were discovered during an archaeological dig at a friary in Hull.

News North West, 13.6.00 (Gillian Oakes, Cheadle)

Hungry for love
Staff at a marine zoo in Anglesey, north Wales, are looking for a new mate for a female red bellied piranha after she ate her male partner.
Western Mail, 2.6.00 (Anne Cowper, Swansea)

Skirting the rules

The Suffolk bowls federation has ruled that a club from Hoxne should forfeit a victory because one of its women players was wearing trousers rather than the regulation grey skirt.

Eastern Daily Press, 14.6.00 (Michael Smith, Swaffham)

No, by George

The landlord of a club claims that a brewery has blocked his plan to change the name from The Scotsman to The St George because it would offend non-English customers.

East Anglian Daily Times, 26.5.00 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Walking carefully
The owners of a collie dog have had wellingtons made for it when they take it for walks near their home in Holmfirth, West Yorkshire, because it is allergic to grass.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 9.6.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Del buoyant
An obsessions with the TV comedy Only Fools and Horses has led a Shrewsbury man to change his name to Derek Trotter and to buy a Reliant three-wheeler to drive himself to his wedding.

Shropshire Star, 5.6.00 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Political move
A local councillor in Camden, London, has had to resign his seat because he can no longer afford to live in the borough.

Camden Chronicle, 25.5.00 (D Barrett, London N4)

Inside knowledge
A persistent offender with more than 70 previous convictions was allowed to go free by a court in Aberdeen so that he could continue his college studies in criminology.
Glasgow Herald 1.6.00 (S O'Tierney, Paisley)

Playing in Europe
Members of a football team in Gateshead were taken by the landlord on a seven-day holiday to Ibiza as a reward for winning a cup competition in their first season.
Newcastle Chronicle, 9.6.00 (Carine Jensen, Middlesbrough)

Wet excuse
Repair work on an all-weather football pitch in Lincoln damaged by vandals has been delayed because of bad weather.

fields.headline: First things first
fields.standfirst:
More cash is good news
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The national plan is promising to be radical and far-reaching in its aim of improving the NHS. But we may be about to discover that the hazards of having too much money can be as great as having too little.
fields.body:
The national plan is promising to be radical and far-reaching in its aim of improving the NHS. But we may be about to discover that the hazards of having too much money can be as great as having too little. With increased funding will come increased expectations. And although, rationally, even the most anti-NHS commentators know it takes time to achieve major change in such a large organisation, it may not be long before impatience and cynicism set in.

The NHS has suffered historically from major under-investment in buildings and modern equipment. Half of all NHS hospital beds are in buildings built before the first world war and a significant amount of patient care is still delivered in temporary huts erected during the second world war. Many post-1945 buildings are proving no better than those built by the Poor Law guardians. The NHS now has a maintenance liability backlog of almost £3bn.

Clinical staff report enormous frustration with out-of-date equipment and inability to access modern diagnostic services. And relatively simple changes in the pattern of service that would reduce waiting, or improve services to patients, are not possible because the upfront investment cannot be made. All this reflects a long history of cost cutting and the use of all available money to keep existing services to patients going.

So before large amounts of new money are spent on new services, the NHS needs to put right some of these basics. Hospital rebuilding would be premature - there are a number of important questions about the future role of hospitals that need answering first. Replacing old equipment, though, would be a real boon to patients and staff.

Meanwhile, expansion of NHS Direct, improving the information and choice given to patients, developing electronic records and enhancing communication among hospitals, GPs and patients will all require enormous investment in information technology. And the almost 900,000 NHS staff also need investment to create a more skilled and flexible workforce able to work across the old professional hierarchies.

The chancellor of the exchequer's watchword has been prudence; this, too, needs to be the approach to extra spending in the NHS. The advantage will be that NHS staff and patients will see immediate investment in things that make a tangible difference to how they are treated.

 Stephen Thornton is chief executive of the NHS Confederation.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText:
Web of intrigue
The Cabinet Office has a lovely website advertising all the benefits which are supposed to follow from GM food and crops. The site's address is www.gm-info.gov.uk. Do not, under any circumstances, confuse this with www.gm-info.org.uk. This upstart, launched on Monday, comes courtesy of Oxford campaigners Corporate Watch, who have uploaded a gigantic database detailing just about every GM test site, corporate head office, university research station, PR company, animal feed mill and seed company in the country. The cheek.
fields.body:
Web of intrigue
The Cabinet Office has a lovely website advertising all the benefits which are supposed to follow from GM food and crops. The site's address is www.gm-info.gov.uk. Do not, under any circumstances, confuse this with www.gm-info.org.uk. This upstart, launched on Monday, comes courtesy of Oxford campaigners Corporate Watch, who have uploaded a gigantic database detailing just about every GM test site, corporate head office, university research station, PR company, animal feed mill and seed company in the country. The cheek.

Do what I say...
Clearly non-governmental groups such as Corporate Watch are out of control, have no legitimacy and should be regulated. How much better it would be, argues UK government-sponsored think tank, the Foreign Policy Centre (president Robin Cook), if all NGOs had to sign up to a proper code of conduct and were made to undertake a programme of self-regulation. Then, says report author Michael Edwards, NGOs who agree to minimum standards of accountability should be rewarded with a place at the negotiating table at IMF and other international conferences. Perhaps the principle could be extended to those bodies who already sit at the tables of power?

Helping themselves

Eco soundings notes that the US, which consistently argues that other countries should not subsidise their exports, has decided to increase direct support to its farmers to more than $15bn a year - a 700% increase since 1996, according to distraught EU agriculture commissioner Franz Fishler. Ah, says the US, but the subsidies mean that America can "help" countries in crisis. More than half the $7.5m given by the US as relief for victims of last October's Orissa cyclone, for instance, was in the form of food aid. Er, the only trouble is that much of this was GM food - which has outraged Indian activists even further.

Damage limitation
Good to see HM police arresting Greenpeace volunteers for causing "criminal damage" on the MV Enif, a ship carrying 1,700 tons of timber from the Amazon. How dare they try to rename the ship "Amazon Crime"? How outrageous that they should occupy the crane of the Enif for more than 72 hours. The police's first duty must be to arrest the protesters and not investigate the people who might or might not be importing 1,700 tons of illegally-felled timber.

fields.headline: Changing gear
fields.standfirst: Is an ambulance always a suitable response to an emergency call?  Alan Kennedy looks at tailoring services to needs
fields.trailText: Is an ambulance always a suitable response to an emergency call? Alan Kennedy looks at tailoring services to needs.
fields.body:
Our ambulance services are trusted by the public; when people need an ambulance, they know it will come. But this will not be enough; we are rapidly moving into a climate where the public expects and demands more. The future lies in more integrated working with the rest of the NHS.

My service in Surrey is working on a joint response to the 12% annual rise in emergency demand that we face. With help from our NHS partners, we can and will make a real difference.

Consider the target of getting a paramedic to arrive within eight minutes for seriously ill patients. By responding to 90% of calls within eight minutes throughout the country, we would save 3,200 more lives. And half of those would be people younger than 70.

Priority-based dispatch was introduced throughout the NHS last year, enabling us to get to seriously ill patients more quickly. In addition, we can respond more appropriately to non-life-threatening cases. In future, we will be working more closely with social care partners and with callers to let them know what services we can provide for them.

In Surrey, we are building a "bridge of care" which will provide prompt and convenient access to emergency and non-emergency care - whether at home or in the community - 24 hours a day, through a whole systems approach supported by technology. But this will be possible only if we introduce new ways of working in and across health and social care.

To take one example, telephone access points to the NHS will be "joined up" so that 999 callers who need nurse advice will get it, rather than being sent an ambulance to move them from home to hospital. Such connectivity with the NHS Direct service will become more fluent as ambulance call handlers work closer with NHS Direct call handlers.

It is easy to foresee this kind of service integration, but far less easy to identify who and how many organisations will be employing the call handlers. But is this really important?

Boundaries between secondary and ambulance care will also blur. Currently, my organisation co-ordinates management of available emergency capacity in the local area, so that "out of hospital" services, such as ambulance crews and GPs, know - at the time they need to - when and where patients will receive the services they need.

This sort of service will grow. It is beginning to happen with NHS Direct booking patient appointments, and it will not be long before ambulance staff will be able to book district nurse visits for 999 callers, or arrange social care input. It even might not be long before district nurses and other community staff benefit from the logistics capability of ambulance services.

With the joining up of service provision, there will be freer flows of NHS skills. Rather than seeing triage nurses in casualty as being different from ambulance paramedics who also triage patients out of hospital, I expect to see "practitioners in emergency care" operating in and out of hospital.

Such a move would help health services retain capable staff, some of which leave as a result of frustration with limited workplace opportuni ties. And it might even help tackle the crisis in nursing recruitment, which is particularly serious in my part of the world.

When people call for help in future, an appropriate response will not always mean using an ambulance crew and transport to hospital. Ambulance services want the public to have easy access to a gateway to the right care, where there is greater connectivity between ambulance control rooms and NHS Direct; closer collaboration between ambulance dispatchers and emergency care bed managers; closer links with primary care "in hours" as well as out of hours; and closer links with community health and social care staff.

We know it does not always make sense for ambulances to transport patients to the nearest casualty department. In future, when they do transport patients, it will be to the most appropriate facility. This calls for greater integration of care provision and close collaboration with other emergency services.

The ultimate challenge facing ambulance services is to eliminate unacceptable variations in performance. The public must know that, wherever they are, they will receive high quality service based on common clinical practices and standards.

So while striving for the local integration required for more joined up delivery of care, we have to balance that with a drive for greater national consistency.

 Alan Kennedy is chief executive of Surrey Ambulance NHS trust. This is taken from NHS Frontline - Visions for 2010, available at £10 from The New Health Network, 42 Southwark Street, London SE1 1UN.
