fields.trailText: One woman's efforts have made a difference to an estate.
fields.body:
When she took off her dancing shoes after a decade with a troupe she formed to tour US military bases on the continent, Amanda Seivewright returned to the estate in South Shields where she grew up - and kicked her heels in frustration.

Not for long. There was no safe place for her young daughter to play on Cleadon Park - a green and spacious estate when it was built for ex-servicemen after the first world war, but now depressingly bleak and hemmed in by busy roads.

Seivewright, a feisty lone mum, was soon bombarding officials with requests for an empty property that could be turned into a community house for 650 or so families in her neighbourhood. Persistence paid: now the three-bedroom house that has been provided has become the home for what might be the biggest extended family on Tyneside.

For a start, a 60-strong core of children between five and 12 years old throng there for after-school and holiday programmes. There's a playroom, a creche, a safe play area, and enough activities to exhaust the energies (and mischief) of the most hyper of hyperactive kids.

Hoax calls to bring fire engines speeding on to the estate used to be the local idea of fun. Seivewright managed to stop that by getting the fire service involved in another way: helping with the boys' and girls' football teams she started.

The police are still frequent visitors on official business, though now it's often to show the youngsters how to computer-code their bikes, making it less likely that they will be pinched.

Until a couple of years ago, Seivewright never saw herself as an organiser, still less an activist. "It started because I couldn't let my daughter play out because the estate was used by joyriders," she says. "I had to do something."

That something has included undergoing training in a field she entered armed with common sense, rather than certificates.

As a winner of an award financed by the millennium commission, she went on the first residential course run by Groundwork, the network which backs local environmental regeneration projects and helps to train volunteer workers to run them.

This week she's on a second Groundwork course - learning how to be a mentor so that she can, in turn, pass on her skills. And tonight, she'll be at a Westminster reception, explaining to MPs, policymakers and business leaders how the organisation delivers - using the mantra "changing places, changing lives".

fields.headline: America's lost revolution
fields.trailText: Earlier this week I mentioned to a social scientist colleague that I was greatly looking forward to a discussion I'd be having with the distinguished American political scientist, Seymour Martin Lipset.
fields.body:
Earlier this week I mentioned to a social scientist colleague that I was greatly looking forward to a discussion I'd be having with the distinguished American political scientist, Seymour Martin Lipset.

We would, I explained, be talking about Lipset's latest book (written with Gary Marks), It Didn't Happen Here: Why Socialism Failed In The United States, which took as its starting point the observation that "parties calling themselves socialist, social democratic, labour or communist have been major forces in every democratic country in the world with the exception of the United States".

My friend seemed unimpressed, so I tried to arouse his enthusiasm with more detail from Lipset's book. Many commentators, I pointed out, had once regarded the US as an ideal site for the development of socialism.

In 1904, the British Marxist, HM Hyndman, noted that "just as north America is today the most advanced country economically and socially, so it will be the first in which socialism will find open and legal expression".

American Marxists were equally confident. In 1906, the leader of the American Socialist Labor party, Daniel De Leon, told the Industrial Workers of the World convention: "If my reading of history is correct, the prophecy of Marx will be fulfilled and America will ring the downfall of capitalism the world over."

Between 1900 and 1940, America was far more consumed by strikes and industrial action than Britain. Trade unions were well organised and an additional impetus was provided by the arrival of a multitude of European immigrants who had already embraced the idea of socialism as a solution to the world's social and economic ills.

I was moving on to Lipset and Marks's subtle use of de Tocqueville's notion of American "exceptionalism" to explain why these and other factors had not led to the formation of a socialist party in the US, when my colleague interrupted. It wasn't, he explained, that he was uninterested in the argument, only that he wondered why we needed to devote time to considering why socialism had failed in the US when we were now confronted with its virtual disappearance in nearly every other democratic country.

I was ready for him. "That's precisely what makes the book so interesting. As Lipset and Marks list the structural and cultural conditions that made socialism impossible in the US, you suddenly realise that exactly those conditions are now in place in Britain. It's not merely an argument about why socialism failed in the US but also a powerful account of the reasons why it may never again happen here."

 Laurie Taylor talks to Seymour Martin Lipset and Richard Sennett about the failure of socialism in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: A health check
fields.standfirst:
How much more NHS reform can health professionals bear before morale reaches an all-time low? Not much, says John Carvel
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: How much more NHS reform can health professionals bear before morale reaches an all-time low? Not much, says John Carvel.
fields.body:
It's hard to know whether to laugh or cry. In a list of key "barriers to change" in the health service, produced by Alan Milburn's modernisation action teams, one observation is incontrovertible and - in this context - full of irony. "Staff feel overwhelmed by the number of new initiatives," warns the draft report of the team working out how to improve patients' speed of access to healthcare.

How true. After years of permanent revolution in the structure of the service, this reaction is not surprising. But when the professionals get to grips with the national plan for health, to be published towards the end of next month, they will realise that, as far as changes in working practices are concerned, they ain't seen nothing yet.

Health managers and non-executives, assembling today for the NHS Confederation's annual conference in Glasgow, are aware of the scale of impending reform - but not yet the detail. Chancellor Gordon Brown's budget speech in March promised that NHS spending would increase by more than 6% a year in real terms over the next four years -double the historic trend. In return, the prime minister demanded modernisation. Health service leaders, initially overwhelmed by the scale of resourcing, said they would do their best to oblige.

Since then, the NHS ideas factory has been working at full stretch. To energise the process in England, Milburn appointed six action teams to think through different aspects of the modernisation programme.

From the teams' confidential draft reports, written a fortnight ago, it is possible to work out many of the key features of the eventual reform package.

To achieve a phased programme of sharply reduced waiting times and improved service for patient, for example, the government wants a complete overhaul of traditional clinical boundaries.

As the action team on reforming the professions puts it: "Many patients experience delays because of unnecessarily rigid rules about which health professionals can assess patients, make decisions about their further care, or about discharge."

New protocols are envisaged to extend the responsibilities of nurses, midwives, therapists, scientists and support staff. Consultants will be expected to agree job plans, monitored by their trusts and linked to the delivery of targets. This will amount to "a major change of culture in the NHS".

The quality of the leaked draft reports looks patchy. They differ in format and style. Some seem to be engaging in blue-sky thinking, while others try to be extraordinarily precise about short-term targets with out mentioning the costs. Greater consistency will be engineered over the next few days as the teams finalise their reports before a meeting with ministers next Wednesday.

Issues that remain to be resolved include performance incentives. The action teams are distinctly cautious about linking pay to results, arguing that any scheme would have to be carefully piloted to eliminate perverse effects. Health staff are unlikely to be landed with anything like the performance-related pay being introduced for teachers. Ministers are still keen, however, on offering team bonuses to reward the groups who work the hardest.

Parallel work in the devolved health services in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will be discussed in a joint ministerial group before the national plan for England is published, probably in the last week of July.

The plan will not be a compendium of action team conclusions. It will be ministers' own work. But from their speeches and from assorted leaks, the direction is clear -and so are some of the problems.

Stephen Thornton, the confederation's chief executive, is enthusiastic about the government's commitment to reform. "At the start none of us realised how radical this exercise was going to be," he says. "The teams have come to realise we cannot find answers by tinkering around the edge. We need really radical change in the way doctors are trained, managed, judged, hired and fired."

How resistant will the NHS be to this intensification of change? The problem for ministers is how to persuade the professionals that the status quo is not an option, without making the public even more discontented with the service they are receiving. For example, the action team on reforming the profession says the care patients receive is often characterised by waiting, lack of information, poor communication skills on the part of frontline staff, lack of continuity in care, poor environment and inadequate standards of personal care, including food and other facilities.

Change may be essential, but it will take time to introduce new systems and train extra staff. If the government tries to mobilise reform by trumpeting too loudly the deficiencies of the present system, it runs two risks.

The first is a collapse in professional morale. The second is the likelihood that everything ministers say now to criticise the service will be thrown back at them at the next general election. Inevitably, however good these reforms may be, the pain of implementation will come before patients and voters are likely to notice the benefits.

webTitle: A gentlemen's agreement for the prince

fields.headline: A gentlemen's agreement for the prince
fields.standfirst: Media correspondent Matt Wells explains how Lord Wakeham's new guidelines on the coverage of Prince William came about
fields.trailText:
Wednesday, 3.45pm: Media correspondent Matt Wells explains how Lord Wakeham's new guidelines on the coverage of Prince William came about.
Special report
fields.body:
For the past five years Prince William has enjoyed shelter from the unrelenting gaze of the red-tops by a rather old-fashioned gentlemen's agreement; Fleet Street editors would not print the sort of intrusive pictures and stories that plagued his mother and in return the Palace would provide suitable access to the young prince's life.

But as he turns 18 and prepares to go to university, the terms of the accord are up for negotiation. Today, the chairman of the press complaints commission, Lord Wakeham, has set out a blueprint for the next period of the prince's accession to adulthood.

There will be intense press and public interest in the handsome young prince's love life. Wakeham declares himself a realist, and acknowledges that the prince will not be able to count on the same degree of privacy as before. But he urges restraint upon editors: "Endless intrusion of the sort we have not seen for five years and the constant, powerful headlamps of unwarranted publicity would make his life a misery, make his friends' lives a misery and make it much more difficult for him to forge proper and meaningful relationships."

Out shopping in Covent Garden (or more likely Princes Street in Edinburgh, given the expected location of his studies), drinking outside a pub, or playing polo on a sports pitch, he will be fair game. But there should be no "snatched" pictures in locations where there was a reasonable expectation of privacy, such as in a restaurant or in private gardens, says Wakeham.

It is likely that editors will continue to observe the commission's exhortations. Relations with St James' Palace are improving: not least because of the close contact with the press complaints commission. It can be no bad thing that Mark Bolland, the Prince of Wales' assistant private secretary who has been responsible for the turnaround in press perception of the heir to the throne, was the commission's former director and was replaced by his friend Guy Black, a highly respected figure among editors.

The palace will continue the successful policy of making available pictures of Prince William at key stages in his life. Lessons have been learned over the copyright fiasco that dogged the release of pictures marking the prince's 18th birthday recently, and such problems are not likely to resurface.

webTitle: Wakeham urges press restraint on prince

fields.headline: Wakeham urges press restraint on prince
fields.standfirst:
'Endless intrusion' could make William's life 'a misery'
The press complaints commission
The British monarchy
fields.trailText: Newspaper watchdog Lord Wakeham today called for continued restraint in coverage of Prince William after he leaves school.
fields.body:
Newspaper watchdog Lord Wakeham today called for continued restraint in coverage of Prince William after he leaves school.

Setting out new guidelines for editors, the chairman of the press complaints commission (PCC) said the 18-year-old prince was entitled to privacy in the same way as any other public figure.

On the potentially difficult issue of stories and pictures about William's future girlfriends, he warned editors that endless intrusion would make the prince's life a misery.

"Before anyone suggests otherwise, I am a realist," said Lord Wakeham. "I do not believe it possible or desirable to prohibit newspapers entirely from speculation and reports about young ladies that might eventually become a more permanent feature of his life.

"But I would say this: endless intrusion of the sort we have not seen for five years and the constant, powerful headlamps of unwarranted publicity would make his life a misery, make his friends' lives a misery and make it much more difficult for him to forge proper and meaningful relationships.

"So newspapers must continue to exercise restraint - as they have done in the past. They must continue to check their facts. And they must continue to think about the impact on Prince William of either inaccurate or intrusive stories on this particular subject."

In a speech delivered on Fleet Street, the former home of the national newspaper industry, Lord Wakeham called for continued cooperation between papers and St James's Palace as the Prince enters adulthood.

William, who turned 18 last Wednesday, leaves Eton tomorrow at the end of his school career and after his A-level exams. He hopes to take a year out from full-time education before studying history of art at university.

Until now, William has been protected from the full glare of the media spotlight as a minor at school.

Under the newspaper industry's code of practice, William's privacy was protected in the same way as that of every other child.

But it was accepted by the palace that there was a legitimate public interest in William as second in line to the throne.

In return for media cooperation, the palace promised to make photographs and information about the teenage prince available at milestones during his childhood.

With one or two exceptions, the strategy has been deemed a success by William's father, the Prince of Wales.

William must absolutely not be "fair game" but, at the same time, "things will change", said Lord Wakeham.

"He has left school, he is growing up and has become a young adult, he is increasingly becoming a public figure - and the way the press covers him will reflect that."

From tomorrow, William could expect to be photographed, like any other young adult, in public places - playing polo, shopping in Oxford Street or sitting outside a pub.

"That is likely to mean that newspaper readers are going to be seeing somewhat more of him in the future," said Lord Wakeham.

But there should be no snatched pictures of William in a private place or place where there was a reasonable expectation of privacy, including private gardens and restaurants.

Under the code of practice, these were off-limits to journalists except on "rare occasions" when there may be a "public interest" in publication.

Lord Wakeham warned: "The ability of all young people to go about their normal lives without physical intimidation is hugely important.

"The absence of paparazzi at Eton during these last five years had been a significant success - and a tribute to all editors who have made clear to photographers that there is no market for intrusive pictures.

"Prince William's 18th birthday is not an invitation for them to return.

"The PCC will come down hard on the publication of any picture of Prince William that has been obtained through intimidation or persistent pursuit - just as we would for any other individual."

Lord Wakeham said William should simply be allowed a private life and freedom from harassment in the same way as any other public figure.

"That is something that will be made much easier - I have no doubt - if there is continuing cooperation between the press and St James's Palace to ensure both that the public sees and reads about Prince William's progress to and through university, and that what is written about him is accurate," he said.

"Following my intensive discussions with them, I can confirm that the palace fully understands that point - and has made clear that, during his gap year and then during his time at university, regular facilities for the media will be made available to record his progress and continuing education.

"That way, I am confident that - even though times are changing - the successful balance we have achieved over the last five years can be maintained during the time in which Prince William completes his education."

Lord Wakeham told the Today programme that each case would have to be judged on its own. Asked whether the protection of the prince's privacy would include occasions when he might be seen with women in semi-public areas such as nightclubs, Lord Wakeham said: "Editors have not been too bad so far. They use their judgment. They want their code to work and so do we."

However, he said there had been some lapses over Prince William's schooldays: "We have had stories of him having girlfriends when he has never met the girls.

"It is ridiculous. Newspapers who do that should check up on their facts. Most of them do take the trouble to get it right. I am emphasising to them that the code requires them to do their best to get it right."

David Yelland, editor of The Sun, said: "The Sun took the commercial risk in being the first newspaper to publicly say we will not invade William's privacy. We did so in 1998 and again two weeks ago.

"Lord Wakeham's statement gives us credit for that - for which I'm very grateful. Lord Wakeham has been a great civilising force on the newspaper industry and therefore on the country.

"The old era of gross invasion of privacy has gone and I will play no part in bringing it back."

fields.headline: Myths and madness: on the road with the Beats
fields.standfirst: In this exclusive online essay taken from the current edition of the London Review  of Books Tom Clark recalls the reality behind the  Beat legend
fields.trailText: Tom Clark recalls the reality behind the Beat legend
fields.body:
This Is the Beat Generation: New York, San Francisco, Paris by James Campbell.
Vintage, 320 pp., £7.99, 4 May, 0 099 28269 0
Buy it at BOL

When Allen Ginsberg's Beat vision-quest came through England in the spring of 1965, I was appointed by this famous renegade minstrel to set down his legend for the Paris Review.

Ginsberg's last words in our interview came in response to an inquiry about the role of command in the compositional process. Sometimes when he was at work on his poems, he declared radiantly, he was overcome by "a sense of being self-prophetic master of the universe."

That empowering sense, a feeling that he had a special mission, "an immediate Messianic thing" involving "movements of history and breaking down the civilisation," had originated nearly two decades earlier, Ginsberg confided, in an auditory hallucination of William Blake intoning 'Ah, Sunflower' to him "like God had a human voice'." James Campbell, who introduces a note of irony into his reworking of twice-told Beat tales, refers to Ginsberg's historic undergraduate illumination as "hand-held" - perhaps an allusion to a key detail in what he had said to me: the fact that an act of masturbation had triggered Blake's phantasmal arrival in his East Harlem tenement flat. This account of the revelatory plunge into Godhead ("the ceremony of his election"), often cited over the years as Beat Scripture, is quoted at length again here, ending with the poet's optimistic verdict as to its meaning for his future life: "The spirit of the universe was what I was born to realise."

Campbell's tour of Beat legend begins with his subjects' youthful exploration of criminal behaviour and moves on through many picaresque adventures, battles with psychic monsters, tiltings against windmills (normality is most often the enemy), pointless side-trips into illusory discoveries and confused rhizomatic intertanglings of relation and motive. He also shows how Ginsberg's quest led him back to the original Blakean delusion of grandeur. Throughout this underground romance, that first infusion of 'divine inspiration' remains for Ginsberg what opiates are for his fellow Beat quester, William Burroughs: a way of attaining to 'vision'. But Ginsberg's heroic mission includes something else as well: an implicit claim to the Beat throne. And more: "I am high and naked," this indomitable Ecdysiac Knight exclaims, splashing into the 1960s on the last page of Campbell's hard-eyed reconstruction of the legend, "and I am King of the Universe."

When we met in England, Ginsberg had abdicated another impromptu throne, as King of the May (Kral Majales) in Prague. He had been expelled for taking off his clothes during a reading to his student subjects. Further prophetic challenges lay in store. We went on a pilgrimage to Glastonbury. There, after pausing under the great conical chimney of the abbey kitchen to scribble notes on the display of chivalric devices, arms and armour, he stood in the chilly drizzle over what was said to be the grave of King Arthur and chanted an extended, improvised rabbinical-druidic hymn. It evoked the strength and innocence of Blake's Albion and ended on what seemed to me, at the time, a strange remark, perhaps a challenge hurled from king to king: "British poets are cowardly!"

Most legends have variants. The Arthurian story locates the mythic King's remains not at Glastonbury but in fabulous Avalon. Campbell puzzles out the meanings of legendary Beat episodes by offering alternative readings: providing, for example, ten different descriptions of the object that Burroughs was aiming at when he shot his wife in the head in Mexico (champagne glass, shot glass, highball glass, wine glass, gin glass, water glass, tin can, apple, apricot, grape), and six possibilities for the kind of paper on which Jack Kerouac typed out the original hundred-foot scroll of On the Road (teletype paper, Japanese drawing paper, oilskin art paper, shelf-paper, canister paper, tracing paper).

He finds strands of Kerouac's road romance throughout the Beat legend. Tangled up in the story, as usual, is the Beat Lancelot, Neal Cassady. "The new American hero . . . delinquent and hungry for a purpose", Cassady shows up here in 1947, a beguiling apparition, naked with an erection in a tenement doorway, waiting to be "miraculously-crafted" into a figure of romance. For Kerouac, who had been blocking out a grand picaresque novel in his notebooks, an American Pilgrim's Progress, this naked stranger held "the keys to America", a kingdom whose magic had until this moment been withheld from him. Kerouac "glimpsed the possibility of romance." There was "something mystical . . . which, in a shaft of insight akin to a vision, he recognised in Cassady," Campbell writes. Kerouac's association with Cassady jump-starts what Campbell calls "the process of a profound change in his attitude towards his own experience." The change was a matter of learning how to blow up real events and people to mythic proportions. It was Cassady who taught him this: the tearaway adventurer who stole cars and carried off women at a dizzying pace appeared to be more than human. The poetic tropes with which Kerouac limned his new-generation hero were often derived from classical mythology, with Cassady cast as a Promethean stealer of automotive fire, chained to his own inarticulate drives as one bound to a rock; a winged-messenger god in a Mercury; a naked Eros.

In Campbell's account of the legend, the last of these figures is rampant. Cassady appears here under the double aspect of danger and desire. The importance of his role, allowing the spectator Kerouac to escape to the position of vicarious participant in his adventures, grows clearer as these adventures become more risky and the romance thickens, muddied by the growing extent of the depravity of the 'errant boy'. Inevitably, in this as in many other versions, we suspect that Cassady's place in the legend may be that of the sacrificial hero, the fated victim of his own terrifying quest for kicks. Being a witness to vision is less blinding than experiencing it, and Kerouac realises with relief that he will not have to put himself at the centre of his romance. Riding shotgun on great road trips will reveal his own ritual aspect, the Brooding Sidekick to Cassady's hyperactive, beguiling Knight Driven and Driver. Even before taking off, Kerouac is excited by a "reflected witchery" he feels sure will signal a new leap in his own vision-quest. "And somewhere along the way," he writes at the start of On the Road, "I knew there'd be girls, visions, everything; somewhere along the line the pearl would be handed to me."

Yet Cassady's reflected witchery turns out to be complex: the legendary cocksman is disclosed as an androgynous beguiler in a subplot that entangles him at once with Kerouac and Ginsberg. Campbell plays this as an episode of double desire, in which Lancelot becomes Guinevere. Balancing between "the desire to please and the desire to profit" by "making an investment in Ginsberg's literary talent", Cassady reveals his mendacious aspect as the Hustler Knight, "only bestowing favours because he wants to gain something by the transaction." The 'investment' in physical attentions will return a certain dividend in Howl ("N.C., secret hero of these poems, cocksman and Adonis of Denver"), but the real score is reserved for Kerouac. Campbell points to a passage in the 1950 scroll draft of the road romance, which left the Beat heroes' real names undisguised, and shows Kerouac seeking to appropriate the naked hero, now a bone of contention, for his own uses: "Allen was queer . . . and Neal saw this and a former hustler himself . . . and wanting dearly to learn how to write poetry like Allen, the first thing he was attacking Allen with a great amorous soul such as only a conman can have."

Campbell suggests that Kerouac's biased account of the three men's interlocking relations in On the Road is intended to point up the hollowness of the Hustler Knight's love for Ginsberg, and that this, in turn, "creates a space for the true romance of the book". He is particularly good on the way that "true romance" is clinched in the symbolic wedding scene. In this blushing, embarrassed bonding episode, which joins the narrator and his 'errant-boy' hero in a golden, illuminated moment on a sunlit hill, exchanging glances above the Western ocean, we are reminded again that in romance, accidents often turn up clues to the hidden intent of a quest. The scene is precipitated by a 'realistic' narrative contingency - the outlaw hero getting bounced (for infidelity) by his 'reigning wife' - but it allows a marvellous revelation of the secret goal. "There were triumph and insolence in his eyes," Kerouac's narrator says, as the two heroes stand marooned in their Beatness on that sunlit hill, "a devilish look, and he never took his eyes off mine for a long time. I looked back and blushed . . . we would stick together and be buddies till we died."

Spelling out the significance of this for the legend, Campbell notes that "theirs is a platonic love, though bedecked by romantic accoutrements, many of them subliminal, some even unconscious." His analysis of the symbolic 'wedding' is central to his account of Beat legend: the scene appears as the ultimate consummation of a sublimated 'boy-gang' love which has not yet adjusted to its later exchange value. The love between the two figures who, as Campbell comments, "possess nothing but their baggage and each other", is naive, deceived and self-deceiving, yet as long as the spell of the road romance lasts, it is untainted by the element of commodification which Cassady's hustler habits introduce into the legend. Had the road book stayed in Kerouac's backpack for ever, there might have been no cancelled cheques with his autograph for Johnny Depp to buy. But not all sacraments are destined to remain sacred.

Given the current commercial success of everything to do with the Beats, it is ironic and curious to recall the resistance that Kerouac - the first, most committed and poetic of the Beat chroniclers - encountered when he began looking for a publisher for the 1950 typescript of On the Road. Campbell retells the story of this seven-year trial of rejection and suspicion, during which Kerouac's bitterness intensifies with the pitfalls and pratfalls of the quest, some of them bizarre, even grotesquely comic - Kerouac being ineptly agented by Ginsberg, and nightmarishly 'edited' by Carl Solomon, the insulin-comatose, glucose-swollen Bughouse Knight of Howl. Kerouac's comments in letters of the period paint an unfunny self-portrait of a gullible 'Li'l Abner' at the mercy of the rapacious commercial 'pigjaws' of Madison Avenue. There is also paranoia about having his creation whisked away, exploited and cashed in on by fellow writers. But paranoia, in his friend Burroughs's formulation, is only extreme consciousness: an enhanced receptivity to truth. It was around this point that John Clellon Holmes, a stay-at-home quester, purloined testimony from Kerouac and Ginsberg for a pelf-garnering pseudo-Beat romance (Go!), and, in a notorious article in the New York Times ('This Is the Beat Generation'), took metonymic possession of Kerouac's ritual term for the underworld heroes' "new stance toward reality" - "a sort of furtiveness . . . a kind of beatness", as Kerouac had explained it to him. "I guess you could say we're a beat generation."

Kerouac's belated effort to grab back the term's ritual magic by retitling his road-book The Beat Generation proved futile. The unparagraphed format of the 1950 hundred-foot scroll typescript clearly worked against its commercial prospects, and the recalcitrant Kerouac finally gave in and broke up the long heroic prose into more conventional units. A related but more serious difficulty was his disinclination to compromise the manner of his writing. On-the Road's headlong, scattered drafting of a collective but disorganised vision-quest, a romance of errantry with no point but the journey itself and "no story beyond the story posted by the signs along the way", inevitably set Kerouac at loggerheads with Malcolm Cowley, the first editor to recognise the mythic potential of his legend. Cowley, seen through the Brooding Knight's cocked eye as "a semi-pedantic Vermont professor-type with a hearing aid", made gentle but firm demands for a conventional structure - a "unified story", an 'A-B-C development' - which Kerouac stubbornly refused to accommodate. His book's construction, he insisted, was consistent with his road vision - a claim for the truth of allegorical romance. As Campbell says, this dispute agonisingly lingered; entire centrifugal movements were required to be cut; it was in desperation that Kerouac at last submitted to the sacrilege of revision which allowed On the Road to see the light.

In This Is the Beat Generation, Campbell himself works with a romance-narrative mode of entrelacement; his reconstruction of Beat legend moves forward by jumping from limb to limb of a branch-narrative structure, following his several heroes' interconnected movements from chapter to chapter. Their quest is anti-normative, anti-conventional from the start. Like Malory's heroes, they are bound to a peculiar way of living, characterised by a restless search for new adventure. Malory's knights, after all, are not only courtly but crazy and confused; Caxton's preface warns readers that they will find not only deeds brave and chivalrous, but 'cowardyse, murdre, hate'. The young knights in search of a 'New Vision' whom Campbell discovers in wartime New York City - Kerouac, Ginsberg, Burroughs, Lucien Carr - all land in mental hospitals by the-age of 30. The loyal boy-gang that develops out of their errant undergraduate 'libertine circle' undergoes some of its severest tests in these early chapters, as their New Vision implicates them in a succession of legendary crimes of impulse, rehearsed by Campbell with something like tabloid relish. They include murder (Carr's "honour slaying" of his ex-scoutmaster, David Kammerer, with Burroughs and Kerouac as accessories); needle-drug addiction ("quite a sensation" is Burroughs's comment on being administered his first shot of morphine by Herbert Huncke); and self-mutilation (Burroughs's prescient deconstructive act, or "Van Gogh kick", of snipping off his left little finger with poultry shears).

Irrationality is etched as deeply into Beat legend as the skull-and-crossbones Ginsberg inscribes beneath the words 'Fuck the Jews' in the dust of his college dormitory windowsill, earning him a brief expulsion from Columbia. The same sepulchral motif would come to figure as his calling-card. At King's College, Cambridge, in our 1965 spring tour, he scribbled it on a cheerful self-introductory note thrust under E.M. Forster's door. Forster later inquired: "Is the fellow mad?" When Ginsberg heard this, he thought it was flattering. In Howl, we recall, it is precisely the madness of the Beat generation's 'best minds' - "starving hysterical naked" - that leads them to vision.

By the mid-1950s the Beat quest had carried its principal heroes to the fabulous western edge of the kingdom. In sunny California Allen Ginsberg's long camouflage trail of half-hearted 'normalcy programs' is finally lost in the hang-up-dispelling daylight of psychotherapy, allowing him to leap from a repressed state - "the blind side of the trick wall", Campbell calls it - out into the full illumination of his ceremonial aspect as the Ecdysiac Knight. To "express secret life in whatever form it comes out," he confided to a group of students, "I practically take my clothes off." At a famous gathering of minstrels in the Six Gallery, in San Francisco, Howl was covered with glory. For the first time in the Beat legend, private weirdness was publicly embraced.

Kerouac the Brooding Knight succeeds less well in this West Coast phase of the legend. All along impatient with his "flighty vagabond romanticism", his latent racism and misogyny, Campbell now reveals him in his later Simple Simon aspect, as a faux-naif "crazy dumbsaint" Knight of Oblivion. The Kerouac of the later parts of Campbell's version is all but finished as a writer, even before his central work has been published: a foolish, besotted, lost hero "to whom thoughts brought trouble, who drank to quell them". Lonesome and bereft after the failed love affair with a black girl chronicled in The Subterraneans - condemned by Campbell as the most reprehensible of Beat texts - he turns to the Life of Buddha to relieve his 'Beermares', but after much untutored study rises only to the "fatalistic and commonplace" in his attempts to smuggle an adopted religion into his writing.

Heading to California, he backpacks with Zen companions Philip Whalen and Gary Snyder, but only gets drunker and lonelier and unhappier. When last we see him, he is typing-up grandiose autodidactic meditation manuals and "spiritual bromide" sutras in a rustic cabin in thought-free California, victim of a fear of "discriminating thinking" that cloaks "a banal fear of life".

The last word on Kerouacian/West Coast Beat Buddhism, here, is reserved for the exiled Invisible Knight, William Burroughs, responding from his 'end-of-the-world' outpost in Tangiers to his friend Kerouac's babblings about renunciation, self-abnegation and chastity: "Buddhism is only for the West to study as history . . . It is not, for the West, An Answer, not A Solution. We must learn by acting, experiencing and living; that is, above all, by Love and by Suffering . . . You were given the power to love in order to use it, no matter what pain it may cause you. Buddhism frequently amounts to a form of psychic junk . . . What I mean is the Californian Buddhists are trying to sit on the sidelines and there are no sidelines. Whether you like it or not, you are committed to the human endeavour." The deadpan, laconic, no-nonsense noir voice of experience that makes Burroughs Campbell's true Beat oracle, at once its trustiest commentator and in some sense its stylistic model, also supplies some of the book's driest lines. Confronted by an 'Ugly Spirit' while shooting his wife in Mexico City, for instance, he reports that it was, in retrospect, as if her brain "drew the bullet toward it". Campbell, clearly impressed, places Burroughs among the "untouchables" of legend, those who perform a "priestly function in taking on themselves all human vileness".

Our last glimpse of this frail, greyish creature of the shadows discovers him in Paris at the outset of the 1960s, the truest of Campbell's Beat survivors, still tuned into that old "silent frequency of junk" and still enacting the oldest and deepest of Beat rituals - transgression and self-mutilation - and turning them now against the legend itself. Taking a cut-up lance to his own writings as "the next logical step in his continuing quest for the secret of telepathic communication" - "If you cut into the present, the future leaks out" - the Invisible Knight finds the Word itself coming apart under his surgical blade. At the end of this demystifying book, Campbell stresses the fundamental difference between Burroughs's approach to the vision-quest and Ginsberg's. Burroughs wanted to eradicate his own identity; Ginsberg wanted to incorporate everything in his.

In This Is the Beat Generation, Campbell himself works with a romance-narrative mode of entrelacement; his reconstruction of Beat legend moves forward by jumping from limb to limb of a branch-narrative structure, following his several heroes' interconnected movements from chapter to chapter. Their quest is anti-normative, anti-conventional from the start. Like Malory's heroes, they are bound to a peculiar way of living, characterised by a restless search for new adventure. Malory's knights, after all, are not only courtly but crazy and confused; Caxton's preface warns readers that they will find not only deeds brave and chivalrous, but 'cowardyse, murdre, hate'. The young knights in search of a 'New Vision' whom Campbell discovers in wartime New York City - Kerouac, Ginsberg, Burroughs, Lucien Carr - all land in mental hospitals by the-age of 30. The loyal boy-gang that develops out of their errant undergraduate 'libertine circle' undergoes some of its severest tests in these early chapters, as their New Vision implicates them in a succession of legendary crimes of impulse, rehearsed by Campbell with something like tabloid relish. They include murder (Carr's "honour slaying" of his ex-scoutmaster, David Kammerer, with Burroughs and Kerouac as accessories); needle-drug addiction ("quite a sensation" is Burroughs's comment on being administered his first shot of morphine by Herbert Huncke); and self-mutilation (Burroughs's prescient deconstructive act, or "Van Gogh kick", of snipping off his left little finger with poultry shears). Irrationality is etched as deeply into Beat legend as the skull-and-crossbones Ginsberg inscribes beneath the words 'Fuck the Jews' in the dust of his college dormitory windowsill, earning him a brief expulsion from Columbia. The same sepulchral motif would come to figure as his calling-card. At King's College, Cambridge, in our 1965 spring tour, he scribbled it on a cheerful self-introductory note thrust under E.M. Forster's door. Forster later inquired: "Is the fellow mad?" When Ginsberg heard this, he thought it was flattering. In Howl, we recall, it is precisely the madness of the Beat generation's 'best minds' - "starving hysterical naked" - that leads them to vision. By the mid-1950s the Beat quest had carried its principal heroes to the fabulous western edge of the kingdom. In sunny California Allen Ginsberg's long camouflage trail of half-hearted 'normalcy programs' is finally lost in the hang-up-dispelling daylight of psychotherapy, allowing him to leap from a repressed state - "the blind side of the trick wall", Campbell calls it - out into the full illumination of his ceremonial aspect as the Ecdysiac Knight. To "express secret life in whatever form it comes out," he confided to a group of students, "I practically take my clothes off." At a famous gathering of minstrels in the Six Gallery, in San Francisco, Howl was covered with glory. For the first time in the Beat legend, private weirdness was publicly embraced. Kerouac the Brooding Knight succeeds less well in this West Coast phase of the legend. All along impatient with his "flighty vagabond romanticism", his latent racism and misogyny, Campbell now reveals him in his later Simple Simon aspect, as a faux-naif "crazy dumbsaint" Knight of Oblivion. The Kerouac of the later parts of Campbell's version is all but finished as a writer, even before his central work has been published: a foolish, besotted, lost hero "to whom thoughts brought trouble, who drank to quell them". Lonesome and bereft after the failed love affair with a black girl chronicled in The Subterraneans - condemned by Campbell as the most reprehensible of Beat texts - he turns to the Life of Buddha to relieve his 'Beermares', but after much untutored study rises only to the "fatalistic and commonplace" in his attempts to smuggle an adopted religion into his writing. Heading to California, he backpacks with Zen companions Philip Whalen and Gary Snyder, but only gets drunker and lonelier and unhappier. When last we see him, he is typing-up grandiose autodidactic meditation manuals and "spiritual bromide" sutras in a rustic cabin in thought-free California, victim of a fear of "discriminating thinking" that cloaks "a banal fear of life". The last word on Kerouacian/West Coast Beat Buddhism, here, is reserved for the exiled Invisible Knight, William Burroughs, responding from his 'end-of-the-world' outpost in Tangiers to his friend Kerouac's babblings about renunciation, self-abnegation and chastity: "Buddhism is only for the West to study as history . . . It is not, for the West, An Answer, not A Solution. We must learn by acting, experiencing and living; that is, above all, by Love and by Suffering . . . You were given the power to love in order to use it, no matter what pain it may cause you. Buddhism frequently amounts to a form of psychic junk . . . What I mean is the Californian Buddhists are trying to sit on the sidelines and there are no sidelines. Whether you like it or not, you are committed to the human endeavour." The deadpan, laconic, no-nonsense noir voice of experience that makes Burroughs Campbell's true Beat oracle, at once its trustiest commentator and in some sense its stylistic model, also supplies some of the book's driest lines. Confronted by an 'Ugly Spirit' while shooting his wife in Mexico City, for instance, he reports that it was, in retrospect, as if her brain "drew the bullet toward it". Campbell, clearly impressed, places Burroughs among the "untouchables" of legend, those who perform a "priestly function in taking on themselves all human vileness". Our last glimpse of this frail, greyish creature of the shadows discovers him in Paris at the outset of the 1960s, the truest of Campbell's Beat survivors, still tuned into that old "silent frequency of junk" and still enacting the oldest and deepest of Beat rituals - transgression and self-mutilation - and turning them now against the legend itself. Taking a cut-up lance to his own writings as "the next logical step in his continuing quest for the secret of telepathic communication" - "If you cut into the present, the future leaks out" - the Invisible Knight finds the Word itself coming apart under his surgical blade. At the end of this demystifying book, Campbell stresses the fundamental difference between Burroughs's approach to the vision-quest and Ginsberg's. Burroughs wanted to eradicate his own identity; Ginsberg wanted to incorporate everything in his.  To read more online essays from the current edition of the London Review of Books visit the LRB. fields.headline: Press regulation
fields.standfirst: As the newspaper watchdog, Lord Wakeham, calls for continued restraint in coverage of Prince William after he leaves school, Colin Blackstock explains how the press is supervised
fields.trailText: As the newspaper watchdog, Lord Wakeham, calls for continued restraint in coverage of Prince William after he leaves school, we explain how the press is supervised.
fields.body:
What is the press complaints commission?
The PCC is an independent watchdog that was set up in 1991 to ensure that British newspapers and magazines follow an ethical code of practice. The code deals with issues such as inaccuracy, privacy, misrepresentation and harassment. The commission resolves complaints about possible breaches of the code and gives general guidance to editors on related ethical issues.

Why is it in the news?
Its chairman, Lord Wakeham, called for continued restraint in the coverage of Prince William after he leaves Eton on Wednesday. He set out new guidelines for editors telling them they should allow the 18-year-old prince the same sort of privacy given to any other public figure.

Have there been previous rulings or guidelines?
Yes. The code of practice protected Prince William's privacy from the full glare of the media spotlight as a minor at school, in the same way as it does for any child. However, Buckingham Palace accepted that there was a legitimate public interest in William as second in line to the throne. A deal was done whereby the palace promised to make photographs and information about the teenage prince available at milestones during his childhood in return for media cooperation.

Did it work? And why is Lord Wakeham calling for restraint now?
On the whole, the deal was regarded to have been a success, but now that William has reached the age of 18 and is leaving school, he is no longer protected by the code's guideline. In a speech delivered in Fleet Street this morning, Lord Wakeham said that endless intrusion into the prince's privacy would make his life a misery and did not want to see endless intrusion into the prince's life, but accepted that there would be reports and speculation about it, although newspapers should continue to exercise restraint. He also called for continued cooperation between papers and St James's Palace as the prince enters adulthood.

So, as the prince hopes to take a year out from full-time education before university, does he now become "fair game"?
Absolutely not, says Lord Wakeham: "He has left school, he is growing up and has become a young adult; he is increasingly becoming a public figure - and the way the press covers him will reflect that That is likely to mean that newspaper readers are going to be seeing somewhat more of him in the future." But there should be no snatched pictures of William in a private place or place where there was a reasonable expectation of privacy, including private gardens and restaurants, he added.

What happens if newspapers ignore this call for restraint?
Lord Wakeham says the PCC will come down hard on the publication of any picture of Prince William that has been obtained through intimidation or persistent pursuit, just as it would for any other individual. If a paper breaches the code and the PCC upholds a complaint, then the publication must publish the PCC's adjudication in full and "with due prominence".

Where can I find out more?
Press Complaints Commission
PCC code of practice
Society of Editors
Official royal website
The future of the monarchy: special report

Books on BOL.com
Sex, Lies and Democracy by Michael Bromley
Ethical Issues in Journalism and Media by Andrew Belsey
Regulating the Press by Clive Soley
Regulating the Media by Thomas Gibbons

fields.headline: You bet your life: day 14
fields.standfirst: With just three gambling days to go before the end of Euro 2000, someone's made a killing, somebody's been killed, and two are (just about) keeping their heads. Now for the first semi-final.
fields.trailText: With just three gambling days to go before the end of Euro 2000, someone's made a killing, somebody's been killed, and two are (just about) keeping their heads. But how do our gambling maestros view tonight's France v Portugal semi-final?
fields.body:
Totals so far:
Scott Murray £116.42
Sean Ingle £70.97
Mike Hodgkinson £27.08
Paul MacInnes RIP

Scott Murray

Portugal v France. France to win golden goal 14-1 (£20)
This tournament, which has had everything so far, has yet to tell a tale of terrible injustice. Tonight it will. Portugal, so profligate against Turkey, will run the world champions ragged for 90 minutes. Of course, they'll fail to find a killer touch and, in extra time, one scuffed kick from a French boot will put paid to the best chance the golden generation will ever have of realising their potential.

Sean Ingle

France v Portugal. 2-1 France win 7-1 (£10)
Blue Square are offering a special bet on Laurent Blanc kissing Fabien Barthez's bald pate, which is a licence to print money, even at 1/10. Unfortunately I've only got £70 and an extra £7 isn't going to help me catch gambling virtuoso Scott Murray.

So I'm going to be bold. The way I see it Portugal will come out firing and go 1-0 up. But then the imperious French will kick into gear and come back to win 2-1. The only question is whether they'll need extra time to do it. After much reflection, I say no. They'll be no shocks. No golden goals. No penalties. Just another French victory

Mike Hodgkinson

France v Portugal. Correct score 90 minutes 2-2 (£10 at 18-1)
These sides are well capable of delivering a high scoring semi-final, so long as 'the fear' doesn't put Figo and his teammates off their stride. France are awesome, but Portugal deserve extra-time at the very least if only because they have the best national anthem in the tournament by far. If you fancy France to win it on a golden goal, pick Zidane.

fields.headline: Standard Life wins ballot
fields.standfirst: Members spurn £5,000 windfalls and send carpetbaggers packing - but also criticise directors
fields.trailText: Members spurn £5,000 windfalls and send carpetbaggers packing - but also criticise directors
fields.body:
Standard Life members yesterday rejected windfalls of £5,000 or more each in a powerful vote for mutuality.

In a setback for carpetbaggers, 54.3% of the 1.1m policyholders who voted opted to keep Standard Life mutual.

The carpetbaggers needed 75% of the vote to force Standard Life to float on the stock market but picked up just 45.7%. Amid applause at a packed general meeting, Standard Life chairman John Trott declared that only 22% of the total 2.3m members of Standard Life voted for windfalls.

"This is a decisive moment for mutuality ... Mutuality should be able to thrive without the distraction and expense of fighting off demutualisation."

Fred Woollard, who led the carpetbagging campaign, ad mitted defeat and stood by his pledge not to push for further resolutions.

But he criticised Standard Life campaign tactics: "We lost the argument because Standard Life misled policyholders. If they had been told the truth, that they would not have been worse off, we would have scored an overwhelming victory."

He also left the door open for other carpetbaggers to take on Standard Life next year.

Last night the scale of Standard Life's victory, only a year after 62% of Bradford & Bingley members voted for windfalls, brought new demands for stricter legal measures to protect mutuals.

Comparing carpetbaggers to the Trotskyites who were expelled from the Labour party, Frank Field, former social security minister, said: "The pro tection of mutuality has to move up the political agenda. It fits in with the sort of society the government wants to create."

Standard Life's rules still allow any resolution to be put forward to a special meeting if it has 50 supporters, although the ban on new membership policies will remain in force.

Standard Life group managing director Scott Bell rejected calls for members to enjoy a special one-off bonus following the carpetbaggers' defeat. But, amid a hostile atmosphere in which members criticised the company for poor endowment policy performance, arrogance and complacency, Mr Bell promised that the company would take steps to demonstrate the value of its mutuality to members.

"There is much to learn from what has taken place" he said.

More than 700 policyholders packed the Edinburgh convention centre for the SGM. One carpetbagging member declared that Standard Life should be renamed "substandard Life" while another won loud support when he attacked Standard Life for his "appalling endowment", which is £22,000 short of its £46,000 target.

But the mood of the meeting also reflected the pro-mutuality ballot result. Another member won loud applause when he compared Standard Life favourably to recently demutualised Scottish Widows.

"At least the Standard Life board have had the guts to stand up for what they believe in."

fields.headline: Diamonds
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the guerrilla's best friend
fields.trailText: 1. Proposals for stamping out the illicit diamond trade will be discussed in London today at a conference hosted by the Foreign Office.
fields.body:
1. Proposals for stamping out the illicit diamond trade will be discussed in London today at a conference hosted by the Foreign Office.

2. The discussion of so-called blood diamonds will be attended by industry representatives, as well as officials from India, Israel, Belgium, and the USA.

3. Diamond thieves and smugglers have poured cash into some of the bloodiest conflicts in Africa - most recently the horrendously brutal civil war in Sierra Leone.

4. Other civil wars financed by illegal diamond sales include those in Liberia, Angola, and the Democratic Republic of The Congo (formerly Zaire).

5. Diamonds have been called a rebel's best friend. But in Sierra Leone at least, the civil war is less about who runs the country, than who runs the diamond mines.

6. Both diamonds and oil are providing the wealth that fuels the civil war in Angola, Africa's longest-running conflict.

7. The Congolese war is part of the Great Lakes regional crisis which involves the armies and militias of no fewer than five African countries.

8. Human rights groups and others have been campaigning for effective controls on what they call fatal transactions: the theft, smuggling and sale of diamonds from the conflict-torn regions.

9. One of the most active groups, Global Witness, has outlined a possible action plan in its latest report.

10. The world's biggest diamond producer and trader, De Beers, insists that it is complying with the embargo on illicit diamonds.

webTitle: Jamie Rainbow's month in an armchair

fields.headline: The Tyldesley project
fields.standfirst: Jamie Rainbow, still strapped to a recliner, believes the world's finest scientific minds should forget the riddle of human life and answer a more demanding question: what goes on in the head of ITV commentators?
fields.trailText: Jamie Rainbow, still strapped to a recliner, believes the world's finest scientific minds should forget the riddle of human life and answer a more demanding question: what goes on in the head of ITV commentators?
fields.body:
If the pre-match hype is anything to go by, we should be in for a classic encounter tonight. Zidane versus Figo? No, silly. Clive Tyldesley versus the powers of hyperbole. Following Peter Van Drury's tour de force on Sunday, Tyldesley will have to go some tonight if he is justify his pre-tournament status as the person most likely to spontaneoulsy combust during the course of a live commenatary.

News that the human DNA genome sequence has finally been unravelled has been described as the scientific breakthrough of the millennium and by all accounts it's a remarkable achievement. Now that that trifling matter has been sorted out, the supercomputers will go to work on unravelling the thought processes of the average ITV commentator. As it took 15 years to figure out the DNA code, scientists are optimistic of getting a basic insight into the workings of Drury and Tyldesley in time for the World Cup of 2074.

When the football's over you can stick with ITV to watch When Athletes Attack II. Athletes Attack I was obviously such a rip-roaring success that ITV has kindly decided to bring us more of the same. The programme takes a light-hearted look at violence in sport (as you do) and is described in today's Guardian as "wickedly enjoyable". I've got my doubts on that but one thing is clear; given the violent incidents at Euro 2000, the individual responsible for scheduling this programme, clearly has a sense of humour.

Incidentally, to compete with the football tonight, the BBC is pulling out all the stops by screening the 1987 Christmas edition of Only Fools and Horses. It features a game of charades and is therefore the closest the BBC can get to live sports coverage these days.

The number of games I've watched during Euro 2000 has now reached 24 (25 if you include watching the entire England Germany game a second time - well I'm sure I wasn't the only one). So far there have only been a couple of matches when I could honestly say to myself: "You really should get out a bit more". But I' ve only got myself to blame - no one forced me to watch England.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Which formation did Terry Venables play during Euro 2000? How good was Lev Yashin? And just who finished second in the BBC's 'Find a Commentator Competition?' (clue - it's a famous TV pundit).
fields.trailText: Which formation did Terry Venables play during Euro 2000? How good was Lev Yashin? And just who finished second in the BBC's 'Find a Commentator Competition?' (clue - it's a famous TV pundit).
fields.body:
We played a game in Kiev last weekend, and our keeper sported a very fetching Lev Yashin top. I don't know squat about this Lev bloke. What's the story? asks Chris Kelly

Whenever journalists are asked to name their 'greatest ever' football side, it is usually Lev Yashin - rather than Gordon Banks - who wears the keeper's jersey. Yashin usually wins because he was a goalkeeping pioneer. He would charge outside the penalty area to clear the ball, he would fist dangerous corners and crosses away, and he would dive fearlessly at forwards' feet. In short, he was the first modern keeper.

He was also a winner. During his career Yashin played for Moscow Dinamo (1948 - 1971) and the USSR national team (1954 - 1967), gaining a host of trophies and accolades along the way. At Dinamo, he won 5 national championships and made a record number of appearances in the league. When he retired in 1971, his last match was in Moscow against a European all-stars team. But in 1986 a knee injury forced doctors to amputate Yashin's leg, and he died four years later in 1990 after complications from surgery.

What formation did Terry Venables play during Euro 96, asked Kim Ulrich.

"If memory serves me correctly England began Euro '96 with a 4-4-2 (or maybe 4-4-1-1) formation with a starting line-up of: Seaman; Neville, Southgate, Adams, Pearce; Anderton, Ince, Gascoigne, McManaman; Sheringham, Shearer" says James Lowther.

"But for the match against Scotland they changed formation to 3-5-2, with Southgate starting in midfield. Then at half time Southgate dropped back to replace Pearce in defence and Redknapp came on as the extra midfielder. For the games against Holland and Spain they reverted to 4-4-2, with Platt taking Ince's place against Spain.

"In the semi-final England switched again to 3-5-2, with Ince returning to the side and Neville dropping out through suspension. Throughout the tournament McManaman and Anderton swapped wings fairly freely. The 4-3-2-1 'Christmas tree' formation was never adopted during the tournament."

A few weeks ago we asked what happened to Idwal Robling, the winner of the BBC's 'Find a Commentator' in 1970 (Apparently he's been tucked away on Welsh TV for the past 30 years). Anyway, we recently received an email from James Doran, who wondered if anyone remembers who finished second. The answer, he says, was football pundit Ian St John - who entered the competition because the first prize was a trip to Mexico, and because his career was coming to an end. Perhaps David Beckham will do the same thing in a few years' time.

A few weeks ago we asked the highest number of countries represented at the start of one Premiership match.

We thought the answer was 16 - the Newcastle v Chelsea game on the 4th March. Not so, says Lars Kollveit. "I still think that Coventry-Chelsea at Highfield this year (with 14 players) is the match with the most nations represented from the starting 22 players. I read that 16 nations played during Newcastle - Chelsea, but actually only twelve nations STARTED the match. Both Ketsbaia (Georgia), Solano (Peru), Petrescu (Romania) and Flo (Norway) came on as subs."

Can you recall the West Bromwich Albion league position at the end of season 1975/76? asks Tony Matthews. And can you possibly tell me a bit about their team?

Inspired by Johnny Giles, who joined as player-manger from Leeds in the summer of 1975, the Baggies finished third in the old Division Two and gained promotion with a record of 20 wins, 13 draws and 9 losses. That year the key players were striker Tony 'Bomber' Brown (who bagged 312 goals in 818 games for the club), a very young Bryan Robson, defender John Wile, (who is now WBA's chief executive) and nippy Scottish international winger Willie Johnston.

Can you help

"Emile Heskey's father apparently made a bet when he was 11, that he would be capped by England at all levels before he was twenty-something (I can't recall the exact age). Any information if he collected on that bet!" asks Martin Hoisington.

"I read your explanation of the evolution of the dugout in football - but is there any possibility of a link to the baseball dug-out, in which players have been ensconced since the early 1900s. Is it possible that there was a transatlantic crossing of grounds ideas, or did they evolve independently of each other?" wonders John Kendle.

"I am desperately trying to contact a former Chelsea player by the name of John Boyle. He played for Chelsea in the 70s and came over to the States to play for the Tampa Bay Rowdies. We are having a reunion in August and need him here, can anyone help?" pleads Mike Connell.

Send your requests and answers to the.boss@theguardian.com and we will do our best to help.

fields.headline: Chelsea sign Stanic
fields.trailText: Croatian international Mario Stanic has joined Chelsea for £5.6m. The 28-year-old Parma player becomes Gianluca Vialli's third summer signing, joining Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Eidur Gudjohnsen at Stamford Bridge.
fields.body:
Croatian international Mario Stanic has joined Chelsea for £5.6m. The 28-year-old Parma player becomes Gianluca Vialli's third summer signing, joining Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Eidur Gudjohnsen at Stamford Bridge.

Stanic impressed many with his performances at France '98 and scored 25 times in 109 appearances for Parma. He can play both on the right wing and up front, and his arrival could spell the end of Dan Petrescu's Chelsea career.

Stanic has returned to Croatia this morning after signing a five-year contract with the Blues.

fields.headline: Goofy, daffy magic
fields.standfirst: On  Jacques Rivette
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney on Jacques Rivette
fields.body:
A few years ago the French director Jacques Rivette was one of several film-makers featured in a documentary made to commemorate the centenary of cinema. Each was asked why they made films, and nearly all attempted some grand statement about time, memory and the image. All except the famously reticent Rivette, who paused at length, shrugged and creased his face painfully into a sheepish "Don't ask me" grin. Similarly, if you asked me why I love Rivette's films, I'd probably have a go at the time-and-memory option but I'd be better off imitating the grin and advising you to go and see for yourself. Next week, his 1974 film Céline et Julie Vont En Bateau (Céline and Julie Go Boating) is re-released at the ICA and it's a prime example of why Rivette's cinema is such an elusive, inexplicable pleasure.

He has managed for years to be the most marginal of the original New Wave directors. In Britain, he means next to nothing - his last film, the austere Secret Défense, was barely seen, while its predecessor, Haut Bas Fragile, a freewheeling, typically enigmatic musical, was never even released here.

Céline and Julie was Rivette's one genuine cult hit, both here and in the US, where it sparked a remake of sorts in Susan Seidelman's Desperately Seeking Susan. Rivette's film is in a different league from Seidelman's urbane romp - a three-hour tangle of dream, cloak-and-dagger intrigue and seemingly haphazard comedy that leaves you exhilarated, if not necessarily any the wiser.

Opinions on it differ. David Thomson has called it "the most innovative film since Citizen Kane". Other people can't abide it. I know plenty who think it's just two whimsical hippie chicks arseing around. It's not a film that tries to please everyone, any more than its abrasively scatty heroines do. You either enjoy their obsessive goofing, or you may as well not bother. The point is that the film belongs as much to them and the actresses who play them as to Rivette. His work on the film, according to the late Juliet Berto (Céline), was a kind of "surgery", splicing and shaping the material that she generated with co-star Dominique Labourier.

Here's a synopsis, not that it will really help. Julie is sitting in a Paris garden, brushing up on her spells, when Céline rushes by, leaving a trail of knick-knacks. Julie goes in pursuit, which becomes a sort of flirtation; the two become inseparable friends, if not lovers, then investigate a mysterious house in which a quartet of ghosts endlessly act out a stiff, disjointed melodrama.

That's only part of it: there's Céline's slapdash magic act as La Mandragore, Julie's manic song-and-dance debut as La Kamikaze, a dead-of-night library raid with roller-skates and an extraordinary number of cats. There's also the way the film captures its time, not least in Berto's wardrobe - boas, bippety-boppety hats and all.

Events seem to happen at random, as though they had been roughly spliced in someone's head. The impromptu feel comes partly from the fact that Rivette started the film when another project fell through; Berto and Labourier devised their own characters and an intrigue, while script collaborator Eduardo di Gregorio contrived the haunted-house business from two Henry James stories. But the overall film is shaped by Rivette's twin obsessions, film and theatre. The old house is like a deserted art cinema where the same faded old print is projected for ever. But what happens there is also a creaky stage melodrama that needs to be endlessly rehearsed until the spell is broken. The "play" finally becomes a Rosencrantz-and-Guildenstern routine, with Céline and Julie, in comic supporting roles, upstaging the principals.

Céline and Julie is one of cinema's great stories about storytelling: despite appearances, the only scene that is improvised has the mythomaniac Céline driving her friends crazy with a tall tale. The whole film, in fact, is a shaggy-dog routine, spun out of old silent serials, comic strips and Lewis Carroll. Even Paris is unreal, despite the location shooting, which captures the feel of its deserted summer doldrums.

Constantly re-running extracts from the haunted-house drama, Céline and Julie are like children watching the Tellytubbies and getting high on repetition. You can watch the film again! again! and always find something new. This week for the first time it occurred to me that this might be the only film in which the story is dreamed by a passing cat.

 Céline and Julie Go Boating opens at the ICA, London SW1 (020-7930 3647) on July 7.

webTitle: Never mind the quality, feel the numbers

fields.headline: Never mind the quality, feel the numbers
fields.trailText: On Monday Saber Hossain Chowdhury managed a feat recently thought impossible: he called cricket a noble game. In his defence, Mr Chowdhury is the President of the Bangladesh Cricket Board and his countrymen began a five-day celebration after entering cricket's world of funny handshakes, secret alliances, off-shore venues and financing. His is a nation of water, rickshaws, non-governmental organisations, and, at last, Test cricket.
fields.body:
On Monday Saber Hossain Chowdhury managed a feat recently thought impossible: he called cricket a noble game. In his defence, Mr Chowdhury is the President of the Bangladesh Cricket Board and his countrymen began a five-day celebration after entering cricket's world of funny handshakes, secret alliances, off-shore venues and financing. His is a nation of water, rickshaws, non-governmental organisations, and, at last, Test cricket.

Bangladesh, now firmly on-shore, has been carefully groomed with considerable support from the outgoing ICC president, Jagmohan Dalmiya of India, and the other South Asian nations. Few would question the passion of its fans or its capacity to stage Test cricket, but plenty will continue to doubt the ability of its cricketers. Even their one major triumph, in last year's World Cup, is tainted courtesy of a gossiping session between Majid Khan and Ali Bacher. I doubt that much will come of ICC's investigation into that match as neither Majid nor Bacher has furnished evidence. But the damage has been done: some members of the public will conclude that Bangladesh can only win a fixed game. The recent Asia Cup confirmed that the Bangladeshis have much to do to catch up with the other Test-playing nations.

Even so, I do not buy the quality argument. Does it really matter that Bangladesh will be the worst side in the world for a few years? Someone has to be, and it also gives sleeping giants like England and India a buffer zone at the bottom of the Wisden World Championship table. It is about time this undue emphasis on quality ended. All nations have been weak when they started but the only way to raise standards is by allowing the lesser teams to play the giants. I doubt that even the first ever Test match was contested by two highly skilled sides. So who cares if Bangladesh aren't much cop at the moment; they will be. And they have a population of 130 million, the highest population density in the world, focusing on one sport. Cricket will have a higher profile there than it does in England. Test cricket's exclusive club needs to be broken up for good; it certainly has little future in our modern world. If countries have the infrastructure and the commitment, let them in.

The irony is that England need Bangladesh and Zimbabwe. They usually shun new boys through a mixture of arrogance and incompetence. But weaker teams have their place, and their uses. Would David Gower and Ian Botham, for example, have achieved greatness without first feasting on an ample diet of trundlers in their early years, when Kerry Packer had weakened world cricket? Those triumphs gave them the confidence to face the real powers of their time. What Freddie Flintoff needs to get him going is a lavish supply of Bangladeshi dobbers on a flat track.

The other main reservation about Bangladesh's inclusion has been that it will strengthen the South Asian bloc vote at ICC meetings, highly topical in these days of a black-white, or brown-white, split looming behind every controversy. This rationale is even more tenuous than the quality-control argument and is based on the dangerous presupposition that a stronger South Asian voice is bound to be a bad thing.

Further echoes of cricket's imperialist past are found in Bangladesh's history. After independence from Pakistan in 1971, Finance Minister Tajuddin Ahmed pushed for cricket to be banned because he believed it was a reminder of Bangladesh's most recent colonials, the Pakistanis and the British. The country's cricketers set fire to their equipment in protest. Mercifully, the Prime Minister intervened to save cricket from an anti-colonial backlash.

Now Bangladesh can tackle its former masters on equal terms. Unlike England, Pakistan and India have both offered to play the inaugural Test match. Instead of showing their customary reserve, England should get some easy wins in while they can.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. To read his previous column, about India's players and the taxman, click here. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the spiel for today's papers dressed up in spandex and hurled around a ring by a man with a name like "the garbage disposer"
fields.trailText: According to Italian newspaper La Stampa, Manchester United have had a £30m bid for Pavel Nedved rejected by Lazio. The Czech star, who has admitted an interest in playing for the Premiership champions, now looks set to stay in Rome.
fields.body:
According to Italian newspaper La Stampa, Manchester United have had a £30m bid for Pavel Nedved rejected by Lazio. The Czech star, who has admitted an interest in playing for the Premiership champions, now looks set to stay in Rome.

Aston Villa are ready to bid £12m for Benfica's Nuno Gomes. A report in the Mirror suggests that Portugal's three-goal striker wants to play in the Premiership, but that Villa will have to fight off rival bids from Fiorentina and Lazio.

Luis Figo's wife has suggested he would not object to a move to London. "Luis loves London and has been there many times", she told Four Four Two magazine. "It's the perfect place, there's nowhere better in the world."

Bobby Robson will sign Portugese midfielder Marcelo Pereira Fernandez for Newcastle within the next few days, according to Teamtalk. The CS Maritimo player, known as Bruno, had been expected to move to Spain, but Bobby Robson's contacts in Portugal appear to have persuaded the player to move to England.

Brazilian midfielder Edu claims he will be off to Highbury for a medical within 48 hours. "I did not expect the deal to happen," the 22-year-old said. "I've never played for the national team and I've only been in the Corinthians first team for four months."

Arsenal cannot be certain of gaining a work permit for Edu, but manager Arsene Wenger believes he will be a good signing. "Edu is a very talented player who can fit in most areas of midfield", he told the Sun.

David Pleat has confirmed that Spurs are interested in Schalke O4's Belgian striker Emile Mpenza. "I can confirm that Mpenza is one of a number of young players that we are closely monitoring during Euro 2000", he said. Mpenza scored one goal in a disappointing tournament for Belgium.

Despite Bryan Robson's protestations to the contrary, the Mirror believes that German wing-back Christian Ziege has a clause in his contract that allows him to speak to any club that makes a bid of £5m or more. Liverpool are set to make such an offer, the paper reports. Yesterday Robson told the press: "There's not one player at this club who's got a clause that lets him out in any shape or form."

Mark Draper is in talks with Southampton over a £1.5m move to the South coast. Teamtalk believe a deal for the out-of-favour midfielder will be completed in days.

The CS Maritimo player, known as Bruno, had been expected to move to Spain, but Bobby Robson's contacts in Portugal appear to have persuaded the player to move to England. Brazilian midfielder Edu claims he will be off to Highbury for a medical within 48 hours. "I did not expect the deal to happen," the 22-year-old said. "I've never played for the national team and I've only been in the Corinthians first team for four months." "Edu is a very talented player who can fit in most areas of midfield", he told the Sun. David Pleat has confirmed that Spurs are interested in Schalke O4's Belgian striker Emile Mpenza. "I can confirm that Mpenza is one of a number of young players that we are closely monitoring during Euro 2000", he said. Mpenza scored one goal in a disappointing tournament for Belgium. Liverpool are set to make such an offer, the paper reports. Yesterday Robson told the press: "There's not one player at this club who's got a clause that lets him out in any shape or form." Mark Draper is in talks with Southampton over a £1.5m move to the South coast. Teamtalk believe a deal for the out-of-favour midfielder will be completed in days.
