Joint statement from Buckingham Palace and St James's Palace
The press complaints commission
The British monarchy
fields.trailText: The Queen and the Prince of Wales welcome Lord Wakeham's speech about Prince William this morning.
fields.body:
The Queen and the Prince of Wales welcome Lord Wakeham's speech about Prince William this morning.

In setting out clear guidelines for the future - which would apply equally to other young people in a similar position - the press complaints commission is building on the restraint shown by newspapers and magazines to Prince William and Prince Harry while they have been at school.

In explaining the terms of the editors' code, Lord Wakeham's speech underlines the importance of personal privacy for all young people - but at the same time recognises the special position of Prince William and the legitimate public interest in him.

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.trailText: Gucci Baby collection
fields.body:
Baby's first stilettoes
It's amazing how het up we get about designer baby gear. The sheepskin Bill Amberg baby sling modelled by Brooklyn Beckham last year aroused a level of self-righteous indignation quite disproportionate to the seriousness of the crime: a wealthy family spending a silly amount of money on a fashion accessory. A similar amount spent on a pair of Chanel sunglasses would not provoke the same reaction, after all. But shopping for baby is a taste danger zone, because you risk being accused of using your child as a status symbol.

Now Gucci is about to sashay into the fray with its Gucci Baby collection, to be launched next month, which includes these red satin high heels small enough for newborns. Before you get apoplectic, they are not designed to be worn, but are purely for display. For a mere £50, you can buy your favourite baby girl a truly memorable gift: My First Stilettoes.

Cute, amusing or bad taste? They are too bizarre to be as adorable as baby Nikes, and there is something a little weird about giving a baby a gift that has such a strong association with womanly glamour. But rich babies have, for years, been given engraved spoons from Asprey & Garrard - as impractical as high heels, so to sneer at one but not the other is mere snobbery.

As a long-term shoe addict, I'd be wary of inculcating this expensive condition by dangling a pair of gorgeous flimsy shoes in front of impressionable babes. My advice would be to give the kid a rattle and save Gucci shoes for someone who'll appreciate them. But the real point of this gift, presumably, is to upstage all other gift-bearers. And you should be safe on that front - unless, of course, someone else gives the little one the Gucci Baby mink coat (£2,755).

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.standfirst: New York worries about Woody's allegiances, France and Germany join to create richer film culture,  Lord of the Rings fraud case in court, and Sixth Sense director to pen Indiana Jones 4, and, on the casting couch, Robert Duvall and Gwyneth Paltrow
fields.trailText: New York worries about Woody's allegiances, France and Germany join to create richer film culture, Lord of the Rings fraud case in court, and Sixth Sense director to pen Indiana Jones 4, and, on the casting couch, Robert Duvall and Gwyneth Paltrow
fields.body:
New York City officials are expressing concern that Woody Allen's growing ties with Hollywood could see the auteur abandon his New York base. The director has recently signed a three-picture deal with Speilberg's DreamWorks studio, which released his current US release Small Time Crooks. "He seems pretty dedicated to New York", says Mitchell Brill of the NY Production Alliance, "but do I worry he might someday work elsewhere? Sure."

The culture ministers of Germany and France have announced the formation of the German-French Film Academy, whose task will be to boost the popularity of homegrown films in both countries: French and German films currently make up only 1% of each other's markets. "The state cannot produce geniuses, or sway the public taste one way or the other, but it can help create conditions for a richer film culture," said German culture minister Michael Naumann. The new body will seek to increase co-productions between the two Countries, improve distribution and marketing of French pictures in Germany and vice versa, create joint educational opportunities for film students; and work together to preserve the nations' cinematic heritage. Members of the Academy include directors Luc Besson and Volker Schlondorff, and actress Jeanne Moreau.

A 36-year-old stuntman has appeared in the Auckland District Court on four charges relating to the Lord of the Rings film production, reports the New Zealand Herald. The man is accused of making a VHS videotape copy containing footage from the long-awaited fantasy epic, and of "dealing in a reproduction of the film footage with intent to defraud".

Steven Spielberg and George Lucas have recruited M Night Shyamalan, director of 1999 smash The Sixth Sense, to pen the long-awaited Indiana Jones 4. Industry mag Variety notes that "the campaign to draft the inventive Shyamalan indicates the trio is serious about putting the film into production sometime in 2002."

Casting couch

Robert Duvall will quiz Denzel Washington in John Q. Duvall will play a police detective who must negotiate with Washington's character, who takes a hospital hostage because his son needs a heart transplant.

Four Weddings and a Funeral director Mike Newell may be teaching Gwyneth Paltrow How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days. The romantic comedy tells the story of a womaniser who bets he can stay with a woman longer than 10 days, only to discover that he's dating a woman who wants to dump him.

webTitle: Break into the movies and break the labour rules

fields.headline: Break into the movies and break the labour rules
fields.trailText: A new film project, Who Wants to be a Movie Star?, was designed to sell speaking roles and behind-the-scenes jobs on an as-yet unnamed film to the highest online bidder has been censured by the California Labor Commission
fields.body:
A new film project spearheaded by major movie players such as the prestigious William Morris Agency, Yahoo! Auctions and the Blockbuster video chain has been censured by the California Labor Commission, according to trade paper The Hollywood Reporter. The project, called Who Wants to Be a Movie Star? came under fire only hours after its launch yesterday at a news conference in Beverly Hills, California.

The website Who Wants to be a Movie Star? was designed to sell speaking roles and behind-the-scenes jobs on an as-yet unnamed film to the highest online bidder. The scheme now looks unlikely to reach fruition, and the site was down for much of yesterday (although it is up again at time of writing), as the California Labor commissioner's office investigates what it calls the "totally illegal" practice of selling jobs. "It's a dead-on violation of the state labor code", said Mark Locker, chief counsel for the commissioner, who said he wants the bidding to "cease immediately".

"We have looked into this," Locker said of the site. "Based on what we saw on the web page, the law is being violated. We are making calls today to get this project discontinued. We would like them to post on the web page that the bidding is discontinued. We want them to do it immediately. We are trying to get this thing stopped as soon as possible to ensure that any jobs on this motion picture project are given to people without charging those people one cent for those jobs." If the bidding is not stopped, Locker said, "there will be legal action taken".

fields.headline: Fox zaps failed cartoon wing
fields.trailText: 20th Century Fox is closing down its animation wing, only six years after it opened with the intention of usurping Disney as cartoon king
fields.body:
20th Century Fox is closing down its animation wing, only six years after it opened with the intention of usurping Disney as cartoon king. The decision to close the Phoenix-based Fox Animation Studios comes after the disastrous box-office performance of Fox's Titan A.E (pictured), which has taken a mere $16.9m in the States in two weeks. The sci-fi cartoon, aimed specifically at male teenagers, stars Matt Damon and Drew Barrymore. It cost a reported $100m to make.

During its six-year existence, the studio only produced two movies - Titan A.E. and Anastasia, about the adventures of the daughter of the last Russian tzar. Both films met with reasonable responses from the critics, but failed to match the artistry or - crucially - the box-office appeal of Disney's animated pics such as the hugely successful Toy Story films.

Fox laid off two-thirds of the staff at its animation plant in February, but now everyone will go - including heads Don Bluth and Gary Goldman (An American Tail, All Dogs Go To Heaven), who have both made a career out of trying to compete with Disney in the animation field.

webTitle: Revived Franco-German axis rings alarm bells in London

fields.headline: Revived Franco-German axis rings alarm bells in London
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: France's clarion call for a "pioneering group" of EU member states puts new pressure on Tony Blair to accept the idea of a two-speed Europe in which Britain, especially a Britain outside the single currency, could find itself in the slow lane.
fields.body:
France's clarion call for a "pioneering group" of EU member states puts new pressure on Tony Blair to accept the idea of a two-speed Europe in which Britain, especially a Britain outside the single currency, could find itself in the slow lane.

Speaking on a state visit to Berlin yesterday, President Jacques Chirac went further than ever before in signalling France's desire for flexibility inside the EU, which some in Germany's leadership also want to allow integrationist-minded member states to strike out on their own.

Defence and security policy, cooperation in the fight against crime and, most significantly, economic coordination, were all areas where Mr Chirac said a core group should be able to forge ahead.

Britain is already a leader, together with France, on European defence. But its self-imposed exclusion from the euro-zone sets it apart in a key area.

The French leader's call for an EU constitution will cause alarm in Britain, but more because it gives ammunition to Eurosceptics than because it poses an immediate practical problem.

Drawing up a constitution for Europe is not on anyone's immediate agenda. It is not an issue for tomorrow, but the day after tomorrow.

British officials believe that France and Germany have seized on flexibility as a way of reviving their recently wobbly axis, once the drive-shaft of European integration.

Strikingly however, France has repeatedly made clear in recent days - as it prepares for the start of its six-month stint in the EU's rotating presidency on Saturday - that at the moment it wants to focus practically on a modest but difficult reform agenda.

Between now and the Treaty of Nice, due to be completed by the end of the French term in December, the EU's 15 member states are supposed to agree on new national voting weights for group decisions, the number of commissioners they send to Brussels, and reducing the use of the veto in order to increase majority voting.

All these changes are necessary to avoid institutional paralysis when the union expands. Up to 12 states are anxious to join after 2003.

But the French president's focus on flexibility, or "reinforced cooperation", as Euro-jargon puts it, worries Britain - as well as sceptical Danes, Swedes and others.

"Those countries that want to proceed further with integration, on a voluntary basis and in specific areas, must be allowed to do so without being held back by those who, with every right, do not want to proceed as quickly," Mr Chirac told Germany's parliament, the Bundestag.

"Together with Germany and France, they could form a pioneering group," he suggested, citing the euro as one "success" already achieved by the 11 EU members who belong to the single currency; Greece is about to become the 12th.

Britain agreed that reinforced cooperation could be on the agenda for the inter-governmental conference due to culminate at Nice.

But Mr Blair is certain to insist on keeping the so-called emergency brake procedure - a restriction obtained by Britain in the 1997 Amsterdam treaty - though minor modifications are not ruled out.

Foreign Office officials say they could accept that moves involving more pooling of national sovereignty would have in future to be blocked by two member states, instead of one as now.

London's greatest and largely unspoken fear is that if closer cooperation is made any easier, the euro zone countries may move to harmonise taxation and budgetary policies, making a British decision on the single currency tougher than it already is.

Flexibility cannot, by definition, apply to the EU's single market, arguably its most important practical achievement.

Britain's public position is that it does not want to create a two-speed Europe at precisely the moment newcomers like Poland and Hungary are set to join.

Faced with the mounting evidence of a big Franco-German-led push on flexibility, Mr Blair's strategy will be to press hard on enlargement and work closely with the Swedes, who take over the EU presidency in the first half of next year.

He will also build on tactical alliances with Spain, Portugal, Belgium and Ireland on the structural economic reforms the EU so badly needs if it is to compete with the US.

Last week's EU summit at Feira in Portugal saw Mr Blair forced on to the defensive about his intentions on the euro.

And it was reported that he had been told by Mr Chirac and Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, that a two-speed Europe already existed, and Britain was definitely in the slow lane.

webTitle: Leading German banks plan swift full-scale merger

fields.headline: Leading German banks plan swift full-scale merger
fields.standfirst: Dresdner-Commerzbank to link
fields.trailText: Dresdner and Commerzbank are poised to deliver plans for a full-scale merger before the end of July at the latest, according to Frankfurt banking sources. They say uncertainties among both staff and customers are forcing the banks to press ahead as fast as possible.
fields.body:
Dresdner and Commerzbank are poised to deliver plans for a full-scale merger before the end of July at the latest, according to Frankfurt banking sources. They say uncertainties among both staff and customers are forcing the banks to press ahead as fast as possible.

"There are too many question marks. The customers want to know what is going on, too. The boards know they have to come up with some answers as soon as they can," said one source. Dresdner chief executive Bernd Fahrholz confirmed yesterday that the banks were working to a tight timetable. "It is clear that we want to come to an agreement," he said.

Initially talks between the German banks were expected to proceed at a relatively leisurely pace and it was expected that they would focus on putting together individual parts of the businesses rather than a full-scale merger.

"They have decided that if they are going to ahead they might as well go for a 100% merger," the same source said.

That could help to explain why Commerzbank was not included in this week's initiative from France's Credit Lyonnaise for the creation of a pan-European investment banking joint venture involving its most important banking shareholders - except the German bank.

Both Commerzbank and Dresdner are facing additional but separate pressures. Dresdner - which saw its earlier plans to merge with Deutsche Bank fall apart over what would happen to its investment banking business Dresdner Kleinwort Benson - would be hard pressed to explain another failure.

For its part, Commerzbank has seen the Rebon investment fund build up a 17% stake. Though Rebon says it wants to be helpful, its approach - including musing publicly about the value of various parts of the bank's operations - has not gone down well with Commerzbank.

One key to the outcome of the merger talks is likely to be the attitude of Henning Schulte-Noelle, the president of the Munich based insurer Allianz which holds a 21.7% stake in Dresdner Bank.

Yesterday in an interview with Le Monde, Mr Schulte-Noelle said it was perfectly usual for banks to hold talks. As for Allianz, the insurer was "open to all alternatives".

Mr Schulte-Noelle expressed a preference for a "E uropean approach" to banking mergers, however, and said he was surprised that German banks had not taken the lead in cross border mergers in Europe.

The Munich-based insurer holds a strong position within the ownership structure of German banking. In addition to its stake in Dresdner, it has a strategic holding of 17.4% in Germany's second biggest bank, HypoVereinsbank, as well as a 5% stake in Deutsche Bank.

webTitle: Police shoot Australian hostel fire suspect

fields.headline: Police shoot Australian hostel fire suspect
fields.trailText: Australian police today shot and arrested Robert Long, the man wanted for questioning over the backpackers' hostel fire that killed 15 people on Sunday.
fields.body:
Australian police today shot and arrested Robert Long, the man wanted for questioning over the backpackers' hostel fire that killed 15 people on Sunday.

Mr Long, 37, an itinerant fruit picker, was tracked by police dogs in bush land six miles from the charred remains of the Palace Backpackers' hostel in Childers, near Brisbane. According to police reports Mr Long was shot in the arm after he lunged at officers with a knife.

He was taken to a hospital in Maryborough, 150 miles north of Brisbane.

Mr Long's injuries are not life-threatening and he will be interviewed by police after medical treatment, a police spokesman said. The police stepped up efforts to find Mr Long yesterday after reports that he had been spotted close to the burned-out hostel. Two police officers tracked the suspect's scent with dogs through the bush until they came to a scrub where it is believed he had been hiding since Friday.

Bill Trevor, the mayor of Childers, said that the town would be relieved that an arrest had been made. "We can now get on to the next step in the process," he said. "We hope Robert Long can shed some light on the terrible fire in the Palace but we must remember that our justice system means we have to give him the benefit of the doubt."

The Queensland state government announced today that it would tighten fire safety regulations at backpacker hostels in the wake of the blaze.

Fourteen of the 15 people who died were trapped in two adjoining rooms, unable to escape because their doors opened to an area above a stairwell that was at the centre of the inferno.

The fire killed six Britons, one Irish national, four Australians, two Dutch, one Korean and one Japanese. fields.bodyText: Australian police today shot and arrested Robert Long, the man wanted for questioning over the backpackers' hostel fire that killed 15 people on Sunday. Mr Long, 37, an itinerant fruit picker, was tracked by police dogs in bush land six miles from the charred remains of the Palace Backpackers' hostel in Childers, near Brisbane. Mr Long's injuries are not life-threatening and he will be interviewed by police after medical treatment, a police spokesman said. The police stepped up efforts to find Mr Long yesterday after reports that he had been spotted close to the burned-out hostel. Two police officers tracked the suspect's scent with dogs through the bush until they came to a scrub where it is believed he had been hiding since Friday. Bill Trevor, the mayor of Childers, said that the town would be relieved that an arrest had been made. "We can now get on to the next step in the process," he said. "We hope Robert Long can shed some light on the terrible fire in the Palace but we must remember that our justice system means we have to give him the benefit of the doubt." The Queensland state government announced today that it would tighten fire safety regulations at backpacker hostels in the wake of the blaze. webTitle: Hurley on Hugh: 'There was something lacking'

fields.headline: Hurley on Hugh: 'There was something lacking'
fields.trailText: Liz Hurley has spoken publicly for the first time about her split from the floppy-haired partner on whose back she rode to fame, Hugh Grant.
fields.body:
Liz Hurley has spoken publicly for the first time about her split from the floppy-haired partner on whose back she rode to fame, Hugh Grant.

Gossiping in an interview with Talk magazine, Hurley, 35, claimed that she was the one who instituted the break-up, which she likened to "amputating my left arm". However, the rupture was one both she and Grant knew was inevitable. She also said - contradicting earlier reports that the split was temporary - that she now doubts they will get back together.

The 13-year relationship began when the two were relative unknowns and survived first Grant's post-Four Weddings rise to stardom and later his seedy dalliance with a prostitute on Sunset Boulevard. Hurley claims still to love the Notting Hill star "passionately", but added that, "I think we've both been unhappy for some time. Our separation is us trying to discover if what we've had is indeed as good as it gets.

"Ultimately we realised that there had to be something lacking, because after 13 years together we still didn't really want to get married and start a family," said Liz. Of the future, she said, "I'd love to be swept off my feet and to gallop wildly into the sunset," - presumably on a horse and not on her own two legs.

fields.headline: Terry Venables wants you!
fields.trailText: Uefa's (longwinded) England debrief; Tel's big pleb; Karel Poborsky has a head on
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"Portugal are in the last four because they have no weaknesses. They should be regarded as the favourites against France," French coach Roger Lemerre. Listen, this self-deprecating thing can go too far you know.

THE EURO-TORIAL

It must be a great job being a Uefa official. Swanning around all the most glamorous football matches, denouncing hooligans, inventing new formats for the Champions League - the fun never stops. So it's not surprising to find that the agents of European football's governing body have also taken to offering their advice to Kevin Keegan.

According to reports, Uefa officials have published a report on every side knocked out of Euro 2000 and published them on their website (www.euro2000.org). Not that you can see them yet. In their assessment of England's performance, the unnamed assessors spare no blows. Or long words.

"For England the lessons of yesterday never seem to impact on the fevered anticipation of tomorrow", Wilhelm Wordsworth writes, explaining that the expectations of supporters and media alike were too high. "Unwisely," he/she continued, "Kevin Keegan added to the delusion."

Not only that, according to the report, M. Keegan "did not know his best formation, yet alone his best team." He wanted to bring Steve McManaman into the side "but could not find a way to do it successfully." He also arrived in Belgium without "a decent left-back" (that means you Phil Neville) while he "continued to overlook Nigel Winterburn."

The Euro is in full agreement with the bureaucrats of Nyon, especially when it comes to the veteran Arsenal full-back who has been ignored by England coaches for years. But if all their reports can tell us is what was perfectly obvious to everyone with a flickering TV screen, then perhaps Uefa should stick to canapes.

TEL 'EM HOW YOU FEEL!

Terry Venables has exclusively revealed to this morning's Daily Mail that he would consider taking the England job on again (the doll). El Al Tel told the venerable Jeff Powell that he wanted the job, but only if the people wanted him too. "This is the people's game, so let them decide," he said. "My wife, bright lady that she is, came up with the idea of a plebiscite. If Tony Blair can hold a referendum on the single currency, why not have one to pick the England coach?"

Too right, and that's why this morning the Euro is pushing forward with plans for Tel Pleb 2000, and would welcome applications for the following positions:

1) Executive ballot-printer. In this role, you would print 40m voting slips offering the English public the chance to select "A: your mate Tel" or "B: some loser". Salary - negotiable. Sorry, negligible.

2) Official door knocker. Charged with knocking on every door in England and asking: "You want Tel back don't you? Guv'nor?" this role is vital to the success of the plebiscite. Salary - yes.

3) FA executive committee assassinator-in-chief. A vital role, as executing the entire FA is about the only way Tell will get his old job back. Salary - what do you mean you want paying?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. And £200 behind the bar. perfect. Win a £200 bar tab for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Emmanuel Petit will be fit for this evening's semi-final against Portugal after recovering from a knee injury. He is expected to reclaim his place in Roger Lemerre's starting XI with either Christophe Dugarry or Youri Djorkaeff stepping down. Although squeezing Dugarry and Djorkaeff into the same jersey has not yet been ruled out.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi, it's Marko Schmerz here, Karel Poborsky's alcohol dependency counsellor. Karel has a tender head on today after his 48-hour bender in a cottage in Plzen. So he's asked me to deal with today's transfer rumours. Which unfortunately I can't do without interpreting them in a psycho-sexual manner.

Aston Villa want Nuno Gomes, and boss John Gregory is prepared to splash £12m on the three-goal Portuguese striker. Which obviously reveals that the Midlands club has a deep underlying hatred of self, which can only be dulled by spending huge amounts of cash. And it wants to have sex with West Bromwich Albion.

Former world player of the year George Weah has been linked with a return to Monaco. An official at the club said: "The two positive points are; first he won't cost a single Franc, because his contract with Milan has ended, and secondly, he could rejoin his former team-mate, Marco Simone." What he did not say was that he has a deep irreconcilable attraction towards his mother. But I could see it in his eyes.

Must go. I have Stanley Collymore arriving at half past. Ciao.

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

ITV: Euro 2000 Live (7.30) Is Des God?

BBC 1: MOTD@Euro 2000 Portugal v France. (11.50) Not according to the Reverend Dion Dublin. This evening's homily: "Alan Shearer must play for England." Again.

BBC 1: Euro 2000 Replay. (12.55) And then he does it again. Only for longer. And half way through Ray Stubbs delivers holy communion.

ITV Euro 2000: The Big Match (1.40) It's way past midnight, so DJ Whisperin' Bob Wilson gets out his moog and plays some ambient Gallic tunes. Smooth.

fields.headline: Government offers post office lifeline
fields.trailText: Subsidies will be offered to post offices to help keep them open under a government rescue package announced today.
fields.body:
Subsidies will be offered to post offices to help keep them open under a government rescue package announced today.

Offices in deprived urban areas will be offered help as part of a drive to expand services and keep the 18,500-strong network intact.

The Post Office will be encouraged to continue with its strategy of offering financial services, including banking facilities.

Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers is expected to announce the government's response to a report by the Cabinet office performance and innovation unit on the future of the service.

Recent attention has focused on the threat to rural post offices, especially after 2003 when benefits will be paid directly into bank accounts, hitting around a third of post offices' business.

But Mr Byers believes that offices in urban deprived areas face exactly the same problems.

Subsidies are likely to be offered to keep post offices open and help improve services.

Plans will also be published to make it harder for post offices to close.

The Cabinet Office report is believed to find that the Post Office has been slow to modernise, and will be pressed to seize new business opportunities, such as e-commerce and handling mail order goods.

Ministers will point out that around 2.5 million people do not have a bank account, so many of them could be offered the chance to pay bills or council taxes at their local post office.

fields.headline: Chirac pushes EU changes
fields.standfirst:
President woos Germany with 'pioneer group' proposal
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: President Jacques Chirac of France moved yesterday to reassure French and German voters that their two countries still dominate the EU's agenda when he used a speech in Berlin to call for closer integration for those member states which want it.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Berlin  and  Michael White  in London
fields.body:
President Jacques Chirac of France moved yesterday to reassure French and German voters that their two countries still dominate the EU's agenda when he used a speech in Berlin to call for closer integration for those member states which want it.

Mr Chirac's use of the phrase "pioneer group" to describe his plan for setting up an inner core of states next year raised renewed Eurosceptic alarm in London at the prospect of a two-speed Europe - with Britain left in the slow lane.

But neither Downing Street nor the Foreign Office took fright at the speech, which they saw as more concerned to persuade voters at home that the Franco-German axis is still a force to be reckoned with despite recent difficulties. "This is not about us," said one senior official.

Two days before Mr Blair dines with Chancellor Gerhard Schröder in Berlin, the French president used a speech to the newly restored Reichstag to echo themes which both leaders and their foreign ministers have explored in recent weeks - how to make the EU cope with the long-term consequences of enlargement from 15 to 20 or more members.

In a speech to the lower house of the German parliament, Mr Chirac declared: "The countries which want to go further towards integration...ought to be able to do so without being held back by those who - and it is their right - do not wish to go ahead so quickly".

The president stressed that he remained opposed to any form of political union that swamped the nation states, let alone a United States of Europe.

And he made clear that his proposed "inner core" of EU states would not - initially at least - deal with the big issues of constitutional and institutional reform. The EU is already grappling with an inter-governmental conference (IGC), due to end at Nice in December, on ways of streamlining decison-making when the numbers increase.

Enlargement to the south and east is fraught with difficulties, not least for France and Germany which fear cheap labour and cheap farm produce as well as the hunch that Britain - and newer EU members - want to use the newcomers to "dilute" the EU into a looser arrangement.

Mr Chirac's speech was being seen in London last night as a counter to that fear, suggesting that the original "common market" six states could pursue closer union, though Italy is conspicuously absent from involvement in such talk.

Mr Blair's spokesman said later: "We are completely comfortable with the debate about the future of Europe. This is something the prime minister is playing a part in, and when we are talking about groups of states being able to go ahead together in co-operating in particular areas - that already happens."

But there were several aspects of the Chirac plan which may set alarm bells ringing in London and elsewhere because they smack of a "two-speed" mentality in which the same states do all the core cooperation.

Mr Chirac's pioneer group would aim to co-ordinate the economic policies of its members. It would have its own secretariat, "responsible for ensuring the consistency of the positions and policies of the members of the group" and, the member states of the inner core would be free to reach agreements outside the 1957 Treaty of Rome.

President Chirac said Germany and France should be among the founders of the pioneer group and that countries which wanted to join should be free to do so.

fields.headline: Prisoners prepare with fake euros
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: It may not be the first test release of the single currency, but it is probably the most tightly controlled. This week inmates of a Cordoba jail are receiving their allowances in euros.
fields.body:
It may not be the first test release of the single currency, but it is probably the most tightly controlled. This week inmates of a Cordoba jail are receiving their allowances in euros.

However, the economic experiment does not offer much temptation to jailed robbers or fraudsters since the currency replacing the peseta is in the form of cardboard facsimiles.

But the scheme may help the inmates to steal a march on their countrymen by enabling them to prepare in advance for the currency which enters circulation in most of Europe on January 1, 2002.

For the past month, the inmates of Cordoba's provincial prison in southern Spain have been receiving instructions on the euro in adult education classes and this week they put their lessons into practice at a two-day workshop.

The majority of the 550 inmates had little idea about the new currency. "We realised that most of them arrived here knowing only the peseta, and they would leave jail still knowing the peseta unless we taught them about the new currency," said Joaquin Morato, one of seven full-time teachers in the prison.

"It was all very well teaching them about the idea of the euro, but many wanted to see for themselves how it would really work," Mr Morato said. And so, the teachers and a group of pupils decided to set up a market in the prison yard, where all transactions would be carried out in euros.

"We received donations of items like soft drinks, coffee, soap and stationery from local shops and businesses. The local tax office made its own donation in the form of a sack of cardboard facsimile euros, enough for each prisoner to receive 12 euros to spend at the stalls," he said.

Mr Morato said: "The inmates came along to the yard in groups of 15 and they all thoroughly enjoyed the experience. They entered into the spirit and have been treating it like a fiesta."

fields.headline: The boy wonder
fields.standfirst: She earns more than the Spice Girls. But JK Rowling is not the only one making a mint out of her adolescent wizard. As the world awaits publication of The Goblet of Fire, John Cassy and Stephen Moss find out who's cashing in on Harry
fields.trailText: She earns more than the Spice Girls. But JK Rowling is not the only one making a mint out of her adolescent wizard. As the world awaits publication of The Goblet of Fire, John Cassy and Stephen Moss find out who's cashing in on Harry
fields.body:
By some appropriately magical alchemy, the new Harry Potter book is both the most hyped and the most secretive project the publishing industry has ever known. The book, which will be published by Bloomsbury on July 8, is already setting records in internet sales, 1.5 million copies will initially be printed in the UK, and 3.8 million in the US (where it is published by Scholastic). Yet no one has read it or even seen it. The television footage screened this week of books being delivered to Amazon was bogus; it will not be distributed to bookshops and warehouses until the day before publication.

For months, the editor at Bloomsbury responsible for the book, Emma Matthewson, has had to keep its secrets to herself. The manuscript has been locked in a bank vault and even its title has been kept under wraps. It was called "Potter Four" in the trade - a suitably Hollywood-style title for the latest in a series that, in marketing clout at least, owes more to LA than Fitzrovia - and at least three plausible titles were in circulation. Bloomsbury finally confirmed yesterday that the book was to be called Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.

The mixture of mega-hype and massive secrecy isn't just a marketing ploy - the publishing equivalent of the dance of the seven veils. Beneath the surface, it is possible to detect unease at Bloomsbury at the sheer scale of the success of JK Rowling's Harry Potter series. "I ask you please not to go into the money," said Bloomsbury's chairman, Nigel Newton, last week. Newton and other directors at Bloomsbury are said to have received begging letters following reports of the success of Potter and its impact on the company's share price.

The first three Potter books have sold 35 million copies worldwide and rocketed Rowling into the earnings stratosphere. Last year, her income of £14.5m put her third in the list of UK women earners, behind two businesswomen but well ahead of assorted Spice Girls. Her royalties were £11.5m, advances £2m, and the sales of film rights brought in another £1m.

She receives royalties of 15-20% - more generous than the norm - on the cover price of her books. Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire will retail at £14.99 in the UK, so Rowling will receive around £4m from sales of the initial print run alone. Total UK sales of the first three books in the series stand at eight million, so further printings of The Goblet of Fire are highly likely. US sales of the first three books have been almost treble those of the UK (the US has accounted for 55% of global sales so far, the UK 20%), and Rowling can expect to net £7m-plus from the first printing in the US.

The rest of the world, though lagging behind the UK and US, is also beginning to catch the Potter bug. The books are available in 35 languages and the magic is especially potent in the vast markets of Japan and Germany, where it has topped the bestseller lists. Many countries are still catching up - most are on the second or third book, but China is only now about to publish the first - and The Goblet of Fire will initially only be published in the UK, US, Australia and Canada. But Rowling's agent, Christopher Little, says that the rest of the world is catching up fast, and that foreign-language editions will quickly start to account for a greater proportion of total sales.

Rowling, who is 34 and lives discreetly with her young daughter in Edinburgh, has created a money-making machine, and the editors at Penguin, Transworld and HarperCollins who turned down the original manuscript must suffer torments whenever they survey the latest sales figures. Publication of the new Potter is sure to give a fresh impetus to sales of the previous three, and, when Warner Bros eventually takes Harry to Hollywood, Rowling stands to make even more on merchandising. (She recently applied to register her name and signature as trademarks.) Even before the film, the toy-maker Mattel is planning a range of action figures and games based on the books.

"Harry Potter has changed the lives of everyone associated with it," says Little. "We thought it would do well, but we never imagined we would have a success on this scale. But Joanne is a consummate pro and has kept her feet on the ground."

She is, however, said to be concerned that the publicity surrounding her earnings will restrict her personal life, and perhaps make her, or her daughter, a target.

The series has been a bonanza for Bloomsbury, which has been transformed in the three years since the first book, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, was published in 1997. Shares in the company, which went public in 1993, have risen eightfold over the past two years, and turnover and profits have doubled. Most of the shares are in the hands of blue-chip investment companies such as the Prudential, Mercury Asset Management, Morgan Grenfell and Legal & General, but Newton himself retains almost 5% (currently worth more than £6m, up fivefold from December 1998 when Pottermania was still in its infancy).

Newton, who was born in California, is the son of a Financial Times journalist-turned-vineyard owner. He is 44, wears glasses and cardigans, and looks bookish, but he is seen within the industry as seriously entrepreneurial. He rose to prominence when he was at publishers Sidgwick & Jackson and with Bob Geldof put together the book for Live Aid in record time. In an era of mega-publishing mergers, Newton has built up a respected house which authors tend to feel is not too big and impersonal.

Potter is reckoned to account for more than 20% of Bloomsbury's turnover, and the attraction of such a big seller is that unit costs are kept down and profit per book maximised. Bloomsbury is likely to receive around 35% of the book's cover price, the retailer getting the remainder (though the latter's margins will be squeezed by discounting). Analysts believe Bloomsbury paid less than £10,000 for the first book, and it has the rights to the first seven Harry Potter books. (Rowling has so far been adamant that the seventh book will conclude the sequence.)

The danger for Bloomsbury is that it will become identified with Pottermania, to the exclusion of the rest of its list, which includes such luminaries as Michael Ondaatje, Will Self, John Irving, David Guterson and Joanna Trollope. Staff at the Soho-based publisher are keen to emphasise that there is more to the company than an adolescent wizard. "We are delighted and amazed that the success goes on," says one. "But it is not the feeling in-house that we are just the publishers of Harry Potter. There are lots of people here who don't work on the series and they're producing really good books."

"We are very proud of Harry Potter," says Newton, "but we publish around 250 books a year across a wide range of subjects, and people were aware of us long before Potter." "There is no doubt that Harry Potter is a phenomenon," says Malcolm Morgan of stockbrokers Williams de Broe. "But he is only four years old. One can only hope that he has the longevity of CS Lewis."

webTitle: Elian can return to Cuba tonight

fields.headline: Elian can return to Cuba tonight
fields.standfirst: Key players in the Elian saga
fields.trailText: The US supreme court has allowed six-year-old Elian Gonzalez, who survived a boat journey from Cuba in which his mother died, to go home with his father.
fields.body:
The US supreme court has allowed six-year-old Elian Gonzalez, who survived a boat journey from Cuba in which his mother died, to go home with his father.

The court rejected a formal appeal filed by the boy's Miami relatives and a separate emergency request aimed at postponing his departure. Its action was announced in a brief order.

He will be able to fly home with his father from 9pm tonight. The order, in its entirety, read: "The application for stay presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the court is denied. The petition for a writ of certoriari (the appeal) is denied."

Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, is finalising plans take Elian and his family home on a chartered flight to Havana, set to leave the Washington area this evening, when the original court order barring their departure is expires.

Elian will also be accompanied by an entourage of Cuban compatriots, including classmates who joined him in April.

Reverend Joan Brown Campbell, former general secretary of the National Council of Churches, one of the sources of money used to pay the father's legal bills, said Elian had not specifically been told that he could be flying back to Cuba today.

"My overwhelming impression is that no one is talking to him about going home," Campbell said. "I don't think his father is going to talk about this until they're sure they're going."

Elian has been the centre of a bitter court battle between his father in Cuba and Cuban relatives in Miami since surviving the boat journey from Cuba.

For Cuban President Fidel Castro, getting Elian back from the US has been a priority. Elian's case has become a rallying point for anti-Castro sentiments in the United States, particularly in Miami's Cuban exile districts.

Elian stayed with his Miami relatives until federal agents seized him on April 22 and turned him over to his father in Washington pending the court appeals.

It is unclear what will happen to Elian when he is returned to Cuba with his father. He may fall back into a routine life of school and friends, but his Miami relatives, who have fought in court for six months to keep him in the United States, contended in court that he will be exploited and persecuted by the Castro dictatorship.

The US justice department has said it has found no evidence that that is likely to happen.

All along, the Miami relatives have said that the immigration service erred in not granting Elian the right to apply for political asylum. Immigration officials have consistently maintained that the desire of Elian's father to repatriate the boy to Cuba must be respected, a position backed by a succession of court rulings.

webTitle: Elian heads for flight back to Cuba

fields.headline: Elian heads for flight back to Cuba
fields.standfirst: Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: Cuban castaway Elian Gonzalez began his journey home to Cuba on Wednesday after the  US Supreme Court ended a custody war that came to symbolise four decades of bitterness between Cuban exiles and the  communist country they fled.
fields.body:
Cuban castaway Elian Gonzalez began his journey home to Cuba on Wednesday after the US Supreme Court ended a custody war that came to symbolise four decades of bitterness between Cuban exiles and the communist country they fled.

The 6-year-old and his family were accompanied in a motorcade from the estate where they were staying in Washington to nearby Dulles international airport where a charter plane was waiting to take them to Havana.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez, whose car was tracked by television cameras aboard helicopters en route to the airport, said through his lawyer he was relieved the seven-month custody battle with his Miami relatives was finally over. "Juan Miguel is happy that his family is together, safe and now free to go home. The legal battle is over," said the statement released by lawyer Gregory Craig.

"The family will now make immediate arrangements to return to their home," the statement added.

A sniffer dog was seen checking the plane that would take the Gonzalez family back to Cuba and officials said they would be free to leave once they had gone through customs. The father was expected to make a short statement before their departure.

The boy with the impish grin who survived a dramatic shipwreck that claimed his mother's life, shined a spotlight not only on US-Cuban tensions, but also on the rights of parents to make decisions for their children.

The highest court in the land rejected without comment or dissent an emergency request by Elian's Miami relatives seeking to keep the boy in the United States and also turned down an appeal seeking a political asylum hearing for him.

The court's action ended bitter legal wrangling over the child's fate in a politically charged case that began when he was rescued from the ocean off Florida last November after surviving a shipwreck in which his mother and 10 others died.

Elian was reunited with his father on April 22 after armed federal agents seized him from his Miami relatives' home in a dramatic dawn raid in which the screaming child was seen being taken from the house.

Hours later, happier pictures were released of Elian with his father, who had come from Cuba in early April to claim custody of his son from the Miami relatives, whom he accused of using the boy as a political tool against President Fidel Castro.

Attorney General Janet Reno, who comes from Miami and took a special interest in the case, said she was pleased the Supreme Court had declined to review the Elian case. "The law has provided a process, and this little boy now knows that he can remain with his father," Reno said in a statement.

"All involved have had an opportunity to make their case - all the way to the highest court in the land. I hope that everyone will accept the Supreme Court's decision and join me in wishing this family, and this special little boy, well."

Elian's great uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez was gazing at the ocean behind a bayfront church in Miami when he received word that the Supreme Court had refused to consider the case.

He turned angrily on a news crew trailing him, shouting at them to leave, while his daughter Marisleysis tugged at his arm and held him back. They and their lawyers planned a news conference later in the day.

Asked to comment on the case, President Bill Clinton said if the father had decided to stay in the United States with Elian that would have been "fine with him," adding he wished the case had unfolded in a less dramatic and traumatic way.

In Cuba, Castro's government reacted to the court's announcement with a call to Cubans to maintain their "serenity" and "discipline."

Meticulous arrangements were being made for Elian's Cuban relatives to receive him at Havana's international airport in a low-key ceremony intended to preserve family privacy.

The Miami relatives had looked after the boy since he was found by fishermen floating on an inner tube off the Florida coast on the U.S Thanksgiving holiday last November and launched a series of legal challenges to keep him in the United States.

They said they wanted him to grow up in freedom in the United States and refused to send him back to live with his father under communist rule in Cuba. Republican presidential candidate George W. Bush voiced dismay about the Supreme Court's decision.

"I'm disappointed he is going back to Cuba," Bush said aboard his campaign plane in Cleveland. "Hopefully he will go down to a Cuba that becomes free someday and will be able to come back to America at his own choice."

The National Council of Churches, which became involved in the case at the request of the Cuban Council of Churches, said it was delighted that Elian was on his way home.

"The courts of our land have done the right thing is saying that Juan Miguel Gonzalez is the only one entitled to speak for his son," said Rev. Robert Edgar, general secretary of the National Council of Churches.

Sally Grooms Cowal, president of Youth for Understanding, which owns the property where Elian stayed, said the child and his family had thanked them for their hospitality. She said the group gave Elian a tour book on Washington, D.C., a globe, a pencil and an American flag. Elian's family reportedly gave them a Cuban flag.

webTitle: Holland's Ian Wright has given us the chance to make history

fields.headline: Holland's Ian Wright has given us the chance to make history
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: The way I see it, Patrick is hungry for goals and I am the person feeding that appetite.
fields.body:
Ever since our quarter-final demolition of Yugoslavia, all the talk has been about my team-mate Patrick Kluivert. As a strike partnership, Patrick and myself are in hot form at the moment - our understanding is just so strong. It has been growing and improving steadily since he burst on to the international scene six years ago, and now it's at its peak.

We just seem to know instinctively what the other player is going to do. He's a natural finisher, with the killer instinct of a true marksman in front of goal.

Even once we are four goals ahead, Patrick is always looking to get more goals. His desire is never satisfied. I don't have that same killer instinct which is why I am more than happy fulfiling the creative half of the partnership. The way I see it, Patrick is hungry for goals and I am the person feeding that appetite.

It's impossible to explain why some strike partnerships click and others do not. I think a large part of it is down to instinct rather than preparation or coaching. I formed fantastic partnerships with players like Ian Wright, Nicolas Anelka and Thierry Henry, all of whom are quick and thrived on me feeding them balls to chase.

Patrick isn't like that. He is more dependent on his physical strength and expert timing. But he does remind me of Wright when I see the hunger in his eyes as he tears away celebrating a goal. You can see he lives for scoring goals, any type of goal. He is just as happy with a tap-in as he is with a wonder goal from 30 yards out.

I get on well with Patrick off the pitch as well. He is outgoing and you could almost call him the Dutch Ian Wright. He has a similar sense of humour and loves his soul music - you often hear him singing away to himself. I reckon he could release a record one day.

Speaking of which, Patrick will probably be the man to break my record as all time top scorer for the Dutch national team with 37 goals, so it is ironic that I am the man supplying him with the chances to do just that.

Still, how could I begrudge Patrick that opportunity? He is a fantastic player to have in our team and it's largely down to his goals that we've got this far in the tournament. My record will be broken one day and I can't think of anyone I'd like to see break it more than Patrick.

A goal tomorrow would be a good start. I made my international debut against Italy in 1990 and then two years later I remember scoring twice against them. Of course I also had an interesting period in the Italian league with Internazionale before I moved to Arsenal. So you could say I have a bit of history with Italian football.

I don't like games like this because the way I play, I'm always looking to find space so I can do my thing on the pitch. When I played with Internazionale against other Italian teams I never got an inch of space from defenders.

They fought for every ball and wouldn't leave me alone for a second. It will be the same tomorrow I'm sure. All we can do is try and stay true to our beliefs and style and hope that if we keep trying, eventually a break will come and we can win the game.

I don't think the Italians have any huge superstars we need to fear anymore - instead they have an extremely effective and fearsome unit. Each player does his job within that unit and they just set about trying to win each match they play rather than depending on one or two key stars.

I think supporters tend to fear one-off big name stars within the opposition but, as players, we will always be more scared of effective team units like Italy. It makes it much harder to beat them because you can't isolate one or two individuals. Instead you have to work against the whole team who will fight for each other and keep going until the end.

I think most neutrals prefer our style to that of the Italians. I have had telephone conversations with friends of mine back in England and they are telling me that it is Holland, rather than Italy, that most people want to see win. They have been telling me that we are now playing the best football in the tournament.

When you receive compliments like that from people outside your country, it gives you immense confidence as a player. We are the host nation and the people's choice - what a fantastic opportunity we have to make history.

For Dennis Bergkamp's Euro 2000 diary, go to his official website at icons.com

He is outgoing and you could almost call him the Dutch Ian Wright. He has a similar sense of humour and loves his soul music - you often hear him singing away to himself. I reckon he could release a record one day. Speaking of which, Patrick will probably be the man to break my record as all time top scorer for the Dutch national team with 37 goals, so it is ironic that I am the man supplying him with the chances to do just that. Still, how could I begrudge Patrick that opportunity? He is a fantastic player to have in our team and it's largely down to his goals that we've got this far in the tournament. My record will be broken one day and I can't think of anyone I'd like to see break it more than Patrick. A goal tomorrow would be a good start. I made my international debut against Italy in 1990 and then two years later I remember scoring twice against them. Of course I also had an interesting period in the Italian league with Internazionale before I moved to Arsenal. So you could say I have a bit of history with Italian football. I don't like games like this because the way I play, I'm always looking to find space so I can do my thing on the pitch. When I played with Internazionale against other Italian teams I never got an inch of space from defenders. They fought for every ball and wouldn't leave me alone for a second. It will be the same tomorrow I'm sure. All we can do is try and stay true to our beliefs and style and hope that if we keep trying, eventually a break will come and we can win the game. I don't think the Italians have any huge superstars we need to fear anymore - instead they have an extremely effective and fearsome unit. Each player does his job within that unit and they just set about trying to win each match they play rather than depending on one or two key stars. I think supporters tend to fear one-off big name stars within the opposition but, as players, we will always be more scared of effective team units like Italy. It makes it much harder to beat them because you can't isolate one or two individuals. Instead you have to work against the whole team who will fight for each other and keep going until the end. I think most neutrals prefer our style to that of the Italians. I have had telephone conversations with friends of mine back in England and they are telling me that it is Holland, rather than Italy, that most people want to see win. They have been telling me that we are now playing the best football in the tournament. When you receive compliments like that from people outside your country, it gives you immense confidence as a player. We are the host nation and the people's choice - what a fantastic opportunity we have to make history. For Dennis Bergkamp's Euro 2000 diary, go to his official website at icons.com

webTitle: US lifts food embargo on Cuba

fields.headline: US lifts food embargo on Cuba
fields.trailText: The US Congress yesterday agreed to lift the food embargo on Cuba in a decision acknowledging that the 40-year blockade had done nothing to weaken Fidel Castro, and that sanctions in general have failed as a foreign policy tool.
fields.body:
The US Congress yesterday agreed to lift the food embargo on Cuba in a decision acknowledging that the 40-year blockade had done nothing to weaken Fidel Castro, and that sanctions in general have failed as a foreign policy tool.

The agreement also eases food and medicine sanctions against North Korea, Sudan, Libya and Iran.

The White House said it supported the measures, but added that it was concerned about some of the wording in the bill which would give Congress a greater say in the president's imposition of future trade embargoes.

The scaling down of the Cuban blockade reflects a move away from the use of sanctions. The shift reflects the increasingly vocal lobbying of US farmers and businessmen who feel they are losing ground to foreign competitors in Cuba and other markets.

In the Cuban case, the congressional agreement to ease the blockade is part of the fallout from the Elian Gonzalez affair - a popular backlash against the Cuban exile campaign to keep the shipwrecked boy in Miami in defiance of a justice department ruling granting custody to his father. That campaign looked doomed to failure yesterday as - barring intervention from the supreme court - Elian and his father are free to return to Cuba this afternoon.

But the deal also represents a profound change in political thinking - an acceptance that sanctions have usually failed, tending to harm ordinary citizens more than their rulers. Privately, state department officials even acknowledge that almost 10 years of the sanctions against Iraq have backfired.

"This is a fundamental shift in American foreign policy and a new day for American agriculture. When America celebrates the Fourth of July next week, our farmers will have a new independence day to celebrate - independence from an outdated foreign policy that only served to punish them," George Nethercuttt, a Washington state Republican congressman, said yesterday.

The plan agreed in Congress is hedged with restrictions representing a rearguard action by the Cuban exile community. Cuba will have to pay for US farm and medical exports in cash. Cuban buyers will not be eligible for trade credits and Havana will not be able to barter for US goods or export Cuban products to the US. But it will be able to arrange the financing of US imports through third parties.

The ban on US tourists visiting Cuba will remain - a restriction hailed as a victory by Cuban Americans. Lincoln Diaz Balart, a Florida congressman, said: "Our greatest concern for the last seven or eight months remaining for Clinton was that he was going to try to open tourism to Cuba. We closed that so we're very pleased."

Similar trade and tourism restrictions will apply to the relaxation of sanctions on Iran, but not to North Korea, Sudan and Libya, which no longer have the official status of "rogue states".

webTitle: Who's who in the Elian saga

fields.headline: Who's who in the Elian saga
fields.trailText:
Elian Gonzalez
Elian Gonzalez entered the public consciousness last November, when he was found clinging to an inner tube in the Atlantic Ocean off Florida. His mother and 10 other people drowned when their boat sank en route from Cuba to the United States, leaving Elian as one of only three survivors. The six-year-old boy spent the next five months as a Miami superstar, constantly cheered and adulated by the Cuban exile community in the city's Little Havana neighbourhood. He was inundated with toys and gifts, and was photographed day and night playing in the yard of his Miami relatives' home. Elian was reunited with his father in Washington after a dawn raid by US immigration officials on April 22.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez
Elian Gonzalez entered the public consciousness last November, when he was found clinging to an inner tube in the Atlantic Ocean off Florida. His mother and 10 other people drowned when their boat sank en route from Cuba to the United States, leaving Elian as one of only three survivors. The six-year-old boy spent the next five months as a Miami superstar, constantly cheered and adulated by the Cuban exile community in the city's Little Havana neighbourhood. He was inundated with toys and gifts, and was photographed day and night playing in the yard of his Miami relatives' home. Elian was reunited with his father in Washington after a dawn raid by US immigration officials on April 22.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez
Elian's father lived in a white stucco house in a working-class area of Cardenas, a village about two hours east of Havana. A cashier at a Cuban beach resort, Mr Gonzalez had known Elian's mother, Elisabeth Brotons, since they were teenagers. The couple divorced and he remarried. He and his current wife, Nersy, have an infant son, Hianny.

Lazaro Gonzalez
Elian's 50-year-old great-uncle led the Miami relatives' fight for custody of the boy. The crowd that gathered night and day outside his Little Havana home would often chant his name. Lazaro Gonzalez was unemployed when the custody battle began, but he soon got his own spokesman, a legal team and a new job as a mechanic.

Marisleysis Gonzalez
Elian's 21-year-old cousin became the boy's surrogate mother and was regularly at his side during his time in Miami, escorting him to school or playfully carrying him on her back. She was also among the family's most prominent speakers, constantly lobbying against Elian's return to Fidel Castro's Cuba. She was hospitalised several times after Elian was rescued. Ms Gonzalez quit her job at a bank as an assistant loan processor in April and was considering pursuing a career as a hair stylist.

Janet Reno
The US attorney general became Cuban Americans' hate figure after the raid to retrieve Elian. In the protests following the removal of Elian, she was depicted as the devil on signs. Ms Reno has strong ties to Miami, having grown up in a house on the edge of the city and is no stranger to violence there. As state attorney, she charged five white Miami police officers with the killing of a black insurance executive after a motorcycle chase. When they were acquitted in 1980, black rioters looted the city chanting "Reno, Reno, Reno".

Donato Dalrymple
One of the two men who rescued Elian, Mr Dalrymple, a janitor, became closely linked to the Miami relatives and was holding a crying Elian when an armed federal agent stormed into the bedroom during the April raid. He's suing Ms Reno, deputy attorney general Eric Holder and immigration and naturalisation service commissioner Doris Meissner, seeking damages in excess of $100m because he says his civil rights were violated during the raid.

Sam Ciancio
Despite not being able to swim, Mr Ciancio dived into the ocean to save Elian. The 41-year-old roofer and avid fisherman faded into the background and cut ties with his cousin, Mr Dalrymple, because of the circus-like atmosphere that surrounded the fight over Elian.

Gregory Craig
Juan Miguel Gonzalez' lawyer served as the special counsel for US President Bill Clinton during his impeachment trial. Since graduating from Yale law school in 1972, Mr Craig has represented a variety of clients. He helped defend John Hinckley after his failed attempt to assassinate President Ronald Reagan and has lobbied Washington power brokers on behalf of a wealthy Haitian family who tried to ward off economic sanctions harmful to its business.

Spencer Eig
A member of the Miami relatives' legal team, Mr Eig was a former US immigration and naturalisation service lawyer. The Miami beach immigration lawyer made an unsuccessful bid in 1997 for the Miami beach city commission.

Kendall Coffey
In recent months, the most visible member of the Miami relatives' legal team, Mr Coffey resigned as US attorney in Miami in 1996 amid accusations that he bit a topless dancer on the arm at a club where he had gone after losing his biggest drug case in five years - when two people accused of smuggling $2.1bn in cocaine were acquitted.

Sister Jeanne O'Laughlin
Ms O'Laughlin acted as a mediator when Elian's Cuban grandmothers visited Florida in January. Ms O'Laughlin, a Catholic nun who is the president of Barry University, first said she had no opinion about whether the boy should be returned. But after the grandmothers' visit, she said Elian should stay in the United States - drawing bitter criticism from the Cuban government and the grandmothers.

The Rev Joan Brown Campbell
The former general secretary of the national council of churches, Ms Campbell supported the boy's return to his father. Ms Campbell, a baptist minister, served as the host for Elian's grandmothers on their visit to the United States and visited Juan Miguel Gonzalez in Havana and in the United States. Brief biography

fields.headline: The Elian Gonzalez case
fields.standfirst: As the Gonzalez custody battle comes to a head, Derek Brown and Patrick Barkham explain the issues surrounding America's most famous refugee
fields.trailText:
Who is Elian Gonzalez?
Six-year-old Elian Gonzalez is America's most famous refugee. He arrived in the US clinging to an inner-tube, after his mother and 10 other Cubans drowned when the boat they fled Cuba in foundered off the coast of Florida last November. Elian's great uncle, based in Miami, gained temporary custody, but the US government ruled the boy must return to his father in Cuba. Elian has been returned to his father, now in America.
fields.body:
Who is Elian Gonzalez?
Six-year-old Elian Gonzalez is America's most famous refugee. He arrived in the US clinging to an inner-tube, after his mother and 10 other Cubans drowned when the boat they fled Cuba in foundered off the coast of Florida last November. Elian's great uncle, based in Miami, gained temporary custody, but the US government ruled the boy must return to his father in Cuba. Elian has been returned to his father, now in America.

The US supreme court has ruled that he cannot be forced to stay in the US - despite a vigorous campaign by his Miami-based relatives to keep him there.

What happened in the intervention? When Elian's father and Miami relatives couldn't come to an agreement, immigration officials resorted to a dawn raid on the Miami house on 22 April. A photographer in the house snatched the dramatic picture of a clearly terrified Elian being snatched from his great uncle at gunpoint. Elian was reunited with his father, a move he appeared happy about, according to publicity shots and US psychologists.

Why did Washington intervene?
"I believe that reuniting Elian with his father is not only a matter of federal law. It is not a matter of immigration law. It is simply the right thing to do," said deputy attorney general Eric Holder. The US Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) also argued that Elian had a "close and continuous relationship" with his father, Juan Miguel Gonzales, even though his parents were divorced and he was living with his late mother.

Who wanted to stop his return to Cuba?
Elian stayed in Miami with his great uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, and other relatives who have temporary custody of the boy. Exiled Cubans make up a third of Miami's population and, as one of America's most successful post-war immigrant groups, dominate the politics of southern Florida. Stridently anti-communist Cuban exile groups, including the Free Cuba Foundation and refugee support group Brothers to the Rescue, backed Lazaro Gonzalez's desire to keep Elian in the US. Anti-Castro protestors threatened to burn Miami if the boy they called "a little miracle", and compared to Moses in the bulrushes, returned to Cuba with his father.

And who wanted him to return?
His father, for one. Fidel Castro, for another, who is milking the dispute for all the patriotic publicity it is worth. His regime gambled that Juan Miguel would not defect to America (which would be a publicity disaster for Castro's Cuba) and allowed him to fly to Washington to collect his son. The Rev Joan Brown, of the influential US National Council of Churches, also spent time in Havana helping to reunite father and son.

What line does President Clinton take?
Unlike Al Gore, who has endorsed special legislation to give Elian and his father US residency status, President Clinton backs the immigration authorities' position. Interviewed on CBS, he said: "The fact that the father has come here, and will be in a position to show his concern for, and desire to be reunited with, his son, should be a big help.'' US-Cuba relations are, of course, at the heart of the dispute. Elian's return to Havana could herald a long-awaited thaw, and maybe even a review of the hotly-controversial Helms-Burton Law, which imposes draconian trade sanctions on the western hemisphere's last communist state.

What is the Helms-Burton Law?
It seeks to extend America's long-standing trade embargo against Cuba to third parties. Foreign businessmen and others who are held to benefit in any way from US property confiscated by the Havana regime, could be barred from doing business with or even entering the United States. Even before the act was passed in 1996, most American citizens were forbidden to trade with or visit Cuba. To buy or sell a Havana cigar, for example is outlawed in the USA. The part of the act which would allow US citizens to sue citizens of other countries who invest in Cuban companies has been suspended by President Clinton.

Where can I find out more?

Let Elian Gonzales go home

Building Socialism in Cuba by Fidel Castro

webTitle: Closer, but still no Cuban cigars

fields.headline: Closer, but still no Cuban cigars
fields.standfirst: America's decision to open up limited trade with Cuba after a 40-year blockade could mark a change in attitudes to sanctions around the world, writes the Guardian's former US correspondent Mark Tran
fields.trailText: America's decision to open up limited trade with Cuba after a 40-year blockade could mark a change in attitudes to sanctions around the world, writes the Guardian's former US correspondent Mark Tran.
fields.body:
Fidel Castro occupies a special place in America's pantheon of rogue leaders. As the only communist leader in the western hemisphere, his very proximity to the US serves to make him a particular bugbear for the American political establishment.

John F Kennedy endured one of his most lacerating humiliations with the botched Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, when disaffected Cubans were left high and dry on the island's beaches. The Cuban missile crisis the following year only confirmed Fidel's privileged place in US demonology to the point where the CIA resorted to exploding cigars to try to get rid of him.

But changes are afoot. Republican leaders in Congress yesterday agreed to the sale of food and medicine to Cuba for the first time, in the most significant relaxation of the sanctions since they were imposed 40 years ago.

The deal is a bit of a mixed bag. It would allow American farmers and agricultural businesses to sell their goods directly to Cuba, but the federal government and American banks would be barred from providing any finance, making it difficult for the impoverished country to buy goods.

Republicans traditionally have taken a hard line on Cuba, but an intense lobbying campaign by the farming industry and a reassessment of the effectiveness of sanctions prompted Republicans to rethink. Congress and the Clinton White House recently eased sanctions against China and North Korea as part of a move against punishing whole countries for the politics of their leaders.

Local politics played a role, too, in the latest detente. George Nethercutt, who championed the Cuba bill, faces a tough re-election battle in his District of Washington state, and with a slim majority in the House, the Republican leadership did not want him to go down as a result of his pet cause.

In the past, Congress has shied away from taking on the powerful Cuban exile community in Florida, who are implacably opposed to anything that can be construed as appeasement of Castro.

But the Miami Cubans did themselves no favours with their overheated behaviour in the Elian Gonzalez case. By taking such an extreme position, they turned off many Americans and discredited themselves politically. Elian, the six-year-old boy who was rescued after a shipwreck off Miami that killed his mother and several others as they tried to flee Cuba, is to return to his country imminently, with his father, much to the chagrin of the Cuban exiles.

Cuba itself is none too pleased by the congressional move. Ricardo Alarcon, president of the Cuban national assembly, argued that the measure not only fails to modify the blockade but in some ways makes it worse, as the agreement would write into law the existing ban on Americans travelling to Cuba as tourists - depriving Havana of much-needed foreign exchange.

Nevertheless, Nethercutt trumpeted the deal as a "fundamental shift in foreign policy". He may have been indulging in a bit of hyperbole in his moment of triumph, but it does represent a big change in US attitudes towards Cuba and sanctions as a whole.

The precedent has been set: it should be easier to chip away at the sanctions on Cuba - one of the most anomalous relics from the cold war.

With the fairness and effectiveness of sanctions increasingly being questioned, Saddam Hussein must be wondering whether the time is at hand when the draconian sanctions against Iraq - and indeed the daily bombing by the UK and the US - will be relaxed. Such a move does not seem so far-fetched as even state department officials have acknowledged that almost 10 years of sanctions have done little to weaken Saddam, but much to harm Iraqi civilians.
