By taking such an extreme position, they turned off many Americans and discredited themselves politically. Elian, the six-year-old boy who was rescued after a shipwreck off Miami that killed his mother and several others as they tried to flee Cuba, is to return to his country imminently, with his father, much to the chagrin of the Cuban exiles. Cuba itself is none too pleased by the congressional move. Ricardo Alarcon, president of the Cuban national assembly, argued that the measure not only fails to modify the blockade but in some ways makes it worse, as the agreement would write into law the existing ban on Americans travelling to Cuba as tourists - depriving Havana of much-needed foreign exchange. Nevertheless, Nethercutt trumpeted the deal as a "fundamental shift in foreign policy". He may have been indulging in a bit of hyperbole in his moment of triumph, but it does represent a big change in US attitudes towards Cuba and sanctions as a whole. The precedent has been set: it should be easier to chip away at the sanctions on Cuba - one of the most anomalous relics from the cold war. With the fairness and effectiveness of sanctions increasingly being questioned, Saddam Hussein must be wondering whether the time is at hand when the draconian sanctions against Iraq - and indeed the daily bombing by the UK and the US - will be relaxed. Such a move does not seem so far-fetched as even state department officials have acknowledged that almost 10 years of sanctions have done little to weaken Saddam, but much to harm Iraqi civilians.

webTitle: Canals to earn cash by carrying water

fields.headline: Canals to earn cash by carrying water
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Canals are to be used to move drinking water to the parched south-east of England, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Canals are to be used to move drinking water to the parched south-east of England, it was announced yesterday.

Pumping trials transporting ground water from Birmingham to London have proved successful, and by this time next year the first contract to supply water from the north-west and Wales to the south-east is expected to be running.

The chairman of British Waterways, George Greener, said yesterday: "Now we have proved the scheme can work, the world and his wife wants to talk to us and do a deal. We are set to become a big water supplier, rivalling the big 10 water companies."

British Waterways is using its 3,000 miles of canals, as well as its 93 reservoirs across the country as "holding tanks" for the the scheme. It is one of a number of ideas the public-owned company is using to generate funds to modernise and repair the network.

The heyday of canals was the early 19th century, but they began a long decline when the railways arrived. Many were drained and lost, and the rest have been kept from crumbling only by government grants and volunteers. Money from selling drinking water will go towards the £237m backlog in repairs and maintenance, and help to return the network to pristine condition.

Mr Greener said the recovery and reopening of the Stroud Cotswold canal between the Severn and the Thames was possible, because the route could be used for navigation and for pumping water from west to east to supply London.

Although a national water grid has long been talked of as a way of solving the south-east's shortages, it has been seen as too costly. But the canals have been used to sell drinking water to Bristol since the 19th century, and in the Midlands industries use the network for their supplies.

Mr Greener said: "All we are doing is reusing and vastly extending a system our engineers know does work. The difference is that we have done the sums and realise it is a money-making venture; we can supply water at a competitive price."

Mr Greener was speaking at the launching by John Prescott, the environment secretary, of the Waterways for Tomorrow document, which encourages British Waterways to make money as well as offer recreation and navigation - for example, using towpaths to lay fibre optic cables, which this year will earn £6m. Mr Prescott was also keen to use the canals' many "brownfield" industrial sites for hotels and housing. Pierre Williams, of the Housebuilders Federation, endorsed the idea. "Houses close to water fetch premium prices, and are a way of rehabilitating industrial sites."

The canals earn £180m a year but need £58.9m in grants from the Treasury to keep going. Mr Greener said he hoped to make them pay their way in 15 years.

Canals carry 3m tonnes of freight a year, less than 2% of the total, but Mr Prescott said he hoped to provide grants for companies switching to canals. One trial under way uses the River Lea in north London to ship rubbish to the site of a planned incinerator, where it would provide electricity. The scheme remains controversial but would save hundreds of lorry journeys.

webTitle: Microsoft and AT&T in Japan deal

fields.headline: Microsoft and AT&T in Japan deal
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Two leaders of America's new economy, Microsoft and AT&T, joined forces yesterday to seize territory in Japan's cable television sector, one of the most underdeveloped but potentially lucrative telecommunication markets in the world.
fields.body:
Two leaders of America's new economy, Microsoft and AT&T, joined forces yesterday to seize territory in Japan's cable television sector, one of the most underdeveloped but potentially lucrative telecommunication markets in the world.

In a deal said to be worth more than £3bn, the two firms will merge their Japanese broadband operations on September 1. This sets the stage for a possible confrontation with NTT, the domestic telecoms company that has a stranglehold on the internet access business.

The decision by Bill Gates, co-founder of Microsoft, to ally with John Malone, the US cable pioneer who heads AT&T cable arm Liberty Media, is a sign that the jostling for position in Japan's broadband field has entered a new stage.

Underlining the increasing activity in the sector, Pacific Century Cyberworks, owned by Hong Kong telecoms tycoon Richard Li, invested $14m (£9.3m) last week in a cable subsidiary of the Japanese trading company Tomen.

However, his operation will be dwarfed by the tie-up between Jupiter Telecommunications, which is 50% owned by Liberty Media, and Titus Com munications in which Microsoft recently took a 60% stake.

Jupiter and Titus are the biggest cable firms in Japan, together controlling 24 local systems with more than 750,000 subscribers. Under a deal announced by the two firms yesterday, Titus shareholders will be given a 30% stake in Jupiter, which will become the owner of its former rival.

Titus chief executive Lee Daniels said the move would create synergies of scale, cost and expertise. "We will establish a leading position in the market and provide new services to our customers."

The merged firm will be controlled by its main shareholders, Liberty Media and Sumitomo, each with 35%, and Microsoft, with 24%. The remaining 6% will be split between Itochu, a trading house, and electronics maker Toshiba.

Jupiter's president, Tsunetoshi Ishibashi, said the integrated company was aiming at a stock flotation, which analysts say could be worth about $5bn.

Japan's cable sector, which is far less developed than those in Britain or the US, is ripe for a shake-up. There are more than 700 operators, most of which cover niche markets and lack the financial resources to expand the country's cable infrastructure.

fields.headline: Press warned over William's privacy
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Newspapers, paparazzi and TV crews which hound Prince William when he embarks upon his university career can expect an instant rebuke from the press complaints commission, its chairman, Lord Wakeham, will say today.
fields.body:
Newspapers, paparazzi and TV crews which hound Prince William when he embarks upon his university career can expect an instant rebuke from the press complaints commission, its chairman, Lord Wakeham, will say today.

In a renewed attempt to protect the 18-year-old heir-but-one to the throne, Lord Wakeham and Buckingham Palace will join forces to set out in detail the circumstances in which photographs of the prince can be taken or published.

Pictures taken in private by hounding or intimidation will not be allowed. That means that restaurant photos and those taken in private gardens will effectively be banned except in specified circumstances.

"The PCC will come down hard," on paparazzi, Lord Wakeham will warn in a statement which follows months of discreet discussions with media executives.

But royal courtiers who have to plan the evolution of "the firm" know that they must also sustain public interest and affection for the young man who is generally accepted as the House of Windsor's most promising asset since Princess Diana. Lord Wakeham will therefore concede that some reporting of William's career is legitimate - so that regular access will be provided wherever the prince goes to university, after his planned gap year abroad.

He will say: "Prince William must absolutely not be fair game, but at the same time, things will change. He has left school, he is growing up and has become a young adult, he is increasingly becoming a public figure."

The new privacy guidelines, leaked last night, appear to realise that speculation about the prince's prospective wife is unavoidable.

But Lord Wakeham will remind editors that "endless intrusion and the constant powerful headlamps of publicity will make his life a misery, make his friends' lives a misery and make it impossible for him to forge proper meaningful relationships".

Prince William is already said to be more wary of media attention than his younger brother, Harry. But some tabloid editors say that public interest has moved on, away from the royals towards the likes of the Spice Girls singer, Victoria Beckham, and her husband, England footballer David Beckham.

fields.headline: Winchester takes Hollywood role
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Winchester Entertainment, owner of the popular Jellabies children's characters, is to establish a separate unit aimed at distributing Hollywood movies to British cinemas.
fields.body:
Winchester Entertainment, owner of the popular Jellabies children's characters, is to establish a separate unit aimed at distributing Hollywood movies to British cinemas.

The move into film distribution follows the announcement of record pre-tax profits of £1.54m for the year to March 31 on the back of a 33% increase in turnover to £4.9m.

Chief executive Gary Smith said Winchester was talking to several US producers about licensing the international rights to their films and distributing them with partners which might include the video company VCI. The first feature film it will distribute will be Another Life, staring Nick Moran and Natasha Little, which is set to be released in Britain in February next year.

"We are looking to increase our control over the exploitation of our intellectual property rights," Mr Smith said. "We are looking to distribute on video, aircraft, television, the internet and video on demand. By going into this area in partnership we will minimise the risks involved by sharing print and advertising costs."

Winchester will also look to increasingly take an ownership position in films. It is already part-funding Heartbreakers, an MGM-produced film staring Sigourney Weaver and Gene Hackman. In return it receives worldwide distribution, sales and marketing rights, excluding the North American market.

Mick Southworth, formerly managing director of Film Four Distributors and responsible for the release of films including Brassed Off and Secrets and Lies, is to head the new division.

Winchester is also talking to toy companies about producing merchandise for The Wheels on The Bus, a new children's programme.

fields.headline: Degas statue sold for £7.7m
fields.trailText: A small bronze statue of a ballet dancer was sold for nearly £8m last night in an auction at Sotheby's in London. The bronze dancer by Edgar Degas (right) was bought by an unnamed bidder after being put up for sale by its anonymous European owners.
fields.body:
A small bronze statue of a ballet dancer was sold for nearly £8m last night in an auction at Sotheby's in London. The bronze dancer by Edgar Degas (right) was bought by an unnamed bidder after being put up for sale by its anonymous European owners.

The 120-year-old statue, entitled Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans, fetched £7,703,500, the highest sterling price paid for a Degas sculpture.

However, the dancer failed to secure the highest bid of the day in one of the strongest sales of Impressionist and modern art in the capital in recent times.

A Monet painting titled La Plage à Trouville was bought for £11,003,500 by an anonymous bidder.

A Sotheby's spokesman said: "It was a historic night. The statue went for what was a record in sterling for a Degas sculpture, to an anonymous bidder."

The statue was created between 1879 and 1881 and was the only sculpture exhibited by the artist during his lifetime.

It was first seen publicly in the sixth Impressionist Exhibition in 1881 when its astonishing realism shocked many contemporary critics.

After Degas' death 28 examples were cast in bronze, only 11 of which now remain in private hands.

fields.headline: Rescue for Robben Island penguins
fields.trailText: Wildlife experts and volunteers in South Africa were desperately trying to rescue thousands more Jackass penguins from an oil spill off the coast of Cape Town yesterday, having already taken 4,500 of the birds for treatment.
fields.body:
Wildlife experts and volunteers in South Africa were desperately trying to rescue thousands more Jackass penguins from an oil spill off the coast of Cape Town yesterday, having already taken 4,500 of the birds for treatment.

The South African National Foundation for the Conservation of Coastal Birds (SANCCOB) said in a statement that it expected at least 10,000 more birds to be plucked from oily graves by the end of the week from Robben Island, home to about 20,000 of the birds, including 6,000 chicks.

The birds have been under threat since Friday, when a freighter carrying a cargo of iron ore and 1,400 tonnes of fuel from Brazil to China sank off Cape Town.

SANCCOB said that the pollution seemed to be spreading, with 200 penguins reported to have been soiled at nearby Dassen Island, which is home to 50,000 of the birds, their largest breeding colony.

Jackass penguins, also known as African penguins, are Africa's only penguins and are native to South Africa's coast, where they number about 150,000.

Robben Island has been declared a World Heritage Site and is better known as the place where the former South African president, Nelson Mandela, spent most of his 27 years behind bars.

The rescue effort is expected to cost at least £300,000 and SANCCOB has appealed to the public for donations.

webTitle: Ministers unveil post office bank to aid poor

fields.headline: Ministers unveil post office bank to aid poor
fields.trailText: Ministers will today unveil plans for a Universal Bank to ensure that all the 3.5m citizens without bank accounts get access to the same basic financial services as the better off enjoy.
fields.body:
Ministers will today unveil plans for a Universal Bank to ensure that all the 3.5m citizens without bank accounts get access to the same basic financial services as the better off enjoy.

The venture, run through the country's 19,000 post offices, will mean that people on the lowest incomes will have access for the first time to cheque books and cash withdrawal cards, as well as reasonably priced loans to help them steer clear of loan sharks who charge exhorbitant interest rates.

The bank will be part of a multi-million pound programme to save thousands of threatened post offices from closure and transform the network into a national agency providing information on a wide range of local and national government services, from benefits advice to details of evening classes.

Postmasters and postmistresses will be encouraged to take on a new proactive role as community entrepreneurs - to be known as "government general practitioners" - dispensing information and support on matters such as form filling or internet use.

Funds will be available to modernise premises and improve security, as well as to open new branches in post office "deserts".

The rescue plan is intended to address the crisis faced by thousands of sub-post offices because of the imminent loss of their government contract to pay out benefits and pensions, responsible for around a third of their income.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, unveiling the plan today, will stress that the fund will tackle the "hidden problem" of closures in run-down inner city areas, as well as the issue of rural post office closures.

The extent of closures in the most deprived urban areas and on run-down estates will be revealed today in a report by the government's performance and innovation unit. Some 3,000 post office branches have closed across the country in the last 20 years. Just as in rural areas, post offices are often the last facility remaining in inner cities when shops and high street banks close down or move out, the report will say.

Ministers are anxious to portray the extra help for post offices as much as a heartland issue, targeted at traditional voters, as assistance for the rural shires.

The new Universal Bank (originally to be called the People's Bank until ministers grew concerned at the name's eastern bloc ring) will be set up with seed money from the government. Pressure will be put on the big high street banks to help get the service off the ground. Following the banks' much criticised rapid withdrawal from rural areas and unprofitable poor urban districts, ministers believe that the institutions have a moral obligation to contribute to the new enterprise.

The government was forced to find a mechanism to provide universal banking facilities because of plans to pay all benefits and pensions directly into bank accounts by 2003. Now the payments will go into the new Universal Bank accounts but can also be collected as before over the counter at post offices.

The decision to centre the service on the post office network came after research showed that people with no bank accounts were confident about using post offices, but found the high street banks intimidating and unfamiliar.

Another key benefit, ministers believe, will be the chance for poorer customers to take advantage of discount schemes of up to 10% offered by utility companies to customers who pay gas or electricity bills by direct debit, and obtain credit and loans at reasonable rates.

fields.headline: Peers inflict social security defeats
fields.trailText: The government's plans to withhold social security benefits from people who breach a community service order for a second time suffered a sharp rebuke from the Lords last night when peers insisted that courts must decide such issues, not officials.
fields.body:
The government's plans to withhold social security benefits from people who breach a community service order for a second time suffered a sharp rebuke from the Lords last night when peers insisted that courts must decide such issues, not officials.

Peers were angry that claimants who might simply be "20 minutes late" for an appointment with a probation officer could be penalised so severely - losing up to 26 weeks benefit - without any prior endorsement by a court.

The 170-116 vote defeat on the child support, pensions and social security bill was the second of the night and the 17th since the government purged all but 92 of the hereditary peers from the unelected upper house.

A cross-party alliance had already voted by 166-135 to safeguard the rights of widows and widowers who were victims of misinformation over the benefits they might expect under state-related pensions (Serps) when changes were made by Conservative ministers in the 1980s.

The junior social security minister, Lady Hollis, had claimed that government changes to Serps had addressed the problem.

On both votes the Department of Social Security said it would respond "in due course".

The major attack came on CSOs and benefit withdrawal and prompted the former Tory minister and ex-parole board chairman, Lord Windlesham, to protest that "if indeed there is a rationale for this legislative process, it is rooted not only in deep ignorance of deviant behaviour and the most effective ways of countering it".

The Labour peer, Lady Kennedy QC, described the government's move as an attack on the poor. "It's an extraordinary departure, constitutionally. It gives to the DSS a punishment to dole out in addition to that doled out by the courts."
fields.bodyText: The government's plans to withhold social security benefits from people who breach a community service order for a second time suffered a sharp rebuke from the Lords last night when peers insisted that courts must decide such issues, not officials. Peers were angry that claimants who might simply be "20 minutes late" for an appointment with a probation officer could be penalised so severely - losing up to 26 weeks benefit - without any prior endorsement by a court. The 170-116 vote defeat on the child support, pensions and social security bill was the second of the night and the 17th since the government purged all but 92 of the hereditary peers from the unelected upper house. A cross-party alliance had already voted by 166-135 to safeguard the rights of widows and widowers who were victims of misinformation over the benefits they might expect under state-related pensions (Serps) when changes were made by Conservative ministers in the 1980s. The junior social security minister, Lady Hollis, had claimed that government changes to Serps had addressed the problem. On both votes the Department of Social Security said it would respond "in due course". The major attack came on CSOs and benefit withdrawal and prompted the former Tory minister and ex-parole board chairman, Lord Windlesham, to protest that "if indeed there is a rationale for this legislative process, it is rooted not only in deep ignorance of deviant behaviour and the most effective ways of countering it". The Labour peer, Lady Kennedy QC, described the government's move as an attack on the poor. "It's an extraordinary departure, constitutionally. It gives to the DSS a punishment to dole out in addition to that doled out by the courts."

fields.headline: The Results
fields.standfirst:
Who's in and who's not

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Who's in and who's not
fields.body:
Who's In

David Coltart , a white member of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, took Bulawayo South despite repeated personal criticism from President Mugabe, death threats and his right to stand being challenged on the grounds that he was eligible for UK citizenship, which he renounced 15 years ago.

Mr Coltart, 42, who was born in Rhodesia after his father emigrated from Edinburgh after the second world war, worked as a human rights lawyer during the Matabeleland massacres in the 1980s and has a dedicated following of both black and white residents of Bulawayo.

Prof Walshman Ncube , secretary general of the Movement for Democratic Change, has accused South Africa's ruling African National Congress of supporting the current spate of farm invasions and violence.

"By supporting government-sponsored land invasions and the political violence in Zimbabwe, the ANC is making enemies with the people of Zimbabwe," Prof Ncube told a news conference.

Prof Ncube is a lawyer and was a leader of the movement to draft a new constitution. He led the successful campaign to reject Mr Mugabe's proposed constitution.

Chenjerai Hunzvi , known as Hitler, is the leader of the so-called war veterans, who organised the farm invasions.

Mr Hunzvi, 49, did not fight in Zimbabwe's battle for independence. He was a representative of Joshua Nkomo's guerrilla force but spent the years of the liberation war in eastern Europe, qualifying as a medical doctor. He returned in 1991 and took up a new battle, politicising the "war veterans".

His former wife claimed in a book that she was so terrorised by him that she fled Zimbabwe.


Who's not

Dumiso Dabenga , 56, the Zimbabwe home affairs minister responsible for police, is a genuine war veteran, having fought against Rhodesia with the Zimbabwe African People's Union under Joshua Nkomo.

He became known as the Black Russian for his military training in the former Soviet Union and rose to become the commander of Nkomo's military forces.

The rebellion prompted by his detention by President Mugabe led to the the use of the army's notorious North Korean-trained Fifth Brigade into southern Matabeleland with a death toll of 10,000.

Mr Dabengwa and Nkomo later joined President Mugabe's government under Zanu-PF.

Thenjiwe Lesabe , one of the few high profile women in the Zanu PF,was minister of national affairs.

She stirred controversy in the run-up to Zanu-PF's national congress when she put her name forward to contest the party's vice-presidency.

Morgan Tsvangirai , leader of the MDC, passed up the chance of a safe seat in Harare and instead chose to run in his birthplace.

Mr Tsvangirai, 48, said if he could not take on Zanu-PF in its heartland, who else would? His brave stand inspired many other MDC candidates to campaign in Zanu-PF strongholds. Two of his supporters were killed in a firebomb attack in his constituency.

Mr Tsvangirai rose from union negotiator to secretary general of the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions. Two years ago, he showed his ability to marshal support by leading successful strikes against the government without violence.

fields.headline: MPs' fury at passport farce
fields.trailText: Jack Straw last night admitted the government had made "mistakes" over what MPs dubbed as last summer's "farce and fiasco" over the long delays in issuing hundreds of thousands of passports, which ruined many holidays.
fields.body:
Jack Straw last night admitted the government had made "mistakes" over what MPs dubbed as last summer's "farce and fiasco" over the long delays in issuing hundreds of thousands of passports, which ruined many holidays.

A damning report from MPs today slates the passport agency for "flawed implementation" of a new computer system which led to lost production of 400,000 passports and enormous queues of desperate people outside Petty France, London's passport office.

David Davis, Tory chairman of the committee, said: "The agency's inability to provide an adequate service during the summer of 1999 represented a deplorable departure from the high standards of service the public has a right to expect. We saw fiasco turn to farce as the summer progressed last year. The agency have assured us that these problems will not recur - we shall hold them to that pledge."

MPs are particularly cross that the fiasco cost the taxpayer £12.6m - of which only £2.45m will be recovered over years from Siemens, the German computer company that won the deal. Most of the money is being recovered in a hike in passports from £21 to £28. Some £3.50 of the increase in fees is to pay for this.

MPs also demand that a £1.50 charge to pay off previous deficits and pay for the issue of overseas passports and the repatriation of British people overseas should be scrapped. They say the Treasury should reconsider charging future passport applicants for past debts.

They attack the agency and the Home Office for signing a deal that placed all the risk of failure with the government - the firm being able to avoid the financial consequences of the debacle. The firm is only contracted to pay £170,000 for the error immediately, with the rest of the money being due over future years.

Jack Straw said last night: "The committee has rightly concluded that there was a regrettable departure from the high standards expected from the passport agency last summer."

UK passport agency chief executive Bernard Herdan said: "The agency is implementing a wide-ranging recovery plan and the service offered to the public has already been transformed. Beyond the immediate short-term recovery plan, the agency has already put in place a strategy for longer-term customer services improvement."

webTitle: Arts Council chief seeks 'tiny' £100m funding boost

fields.headline: Arts Council chief seeks 'tiny' £100m funding boost
fields.trailText: The Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, last night demanded an extra £100m a year from the government, an increase of almost 50% in the council's grant, calling it "a tiny sum".
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, last night demanded an extra £100m a year from the government, an increase of almost 50% in the council's grant, calling it "a tiny sum".

He recognised Labour's commitment to the arts, which led to a grant increase - £125m over three years.

The council's budget is £229m, due to rise to £244m next year, compared with £190m before the election.

However, he said it was not enough. "Two years ago it put down a deposit on the arts. That deposit has been of considerable value. But it was never the complete answer. And there is no point putting a deposit down if the balance is not then found."

Mr Robinson, who was deliv ering the annual New Statesman lecture, backed his demand with figures from a recent Mori poll for the council which found massive support across all social groups. "The arts can no longer be characterised as a middle- or upper-class pursuit," he said. "As many people play a musical instrument as play football."

According to Mori, 78% of people believe the arts are valuable, 73% that they should be publicly funded, and 95% that schoolchildren should have more experience of the arts.

In the lowest income groups two in five said the arts played a valuable role in their own lives, and two in three that they contributed to job creation and urban regeneration. The poll showed that 57% of the group had attended a theatre or taken part in some form of drama, and 25% had done so in the previous year.

A 1995 survey, by the Voluntary Arts Network, also cited by Mr Robinson, found greater participation in the arts than in sport among lower income groups. When he took on the chairman's job two years ago, Mr Robinson said he expected the arts to be "inefficient, overstaffed, and delivering poor value for money". He had found some of that, but overwhelmingly a sector struggling to survive.

webTitle: We shall not be moved, say the royals, as Mo Mowlam's palace coup falls flat

fields.headline: We shall not be moved, say the royals, as Mo Mowlam's palace coup falls flat
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen took the rare step last night of rebuking a minister of the crown when Buckingham Palace dismissed suggestions by Mo Mowlam that the royal family should move into "a good modern building".
fields.body:
The Queen took the rare step last night of rebuking a minister of the crown when Buckingham Palace dismissed suggestions by Mo Mowlam that the royal family should move into "a good modern building".

Incensed by Ms Mowlam's provocative intervention, royal sources pointed out that the Queen's lavish 18th century residence is a working building.

"We are not entering the debate," a royal source remarked sniffily last night. "We just want to make clear that Buckingham Palace is a working building - it is the seat of the head of state where 550 people work and receptions are held most days."

The royal put-down capped one of the most miserable days of Ms Mowlam's career after she resumed her campaign to move the Queen out of Buckingham Palace.

In an interview with Saga magazine, the cabinet office minister reiterated her famous 1994 suggestion that Buckingham Palace - originally bought by George III in 1761 - was no longer appropriate in the modern world.

Ms Mowlam compounded her error, in the eyes of traditionalists, by coming close to advocating a republic. "I am no great fan of the monarchy," she declared.

Her remarks were dismissed by Downing Street and a host of cabinet ministers, some of whom were privately delighted by Ms Mowlam's fall from grace. Downing Street made light of her interview, although the underlying message was clear: the accident prone cabinet office minister has tripped up once again.

A Downing Street spokesman said Tony Blair would have more important matters on his mind when he visited the Queen at Buckingham Palace last night for his weekly audience with the monarch. "When he goes to see the Queen tonight I would be very surprised if he suggested she moves out," the spokesman said.

The spokesman offered the customary support for Ms Mowlam - always a bad omen for a minister - before distancing the Mr Blair from her remarks. "The prime minister is an ardent supporter of the monarchy," the spokesman said.

"He values his relationship with the Queen and he feels the Royal Family plays a central role in our national life. The Queen lives in Buckingham Palace and I don't think she's intending to move and the prime minister doesn't think she should."

Cabinet ministers piled in throughout the day. John Prescott, enjoying the spectacle of a New Labour moderniser in trouble, had the greatest fun when asked about Ms Mowlam's remarks during a trip on a canal boat. "Mo Mowlam is living here," he laughed.

Alan Milburn, the ultra-Blairite health secretary, was no less dismissive. "Mo's views are very well known on the monarchy," he said. "Those happen to be Mo's views. They don't happen to be my views."

The Tories wasted little time in rounding on Ms Mowlam. Andrew Lansley, her opposite number, said: "After the Dome comes the plan to move the Queen into a people's palace. The prime minister is keen to use Chequers and John Prescott loves Dorneywood and even Mo Mowlam has a flat at the Admiralty, but the Queen apparently has to be moved out of Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle."

His response was echoed by the usual array of "constitutional experts." Lord St John of Fawsley, the former leader of the Commons, a favourite of the Queen Mother and a constitutional expert, dismissed the interview as "a load of ill-informed codswallop". "Ms Mowlam is like one of those ultra modernistic architects who inflict their eyesores on our major cities and retire to their Georgian houses at the weekend," Lord St John said, reminding the nation of what a treasure he was during the bleak days of Margaret Thatcher. "I am very glad she has been corrected by the prime minister whose assurances I accept."

Sounding remarkably similar to the royal sources who dismissed Ms Mowlam, Lord St John also proffered the helpful information that Buckingham Palace was a thoroughly modern pad.

"Buckingham Palace houses the up-to-date offices of the Queen and is her major place of work as sovereign," he said, making clear to one and all that he knows his way round the place. "It is equipped with very modern devices to keep the Queen in touch with political and social developments.

Honest
Some Labour MPs offered their support to Ms Mowlam, however. Tony Wright, the MP for Cannock Chase, praised Ms Mowlam for opening up a debate on the monarchy. "Mo is being unfairly treated for being characteristically honest," he said. "The monarchy is the last taboo in Britain, but the idea that it should not be talked about is not grown up politics. We have to let daylight in because if we do not reform the monarchy the Windsors will become a soap opera."

His support will offer little comfort for Ms Mowlam's dwindling band of friends who fear that her position is becoming increasingly weak ahead of a possible summer reshuffle.

Ms Mowlam has made no secret of her frustration at the cabinet office where she has been the subject of a whispering campaign by Blairite loyalists.

Blair loyalists whisper in private that Ms Mowlam has lost the political touch which made her the darling of Labour conferences, earning her a standing ovation during the prime minister's speech. They say that she fails to master her briefs and flounders during meetings.

Ms Mowlam's supporters react angrily to the whispering and the suggestion that her earlier illness has weakened her. They say that she enjoys the main areas of her work, which include co-ordinating the government's anti-drugs policy.

The spat between Ms Mowlam and the Queen was not the first time Buckingham Palace has been a source of tension between crown and parliament. When John Nash transformed the royal "pied-à-terre" into a palace for George IV, parliament agreed a budget of £150,000. The King insisted this was not enough and demanded £450,000, which was eventually granted.

Costs escalated so much that George IV offered the palace to parliament as a new home when Westminster burnt down in 1834. The offer was declined.

webTitle: Row over Labour's new spin offensive

fields.headline: Row over Labour's new spin offensive
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Alastair Campbell sparked a fresh row last night after a leaked memo revealed that he had ordered civil servants to prepare a public relations offensive to boost the government's standing.
fields.body:
Alastair Campbell sparked a fresh row last night after a leaked memo revealed that he had ordered civil servants to prepare a public relations offensive to boost the government's standing.

The prime minister's press secretary has instructed officials in every Whitehall department to produce at least two "substantial news stories" every week for two months "highlighting the government's core message". They will be released during the parliamentary recess in August and September in an attempt to secure favourable media coverage.

The leaked memo follows last month's disclosure that Tony Blair had ordered civil servants to come up with "killer facts" to beat William Hague at their weekly Commons duel at prime minister's question time.

The orchestrated campaign of spin was described as "unprecedented" by one civil servant and triggered Tory calls last night for Mr Campbell to be stripped of public duties.

A note sent round the Cabinet Office yesterday and obtained by the Guardian underlines how Mr Campbell is running the government's spin operation as head of the Downing Street strategic communications unit. Although taking a lower public profile by appearing infrequently at the twice daily Westminster press briefings, he is playing a full role behind the scenes.

The memo, inspired by a longer letter from Mr Campbell to departments, was written by a civil service press officer, Tim Hunt, and sent to key figures in the department, including Michael Pakenham, chairman of the joint intelligence committee which assesses reports from MI5 and MI6, and Moira Wallace, head of the social exclusion unit.

The message said: "Alastair Campbell wishes to draw up a plan to ensure a steady stream of stories highlighting the government's core messages through the summer recess.

"He has asked that each government department provides at least two substantial news stories per week throughout August and September, noting in each case the message which it will convey.

"I should be grateful if heads of management units can identify at least two suitable stories each which we can submit to No 10. Unless there is a particular reason for issue on a fixed date it would be useful if publication could remain flexible.

"Please send your returns to me (Tim Hunt) copied to Maggie O'Boyle in the press office by lunchtime this Friday, 30 June. Sorry for the tight timescale but we have to make our returns to No 10 by Wednesday 5th July after obtaining ministerial approval."

Downing Street attempted to play down the leak, claiming that the request for good news stories to put out during the parliamentary recess was normal. A spokeswoman said: "This is part of routine planning. It goes on every year, under this government and previous governments."

But one Whitehall press officer claimed that the civil service was being "politicised" and said the request went far beyond presenting announcements and initiatives in a professional light.

Since the election, spin has been put at the heart of the government and more than a dozen departmental PR heads have lost their jobs. The number of special advisers has more than doubled.

The Tories last night called on Mr Campbell to leave his almost £100,000 publicly-funded post. Andrew Lansley, the shadow Cabinet Office spokesman, said: "Alastair Campbell is again acting in a political way when employed as a civil servant. "He is undermining the impartiality of civil servants by ordering them to turn out Labour party propaganda. [He] should be paid by Labour rather than by the taxpayer."

The Campbell memo is the latest in a long list of leaks that have embarrassed the government. This month Labour was put on the back foot by the disclosure that Mr Blair's millionaire fund raiser friend, Lord Levy, paid only £5,000 tax in 1998-99. And a leaked focus group report revealed that a growing number of voters distrust Mr Blair.

Downing Street attempted to play down the leak, claiming that the request for good news stories to put out during the parliamentary recess was normal. A spokeswoman said: "This is part of routine planning. It goes on every year, under this government and previous governments." But one Whitehall press officer claimed that the civil service was being "politicised" and said the request went far beyond presenting announcements and initiatives in a professional light. Since the election, spin has been put at the heart of the government and more than a dozen departmental PR heads have lost their jobs. The number of special advisers has more than doubled. The Tories last night called on Mr Campbell to leave his almost £100,000 publicly-funded post. Andrew Lansley, the shadow Cabinet Office spokesman, said: "Alastair Campbell is again acting in a political way when employed as a civil servant. "He is undermining the impartiality of civil servants by ordering them to turn out Labour party propaganda. [He] should be paid by Labour rather than by the taxpayer." The Campbell memo is the latest in a long list of leaks that have embarrassed the government. This month Labour was put on the back foot by the disclosure that Mr Blair's millionaire fund raiser friend, Lord Levy, paid only £5,000 tax in 1998-99. And a leaked focus group report revealed that a growing number of voters distrust Mr Blair.

webTitle: Foreign Office memo dismisses Hague's 'barmy' plan to join American trade area

fields.headline: Foreign Office memo dismisses Hague's 'barmy' plan to join American trade area
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague suffered an embarrassing blow to his credibility last night when it emerged that a senior Foreign Office mandarin has branded his European policy "barmy".
fields.body:
William Hague suffered an embarrassing blow to his credibility last night when it emerged that a senior Foreign Office mandarin has branded his European policy "barmy".

In notes written on an internal Foreign Office memorandum, which has been passed to the Guardian, the head of its EU department launched a withering attack on Mr Hague's plans to apply for British membership of the North America Free Trade Area (Nafta).

"This is a pretty barmy study," Simon Featherstone wrote of an investigation into possible British membership of Nafta, which was inspired by Tory frontbenchers.

The memorandum outlined the government's response to an investigation by a powerful American senate committee into the possibility of Britain joining the free trade area. The investigation, which was launched by Republicans after a lobbying campaign by Tory frontbench Eurosceptics, is supported by Mr Hague who wants Britain to join Nafta.

The memorandum, written by Colin Dick of the Foreign Office's EU department, said British officials would have to meet members of the US international trade commission carrying out the Nafta investigation on behalf of the senate committee. But Mr Dick is dismissive of the entire project, saying that the Republican senator Phil Gramm had launched the investigation after being "encouraged to do so by the UK Conservative party".

The memo says that the investigation is based on two "hypothetical models" which would see Britain either joining Nafta as a member of the EU or abandoning the EU to join the trade area. Mr Dick warns that the investigation could be "used mischievously by those who would like Britain to leave the EU".

This prompted Mr Dick's boss to dismiss the whole idea because both Downing Street and the White House are opposed to British membership of Nafta. In handwritten notes on the front of the memo, Mr Featherstone said: "This is a pretty barmy study, based on hypothetical models which will not happen. But unfortunately that may not stop the media latching onto it."

His remarks will embarrass Mr Hague who believes that Britain can join Nafta without jeopardising British membership of the EU. Ministers have consistently said that Mr Hague's stance is code for British withdrawal, a view now supported by Foreign Office diplomats.

Pro-Europeans last night welcomed the Foreign Office memorandum as an important reminder of the dangers of flirting with Nafta membership. Kitty Ussher, chief economist of the cross-party Britain in Europe group, said: "Joining Nafta is an extremist position which has no economic rationale. Neither the British nor American governments supports the idea which shows that Eurosceptics are economically illiterate. More than half of our trade is with the EU, compared with 17% with Nafta."

The disclosure of the Foreign Office memorandum came on the eve of a visit by members of the US senate finance com mittee to London. Senator Gramm is due to have a series of meetings over the weekend with Tory politicians before delivering a lecture to the rightwing Centre for Policy Studies.

His visit comes amid a cabinet row over the government's approach to the European single currency. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will tomorrow step up his campaign for the government to sound more enthusiastic about the euro when he addresses a conference on Japanese inward investment. Mr Cook is expected to outlinine four arguments in favour of the single currency which he left out of a Commons statement earlier this month at the height of his row with Gordon Brown. These included a warning that Britain could end up the only EU member outside euroland.

webTitle: A lesson in self-help from the class of 2000

fields.headline: A lesson in self-help from the class of 2000
fields.trailText: Yesterday MPs had their monthly treat, with questions about the House of Commons, and thus their own lives. It turns out that they want to do less work, less often, at a time more convenient to themselves.
fields.body:
Yesterday MPs had their monthly treat, with questions about the House of Commons, and thus their own lives. It turns out that they want to do less work, less often, at a time more convenient to themselves.

Basically, they feel the place should be run like a school, only with less discipline. Geraint Davies of Croydon wanted recesses to fit in with school holidays. Fiona MacTaggart wished to know exactly when the house would rise. "I wonder what ministers would think about a school which intended to finish the A-level schedule by July 29, then said it would go on to August 3?" Margaret Beckett said wryly that this particular school was full of unruly pupils.

One of them, John Bercow, pointed out that if the house kept to the same timetable as a school, it would sit for much longer, and Gwyneth Dunwoody asked with silky charm - her manner like a flirtatious elk - which half of the legislative programme Ms Beckett would drop in order for MPs to have longer holidays. Ms Beckett said firmly that none of it would be dropped.

But MPs are never happy. It turns out that during the school holidays the place will be open for paid tours by the hoi polloi. Angela Smith said: "It is very difficult to go to the toilet or to get a cup of tea. Won't visitors be disappointed in the lack of facilities and will they be satisfied by the temporary toilets?"

(Years ago, on a train, I met an American tourist who had taken a tour of parliament, and had been thrown out of a toilet in the House of Lords. "This guy said, 'Can't you see the sign? It says peers only.' I told him, 'Hell, that's all I wanted to do'.")

Geoffrey Clifton-Brown added that when constituents came to visit, there was nowhere for him to sit with them. I don't think MPs will be happy until there is the smell of frying hot dogs and onions in Westminster hall, and they can meet the voters in giant jacuzzis with poolside bars.

They wouldn't let go. Tony Wright wanted to know how the modernisation of the house was going on. "More toilets!" cried a voice which sounded like Nicholas Soames, a man with a genius for encapsulating all the complexities of a difficult issue in one crisp yet evocative phrase.

Next, the youngest MP, Mr David Lammy, last week's victor of Tottenham, formally took his seat. Before signing in he had to stand and listen to a statement by Alastair Darling. This is the point when you invariably see a look on the face of the newcomer which means: "I went through all that work, all that door-knocking, all those cringing humiliations, all those late nights - for this?"

We are told that Mr Lammy may be our first black prime minister, a view I would have thought hyperbolic, until I heard him take the oath in full - all that stuff about "almighty God" and "bearing true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth, her heirs and successors..." This is a man whose first act as an MP was to align himself firmly against the Mo Mowlam wing of the party.

Then after a cuddly greeting from the Speaker ("I hope you'll be very successful," Betty said, and I swear she pinched his cheek as she said it), he sat on the bench.

At that point Mr Gordon Brown, his face stretched into a smile like the brass plaque on an undertaker's door, leaned over and gave him a hearty handshake.

Since this is something Tony Blair hasn't received from the chancellor for years, it was the best greeting Mr Lammy could possibly get.

In the new school-like House of Commons he will have a polished apple on the teacher's desk every day and will soon wear a badge saying Prefect.

webTitle: House swap: Some possible new homes for the royals

fields.headline: House swap: Some possible new homes for the royals
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Buckingham Palace
fields.body:
Buckingham Palace

Built: 1677; royal renovations since 1762
Cost: initial conversion £73,000 (in 1762); now, take a guess.
Bedrooms: 52 royal and guest rooms, 188 staff apartments
Dining/recreation: Ballroom with seating for 1,500.
Handy for: Changing of the Guard.
Staff required: 422 plus tour guides

Possible alternative: William Hunt mansions, Harrods Village, west London

Built: 1894; new penthouse conversion
Cost: (estimated): £2.75m
Bedrooms: three suites
Recreation: Rooftop terrace includes circular spa pool
Other features: Neighbours include Mohamed Al-Fayed
Handy for: Watching the boat race

Balmoral Castle, Grampian

Built: 1853
Estimated cost: At least £3m.
Rooms: Grand ballroom and an unknown number of reception/dining/bedrooms.
Other features: 25,000 hectares (62,500 acres) of moors, mountains, farmland, forests and and 2,000 deer.
Staff: 50.
Handy for: Edinburgh festival, fishing trips

Possible alternative: Dalnaglar House, 18 miles south of Balmoral.

Built: 1864
Cost: Offers over £950,000
Rooms: 16 bedrooms; dining rooms/recreation rooms; large reception hall.
Other features: 26 hectares (66 acres) with paddocks, tennis court, pond and 5 cottages.
Staff: 3.
Handy for: getting lost

Windsor Castle, Berkshire

Built: dates from 1170
Cost: unfathomable
Rooms: 1,000
Recreation: investiture ceremonies; Queen Mary's dolls house
Other features: two chapels, large art collection
Handy for: Eton, Heathrow
Staff: 225 (plus 111 in tourism)

Possible alternative: Millennium House, west Berkshire

Built: 2000
Cost: £550,000+
Bedrooms: three, flexible design allows 'annex for elderly relative'.
Other features: Environmentally-friendly measures include water-recycling, computerised heating and solar power. As an 'intelligent' house, it will be fully wired up to the internet and have good telecommunications links.
Handy for: Ascot
Staff required: IT assistant

Sandringham

Built: Rebuilt in 1870
Cost (est): £20m
Recreation: Country pursuits, occasional craft fairs in Sandringham country park
Other features: Comes with 20,000 acre estate
Handy for: Norfolk Broads
Staff required: 140, including stud handlers

Possible alternative: Britannic Park, Birmingham

Built: 1963, new penthouse conversion
Cost: £700,000
Bedrooms: Three suites
Dining: Kitchen with metallic "Parisian café-bar style" tall table
Recreation: Shower has 23 adjustable jets for full body massage
Other features: Plasma TV screens a la Bill Gates, "panoramic views of the Birmingham skyline"
Handy for: Taking William to watch Aston Villa

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Borrow A Baby
9pm, Channel 4
Given that Britain has the highest rate of teenage pregnancies in Europe, teaming three teenagers up with other people's babies for a weekend might seem a worthwhile experiment. Which is why three couples selflessly agreed to hand over their offspring to teenagers as a lesson in parental responsibilities.

Before the teenagers moved in, each couple's house was wired up with CCTV cameras so that the anxious parents and the ever-present health visitors could monitor proceedings from their garages. By Saturday, 15-year-old Amy is covered in puke and 13-year-old Sam's young charge has pooed in the bath.

"What.. is.. wrong.. with.. you?" pleads Sam in his best alien-speak. By the time he puts young Luke in a baby bouncer, precariously balanced on the sofa, panic-stricken mum Karen is already sprinting in from the garage.

When Athletes Attack II
9.50pm, ITV

There's something perversely satisfying about watching the great and good of the sporting world lashing out in anger. Perhaps it's the knowledge that, no matter how keenly honed their muscles and minds are, they're as fallible as the rest of us. Here we see some of the world's most unsporting heroes in action. Not exactly a glowing testament to the spirit of competition but wickedly enjoyable nevertheless.

Wallace And Gromit Go Chicken
10.30pm, BBC1

A look at the work of Oscar-winning animator Nick Park, as he embarks on his first feature film, Chicken Run. Most people remember Park dressed in a tuxedo and grinning embarrassingly outside some Oscar ceremonies bash. But this film reveals a relatively serious and intensely driven person. As well as critical accolades, there are some revealing moments: such as Park hastily assuring his father that it was his cellar and not him personally that inspired the character of Wallace. Park also shows some of his first animated attempts. "Walter the Rat," he says fondly. "That was going to be my really big success."

fields.headline: Labour faces contest strife
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour MPs braced themselves for a period of party turbulence last night as Andrew Mackinlay's bid to become the backbenchers' shop steward - with enhanced powers - triggered further criticism of the current leadership.
fields.body:
Labour MPs braced themselves for a period of party turbulence last night as Andrew Mackinlay's bid to become the backbenchers' shop steward - with enhanced powers - triggered further criticism of the current leadership.

Today's weekly meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party (PLP) will see Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, face criticism from MPs on both wings of the party over government reluctance to modernise procedures - not least to give backbenchers greater powers to hold the executive to account.

Robert Sheldon, veteran chairman of the backbench liaison committee - consisting of all 25 committee chairmen - will press Mrs Beckett to endorse the case for such committees to control their own membership, free from the conformist pressure from government whips.

Other senior MPs will back him, not least because they want more done to campaign for better terms and pay for their staff at Westminster.

It was the decision of Clive Soley, current chairman of the PLP, publicly to back the government in resisting such reforms which helped goad Mr Mackinlay into announcing yesterday yesterday that he will challenge him for the job in November.

Mr Soley warned: "I think it's very unwise to go for what is, in effect, a four-months election campaign." He reminded MPs how damaging it had been for Conservatives to see the chairmen of their 1922 committee openly criticise John Major.

Mr Mackinlay brushed aside such fears.

"I am not so much standing against the present incumbent as, more importantly, seeking to shape and mould a roll for this important office," the MP for Thurrock said.

He wants future PLP chairmen to become US-style "caucus leaders" with the right to be heard by the prime minister of the day, especially since Britain is "inexorably moving towards a presidential style of government."

webTitle: Five teenagers hurt as car plunges over 150ft cliff

fields.headline: Five teenagers hurt as car plunges over 150ft cliff
fields.trailText: Five teenagers were injured, two critically, when their car plunged off a 150ft high cliff near Beachy Head in Sussex yesterday.
fields.body:
Five teenagers were injured, two critically, when their car plunged off a 150ft high cliff near Beachy Head in Sussex yesterday.

Police believe the 17-year-old driver, who is believed to have passed his test a week ago, was attempting a three-point turn on a narrow clifftop track when the blue Ford Fiesta car slipped over the edge, plunging on to the beach below.

The car's occupants, two women and three men, were thrown from the vehicle as it bounced off the cliff face on its way down. Rescuers found them scattered around the crushed remains of the car.

Police said it was a miracle that anyone survived the impact. They are understood to be investigating claims that a gate that was normally locked had been left open, allowing access to the cliff edge.

The accident happened on King's Parade in Eastbourne, East Sussex, at a spot known locally as the Sugar Loaf, one mile east of Beachy Head. A coastguard spokesman said: "Fortunately the tide was out or they would probably have drowned."

Two helicopters from Sussex police and Solent coastguard took the injured to Eastbourne district general hospital where a spokeswoman said two of the victims, a male and female, were in a critical condition with head and internal injuries.

Eastbourne's inshore lifeboat also travelled to the scene. Fire chiefs say no one was trapped in the car, which crashed over the cliff at around 4.45pm.

Superintendent Simon Parr of Eastbourne police, coordinating the investigation into the crash, said "At this point it is quite remarkable that there is anybody from the car able to speak at all to ambulance paramedics. It is too early to say how the car crashed over the cliff. It is amazing that anybody survived at all."

Ian Slothron, 38, from Brighton, sitting 150 yards from where the car crashed down on the beach, said: "It was just unbelievable. I just saw this car coming over. It was coming front first but then the driver may have hit the brakes because it seemed to spin backwards but then it crashed nose first on to the beach.

He added: "It looked like it struck the cliff on the way down and did a somersault before bouncing off the rocks before coming to rest upside down. People were screaming. I ran over to the cafe on the beach to call 999."

The cliff is 110ft high with a sheer drop for 60ft, then a 45 slope to the beach.

A spokesman for East Sussex Fire Brigade said: "It looks like it was going down the rough lane which gradually narrows into a footpath. There is a very small turning point and it looks like they have turned round to return and the car has gone over backwards.

"I would say they were in their late teens or early twenties. The car was on its roof and pretty crushed up."

Superintendent Simon Parr of Eastbourne police, coordinating the investigation into the crash, said "At this point it is quite remarkable that there is anybody from the car able to speak at all to ambulance paramedics. It is too early to say how the car crashed over the cliff. It is amazing that anybody survived at all." Ian Slothron, 38, from Brighton, sitting 150 yards from where the car crashed down on the beach, said: "It was just unbelievable. I just saw this car coming over. It was coming front first but then the driver may have hit the brakes because it seemed to spin backwards but then it crashed nose first on to the beach. He added: "It looked like it struck the cliff on the way down and did a somersault before bouncing off the rocks before coming to rest upside down. People were screaming. I ran over to the cafe on the beach to call 999." The cliff is 110ft high with a sheer drop for 60ft, then a 45 slope to the beach. A spokesman for East Sussex Fire Brigade said: "It looks like it was going down the rough lane which gradually narrows into a footpath. There is a very small turning point and it looks like they have turned round to return and the car has gone over backwards. "I would say they were in their late teens or early twenties. The car was on its roof and pretty crushed up."

webTitle: Hello! glitz too much for MPs

fields.headline: Hello! glitz too much for MPs
fields.standfirst: MPs demand inquiry into hiring of Kenwood for royal wedding
fields.trailText: A parliamentary inquiry is to be launched into how Sir Jocelyn Stevens, the former chairman of English Heritage, last year hired out the prestigious Kenwood House in London for the wedding of the daughter of his friend, former King Constantine of Greece, for a £5,000 donation.
fields.body:
A parliamentary inquiry is to be launched into how Sir Jocelyn Stevens, the former chairman of English Heritage, last year hired out the prestigious Kenwood House in London for the wedding of the daughter of his friend, former King Constantine of Greece, for a £5,000 donation.

Pam Alexander, the agency's chief executive, admitted to MPs last week that no sum had been agreed at the time for the donation, and that it had been paid nearly a year late - just before she was summoned to appear before the Commons public accounts committee.

The wedding last July, billed in Hello! magazine as the royal event of the year, united Princess Alexia, 34, and Carlos Morales Quintana, 28, a Spanish architect. It attracted two kings, seven queens, 26 princes, 33 princesses and a grand duchess. Among the guests were the Queen and Prince Charles.

On Monday night the Commons public accounts committee decided to ask Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, to hold a full investigation into the wedding arrangements after it was revealed that English Heritage could have broken the rules of a bequest by closing the house and its 112 acres of grounds bordering Hampstead Heath to the public.

MPs were furious after Ms Alexander told them that the deal had been done before the 409 homes the quango holds for the nation were made available for corporate hospitality. Under a new rule any company wanting to hire out Kenwood House would pay at least £4,000 for just two hours' use of the house at a time when it is closed to the public. This fee would not include use of the grounds. On this basis the cost to King Constantine of hiring the house for the wedding would have been between £10,000 and £20,000.

The deal was disclosed after David Rendel, Liberal Democrat MP for Newbury and a member of the public accounts committee, demanded details last week. After getting Ms Alexander to agree that it was not English Heritage's policy to shut homes owned by the agency to meet the demands of corporate hospitality, he pressed the case. When questioned about the deal she said: "I would be surprised if it had not come through my then chairman, Sir Jocelyn Stevens."

She said the king was "a personal acquaintance of his, and therefore I imagine there may well have been a direct approach".

She added: "We agreed that the wedding would be of benefit and that the benefit would be the advantage of the publicity, and that a donation would be offered, but most importantly, we ensured that all of our costs would be covered."

Last night a spokeswoman for English Heritage told the Guardian that the proposal had been approved by the commissioners of the quango. The royal protection squad had insisted that the grounds be closed, the spokeswoman said.

At the time of the wedding Martin Wright, chairman of the Heath and Hampstead Society, wrote to Sir Jocelyn, demanding details of the arrangement and protesting at the commercialisation of Kenwood. Sir Jocelyn accused him of "asking impertinent questions" and tore up his letter at a public meeting.

webTitle: Mugabe's new threat to grab land

fields.headline: Mugabe's new threat to grab land
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: A defiant President Robert Mugabe last night vowed to continue with his controversial policy of seizing and redistributing white-owned land after being thrown a political lifeline in Zimbabwe's general election.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele  and  Andrew Meldrum in Harare
fields.body:
A defiant President Robert Mugabe last night vowed to continue with his controversial policy of seizing and redistributing white-owned land after being thrown a political lifeline in Zimbabwe's general election.

In a nationwide television address, a relieved looking Mr Mugabe promised to work towards national reconciliation after his Zanu-PF party scrambled to victory by the narrowest of margins over the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

But he could not resist a sideswipe at foreign observers who had condemned the electoral process as tainted. In his 10-minute broadcast, Mr Mugabe said many had come to Zimbabwe with pre-conceived notions "in the mould of Victorian missionaries who came to pacify and redeem the natives. They go home humbled and educated."

He now faces a strong opposition in parliament for the first time since 1980. Seven government ministers were swept away as a tide of protest over unemployment, inflation and high level corruption gave the MDC 57 seats, only five short of Zanu-PF's total. The opposition won every seat in Harare and Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's two main cities. There is one independent.

Along with the 20 extra MPs whom the president is allowed to appoint, plus 10 traditional chiefs, Zanu-PF's 62 seats give it a strong working majority in parliament. But it fell short of the two-thirds needed to pass amendments to the constitution, a measure used earlier this year to authorise the seizure of white-owned land.

President Mugabe also made it clear that he would not back off his plans to take white-owned land and give it to Africans. "There are great expectations around land which will soon come to the people in a big way," he said.

An unsmiling Mr Mugabe read slowly from a text and rarely looked up. "Victory and defeat are quick to reconcile, quick to connect and cohabit in the same national space for greater peace and togetherness. The results are out. They bind us all, losers and winners alike." Without mentioning the MDC by name, he said he wanted to see unity across Zimbabwe.

In London, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, pointedly chose not to congratulate Mr Mugabe on his victory. Instead, he said Britain would withhold £36m earmarked for land reform in Zimbabwe unless the new government steered a path of national reconciliation.

"This is a crucial moment for Zimbabwe. In the event of real reforms which reflect the people of Zimbabwe's clear desire for change, Britain will be ready to respond."

The MDC, which was founded seven months ago, had become infected with optimism in the last stages of the campaign and felt cheated yesterday. "Our supporters expected a sweeping victory. Without the subversion we would easily have won this election. There is no doubt in my mind," its leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, declared.

The result was a huge relief for President Mugabe, who felt the entire foreign press, as well as western governments, were against him. The defeat of one of his main party rivals, Emmerson Mnangagwa, the justice minister, eases the pressure on him to make an early announcement that he will not stand in the presidential elections of 2002. Now he has more time to decide his future than if his party had lost the election and started to rebel against its leader.

Mr Tsvangirai was evasive yesterday on whether he would urge foreign governments to keep maintaining Mr Mugabe at arm's length. "We must let him clean up his own mess," he said, adding: "Targeting Mugabe and targeting Zimbabwe are separate things."

Mr Mugabe's victory was based on a strong showing in rural areas, where a combination of intimidation, conservatism and respect for the man who brought the country to independence carried Zanu-PF forward.

To the delight of the pro-government press, which splashed the news on its front page, Mr Tsvangirai failed to win his rural constituency. The MDC leader refused to see this as a humiliation, saying he had been warned by agents of the central intelligence organisation that they would target his seat to ensure his defeat.

Mr Tsvangirai intends to challenge the results in about 20 seats, either by calling for a recount or through the courts. Another 12 Zanu-PF MPs already face court proceedings on various charges, including Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi, the leader of the war veterans who have invaded white-owned farms.

But the opposition does not want to get bogged down in legal battles. It wants to build experience in a parliament where none of its members has ever sat.

webTitle: Tory blow as revival is halted

fields.headline: Tory blow as revival is halted
fields.standfirst:
ICM poll

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Labour is 11 points ahead of the Conservatives in this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll, which puts Tony Blair firmly back into the comfort zone and suggests that the revival in support for the Tories since last month's local elections has been halted.
fields.body:
Labour is 11 points ahead of the Conservatives in this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll, which puts Tony Blair firmly back into the comfort zone and suggests that the revival in support for the Tories since last month's local elections has been halted.

The survey will dash Tory strategists' hopes of using the momentum from the May election successes and William Hague's populist campaigns on law and order and asylum seekers to bridge the gap in time for next year's general election.

May's Guardian/ICM poll showed Labour's lead cut to seven points, and other opinion polls suggested that a Conservative revival was under way. But today's survey shows the Tories have again slumped to the low 30s - on 32% - where their support has languished for the past year.

Results of the poll's regular monthly euro question show a sharp rise in the "don't knows", from 14% to 19%, and falls in both the proportion who would vote against Britain joining the euro (down two points to 58%) and those who would vote to join (down four points to its lowest level ever at 23%). But while support for joining the single currency has slumped to its lowest level yet, some 40% still believe that it is inevitable that Britain will join the euro, and that in 10 years it will be the currency of most of Europe, including the UK. The proportion who believe euro membership is inevitable has risen from 36% in July 1999, giving ministers hope that there is still some "middle ground" who may be persuaded to back the single currency in the referendum expected after the general election. The ICM poll also found that 25% believe that by 2010 the euro will be the currency of most of Europe, but that Britain will retain the pound - about the same as a year ago.

Detailed analysis shows that the sharpest erosion in support for Labour in the last year has been among women in the 18-35 age group. In early 1999, Labour enjoyed a 40 point lead over the Conservatives among women of this age group, compared with a 23 point lead among men of the same age. But in the last 12 months the lead among this group has fallen by a staggering 19 points. Labour still enjoys a healthy lead among younger voters, of 21 points for both men and women. The poll found no significant gender gap between older men and women voters.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,061 adults, aged 18 and over, by telephone between June 23-26. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results were weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: A legacy of division
fields.standfirst:
Mr Mugabe's conditional victory

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe today enters what is likely to be the most hectic and dangerous period in the country's history as an independent state.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe today enters what is likely to be the most hectic and dangerous period in the country's history as an independent state. The election shows the country divided as never before - between two parties and political movements of equal weight, and between the urban areas, which voted strongly for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change , and the rural areas, which generally supported the government party, Zanu-PF.

That there was widespead intimidation and other irregularities we already know. Yet it seems unlikely that the appeals the MDC is making against the results in some constituencies, or the byelections it may force in the case of ministers charged with corruption, will change the broad picture even if they have some successes. President Robert Mugabe and the government party will continue to control the levers of power, but the MDC, strongly represented in parliament, will have a much more secure base from which to seek to win the hearts and minds of citizens in the two years until presidential elections take place in 2002.

There seems little chance of the coalition government that some have suggested, because neither side wants it. Zanu-PF sees no advantage in sharing power with the MDC, while the MDC sees no advantage in sharing responsibility for the country's many woes with Zanu-PF. So the stage is set for a political campaign of a kind which Zimbabwe has never seen before. Much will depend on how it is conducted. Both parties have substantial real constituencies, even if that of Zanu-PF is smaller than the actual numbers which violent and unfair tactics enabled them to enlist as voters. The MDC will want the access to rural areas, to put their case before conservative country folk, which they were often de nied in the past. Zanu-PF will strive not only to retain rural allegiances, in particular by distributing at least some of the white farming land it has promised to hand out, but also to regain the urban voters it has clearly lost. Foreign aid is critical here. Zimbabwe was already in deep economic trouble before the rampage against white farmers and their workers began. That cost the country the proceeds of a tobacco harvest and the income that would have come in from other agricultural commodities.

If agricultural income is to be stabilised, let alone fully restored, there has to be aid from outside to help the new farmers and compensate those displaced. Zanu-PF may now be ready to meet the conditions which Britain has outlined because, with the election behind it, it now needs the money more than it needs the issue. The opposition's ambivalence is already evident. It cannot be seen to be blocking aid which the country needs but it does not want Mugabe to get so much aid that he can rescue himself politically.

Yet the pressing need for aid may persuade Zanu-PF to conduct the political contest in a more civilised way, and thus bring benefits to the opposition. The game will be a complex one, and not only between the parties, for there is obviously a serious possibility of change within Zanu-PF. Chenjerai Hunzvi, the war veterans' leader who orchestrated the invasion of white farms, lost no time yesterday in calling for "an overhaul from the grassroots to the top." Outside powers, whose attitude to President Mugabe and decisions about aid will have an unavoidable effect on what happens on the ground, will need to exercise cool judgment over the next two years as the next phase in the politics of Zimbabwe works itself out.

fields.headline: Playing the palace
fields.standfirst:
The Queen has little to fear from Mo

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen has little to fear from Mo
fields.body:
Mo has really gone over the top this time. Asked by Saga magazine if she stood by the view she took six years ago that the Queen should move out of Buckingham Palace and open it up to the people, Dr Mowlam confessed with her usual frankness that she did. She liked Prince Charles and Princess Anne and her dealings with the Queen had been agreeable, but she wasn't a fan of the royal family and believed the monarchy would have to evolve.

Downing Street could hardly have been more alarmed had she driven up the Mall in a tumbrel. Mr Blair, we were told, was an ardent supporter of the monarchy. He valued his relationship with the Queen and felt the royal family played a central role in our national life. The Tories, sensing a swing against Labour, crowed. A phalanx of sapient commentators wheeled into action. Once Professor Starkey had spoken, Lord St John of Fawsley, Lord Blake and Professor Bogdanor could hardly be far behind.

And yet what the minister said was hardly republicanism. Real republicans rarely advise the monarchy to evolve. They prefer to keep it as unreformed as possible, since that in their estimation makes it more vulnerable. Nor is the call for the palace to be vacated so flamingly radical. In April the Public Records Office released details of a plan submitted to Harold Wilson back in the 1960s by Sir William Armstrong, when as permanent secretary to the Treasury he was asked to investigate ways of reducing the family's spending. The Queen, he advised, should move to a purely private house which she would pay for herself. The palace would then become a historical monument open to the public and available for great ceremonial occasions. As for her majesty, she is probably far less agitated by what Mo confided to Saga than are those now squawking on her behalf. The Queen is a grown up person. It's a shame that so many of her eminent subjects have yet to reach that condition.
