webTitle: Fear and uncertainty grip white farmers as they await their fate

fields.headline: Fear and uncertainty grip white farmers as they await their fate
fields.standfirst:
Land issue: 'Veterans' stay in occupation, fuel is short and safety is in doubt

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The hope and anxiety with which Alan Hart regards his newly ploughed fields matches the mood of Zimbabwe following the parliamentary elections. "I hope to plant new crops soon, but the future is uncertain," said Mr Hart. "I don't know if law and order will be restored so that my family can move back onto the farm. I don't know what the government will do about the land situation. We don't have enough diesel to prepare our fields and we don't know when the fuel will be available.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Goromonzi, northern Zimbabwe
fields.body:
The hope and anxiety with which Alan Hart regards his newly ploughed fields matches the mood of Zimbabwe following the parliamentary elections. "I hope to plant new crops soon, but the future is uncertain," said Mr Hart. "I don't know if law and order will be restored so that my family can move back onto the farm. I don't know what the government will do about the land situation. We don't have enough diesel to prepare our fields and we don't know when the fuel will be available.

In Mr Hart's opinion, the Movement for Democratic Change did very well in the elections, considering the "violence, intimidation and rigging" that they faced. . "But I don't know if the results will guarantee a return to normality for the country or a return to conditions that will allow me to get on with farming."

Mr Hart and his wife and three children left the farm in May after he received death threats from government officials because of his work to the MDC. Unlike many other white farmers, Mr Hart decided to keep supporting the MDC and to evacuate his farm.

Like many of Zimbabwe's white minority, Mr Hart had not taken an interest in politics since independence. "Most whites accepted the status quo as long as we were in our comfort zone," he said. "But now I believe if we want to stay here then we must be involved in politics."

Over the next few weeks four other white farmers were killed. After that, Mr Hart had to take it seriously when his name appeared on a "hit list" circulated by top Zanu-PF officials.

The president, Robert Mugabe, based his party's electoral campaign on the land issue and concentrated on painting the country's white farmers as demons. He repeatedly said that white Rhodesians stole land from black Africans without paying any compensation and therefore it was time for Africans to take back their land. Mr Mugabe incited his supporters to invade white-owned farms and claim them as their own.

But there are many who do not fit Mr Mugabe's definition of white farmer equals white racism. Mr Hart is one of them. He is leasing his 25-hectare farm from a black African woman. He believes he is a good and fair employer and has ambitious plans to help black Africans start up similar small export operations. After the threats, he had to reduce his staff from 15 to 12 employees and could only safely visit his farm for a few hours every two weeks.

Yesterday Mr Hart returned to the abandoned farmhouse to oversee the preparation of fields for a new crop of marigolds. Now that Zimbabwe's elections are over, Mr Hart wants to move back onto the farm with his family, but he is not certain if he will be safe from the violence of state-sponsored war veterans and Zanu-PF supporters. "Once they've let the genie out of the bottle that brings violence and intimidation, it will be hard to put it back in. Zanu-PF has made promises they can't keep and that does not augur well for a return to normality."

The future of Zimbabwe's agriculture is equally uncertain. More than 1,400 farms are occupied by Zanu-PF supporters. On Mr Mugabe's orders, police have refused to protect the mostly white owners. Mr Mugabe has taken steps to seize 804 farms without paying compensation and he vowed repeatedly during the election campaign that poor blacks would be moved onto those farms quickly.

A great deal is at stake. The commercial farms are Zimbabwe's largest employer with more than 300,000 full-time jobs. It is also the country's largest earner of desperately short foreign exchange. The widespread violence on the commercial farms has contributed to a more general breakdown of law and order.

But it is not clear if Mr Mugabe will order his followers off the occupied farms or begin land redistribution programme. Some officials say Mr Mugabe is determined to pursue the course he has begun.

"It is more than just the future of commercial agriculture that is uncertain," said David Gollach, director of a firm which processes paprika for export. "We don't know if Mugabe will change the economic policies that are ruining this country. We don't know if he will pull our troops out of the Congo war. We don't know if he will order the police to restore the rule of law."

But Mr Gollach is optimistic. "This is the beginning of the end for Mugabe and the beginning of a viable democracy," he said. "The MDC achieved more than simply winning 57 seats. It attracted support from blacks and whites, Shonas and Ndebeles, urban and rural people. The MDC is a truly national party and that is a great achievement.

"In contrast, Zanu-PF is not nearly so impressive. Mugabe won the election but he destroyed the country and the economy to do it. He will find it very difficult to rule over the shambles he has created."

fields.headline: First Tuesday fee provokes row
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: First Tuesday, the technology and internet networking group, is to cash in on its dating service that plays match-maker between entrepreneurs and investors, by charging a fee.
fields.body:
First Tuesday, the technology and internet networking group, is to cash in on its dating service that plays match-maker between entrepreneurs and investors, by charging a fee.

However, the proposal has already drawn complaints from some venture capital clients who have threatened to bypass the service.

The 2% fee will be charged only if a deal is successfully concluded between an entrepreneur with a business plan and one of the investors. These match-making sessions are separate from the weekly forums that First Tuesday holds.

The seventh match-making forum will be held next month. It is distinguished from First Tuesday's other services because it only gathers together a handpicked group of venture capitalists and e-business entrepreneurs whose business plans have been screened by an accounting firm.

On Monday, the first match on which First Tuesday collected its success fee was concluded with the $2m (£1.4m) financing deal for OpenMobile.

Jo Taylor, 3i's head of British technology investment, is not a fan of the new service. He said that venture capitalists preferred to deal with the principals of a business they were investing in and not intermediaries.

"It might lead us to the decision to bypass altogether First Tuesday," Mr Taylor said. "It might not be a great thing for that organisation. I think they would be challenged in terms of their pricing power and value of their network.

"It could be the case that the better-name investors go elsewhere."

Daniel Chamier, venture capital analyst at JP Morgan, said: "I think it can work, but they are going to struggle as they haven't really got the credentials. Probably people [venture capitalists] would find ways around it."

First Tuesday has about 100,000 members globally and said that in the past 18 months $150m in seed capital for busi ness had been invested because of its network.

Julie Meyer, co-founder of First Tuesday, said generating a revenue had always been in the organisation's business plan. "We are not trying to milk people," she said. "We realise quite a lot of deals get done in our market place and we are creating value."

Christopher Spray, a partner at Atlas Ventures, is one venture capitalist who thinks the fee is a good idea.

"It's something that will be viewed as being acceptable by some venture capitalists and not by others. We have not attended an event so far that has been fee-charging. We plan to attend to see what the quality of the opportunity is going to be."

First Tuesday is looking at other ways of generating a revenue stream, including charging for providing a recruitment service. Its website has a bulletin board where companies can advertise for staff. In London, the bulletin board draws 600 ads weekly.

webTitle: Junior doctors 'lack training' for life or death decisions

fields.headline: Junior doctors 'lack training' for life or death decisions
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The British Medical Association warned yesterday that inexperienced junior doctors are often left to decide whether seriously ill patients should be denied resuscitation without proper guidance from consultants or adequate training in how to consult the patients' families.
fields.body:
The British Medical Association warned yesterday that inexperienced junior doctors are often left to decide whether seriously ill patients should be denied resuscitation without proper guidance from consultants or adequate training in how to consult the patients' families.

Their representatives at the association's annual conference in London backed a resolution against junior doctors being "coerced or cajoled" into signing Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) orders. They called on the BMA medical ethics committee to consider whether doctors should be obliged to get written consent from patients or their families before taking these decisions.

The debate was sparked by a case last month when Jill Baker, 67, from Southampton, who has stomach cancer and was being treated for septicaemia, discovered after leaving hospital that a DNR order had been written in her notes by a junior doctor. Neither she nor her husband had been consulted.

The charity Age Concern complained that elderly people were being written off by DNR orders from doctors.

The BMA said its guidelines recommended maximum consultation with patients and supervision by consultants of decisions on whether resuscitation would save life.

Alex Freeman, a Southampton GP, said: "In reality, far too many DNR orders are made by inexperienced junior doctors, usually at the request of nursing staff and often in the middle of the night or on call during busy weekends when patients are moribund or relatives are unavailable.

"It is unacceptable for DNR orders to be made by doctors who are not familiar with the patient and by junior doctors with no input from patients or senior staff, and for juniors to be forced into making these decisions."

Dr Freeman added that the DNR procedure was often appropriate. He said postponing death was "not the same as prolonging life and attempting resuscitation when it is clearly futile is insensitive and undignified."

Mark Porter, a Coventry consultant anaesthetist, told how, as a junior doctor, he was called in the middle of the night after a dying cancer patient's heart stopped. "The two nurses who were doing CPR [trying to restart the heart] said they wanted me to tell them to stop.

"I agreed it was the right decision but felt unhappy that I had to make it because it had not been made by the admitting team who knew the patient. This is typical of my experience as a junior doctor."

Jonathan Fielden, a Reading consultant in intensive care, said patients were misled by hospital dramas on television into believing that attempts to resuscitate would usually succeed. The real figures showed a survival rate of 10-15% of patients resuscitated outside hospital and 15-30% inside. Of those, only half would live for a further three years.

"Doctors need to be able to take these decisions but they need to communicate with patients and their relatives first," Dr Fielden said.

Michael Wilks, chairman of the medical ethics committee, defended DNR guidelines drawn up last year by the BMA, the Royal College of Nurses and the Resuscitation Council.

He urged caution about the conference resolution that DNR orders should not be made without written consent from the patient or patient's family.

"A consent form is just a piece of paper. What matters is what happens before that consent form is signed. Doctors should be more aware of existing guidelines."

fields.headline: Under pressure
fields.standfirst:
Whatever happened to Mayor Ken's grandiose plans and the devolution of power to local government?

Livingstone's London: special report
fields.trailText: Say what you like about Ken, but he's not afraid to talk big and aim high. To celebrate his formal accession to power as London's first elected mayor on Monday, he had wanted to throw a massive street party, drawing 250,000 people into the capital - just like the Thames Days of yore, when the Greater London Council spent pots of ratepayers' money organising giant knees-ups.
fields.body:
Say what you like about Ken, but he's not afraid to talk big and aim high. To celebrate his formal accession to power as London's first elected mayor on Monday, he had wanted to throw a massive street party, drawing 250,000 people into the capital - just like the Thames Days of yore, when the Greater London Council spent pots of ratepayers' money organising giant knees-ups. When he realised he had no staff to organise it, the new mayor refused to let his dream die. So now he promises that, at this time every year, London will have it's very own Independence Weekend, celebrating the moment when the capital broke free. "Sometimes it will coincide with the fourth of July," he says mischievously.

Ken Livingstone has not lost his talent for the eye-catching idea - or for shooting his mouth off. As if comparing the creation of his new job with America's declaration of independence is not grandiose enough, Ken allows himself a fantasy about the capital joining the euro - on its own. "London could clearly survive as a separate, independent country within Europe," he says, noting that the city's economy is overtaking that of Austria and that its population is "up there in the Belgium league".

So far, big talk like that is pretty well all Livingstone has been able to produce. Instead of that bash he wanted on Monday, he promises "a big, boring speech". There will be no magic wand to transform the capital overnight, no instant sense of living in Livingstone's London - for the same reason there could be no splashy party. He just doesn't have the staff. Unlike his counterparts in Edinburgh and Cardiff, Ken had no equivalent of the Scottish or Welsh Office to inherit. He has had to create a machine from scratch. That has forced him to spend the eight weeks since his victory knee-deep in job applications and "transition meetings". He predicts it will be Christmas before he can really start making a difference.

Which is a smart politician's way of lowering expectations. The truth, Livingstone admits, is that he "loves" the job, even before it has started. His every move gets publicity, whether handing posts to former rivals, such as Glenda Jackson and Steve Norris, or asking Bob Geldof to organise yet another big party for New Year's Eve. And, despite the frustrations, he has some real power. He has been horrified to discover that he alone can decide on planning applications. He's realised that a corrupt successor could grow very fat on the bribes of property developers. All of which makes Mayor Livingstone a figure of envy - at least to the 1,500 or so people gathering in Bournemouth today. They are the Local Government Association, foot soldiers in the army of grassroots democracy. And their outlook is not nearly as sunny as Ken's.

Not for them the buzz of a glamour mayoralty. They are stuck with the thankless tasks of clearing up rubbish, organising libraries and tending the elderly in villages, towns and cities which don't get Technicolor attention. But that is not their complaint; they are happy with the job they are supposed to do. The problem is a central government which seems hell bent on stopping them doing it.

The paradox of New Labour used to be that it decentralised more power than any government had ever done before - via devolution - only to deal with party activists and the press like a power-grabbing control freak.

Yet now we have a prime minister who admits his attempt to stop Welsh Labourites picking Rhodri Morgan was a "mistake" and who tells the WI he no longer wants to fight over "every headline". Meanwhile, in the areas of substance that matter, the government is sending the devolution process into reverse - crushing local authorities by grabbing their powers and keeping them for Whitehall. The paradox has been reversed. Now Labour seems ready to loosen its grip on message - but determined to keep control over power.

So Gordon Brown's last budget bypassed local education authorities by sending top-up money for schools directly to head teachers. Now the LEAs fear they will be done away with altogether, with London sending even the core money to schools direct. In health something similar is afoot, with Alan Milburn centralising yet further an already centralised service. Local councils now fear the health secretary is eyeing up one of their biggest jobs: responsibility for the elderly. In every government department there are ministers and bureaucrats handing money to councils on condition that they spend it Whitehall's way - to meet Whitehall's targets on Whitehall's timetable.

No wonder people in local government feel as besieged as they were in the dark days of Thatcherism. Not only is turnout in local elections depressingly low but now, as then, they face an ideological enemy in Downing Street. For all his talk of community, Tony Blair has little patience or respect for councillors and their works. In the Blairite view, local democracy is not the route to efficient public services, but an obstacle in the way. If schools need to be turned around, then LEAs are not the ones to do it; only Whitehall can. The government's guiding maxim is the old cliche: "If a job needs doing, you'd better do it yourself."

That leaves the folks in Bournemouth with quite a challenge. They have to tackle head-on the notion that democracy and quality are enemies. They could begin by pointing out that central government is hardly a paragon of efficiency itself. Ken Livingstone says no local council could ever match the Home Office's asylum and immigration department for sheer "incompetent maladministration". And it is the ultra-centralised NHS which has produced "postcode rationing" - failing to bring the equality of provision that is meant to be central government's forte.

Next, councillors have to improve their own performance, providing better services and communicating with their constituents more often and more fluently (one of Bournemouth's big themes). They need to disprove their critics in central government, showing they can raise their game.

Finally, they have to remake the case for democracy in principle. That means persuading us all that a pin-striped bureaucrat in Whitehall is never going to organise a home-help system for the elderly in South Shields as well as a person who lives among, and was elected by, the people of South Shields. They need to turn back on Labour the very same logic Labour itself deployed to argue for devolution in Scotland, Wales and London: that, in Mayor Livingstone's words, "You can't run Britain from the centre."

If the folks gathering in Bournemouth today can remake that case, they will not only arrest Labour's stealth programme of centralisation. They might even even create a virtuous circle. For the better job they do, the more power and money we'll all be prepared to give them - and the more we'll want to vote when their jobs come up for election. Ken has shown that local democracy can be exciting. Now the grassroots army have to show that it can work.

Ken Livingstone says no local council could ever match the Home Office's asylum and immigration department for sheer "incompetent maladministration". And it is the ultra-centralised NHS which has produced "postcode rationing" - failing to bring the equality of provision that is meant to be central government's forte. Next, councillors have to improve their own performance, providing better services and communicating with their constituents more often and more fluently (one of Bournemouth's big themes). They need to disprove their critics in central government, showing they can raise their game. Finally, they have to remake the case for democracy in principle. That means persuading us all that a pin-striped bureaucrat in Whitehall is never going to organise a home-help system for the elderly in South Shields as well as a person who lives among, and was elected by, the people of South Shields. They need to turn back on Labour the very same logic Labour itself deployed to argue for devolution in Scotland, Wales and London: that, in Mayor Livingstone's words, "You can't run Britain from the centre." If the folks gathering in Bournemouth today can remake that case, they will not only arrest Labour's stealth programme of centralisation. They might even even create a virtuous circle. For the better job they do, the more power and money we'll all be prepared to give them - and the more we'll want to vote when their jobs come up for election. Ken has shown that local democracy can be exciting. Now the grassroots army have to show that it can work. jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com

webTitle: Postman Pat: the most trusted government agent

fields.headline: Postman Pat: the most trusted government agent
fields.standfirst:
Rural post offices are set to become bankers for the underclass

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government has discovered how much people love the Post Office. Warm Postman Pat responses flooded the focus groups. It is the one arm of government people clasp to their hearts, evoking images of village shops with roses round the door where apple-cheeked postmistresses dispense postal orders and sealing wax along with the bull's-eyes, ices and minerals.
fields.body:
The government has discovered how much people love the Post Office. Warm Postman Pat responses flooded the focus groups. It is the one arm of government people clasp to their hearts, evoking images of village shops with roses round the door where apple-cheeked postmistresses dispense postal orders and sealing wax along with the bull's-eyes, ices and minerals. Children pay a few pennies pocket money into Post Office savings book, while those who once collected sweet ration coupons at the counter now draw pensions there. Many people told researchers they found banks snooty and intimidating but post offices made them feel at home. Claimants who hate benefit offices feel nothing but warmth for post offices which pay out the benefits.

This folk memory is so powerful that it may block out the reality, which can be harsher (I think of the long queues of the downtrodden at my seedy local crown office). Dusty tins and yellowing birthday cards are the hallmarks of less enterprising sub-post offices, enticing ever fewer employed people who live in a world of credit cards and cash machines, in-trays at work for their mail and direct debit for their bills. Twenty-eight million people may use post offices every week but it's mainly the old and the poor who stand in queues. Fond nostalgia for post offices may not translate into frequent use by more lucrative customers.

The crisis for the nation's 19,000 post offices comes to a head in 2003, when all benefits will be paid into claimants' bank accounts, and not over the post office counter. These new automatic credit transfers will save the state a fortune - each payment that now costs 49p to administer will cost only 1p. But for post offices it spells disaster, since one third of their income comes from the contract with the benefits agency: without that many of these marginal sub-post offices would close. (Only 600 are crown post offices, the rest are franchised private businesses.) Thousands of sub-post masters marched on Downing Street a couple of months ago, alerting government to their plight. It isn't just village post offices at risk. In blasted urban wildernesses where every other business has fled the poverty, crime and vandalism, the post office is usually the last survivor and the only hope of future regeneration to urge other businesses to return. The paying of benefits was almost their only profitable business, without which they will collapse.

Seeing decline and trouble ahead, Mrs Thatcher wanted to privatise it and to get rid of this limping business. But Michael Heseltine drew back, faced with overwhelming opposition from his own tribe, outraged at the sacrilege to the Queen's head on the stamp and the risk to rural post offices in Tory heartland shires. Giro bank was sold off and Mrs Thatcher had to be satisfied with that. When Tony Blair reached the part of his speech to the WI where he mentioned rural post offices, the women broke out in the loudest jeers of all, shouting "No! No!" Although he promised to preserve them, they weren't listening or didn't believe it. But he meant it and tomorrow they will see it when the government sets out a multimillion pound rescue and revitalisation plan.

First there will be a new bank at the post office, the Universal Bank. It will reach the 3.5m people who have no bank account, the "unbanked underclass" who lose out heavily for lack of decent financial services. Pensioners and claimants will have their benefits paid into their Universal Bank account at the post office: if they wish they can collect their money in cash as usual. But the aim is to help them use direct debits for bills, so they too can gain the 10% discounts earned by the middle classes but not by the poor. They too can have cheque books and cards for withdrawing their money when and where they choose. Most important, they will get access to loans for first time and escape the clutches of loan sharking companies, often their only source of credit.

The big banks are to have their arms sharply twisted to help found this new bank, rubbing their noses in the shameful way they have abandoned every unprofitable community, rural and urban alike.

However the Universal Bank won't on its own generate enough post office business to compensate for the loss of the benefit payments. The government's performance and innovation unit looked long and hard at the post office business. It weighed up profits and losses (8,000 post offices already lose money, before the benefit money is withdrawn). Then they weighed up the social value and found that postmasters and postmen act as advisers, friends and supporters of the old, the poor and the lost. They are trusted as no other arm of government. That trust and affection is too valuable to be thrown away as unprofitable. So tomorrow the government will announce payments of many millions to develop that role for sub-post offices, turning them into "government general practitioners". They will be trained to become the semi-professional point of access for every kind of government service. Already 170 different services cross the post office counter, but why not more? Why not information about local adult education classes, local school league tables, volunteering, access to all local government services from pest control to dustbin inquiries? Why not add internet access terminals and offer information from the internet for those who can't use it themselves? The government will pay sub-post offices a fee to do all this in the areas that most need it, both in villages and in urban wastelands. (Urban post offices in well-served areas would have to sink or swim on their own initiative.) The idea is for the post office to become the friendly and useful face of government in an ever more complex world, where people don't know where to turn for help. At the same time, they will offer more professional help for sub-post offices to generate commercial income, sweeping away the fly-blown old image of the worst.

All this springs from the government's aim to regenerate places bereft of any sense of community. Some post offices may never be profitable but they could become focal, energising local centres to encourage other enterprises back into desolate places. The bottom line is no longer the most important thing: value to the community matters more. This is precisely the kind of thinking we need more of. Since we are to become so much richer in the next decade (national growth of at least 30%), for the first time there is the finance, the intelligence and the will to spend that money well - not squandered on private excess and extravagance, but well spent on public things people most prize in their communities, from the rich in their model villages to the poor on their housing estates, a perfect lesson in the good value of public spending.

webTitle: The biotech bullshit that baffles brains

fields.headline: The biotech bullshit that baffles brains
fields.standfirst:
I haven't the faintest idea what these scientists are talking about

GM debate: special report
fields.trailText: I was instinctively against the idea of GM crops until I heard that they've managed to isolate the gene that makes mangetouts vaguely posh. Soon it will possible to ask for mangetouts in the greengrocers without feeling a bit stupid.
fields.body:
I was instinctively against the idea of GM crops until I heard that they've managed to isolate the gene that makes mangetouts vaguely posh. Soon it will possible to ask for mangetouts in the greengrocers without feeling a bit stupid.

What has already been achieved with vegetables will now be possible with humans. We could find the gene that makes people pretend to sit and read the credits in the cinema. The gene that makes us keep looking round at our new cars when we've just parked them. And of course the gene that makes us lose concentration when we read about the linear sequences of amino acids in the synthesis of proteins. Judging by some of the rubbish that has been written about DNA this week, the leap from vegetable to human is not such a great one. Pages and pages have been churned out by pompous leader writers hailing this incredible scientific breakthrough and using the word "millennium" a lot. Why can't everyone just be honest about it; put their hands up and say: "Sorry, but I haven't the faintest bloody idea what these scientists are talking about, but they tell us it's important so I suppose we'd better take their word for it." Most of us were completely baffled by Monday's breakthrough in genetic decoding.

"I thought they'd just closed down DNA?"

"No, that was C'n'A wasn't it?"

We are told that the Book of Life is the most complex sequence of letters ever written, though whoever said that never took One Hundred Years of Solitude on holiday.

"Let us be in no doubt about what we are witnessing today . . ." proclaimed Tony Blair, "a revolution in science that far surpasses even the discovery of antibodies." I wish that instead of nodding wisely and trying to look moved, the journalists had asked him: "So could you explain it a bit further please, Tony?"

"Er . . . well. . . erm, there's your chromosomes and er - genes and DNA and stuff . . . anyway, must dash, nappies to change and all that."

Bill Clinton wouldn't take questions either. His advisers were worried that journalists asking about DNA storing vital information might set him off denying having sex with Monica Lewinsky all over again. DNA on genes you say? I could have sworn it was on her dress.

Now the debate has quickly moved on to the predictable second stage - the ethical and moral debate. This discussion is as old as science itself. When the first caveman invented the wheel, an anxious discussion no doubt ensued as to what terrible uses this "wheel" might be put - a nightmare which finally became reality in the 70s when the first Austin Allegro rolled off the production line. But you can't attack the pioneers for the social consequences of their work (Captain Cook discovered Australia but you can't blame him for Neighbours). If there are discoveries to be made then people will seek them out. Of course there are dangers. We must not have people being discriminated against because of their genetic inheritance - Carol Thatcher excepted. We cannot allow the insurance companies to demand genetic testing. They should continue to refuse to pay out to everyone on the same equal basis. The risks are not from science itself but, as always, from the way we have constructed our society. You don't have to have read the Book of Life to know that unless they are restrained some individuals will try to use this week's breakthrough to increase their own wealth and power at the expense of others.

There may well be areas of human endeavour that are best left to the private sector, such as cosmetic surgery and pizza deliveries. But the future of the world's health, the right to patent and profit from human genes, ultimately to redesign and alter our species, is not something I would want to entrust to the good people who run the multinational drug companies. Yesterday's Times argues that without the profit motive the next stage of scientific development would happen more slowly - as if we are all impatiently sitting around saying: "Come on, boffins! The rate of scientific change at the moment is no nowhere near fast enough!"

We have to take control of what is happening. How is it than we are able to decode the entire genetic make up of human beings - something it would take one person 50 years to type out (or longer if they had to keep stopping to overrule their spellcheck) and yet we are already admitting defeat at the comparatively minor challenge of regulating and legislating to ensure all this work is put to the best use? The prize of conquering susceptibility to so many diseases is too precious to surrender to the inherently discriminatory free market. This information belongs to us all - our politicians need to work as fast as our scientists to make sure it stays that way. And while we are at it, we need to find and isolate that gene that makes some people only be motivated by the lure of enormous personal wealth. A billion dollars for the first one who finds it.

webTitle: More aid for childhood jab victims

fields.headline: More aid for childhood jab victims
fields.trailText: Children left disabled by routine vaccinations for diseases such as whooping cough and measles are to get increased    payments from the government. After a 20-year campaign by the families of children who suffered mental and physical handicaps through inoculations, Alistair Darling, the social security secretary,   yesterday announced a £60m boost to the aid package.
fields.body:
Children left disabled by routine vaccinations for diseases such as whooping cough and measles are to get increased payments from the government. After a 20-year campaign by the families of children who suffered mental and physical handicaps through inoculations, Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, yesterday announced a £60m boost to the aid package.

One-off payments to new victims will be more than doubled, to reach £100,000, while the families of 900 children who have already had cash will get lump-sum payments of up to £67,000 to pay for nursing and equipment.

The move follows a two-year review of the vaccine damage payment scheme, set up in 1979 and criticised by campaigners as wholly inadequate. Families of vaccine-damaged children have recently stepped up their campaign to press ministers to reach a new settlement, although government efforts to press drug companies to contribute towards the fund have failed. The package represents only an extension to the payments scheme, rather than the compensation programme sought by the campaigners.

Mr Darling told MPs: "The government recognises that caring for people who have suffered damage puts a considerable burden on their families and carers. Nothing can make up for what has happened to these children, but we have a clear duty to support them and their families."

He acknowledged on Radio 4's PM programme that pharmaceutical companies had resisted pressure to contribute. "Earlier this year we did think about trying to set up a trust fund jointly with ourselves and the pharmaceutical industry. The reply was, I am afraid, very, very reluctant." Under further concessions, the time limit for making claims will be extended, and the "disability threshold" which victims must cross before getting payments will be lowered from 80% to 60% disability.

Campaigners yesterday welcomed the announcement, but questioned whether the cash would cover the costs of care for severely disabled children.

Ann Coote, a founder member of the campaign group, Justice, Awareness and Basic Support, whose daughter was disabled by a measles, mumps and rubella vaccination, said: "Any increase and acknowledgement that vaccine-damaged children exist and need help has got to be beneficial. But there will still be children who do not qualify for help. We need to look at the fine print to see if those previously turned down can reapply."

Ian Stewart, Labour MP for Eccles, who has led the campaign on behalf of vaccine-damaged children, said: "This will be welcomed - this isn't just about the individual who's damaged, it's a whole family issue. These proposals go a long way towards meeting the immediate help for those families."

But he added that the issue of compensation, rather than just the payments scheme, now needed to be addressed.

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, who has also campaigned on the issue, said: "There is an indisputable need for the creation of a medical injuries compensation board to oversee a system which guarantees timely payment of no-fault compensation to those injured as a result of NHS treatment or care."

fields.headline: Crash admission by ex-minister
fields.trailText: A former defence minister admitted yesterday he had misled MPs over the worst peacetime accident in the RAF's history - the crash in June 1994 of a Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre killing all 29 on board, including senior security and intelligence officers based in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
A former defence minister admitted yesterday he had misled MPs over the worst peacetime accident in the RAF's history - the crash in June 1994 of a Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre killing all 29 on board, including senior security and intelligence officers based in Northern Ireland.

James Arbuthnot, now Conservative chief whip, told the Commons he was wrong in dismissing doubts about the Chinook's electronics. "I now apologise...there is a gross injustice here and it must be put right," he said.

Mr Arbuthnot referred to what he called an "inadequate" reply he gave to the Labour MP, Martin O'Neill, when he was defence procurement minister.

He intervened in a debate where the government came under renewed pressure to set aside a verdict by two air marshals accusing the pilots of gross negligence.

Sir William Wratten and Sir John Day overruled an RAF board of inquiry which concluded that while the most probable cause was that the crew selected an inappropiate rate of climb, there were "many potential causes". In common with a Scottish fatal accident inquiry, the board was unable to determine a definite cause.

Martin Bell, independent MP for Tatton who opened yesterday's debate, pointed to what he called a mass of new evidence which undermined the verdict against the pilots. It included two subsequent accidents in the US involving similar Chinooks, one blamed on technical malfunction, the other explained only by "uncommanded flying control movement", an issue at the heart of the controversy over the Mull crash.

According to the MoD's own figures, RAF pilots had reported 35 similar incidents since the 1994 crash, Mr Bell said.

"I now apologise...there is a gross injustice here and it must be put right," he said. Mr Arbuthnot referred to what he called an "inadequate" reply he gave to the Labour MP, Martin O'Neill, when he was defence procurement minister. He intervened in a debate where the government came under renewed pressure to set aside a verdict by two air marshals accusing the pilots of gross negligence. Sir William Wratten and Sir John Day overruled an RAF board of inquiry which concluded that while the most probable cause was that the crew selected an inappropiate rate of climb, there were "many potential causes". In common with a Scottish fatal accident inquiry, the board was unable to determine a definite cause. Martin Bell, independent MP for Tatton who opened yesterday's debate, pointed to what he called a mass of new evidence which undermined the verdict against the pilots. It included two subsequent accidents in the US involving similar Chinooks, one blamed on technical malfunction, the other explained only by "uncommanded flying control movement", an issue at the heart of the controversy over the Mull crash. According to the MoD's own figures, RAF pilots had reported 35 similar incidents since the 1994 crash, Mr Bell said.

webTitle: Families of Shipman's victims go to high court for open inquiry

fields.headline: Families of Shipman's victims go to high court for open inquiry
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Families of 55 victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman went to the high court yesterday to try to force the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to hold a public inquiry into how Shipman was able to evade notice for so long.
fields.body:
Families of 55 victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman went to the high court yesterday to try to force the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to hold a public inquiry into how Shipman was able to evade notice for so long.

QCs for 113 relatives and for eight national newspaper groups and the BBC branded as "irrational" the decision by Mr Milburn to hold the inquiry behind closed doors.

Thirty relatives were in court to hear their QC, Augustus Ullstein, tell Lord Justice Kennedy and Mr Justice Jackson that an inquiry open to the public and the press was vital "to restore faith and confidence in general practitioners and the NHS".

It was not enough, he said, that the report would be published along with any evidence the inquiry team deemed "appropriate."

For the media, Desmond Browne QC said: "It is not just the confidence of the families who have been bereaved which has been undermined." He said Mr Milburn appeared to have ignored the need to restore public confidence generally in the NHS, which was a function of the media, and instead regarded news organisations as intrusive and took the view there was a need to protect the families from their "malign attentions".

But the families had made it clear they themselves wanted a full and open inquiry. It was the "vital role of the press as public watchdog" to report the proceedings and assure the public "that nothing is being swept under the carpet", said Mr Browne.

Shipman, 54, of Mottram in Longendale, Greater Manchester, was convicted at Preston crown court of murdering 15 patients, but he is suspected of killing nearly 200.

Mr Ullstein said the relatives had been led to believe the inquiry would be in public because Mr Milburn had referred to a "public inquiry" in statements in the House of Commons. But he had decided the inquiry, chaired by Lord Laming, a former head of the social services inspectorate, should be in private.

Mr Ullstein argued that those statements had given the relatives a "legitimate expectation" that the inquiry would be public.

Had the inquiry been set up under the Tribunals and Inquiries (Evidence) Act 1921, it would have been public, with power for the relatives to have legal representation paid from public funds and to cross-examine witnesses.

But because Mr Milburn had established it up under the National Health Service Act 1977, it could be held in private, with no legal representation for relatives, and they would have no right to see statements submitted by witnesses or to cross-examine witnesses.

Mr Ullstein said Mr Milburn had no power to use the NHS Act model, because the inquiry's terms of reference covered not only health service matters but also the roles of the coroner and police, death certification and controls on drugs - all matters outside the remit of the act.

Backing the relatives' application for judicial review are Associated Newspapers, Express Newspapers, Guardian Media Group, Guardian Newspapers, MGN Ltd, News Group Newspapers, Telegraph Group, Times Newspapers and the BBC.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Guard blows lid off Chile deaths

fields.headline: Guard blows lid off Chile deaths
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Political prisoners were routinely executed at a soccer stadium in the Chilean capital, Santiago, after the 1973 military coup, a former non-commissioned officer has claimed.
fields.body:
Political prisoners were routinely executed at a soccer stadium in the Chilean capital, Santiago, after the 1973 military coup, a former non-commissioned officer has claimed.

Rumours have long been rife of executions, torture and other human rights violations at the National Stadium after General Augusto Pinochet seized power, but this is the first time a member of the armed forces has confirmed the stories publicly.

Roberto Saldias told state-owned television that the executioners "took the law in their own hands". He added that at the time he was one of hundreds of guards at the stadium, which was used as a prison camp.

According to Mr Saldias, prisoners at the stadium were organised in groups identified by yellow, black and red discs. "Whoever received a red disc had no chance," he said.

Mr Saldias's willingness to reveal the names of human rights violators could be the first concrete, public result of the armed forces' commitment to help determine the fate of more than 1,000 dissidents who disappeared after being arrested under Gen Pinochet's dictatorship.

An agreement with the military reached early last week included a guarantee of anonymity for anyone willing to come forward with information on those who had disappeared.

The only person named by Mr Saldias was former Lieutenant Armando Fernandez Larios, who fled to the US in the late 1970s.

According to an official report, 3,190 people were killed under Pinochet's regime, and more than 1,000 remain unaccounted for.

webTitle: Bishop says Labour failing on marriage

fields.headline: Bishop says Labour failing on marriage
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The government is letting the country down by failing to support the institution of marriage, a senior Church of England bishop claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The government is letting the country down by failing to support the institution of marriage, a senior Church of England bishop claimed yesterday.

The Right Rev Michael Scott-Joynt, bishop of Winchester, ranked fifth in the church's hierarchy, and chairman of its marriage working party, said ministers' ambivalence amounted to a denial of responsibility for one of the bedrocks of a stable society.

The attack, at a conference on marriage in Plymouth, follows reports last year on marriage and whether those who have been divorced should be allowed to remarry in church - an issue of crucial importance given that the Prince of Wales, who will become supreme governor of the Church of England when he succeeds to the throne, is divorced and may marry a divorcee.

The bishop told the conference: "In the first years of the present New Labour government the churches, and especially the Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales and the Church of England, were hopeful that the government would prove explicitly supportive of marriage both in fiscal and other supportive provision and more generally in its language and perceived stance.

"[But] there is an explicit denial of any responsibility to support marriage for itself as fundamental to human flourishing, a stance consistently confirmed ... by the government's refusal, as it has dismissively put it, to 'preach about marriage' and to contemplate any discrimination (I use the word advisedly) between marriage on the one hand and stable relationships, whether same sex or heterosexual, on the other."

The assault comes as both the prime minister and William Hague are courting Christian voters and claiming to be supportive of traditional values.

Tony Blair is addressing a conference in Germany organised by the Catholic theologian Hans Kung later this week and in 10 days time will speak to black evangelical church leaders in Brighton.

Mr Hague has said that Conservatives are the party most supportive of married couples and families.

The bishop claimed that church disillusionment followed publication of the government's Supporting Families green paper in 1998, criticised by the church's board of social responsibility as ambivalent towards marriage.

fields.headline: Symbol of state
fields.standfirst: Thatcher handbag to be auctioned
fields.trailText: Thatcher handbag to be auctioned
fields.body:
It was as potent a symbol of Margaret Thatcher's authority as Churchill's cigar, and was wielded so frequently, it became a byword for how she dealt with political opponents.

The former prime minister's trademark handbag drove the dissident backbencher Julian Critchley to say of it: "She cannot see an institution without hitting it with [it]."

But now the famous accessory is to be used for a rather more charitable purpose. The medium-size, black, gilt-chained Salvatore Ferragamo number, bought in the mid-Eighties, is to be auctioned to raise money for Breast Cancer Care.

The bag, one of five which Lady Thatcher has, until now, regularly used, is being sold alongside others, such as the slightly battered black Jaeger bag belonging to the Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam, and an unused, zebra-printed creation that has been donated by Cherie Blair.

But it's that handbag - probably the only one to have graced the arm of a British prime minister - which is expected to raise the top price. The auction's organisers expect that, over the 10-day online sale, starting July 3, its value could well push past £50.

Donating the bag, which, it is believed, she clutched on the fateful evening in November 1990 when she was wobbling in her premiership, Lady Thatcher said: "I would only let go for a good cause."

The politician's skill with the handbag prompted the Oxford English Dictionary's entry: "To handbag, transitive verb (of a woman politician), treat (a person, idea) ruthlessly or insensitively."

webTitle: OECD imposes ethical code on multinationals

fields.headline: OECD imposes ethical code on multinationals
fields.trailText: Western governments yesterday agreed an international code of conduct for multinational companies which they hailed as a breakthrough in holding corporations to account for abuses of workers and the environment throughout the world.
fields.body:
Western governments yesterday agreed an international code of conduct for multinational companies which they hailed as a breakthrough in holding corporations to account for abuses of workers and the environment throughout the world.

After a tense two days of negotiations during which Mexico demanded of the other 28 members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development that standards be watered down, an agreement was hammered out early yesterday.

The guidelines replace an earlier OECD code and for the first time incorporate human rights and core labour standards. However, they are still voluntary and there are no procedures for imposing sanctions on offending companies.

Britain's trade minister, Richard Caborn, said the new code would make a "significant contribution to sustainable development and help pave the way towards eliminating child labour and poor labour standards in the global workplace".

Mr Caborn claimed foreign investors put pressure on Mexico to resist the OECD's attempt to raise standards.

Most of Mexico's amendments were rejected and other delegations said the concessions granted were mostly a face-saving exercise.

"You may call the changes just semantic, but when they are enshrined in a code of conduct they can jeopardise the free flow of investment," Mexican foreign affairs minister Rosario Green said. "We had to be careful."

The OECD's trade union committee said governments had to commit themselves to working with trade unions, nationally and internationally.

"The business-as-usual approach to globalisation has failed," said John Evans, head of the committee. "There is a need to establish new global rules covering labour, social, environmental and other issues, if globalisation is to work for working families everywhere."

However, non-governmental organisations expressed disappointment that the OECD had not been tougher.

webTitle: Moores might face a new generation game

fields.headline: Moores might face a new generation game
fields.standfirst: Notebook Empire's fate rests on retailing
fields.trailText: Gone are the days when winning the pools brought headlines and overnight fame. The lottery got in the way and millions of Britons are now spending their pennies trying to win the national jackpot rather than take pot luck on the nation's football teams. Little wonder that the Moores family decided to sell its pools business for £161m to a little shell company with bigger ambitions on its mind.
fields.body:
Gone are the days when winning the pools brought headlines and overnight fame. The lottery got in the way and millions of Britons are now spending their pennies trying to win the national jackpot rather than take pot luck on the nation's football teams. Little wonder that the Moores family decided to sell its pools business for £161m to a little shell company with bigger ambitions on its mind.

Try as they might to squash it, the Moores family members now face non-stop speculation about when and how the retailing rump of the 75-year-old Littlewoods business will be floated. Like all its mid-market rivals - selling to families with incomes below £25,000 a year - Littlewoods is finding the going tough.

The hardest area is clearly clothing, easy prey for the discount retailers and particularly so when Littlewood's catalogue prices are set months in advance. Littlewoods' belated response in its stores and catalogues has been straightforward price cuts.

The in-store Index shops,like GUS's Argos, are holding their own in sales terms - up by 7% over the past year - but less so in profitability. At the same time, the company refuses to give up on the agency home shopping business despite a disastrous performance for clothes sales.

The group is also trying out new sales channels, such as its shop-i.co.uk internet site, indexshop.com and its Shop! shopping channel on digital television.

Clearly, while attempts are being made to keep the retailer on track, now is hardly the time to rush to the stock market; Dutch-owned C&A has just pulled the plug on its stores in Britain, while BhS, once regarded as a potential suitor for Littlewoods, is now in private hands.

But the presumably emotional decision to sell off the pools is likely to be taken as an indication of a wider trend within the Moores family. While 30 or so members own the group, that number is expected to double in the next five years as the great-grandchildren of the founders reach the age of inheritance.

It seems inevitable that as the younger blood take up their rights the emotional attachment will lessen and a portion of the family will demand a realisation of the wealth.

Just how much will be left by then is another matter.

Fed dilemma

Setting US borrowing costs has not been easy of late, and ahead of today's rate decision by the Fed the uncertainty is palpable. As the authorities try to engineer a soft landing for the soaraway American economy, the Fed and Fed watchers alike still have not cracked the question as to how much technology has changed the US economy.

The problem is getting trickier - for two reasons. This is election year. The closer Al Gore and George Bush get to their date with the US electorate in November, the harder it will be for the Fed to act without risking being dragged into the political era.

The second reason relates to the "new" economy. Does the US consumer still feel wealthy enough to carry on spending? Or should the Fed try to slow demand by raising rates again, depress ing markets and thus making Americans feel that little bit poorer and less ready to splash the cash? The issue is finely balanced. Take the Nasdaq. It is now poised - rather uncertainly in the light of events at Amazon.com - slightly under half way between its March peak and its April-May lows.

As Charles Dumas at research group Lombard Street points out, it is hard to see the index marking time. Either the momentum bulls, who drove the index to its peaks by buying stocks simply because the price was already going up, will reassert their hegemony and the market will rise, or more conventional valuation models, with their stress on delivering real earnings, will return to favour and the market will fall.

If Nasdaq rallies from here, the wealth effect would appear to make a rise in rates a certainty. If it falls, the Fed could probably risk resting on its laurels.

But, as things stand, the markets are caught somewhere in the ether between traditional value investing and momentum bullishness.

At one extreme, old economy favourites are sitting on historically low multiples, but still failing to make headway.

At the other, hi-tech and media companies are holding on to what are, on past experience, highly stretched ratings. Yet there is no sign of shares in these firms roaring back to and beyond the highs seen during the first quarter's speculative feast - something that is central to the momentum thesis.

At the same time, the flotation bandwagon, badly derailed in May, is already back up and running. In London we have had or are expecting the likes Telecity, Egg, Carphone Warehouse and Granada Media, and this trend is echoed across the leading continental European bourses and in New York. Any sort of shock from the Fed today could cause some real and widespread damage.

fields.headline: We want jobs and rights
fields.trailText: Dennis MacShane (TUC gets its due for rise in recruits, June 26) suggests that there is a trade-off between workers' rights and jobs. Like the Victorians he seems to believe that fewer rights equals more jobs, and that improvements in democracy at work will threaten competitiveness in world markets.
fields.body:
Dennis MacShane (TUC gets its due for rise in recruits, June 26) suggests that there is a trade-off between workers' rights and jobs. Like the Victorians he seems to believe that fewer rights equals more jobs, and that improvements in democracy at work will threaten competitiveness in world markets.

MacShane is right to point to the empowering properties of full employment in civilising the workplace. But surely in a modern industrial economy we can aspire to both jobs and rights. Trade union density in Britain is below 33% and millions of workers, particularly those in small companies and low-paid, insecure jobs, are denied both the benefits of trade union organisation and employment rights protection. So modern socialists need to be campaigning for: full employment based on decent jobs - expand the public sector and modernise the manufacturing base; employment rights for all including trade union representation rights in small companies and wherever there are trade union members; international agreements which globalise trade union freedoms and workers' rights based on International Labour Office standards; and finally a world economy which tackles poverty and creates jobs.
Tom Sibley
Editor, International Union Rights ictur@gn.apc.org

fields.headline: No tears for 58 victims
fields.trailText: The way the people of Queensland have responded to the deaths of 15 backpackers in Childers (Tears cannot extinguish town's trauma, June 26) is a public reflection of the basic decency of many within Australian society. When commentators speculate about what sort of society Britain is becoming, they might like to contrast the response of this country to the death of 58 foreign nationals in Dover.
fields.body:
The way the people of Queensland have responded to the deaths of 15 backpackers in Childers (Tears cannot extinguish town's trauma, June 26) is a public reflection of the basic decency of many within Australian society. When commentators speculate about what sort of society Britain is becoming, they might like to contrast the response of this country to the death of 58 foreign nationals in Dover.

Has there been a memorial service for them with the prime minister and the Queen's representative in attendance? Has there been an outpouring of grief at the horrific way they died? Or has the way that asylum seekers have been denigrated by both Labour and Conservatives over the last 18 months rendered those 58 people less than human?

Let's not pretend that this country is becoming a more multi-cultural, less racist society, whatever Jack Straw likes to claim. Racist attitudes are not simply articulated in the vicious attacks of racist thugs. They are also reflected in the indifference to what happened in Dover and to the persecution that forces asylum seekers to seek exile in Britain.
Kevin Blowe

fields.headline: Pinning down the truth
fields.trailText: Alex Holmes (The police take sides, June 27) is entirely right in his analysis of the police's inability to understand the culture of neglect at the Kent care home for adults with learning disabilities or the danger of the restraint techniques used there.
fields.body:
Alex Holmes (The police take sides, June 27) is entirely right in his analysis of the police's inability to understand the culture of neglect at the Kent care home for adults with learning disabilities or the danger of the restraint techniques used there.

I have been involved in the training of safe restraint skills for use in caring for people with learning disabities for many years. Staff have a "duty of care" even when the client is threatening or violent, and need to use methods which treat clients with respect and give them back self control rather than "overpowering" them.

The methods used in the home were based on the outdated and unethical use of "pain compliance", eg wrist locks, and the dangerous practice of "face-down restraint" on the floor.

Police and prison staff in Britain still use similar methods and fail to understand that there are effective methods which maintain the dignity of people needing to be held or restrained, balanced with the safety of staff.

The Kent police obviously have no understanding of what a caring culture can be like for adults with learning disabilities. Rather than worrying about the comparatively small amount they spent on an entirely justifiable investigation into "assaults, abuse, threats of violence, mistreatment and casual callousness", perhaps they could spend a bit of police time visiting local social services care homes for adults with learning disabilities, so that future investigations are better informed.
Andy Berrington
Oxford abts@dtn.ntl.com

 It would be obvious to any viewer of the MacIntyre documentary that they had witnessed a series of abuses directed towards the residents of the home; how these were edited together, and the time scale over which they took place is irrelevant.

The statement from Kent police that restraint methods employed at the home were not dangerous is highly misleading. There is now a fairly substantial body of evidence to indicate that face-down restraint on the floor has been a major contributory factor in the deaths of a significant number of individuals within penal and mental health services in the UK and in North America. Given that the methods shown were also devised originally for use in the prison service, perhaps the police are not best placed to provide a neutral view on the risks that they pose.
Dr David Allen
Welsh centre for learning disabilities AllenDG1@Cardiff.ac.uk

Your leader (June 27) concerning the BBC's MacIntyre Undercover is a testament to misguided vitriol over accuracy. You are quite wrong when you say "that jack-of-all-charges 'wasting police time' has even been mentioned". Your clear - and totally unwarranted - hint is that we, as the stereotypical, heavy-footed Old Bill, are doing whatever we can to thwart the heroic efforts of Her Majesty's Press. No one speaking for the Kent county constabulary ever used that phrase. You then say that we regret that the care facility has been closed. Wrong again. You say that the decision to close the facility was made by Kent county council. Wrong a third time. It was taken by Medway council. In countless interviews, I said that Medway council, confronted by the lurid, sensational - and ultimately unsubstantiated - "revelations", had no choice but to do what it did.

For the BBC to try to wash its hands by saying that it was our decision to initiate a criminal inquiry is to stretch disingenuousness to its breaking point. If, in the face of the programme's claims that it was exposing "restraint methods that could kill", we had done nothing, I have little doubt that your paper would have been one of only many accusing us of callous indifference to the plight of the vulnerable. You can't have it both ways. Mark Pugash Media services manager, Kent county constabulary

fields.headline: Marching towards peace
fields.trailText: Now that the IRA is "verifiably putting their arms beyond use", it is time for the British government to make a "confidence-building gesture" (A blacked-out vehicle, a piece of history, June 27).
fields.body:
Now that the IRA is "verifiably putting their arms beyond use", it is time for the British government to make a "confidence-building gesture" (A blacked-out vehicle, a piece of history, June 27).

The partisan nature of the RUC was again evident during the recent Orange march on the Springfield Road; an anti-Nationalist stance certain to be repeated over the course of the coming "marching season". Blair and Mandelson must stop messing around with Patten's report and implement it.
Ignatius Vroop
London ignatiusvroop@hotmail.com

 More money is to be spent on sending extra troops to Ulster for the marching season. Why not guarantee all communities which forgo their "right" to hold provocative marches an appropriate share of this money for extra investment in local assets like schools, sports facilities and hospitals instead?
Michael McCarthy
London michaelmccar75@hotmail.com

 The BBC's news item covering the inspectors' encouraging report on IRA arms was unable to show pictures of the arms in store. Instead it showed what appeared to be a museum of arms seized by the police and the army. The IRA weapons may not have been sent to the metal grinders but this other collection should be.
Peter Stokoe
London peter@pstokoe.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Beyond this DNA hype
fields.trailText: Tuberous sclerosis is one of the 4,000 rare genetic conditions that can cause serious lifelong ill health arising from tumours produced in any organ of the body, and our association welcomes the announcement from the human genome project that 90% of human genetic make-up has now been sequenced (Scientists revel in a day of glory, June 27).
fields.body:
Tuberous sclerosis is one of the 4,000 rare genetic conditions that can cause serious lifelong ill health arising from tumours produced in any organ of the body, and our association welcomes the announcement from the human genome project that 90% of human genetic make-up has now been sequenced (Scientists revel in a day of glory, June 27).

However, before we get swept away by the hype about what could be achieved by using this new knowledge, let us look at the reality of even getting a DNA test through the NHS today.

There are already such tests in existence for tuberous sclerosis and similar genetic disorders, but they are not on the list of tests that can be automatically given in genetic counselling. The tests that can be given are for conditions such as cystic fibrosis and muscular dystrophy, whose research had already provided DNA tests before the reorganisation of NHS funding a couple of years ago. But tests developed for other genetic conditions cannot be automatically offered as there is no money or mechanism in the NHS to incorporate the results of all this genetic research.

So every time someone in a family affected by Tuberous Sclerosis wants a test, it is touch and go whether they will get it. If the government is serious about its commitment to preventing the chronic ill health genetic disorders produce, a good first step would be to provide the money so that families at risk can be tested should they choose to seek that information.
Ann Hunt
Tuberous Sclerosis Association research@tuberous-sclerosis.org

 You state (Leader, June 26) "of course patenting is a necessary protection for...inventors and scientists". This is open to debate. The patent system, which is a survival from medieval times, creates legal monopolies over the exploitation of scientific knowledge and works mainly to benefit large companies, not "inventors".

Like all monopolies, patents damage the public interest in obvious ways. We have to ask what is the counterbalancing benefit to the community, and whether it is enough to justify the harm. Patents in the areas of biology and computer software raise particularly troubling issues. We need to reopen the question of whether we should have patents at all.
Prof DA Turner
Computing laboratory,
University of Kent

 Now that the human genome has been unravelled, can we switch my hair back on please?
Alex Chester
Paris
alex.chester@bnpparibas.com

webTitle: Why Mugabe owes a debt to rural voters

fields.headline: Why Mugabe owes a debt to rural voters
fields.standfirst:
Key issues: Opposition says it had little time to change old attitudes

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: It was the rural vote which saved Robert Mugabe's face in Zimbabwe's hotly contested elections, and even Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader, accepted that yesterday. "The result was a true reflection of rural people's views. We didn't have access to them, and the work we did there before the reign of terror was insufficient. We didn't have enough time to change attitudes."
fields.body:
It was the rural vote which saved Robert Mugabe's face in Zimbabwe's hotly contested elections, and even Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader, accepted that yesterday. "The result was a true reflection of rural people's views. We didn't have access to them, and the work we did there before the reign of terror was insufficient. We didn't have enough time to change attitudes."

So, although the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) still insists that intimidation by the ruling Zanu-PF party played a large role, it acknowledges that the party was working in a context which was favourable to it.

Rural people, particularly the middle-aged and elderly who remembered the seven years of war before liberation were ready to accept Zanu-PF's argument that war could resume if the opposition won.

The line of thinking may not have been logical but the conservative sentiment was there. Others were swayed by the feeling that Zanu-PF brought liberation from white minority rule in 1980 and to desert it would be a betrayal, not only of the liberation forces but of earlier generations.

Whatever the motives which prompted individuals in the polling booth, Zanu-PF's sweep through Mashonaland - the heartland of its supporters during the liberation war - was remarkable. It won all 10 constituencies in Mashonaland Central, 10 out of 12 in Mashonaland West, and 11 out of 12 in Mashonaland East.

Mr Tsvangirai had hoped to break into this territory, which is why he chose to fight in a rural constituency, albeit in Buhera North in Manicaland, another largely Shona area. "My national executive advised me to take a safe seat in Harare, but it was my strategy to go out into the rural areas and show that discontent there was the same as in the towns," he said.

His decision to take the risk of a rural constituency followed from his analysis of the results of the February referendum, which was defeated entirely on the basis of the urban vote. Indeed, MDC supporters repeatedly pointed out before last weekend's vote that their referendum victory by no means guaranteed success in a general election.

They reminded reporters that although the overall total of No votes was enough to reject the draft constitution which had been put to referendum, it was carried in 63 constituencies and defeated in 57. The figures bear an uncanny similarity to Zanu-PF's tally of 62 seats yesterday against the MDC's 57.

Government ministers say the referendum's defeat was a wake-up call for Zanu-PF. "We realised we had to start mobilising, and we did," one senior party figure said yesterday. They chose to fall back on their traditional issue, the question of land. The occupations of farms by war veterans served a double purpose. It raised the profile of the land issue nationally as unfinished business left over from the liberation struggle, which had brought political independence but not econonomic independence.

The strategy was obviously successful in reminding peasants in the so-called communal areas where no white farmers live (known in colonial days as the tribal trust lands) that unfair land distribution was still a key issue.

It must also have had some effect among black farmworkers and other Africans in the so-called commercial farming areas. In Chinhoyi, for example, where Mr Mugabe held an emotional rally on the last day of the campaign, the Zanu-PF candidate won the seat, though by a relatively narrow margin of 8,176 to the MDC's 7,602.

Though this was probably not intended, the land issue had the effect of arousing strong reactions from the British government, especially Peter Hain and Robin Cook. This allowed Mr Mugabe to claim there was a real danger of a reversion to white rule.

Privately, Zanu-PF ministers were equally angry with the United States, which they rightly believe controls the IMF and the World Bank. It is these two institutions that have been imposing the main conditions for new loans to Zimbabwe. They are also furious with the US Senate for passing a Zimbabwe Democracy Act, which supports programmes for aiding opposition-minded civic groups and the non-governmental media in Zimbabwe. "We're being turned into another Iraq or Cuba," says Chen Chinutengwende, the information minister.

Finally, the land issue had the benefit for Robert Mugabe of deflecting attention from other issues, such as joblessness, inflation and corruption. This was what worried urban voters most. Here Zanu-PF failed miserably. Every seat in Harare and Bulawayo, the two main cities, went to the opposition MDC.

Zanu-PF also did very badly in Matabeleland, picking up only two out of 15 constituencies, and losing several cabinet ministers' seats.

To try to win urban voters back in the two years until the presidential elections, Mr Mugabe has promised to bring in price controls on a few basic commodities, bread, mealie meal, milk, and meat. During the campaign these promises did not win enough people over, perhaps because they did not believe they were practical. Zanu-PF will have to deliver on its promises now it has won the election.

fields.headline: Philosophy in a flat pack
fields.trailText: Now I know why thousands of shoppers have to suffer the consequences of the flat pack purchases we make at Ikea. There is a religion and a philosophy behind it all. Stephen Moss's article (The gospel according to Ikea, G2, June 26) was one of the best tongue in cheek stabs at corporate bullshit I've read in years.
fields.body:
Now I know why thousands of shoppers have to suffer the consequences of the flat pack purchases we make at Ikea. There is a religion and a philosophy behind it all. Stephen Moss's article (The gospel according to Ikea, G2, June 26) was one of the best tongue in cheek stabs at corporate bullshit I've read in years.

Having endured the queuing process at Ikea Croydon this past weekend, having puzzled out how to fit the flat packs into a Volvo estate, I spent most of Sunday devising a safe method of self-assembly of a large wardrobe unit (safer than the lethal graphics suggested by the company). "It is better to be two people when assembling this unit," the quirky English instructions suggested. By the afternoon, my mental state clearly was that of two people, one wanting to take the whole lot back, the other determined not to be beaten.

The latter succeeded. The finished item stands menacingly in my hallway where it functions as a storage cupboard and I believe it could fall apart at any minute. That's where I concur with Moss's analogy with New Labour.
Gerry Woolf
Rottingdean, Sussex gerry@gwassoc.dircon.co.uk

 Presumably the practice of not punishing mistakes accounts for the erratic stock control system and an infuriating inability to put things in the warehouse where the signs say they should be. Nice design, shame about the organisation.
Rod Warrington Upton, Chester
rlw@care4free.net
