fields.headline: Risks worth taking
fields.standfirst: The outlook for jobs is brightening
fields.trailText: The outlook for jobs is brightening
fields.body:
Next month's spending review will confirm public expenditure as a key engine of growth and a central pillar in Gordon Brown's determination to bring unemployment down to levels not seen since the 1950s and 1960s (when it was well below a million). The chancellor is taking advantage of the fact that public spending has a better public image these days if it is targeted to the areas people would like more money spent on (such as health and education) and does not jeopardise his fiscal stance. Public spending is increasing this year by 5% in real terms - well ahead of the growth of the economy - and health spending by 8%. By the end of the next three year period an extra £28bn will have been spent in other (non-health) areas with an unusual degree of cooperation between government departments. If that does not bring cheer to Labour's heartlands, what will?

But can unemployment - at present 1.1m on the claimant count or 1.68m on the more reliable International Labour Office measure - keep on falling without triggering fresh inflation? We won't know until we try - but it is definitely worth the risk. Half of the increase in jobs during the past year has come from people who were not on the unemploy ment register. Projections suggest that this source of labour will continue to grow and will be augmented by more people seeking jobs as a result of Mr Brown's new deal - including single mothers taking advantage of a large rise in their incomes if they go to work. This is happening at a time when companies - thanks to globalisation and the deflationary effects of the internet - are finding it very difficult to raise prices. It is also possible that Britain will soon get a boost to productivity of the kind that has underpinned the recent success of the "new" economy in the US.

If these favourable influences converged, it would be feasible to recreate the low unemployment of the post-war economy. People then took it for granted. They won't do so any more. If Labour approaches the election with unemployment heading to below a million but without reigniting inflation, it will be impossible for the Conservatives, who presided over unemployment of over 3m, to make political capital out of it. Of course, if this has happens, the UK will still be way out of line with unemployment in the rest of the EU, making Mr Brown's convergence criteria more difficult to meet. But that is another story.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Hats off to the Sunday People for its exclusive about three England footballers alledgedly making a "porn video" of themselves and various girls in Cyprus.
fields.body:
 Hats off to the Sunday People for its exclusive about three England footballers alledgedly making a "porn video" of themselves and various girls in Cyprus. If the People version wasn't that unlike a more polished, News of the World version, there was one salient difference: on its front page and inside, the People featured Michelle, "one of the stars of the sick video", and pictured with her blonde head hidden in her hands in anguish at having "been tricked" into acts from which she "fled in tears". Who knows how the People found her, but the photograph used of Michelle is said to resemble the People's staff reporter Lucy Panton. When we ring, Lucy recovers from the shock to issue an engagingly half-hearted denial. "It's, um, nothing to do with me," she says. But have you anything to say off the record? "Um, errrrr . . . there's another call coming through." Click, brrrr. Oh dear. Effete editor Neil Wallis, whose circulatory problems seem to indicate his own amputation, was in charge last week but is now on holiday, while his deputy Alan Edwards is tied up in "conference" the entire afternoon (but of course: Tuesdays are frantic for Sunday papers) and fails to return any of our several calls. Ah well, early days, early days.

 A contender emerges for Most Amusing Press Release 2000. It comes from the Services Sound and Vision Corporation, the firm contracted by the ministry of defence to supply a television service specially for the British troops serving in Sierra Leone. After this went on line last Tuesday, making its debut with a game of football, the chairman was quoted as declaring: "I have spoken to the men in the field and they say this has been a great help for keeping spirits up." Oh yes, that's England's game with Romania? Scottish troops, then.

 Can anyone help Carlton television with a mystery? An email sent to all staff recently by one Lorraine Hutchin inquires: "Do you know McCready and co ltd? The finance department have received a cheque for £21,623.65 from the above company for sound van and equip. As the company are no longer contactable, is there anybody out there that knows what this cheque relates to?" But isn't that just typical of Carlton . . . they're so busy worrying about making fine programmes that they simply don't have time to concentrate on the money side of the business.

 In relentlessly controversial Saga magazine, Mo Mowlam causes a stir by suggesting the Queen be turfed out of Buckingham Palace. If anyone is baffled why Mo's remarks about shoving the Queen out of Buckingham Palace have surfaced now, when she first made them six years ago, it's very simple. The people at Saga have only just remembered. "Which one, dear? Oh, the nice one in the green cardie? Yes, it's coming back to me now . . . didn't she say something funny about the Queen?" Elsewhere in the interview, our most beloved Mo is on cute form when asked about the poisonous briefings against her last year. "Somebody is not happy with me, I know that," she replies. "I don't think it's Tony Blair." I don't think it's Tony Blair - very nicely judged, Mo. Very delicate.

 A cellophane-wrapped chocolate arrives, with "The British Council" iced upon it. Good to see a body dedicated to promoting British business prepared to advertise itself. For God's sake, there's nothing to be ashamed of in selling our country and her splendid products to the world - and yes, woolly-minded chatterers, that means us too. On the back of the cellophane, meanwhile, in smaller lettering, are the words "Made in Belgium".

 At last, the government finally shaking off its exhausting obsession with presentation, and the Civil Service is the first to benefit. A colleague ringing the Department of Health with a factual query is told: "I'm sorry, I'm a media officer. You need a press officer." Of course, of course.

fields.headline: Power failure
fields.standfirst:
It was briefly the world's most successful nuclear power station. Now on the verge of closure, Bradwell's pioneering plant will soon serve only as a landmark to sailors. Andy Beckett on the end of an era
<A HREF="http://www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/nuclear">Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: It was briefly the world's most successful nuclear power station. Now on the verge of closure, Bradwell's pioneering plant will soon serve only as a landmark to sailors. Andy Beckett on the end of an era
fields.body:
At the main entrance to Bradwell nuclear power station, the first thing you hear is the clinking of flagpoles. There are three of them outside the gates and another inside, very tall and white against the wide Essex skies. In the wind off the sea, and off the flat fields and rivers to all sides, the flagpoles' ropes twitch expectantly. Freshly trimmed lawns and flowerbeds beckon towards the gatehouse. A dummy nuclear waste flask on a plinth awaits inspection.

But visiting dignitaries rarely come to Bradwell these days. Just the odd school party or middle-aged couple. And the flagpoles are empty, except the tallest one. It flies the company flag of British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL), a small flapping rectangle of the mildest blue. It almost looks like an apology.

Bradwell is Britain's oldest commercial nuclear power station still in operation. It was opened 37 years ago by the then Lord Lieutenant of Essex, Sir John Ruggles-Brise. It was, for a brief period, the world's most successful nuclear power station, in terms of total electricity supplied. In its new smooth cubes of concrete and glass, pipes and ducts proudly visible inside, the industry's distant heroic age was played out. Newspapers hailed Bradwell and Britain's programme as "progressive" and "the largest in the world".

Now "the Monster of the Marshes" is closing down. Last month, it was confirmed that all the British Magnox reactors, our unique national experiment with magnesium alloy, uranium and optimistic accounting, will be switched off, with Bradwell the first in less than two years' time. A scattering of other nuclear power stations will keep generating for a decade or two, in obscure corners of the British Isles, but the industry's impetus feels long gone. No new reactors are being built. Safety scandals seem unceasing. Germany, Japan and Sweden have stopped importing our radioactive fuel. BNFL, once thought ripe for privatising, is now reportedly ruined as a commercial prospect because of the cost of cleaning up after itself.

Last year, 27.6% of our electricity came from nuclear power, down from 28.9% the year before. This figure is expected to drop further as the Magnox plants close and the rest grow old. France and America, the other atomic energy pioneers, have both stopped constructing reactors. The whole nuclear equation, the once confident balancing of public attitudes, technical possibilities and economic benefits, now seems absurdly optimistic. Nuclear power, even from the most modern station, even without including the expenses of decommissioning, is still about twice as costly as conventional electricity production. Public opinion has turned sceptical. Valerie Mainwood, one of the founders of the Stop Bradwell campaign in the mid-80s, gives a small smile: "I've done the job I set out to do."

The road to Bradwell struggles up the Dengie peninsula, in emptiest, easternmost Essex. The railway gives out at Southminster, six miles short. After a small eternity of sharp corners - which the nuclear waste trucks, too, have to negotiate - past dusty farms and an abandoned hotel, the station comes suddenly into view. It rises, grey and vast, above wheatfields and a bank of fir trees, like an installation from the former Soviet Union. From a distance, the great reactor cubes and the long turbine hall look streamlined, almost modern. Up closer, the black streaks on the concrete, the dirty scaffolding and old Portakabins tell a different story. Nobody builds power stations out of pebbledash any more.

"There's no more budget to keep it running beyond 2002," said the tour guide, as he led the way along a formica corridor. He had grey in his beard, had been at Bradwell two decades, and seemed resigned. "It's had its time. I'll take the pay-off. There's not many long-term jobs left in the nuclear power industry."

Next to the turnstiles where employees check their radiation levels, a row of leaflets about retirement and looking for work had been Sellotaped to the wall. Bradwell employs about 350 people, more than anyone else on the peninsula. Most of them are local: middle-aged men in overalls, used to the heat in the glassed-in corridors, taking coffee and cigarette breaks in the shadow of the reactors. The station has been shut for repairs so much recently they have almost run out of maintenance tasks. Fresh paint was drying on the floor of the doomed turbine hall.

The goods lift to reactor one felt like the inside of an old battleship: metal panels, rivets, a reluctant creaking motion. The reactor itself, which was not generating, resembled a dug-up tennis court. Thick pieces of its concrete cap had been removed and scattered. The reactor's internal seals, great scuffed yellow rings, lay beached on the floor. A man wearing rubber boots and gloves but no facial protection was calmly, slowly, attending to one of them. Was there any risk involved? "There's no airborne radiation," the guide said. But all around the reactor chamber, on the pipes and ledges and bakelite telephones, there was dust in feathery drifts.

Bradwell's safety record is not bad by Sellafield standards. "They're good, solid engineers," Mainwood admits. Yet ageing produces its problems. Between January and September 1999, according to the latest report from the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate, there were "recurrent problems" with Bradwell's electrical system; the "discovery of debris" in a fuel channel; "apparently inadequately filtered liquid waste discharges into the estuary of the River Blackwater"; and deficiencies identified in the station's "emergency arrangements" during an exercise simulating "multiple casualties".

Such anxieties were unknown when Bradwell was first thought of. It was the early 50s, and the British government was preoccupied by fuel shortages and the cold war. Nuclear power appeared to offer a way both to outflank foreign blockades - or striking miners - and to acquire a vital strategic item: plutonium for bombs, a byproduct of uranium reactions. The electricity generated would be clean and cheap. Bradwell, the site of a second world war emergency airstrip for returning bombers, was safely isolated and close to water for cooling purposes. It was ideal for the next brave national endeavour.

Construction began in 1957. For five years, rather longer than anticipated, concrete was poured and locals reassured and the reactors were coaxed towards operation. "I used to watch those instruments in the control room," says Derek Smith, a commissioning engineer then, who had been hired from a traditional power station, "and think, 'Are they ever going to move?'" In 1962 Bradwell finally started generating commercially, beaten into second place in Britain, by half an hour, by another prototype station (now closed) at Berkeley in Gloucestershire. "We did our testing more thoroughly," says Smith with a slight pout.

The power plant brought apparent benefits to the peninsula. The pay was good. People swam in the warm water that Bradwell pumped into the river. Workers' houses were built in sleepy Southminster. The railway survived Dr Beeching's cuts, gaining a discreet siding for loading the waste flasks. A celebratory brochure was printed about Bradwell, with headings in electric orange.

But behind its double ring of fences, the experiment had its rocky moments. On January 26, 1963, in the middle of that bitter winter, there was a power cut and the station's cooling system froze. Another engineer recorded in his diary: "5am. Station shut down due to grid failure. Diesels didn't work. Essential supplies failure!!! Control room in darkness!" None of the alarms sounded. The atmosphere inside the compound, for 15 minutes, was "absolute mayhem". Official confirmation of the incident didn't come until 1988.

Regardless, for Bradwell's first six years, the staff managed to keep it continuously running. The station's long-term future was not much pondered: "They just didn't realise that these things would need disposing of," Smith says. Then the stoppages began. The activity in the reactors, it became apparent, was making parts of the structure brittle. Each time cracks were found, the plant had to be closed - on top of the usual halts for maintenance. Steadily through the 70s and 80s, Bradwell gained a reputation for patch-ups and imperfections.

Across the Blackwater in Wiven hoe, a village near Colchester, Mainwood started her campaign. She was a fretful CND veteran, worried about the local winds and radioactive dust and the wandering of polluted silt up the rivers and creeks. And as Bradwell began to struggle, she worried about its fragility: "They have to warm the old girl up for 24 hours when they restart," she says, sounding almost affectionate. Then her open face tightens: "We have to live through that."

It was economics, though, as much as Mainwood's countless meetings and stunts by the gates (there was a satirical pantomime, and an attempted abseil), that did for Bradwell. It never produced the cheap electricity anticipated. When nuclear power was privatised in the late 80s, the state could not find buyers for the Magnox stations. With their suspect old technology, shrinking staffs and constant rebranding and changes of management, these stations have had a whiff of Rover about them ever since.

But not to Derek Smith. He retired 10 years ago ("arthritis"), but he has not gone far: about 50 yards, in fact, to a small lichen-covered bungalow comically close to the looming grey towers. From his garden, Bradwell blocks out half the sky. The station has installed a radiation monitor on his garden shed. His apples have to be tested.

Yet he looks over his specially-clipped hedge with pride. "Even today... I marvel," he says, arms folded, a tousled and schoolboyish 65. "The ideas are stunning. The mechanical soundness of that plant is astounding." At night, from his home stuffed with clocks and electrical gadgets and nuclear industry drinks mats, Smith relishes the sight of his hulking neighbour's floodlights. BNFL, for its own undeclared reasons, owns his bunga low and every other property and field for several miles around. The station's infra-red security cameras sweep his lawns. Smith breaks off from blaming "the bloody Russians" for the demise of nuclear power: "I can't buy security like that!"

Bradwell, like the rest of the nuclear industry these days, is very keen on such small public relations coups. A nature trail has been planted around the station perimeter. There is a modern visitor centre, full of sly claims about atomic energy's environmental advantages - no greenhouse gases, it is claimed - over fossil fuel-burning power plants. An exhibit about the decommissioning of Bradwell is already in place. It shows the reactors stripped, smoothed into harmless-looking mounds and, after a century or so, disappearing altogether.

Mainwood challenges this picture: "People are going to be left with a nuclear waste dump." Yet she admits her views, formed in sheltered, relatively liberal Wivenhoe, have rarely gained much support out on the raw peninsula itself. There will be jobs in dismantling Bradwell as there have been in operating it. Local sailors use it as a landmark. And the fields around are already littered with old wartime pillboxes and sections of runway; perhaps the plant will crumble benignly into Dengie legend. Smith already refers mistily to "when she goes down".

He points out the healthy-looking hares nibbling his lawn. The evening light softens the edges of the power station. But the next day, on the telephone, someone from BNFL confesses that there is no absolute guarantee of company money to clean up Bradwell. "In the end, the government is the guarantor." Dignitaries may visit Bradwell again one day, in less optimistic circumstances than before.

There is a modern visitor centre, full of sly claims about atomic energy's environmental advantages - no greenhouse gases, it is claimed - over fossil fuel-burning power plants. An exhibit about the decommissioning of Bradwell is already in place. It shows the reactors stripped, smoothed into harmless-looking mounds and, after a century or so, disappearing altogether. Mainwood challenges this picture: "People are going to be left with a nuclear waste dump." Yet she admits her views, formed in sheltered, relatively liberal Wivenhoe, have rarely gained much support out on the raw peninsula itself. There will be jobs in dismantling Bradwell as there have been in operating it. Local sailors use it as a landmark. And the fields around are already littered with old wartime pillboxes and sections of runway; perhaps the plant will crumble benignly into Dengie legend. Smith already refers mistily to "when she goes down". He points out the healthy-looking hares nibbling his lawn. The evening light softens the edges of the power station. But the next day, on the telephone, someone from BNFL confesses that there is no absolute guarantee of company money to clean up Bradwell. "In the end, the government is the guarantor." Dignitaries may visit Bradwell again one day, in less optimistic circumstances than before.

webTitle: Poll may shock Zanu-PF into ditching president to save itself

fields.headline: Poll may shock Zanu-PF into ditching president to save itself
fields.standfirst:
What now?: The presidency will be the next battleground

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe is nothing if not forewarned. His party's narrow escape from outright defeat in Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections bodes ill for his chances of clinging to power in the 2002 presidential ballot. And if it looks as if the   voters plan to dump him, his own party may ditch him first.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe is nothing if not forewarned. His party's narrow escape from outright defeat in Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections bodes ill for his chances of clinging to power in the 2002 presidential ballot. And if it looks as if the voters plan to dump him, his own party may ditch him first.

But just as the government's defeat in the referendum on constitutional reform in February alerted it to the level of voter discontent, so the parliamentary vote gives Mr Mugabe plenty of notice to hammer out a fresh strategy, legal or otherwise, to reverse his declining fortunes.

The sweeping parliamentary gains by the Movement for Democratic Change will provide the opposition with a powerful springboard to end more than two decades of Mr Mugabe's increasingly abusive rule. Morgan Tsvangirai, the MDC's leader, failed to win a seat but that may be to his advantage, as it frees him to concentrate on being the presumed opposition presidential candidate.

If the MDC uses its considerable presence in parliament smartly during the next two years it will not only curtail the government's worst excesses but nail the official lie that there is little alternative to Zanu-PF's rule. The MDC can expose and curb corruption. It can press for real accountability by the police and military. It will also be able to circumvent the government's monopoly of the state media through the live broadcasts of parliamentary debates.

Zanu-PF may decide that Mr Mugabe is too much of a liability when it holds its election post-mortem. After the government lost the referendum on constitutional reform earlier this year, which warned it of looming defeat in the parliamentary ballot and raised the stakes in the campaign against white farmers and Britain, some party leaders told Mr Mugabe to step down.

He managed to stave off that attempt to unseat him, but the critics will be harder to silence this time. There are those who are keen to find another candidate for the 2002 election and to usher Mr Mugabe into the role of the elder statesman of independence.

But there will still be many opportunities for him to make mischief. He may try to tempt the MDC into his government under the guise of national unity, while tainting his opponents with the flaws of his administration.

The near defeat will probably encourage Mr Mugabe to press ahead with land reform in the belief that it will bring back some of the voters who defected to the MDC this week. That will keep the race issue alive, and the war veterans at his beck and call. But if he is to make political capital from the redistribution of white-owned farms it will have to be far more transparent and free of corruption than to date.

Zimbabwe's unpopular involvement in the Congo war has also cost the ruling party support. The government has already said it will pull its troops out under the shaky peace deal, and Mr Mugabe will probably want to make sure that the whole episode is a distant memory by the time of the presidential election.

The shock to Zanu-PF this week may yet save the party, particularly if it can find a suitable presidential candidate and the opposition fails to live up to expectations, or does what so many have done elsewhere in Africa and degenerates into a bickering, divided collection of self-serving politicians. For all Zanu-PF's shortcomings, there remains significant residual emotional support for the party that fought Ian Smith's minority regime.

In the end, it may be that Zimbabweans come to look on the gradual erosion of its power as far better than the shock of sudden change. There has been violence and other outrages, but it has not been at a level to tear society apart.

Ultimately, the referendum, parliamentary ballot and presidential election may be seen as a relatively smooth and stable transition from effective one-party rule to more representative and accountable government.

But there is 2002 to get through first, and Mr Mugabe is not a man to give up easily.

webTitle: Swiss charge man linked to Yeltsin

fields.headline: Swiss charge man linked to Yeltsin
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Geneva magistrates charged the head of a Swiss-based construction company with money laundering yesterday, paving the way for a court case that could expose an alleged $64m (£43m) corruption trail that reaches deep into the Russian corridors of power.
fields.body:
Geneva magistrates charged the head of a Swiss-based construction company with money laundering yesterday, paving the way for a court case that could expose an alleged $64m (£43m) corruption trail that reaches deep into the Russian corridors of power.

Beghjet Pacolli, a Kosovan, is accused of laundering £2.7m through Swiss bank accounts to conceal kickbacks which his firm, Mabetex, is alleged to have paid to Russian officials in return for public works contracts that included the renovation of the Kremlin.

Mr Pacolli has denied the charges, which carry a maximum sentence of three years and a fine. Two as yet unnamed former asset managers for the Swiss bank UBS and a lawyer have also been charged.

Viktor Stolpovskikh, a Swiss-based Russian businessman, failed to turn up on Monday to face similar charges. His company, Mercata Trading, is alleged to have laundered £41m in association with Mabetex.

More than 150 bank accounts have been frozen in Switzerland.

An international arrest warrant has also been issued for Pavel Borodin, the Kremlin's financial supremo while Presi dent Boris Yeltsin was in power. Mr Borodin is wanted for questioning in connection with the case, but Swiss magistrates doubt they will ever see him. However, they hope that, even if key Russian figures fail to appear, enough evidence will be produced in open court to embarrass those involved.

The Mabetex investigation was started by Russia's then chief prosecutor, Yuri Skuratov, in spring 1999. But since Mr Skuratov was controversially forced out of office in April this year, several high profile cases implicating Russia's elite have faltered.

Despite regular meetings with his Russian counterparts, Geneva's public prosecutor, Bernard Bertossa, has not received assurances that investigations against Mr Borodin or his associates are still under way in Moscow.

"We're rather puzzled about our Russian colleagues' degree of independence and [their] desire to act. Mr Skuratov's removal hasn't helped matters," Mr Bertossa said.

Russian assets figured prominently in the latest Swiss money-laundering statistics released yesterday; bank accounts containing £607m were temporarily frozen in the year up to March, with 15% of the suspicious transactions involving Russian beneficiaries.

fields.headline: US missile shield 'unnecessary'
fields.trailText: Washington's plan for a national missile defence shield is unlikely to work, unnecessary, and predicated on exaggerated assessments of threats to the United States, according to a former congressional adviser on security affairs.
fields.body:
Washington's plan for a national missile defence shield is unlikely to work, unnecessary, and predicated on exaggerated assessments of threats to the United States, according to a former congressional adviser on security affairs.

"Missile defences are unlikely to provide military commanders reliable and effective defences anytime in the next decade," Joseph Cirincione, the director of the Carnegie Endowment's non-proliferation project, will tell a London conference today.

"All available evidence, including the performance of the Patriot [missile] in the Gulf war, missile defence tests to date and current deployment schedules, support this conclusion," he says in a text prepared for a meeting organised by the the International Security Information Service and King's College centre for defence studies.

"Current threat assessments exaggerate the danger" posed by Iraq, Iran and North Korea, described by Washington until last week as "rogue states", but now called "countries of concern". Threats described in America's 1999 national intelligence estimate (NIE) were assessed by projecting "possible and likely missile developments by 2015 independent of significant political and economic changes", Mr Cirincione will point out.

He says the NIE report contained two critical findings which are often overlooked: Any country with long-range missiles would be able to develop "numerous countermeasures" to penetrate a missile-defence system; and that there were "several other means to deliver weapons of mass destruction to the US that would be more reliable, less expensive and more accurate than potential new intercontinental ballistic missiles over the next 15 years".

Mr Cirincione's criticism is echoed in a recent report by the British American Security Information Council (Basic).

The US has spent $122bn (£81.5bn) on missile defence and it will take tens of billions more to deploy and maintain the proposed system, which has not yet been shown to be effective, says Basic.

Deeper cuts in Russian and US nuclear arsenals would be severely jeopardised, as would opportunities to bring China, India and Pakistan into the arms control process, it says. It adds: "North Korea, if it decides it needs to attack the US, could put weapons on a plane, boat, or truck, rather than a missile."

The next test for the proposed land-based system is scheduled for July 7, when a target missile will be launched from Vandenberg air force base in California, and an interceptor fired from Kwajalein island in the South Pacific will attempt to destroy it.

fields.headline: Hain lauds opposition result
fields.standfirst:
Reaction: Aid package still depends on cooperation

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, last night hailed the opposition performance in the Zimbabwe election as vindication of Britain's controversial diplomatic stance.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, last night hailed the opposition performance in the Zimbabwe election as vindication of Britain's controversial diplomatic stance.

The Foreign Office welcomed the achievement of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) in going from almost a standing start to near parity with president Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF party.

The hard line taken by Mr Hain in particular and by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, earlier this year saw heated exchanges between the countries. This led to criticism that the Foreign Office had played into Mr Mugabe's hands, allowing the president to present the election as a battle against British colonialism.

Mr Hain rejected criticism of British tactics: "I think the outcome is a complete vindication of the strong position that both I and Robin Cook took. The fact is that we have been dealing with a person since last year who has denounced the British prime minister as a gay gangster, who has brought his country to the point of economic collapse, who personally ordered the attacks on the opposition, who personally backed the land invasions, who did nothing about the violence that followed the campaign of terror which the government unleashed and who authorised the opening of our diplomatic bag in an unprecedented defiance of the Vienna convention.

Mr Hain, who was brought up in South Africa and retains a strong interest in African affairs, said: "If either I or Robin had adopted a weaker stand in the face of that kind of belligerence, we would have been accused of weakness."

He added that Zimbabweans, at least where they were free from intimidation, had voted on the basis of hunger and jobs rather than the exchange of rhetoric between Britain and Mr Mugabe.

During the election campaign, the British government deliberately adopted a low profile, in contrast with previous months.

Mr Cook had been in touch with the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, several times during the campaign and he had said he was happy with that approach.

Mr Cook called on Mr Mugabe to accept the mood for change and urged Zanu-PF to respond positively to an offer from the opposition to discuss how they can work together for the people of Zimbabwe.

A £36m aid package previously offered by Britain to assist land reform was still on the table if this cooperation was forthcoming, he said.

But he warned Mr Mugabe that if he failed to work with the opposition on policies to tackle Zimbabwe's deep economic crisis and to restore the rule of law, the cash would be withheld.

The Conservative foreign affairs spokesman, Francis Maude, also welcomed the result: "This election drives a stake through the heart of Mugabe's claim to represent the legitimate will of the Zimbabwe people." The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, described it as a "stunning result".

South Africa's ruling African National Congress described Mr Mugabe's win as evidence that democracy was taking root in the country and Africa.

The South African president, Thabo Mbeke, has been left in a difficult position by the Zimbabwe crisis. He did not want to be seen to be critical of a neighbouring country, especially where the issue was land owned by white farmers.

The ANC said: "We congratulate Zanu-PF on their victory as we realise that the election process has underscored the fact that democracy is taking root not only in Zimbabwe but in the sub-region and, indeed, in the whole of Africa."

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said parliamentary elections in Zimbabwe should be respected in spite of reports by observers that they could have been tainted by pre-election violence and threats.

webTitle: Greens' growing strength threatens to let Bush steal it

fields.headline: Greens' growing strength threatens to let Bush steal it
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: New opinion polls indicate that Ralph Nader, confirmed this week as the Green party's presidential candidate, could play a crucial part in November's US election.
fields.body:
New opinion polls indicate that Ralph Nader, confirmed this week as the Green party's presidential candidate, could play a crucial part in November's US election.

With George W Bush and Al Gore neck and neck, the 7% showing for Mr Nader has provoked a debate on the left about whether supporting him may leach away some Democratic support and help Mr Bush and the Republicans.

The American Green party had gathered at the weekend in Denver, Colorado, for a convention which its members hoped would be the prelude to a campaign that would finally put the party on the political map.

As the Greens' candidate in the 1996 election, Mr Nader won 700,000 votes - less than 1% of the vote - but the party is hoping for a much more substantial showing this time.

"The two major parties are not only run on the same well worn set of ideas but their campaigns are funded by millions of dollars provided by the same corporate interests," Mr Nader said. He called the Gore-Bush contest "the drab against the dreary".

The Green party now has organisations in 29 states and has 79 political office-holders nationally.

In Texas it was confirmed last week that 74,000 people, nearly double the 40,000 required, had endorsed the party to ensure its place on the presidential ballot. The party is strongest in California where there are 31 office-holders. In New Mexico, one of its candidates, Carol Miller, got 17% of the vote in the last congressional election.

Four years ago Mr Nader, now 66, was accused of running a lacklustre campaign. This time he plans to seek votes outside the party's obvious constituency and campaign in all 50 states.

He earned his title of "consumer advocate" 35 years ago when he exposed the failings of the motor industry and there are now plans to film his book, Unsafe At Any Speed, which catalogues his challenge to one of the country's most powerful lobbies. But his more immediate task is to convince the left to campaign for him.

Last week, his campaign received an unexpected endorsement when the Teamsters union leader, James Hoffa, appeared publicly with Mr Nader and said that it was vital that he was on the presidential ballot in November. "No one speaks stronger on the issues important to American families than Ralph Nader," said Mr Hoffa.

Mr Hoffa's intervention signalled to the Democrats and their presidential hopeful, Vice-President Al Gore, that if some of their traditional backers fall in behind Mr Nader, they could suffer serious damage in a close race with the Republicans.

Equally, the Republicans and their contender, Mr Bush, will be watching to see how the Reform party candidate Pat Buchanan fares as conservatives could drift from Mr Bush to Mr Buchanan if they think he is making any headway; currently he is polling well below Mr Nader.

The mantra of Al Gore's supporters is, "A vote for Nader is a vote for Bush". Yesterday Mr Nader said: "People ask me if I'm worried about taking votes away from Gore. I'm worried about Gore taking votes away from me."

His vice-presidential running mate is Winona LaDuke, a Native American activist educated at Harvard. Her speeches have concentrated on poverty, urban decay, civil rights and disparity of income while Mr Nader leads on the issues of globalisation, corporate power, media monopolies, blue-collar jobs, consumer rights and the environment.

Although sometimes accused of lacking sufficient charisma to mount a serious challenge to the main parties, Mr Nader has been entertaining gatherings this year with witty and biting speeches, mocking the local media's political coverage and the compromises made by the main candidates to accommodate their backers.

Mr Nader's own finances came under scrutiny last week when he opened his accounts and was shown to have assets worth $3.9m (£2.6m). He said he normally gave 80% of his earnings - $512,000 in the previous 16 months from speaking engagements - to civic causes. Mr Nader, who lives in Washington, does not own a car or property.

The Green party campaign received a setback last week when the commission on presidential debates confirmed its decision to deny Mr Nader and Pat Buchanan a place in televised prime-time debates during the campaign, on the grounds that they had taken less than 15% of the vote in national opinion polls.

Mr Nader has responded by filing a civil law suit arguing that those who stage the debates, which cost around $550,000, are making illegal contributions to the Democrats and Republicans because of the publicity the debates will give them.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What ice-cream sellers are watching on television
fields.trailText: What ice-cream sellers are watching on television
fields.body:
Jared: "I've decided not to watch any more television since we lost the football. I've gone on strike. I've told my girlfriend that if I catch her watching Friends or anything, then she's out. You don't get that many ice-cream sellers on TV, no. I don't think we'd make good TV. Why not? Too many kids and foreigners - ha, you wouldn't be able to direct them. I see their little dramas before they get to me, and after, but I think it would be a bit samey, as a programme, at the end of the day. Backs against the wall, we're a boring lot."

Mitch Doheny: "I used to watch television quite a lot, but it's all soaps and drama serials with whatsisface. What is his name? Big guy, from that soap... Grant Mitchell, that bloke. Ross Kemp, yeah, brother of Phil - he was a bastard, wasn't he? Yeah, he's in all of them now, hanging from billboards looking like... a bastard. At least they could give him another sort of role to play. My kids hate him. He used to make them cry when he was being mean in EastEnders. What else do I watch? Bit of rugby, great game, although I prefer to go and see it. Go down to Twickenham, yeah, then take over the riverside. Great pubs."

Gina Teigh: "What do I watch? I don't watch much, I go down the pub. I prefer the pub, you can chat away and people don't tell you to be quiet. Mind you, the pub has telly these days, doesn't it? I suppose I do get videos out, does that count? I go to Blockbuster and I can't resist the popcorn and the chocolates. Last film I rented... was... The Matrix. I'm a bit slow on the uptake. Actually, I tell you what I like, seeing as it's futuristic as well, I really like Robot Wars. Funny that, isn't it? No idea but I just like watching them zoom around. So clever."

Kenny Pilson: "I sit in the van of a summer and I watch the world go by, I haven't got time for TV. When I'm not at work? Well, dahlin', I'm out drinking, aren't I? Sorry can't help you out more. Do I like Barrymore? No, I think he's a ponce. Goodbye."

fields.headline: On a hiding to nothing
fields.standfirst: Francis Wheen on: Archie Norman's failed alchemy |  Hague's complex chromosomes
fields.trailText: Francis Wheen on: Archie Norman's failed alchemy |  Hague's complex chromosomes
fields.body:
While spring-cleaning my study last week, I found a newspaper dated November 4 1999. "Awesome foursome turn £5m into £600m overnight," a front-page headline announced. The foursome consisted of the Tory MP Archie Norman and three business colleagues. They had achieved their alchemy by buying 247.5m shares at 2p each in Knutsford, a small leather company in Cheshire whose total assets were worth little more than £5m. On the first day of the new regime the share price rose to 232p, giving Norman a paper profit of about £50m on his £500,000 investment and valuing Knutsford at £600m - more than Storehouse, the owner of BhS and Mothercare.

Ah yes, I remember it well. But, as they say on A Question of Sport, what happened next? The brief history of Knutsford is a most illuminating fable of hype and hogwash, and a useful cautionary tale for those who - like our present government - believe that "the market" is the most wise and rational economic mechanism ever devised, rather than a mad carousel driven by greed and fear.

November 1999: The amazing overnight rise in Knutsford's valuation sets a new stock market record. A company spokeswoman attributes it to investors' expectation that Norman and his three chums will soon buy a high street retailer. "This is a dream team," she says, "and it is no secret they are going big time with this one." Though no target has yet been identified, rumour suggests that they may bid for Marks & Spencer - or indeed Storehouse.

The City pages can hardly contain their excitement. The Express hails "the modern-day buccaneers, the men with the Midas touch, the colossi of the financial world". In a postscript, it admits that "so far [Knutsford] has done nothing at all but, as ever with the stock market, much depends on smoke and mirrors".

January 2000: There is speculation galore about which retail giant will be taken over: House of Fraser, MFI, Allders, the Co-op, Great Universal Stores, Somerfield, Sainsbury's and Boots are all mentioned. The Knutsford team "may be close to identifying a target". On January 18 the foursome announce an all-shares bid for Wassall, an industrial conglomerate. Twelve days later they pull out, blaming the greed of Wassall's shareholders. As a Knutsford spokesman complains: "Wassall shareholders have been in this stock for a long time and a lot of them want cash." So it's back to Plan A: "We are now going to do what we have always said we would do, which is to acquire an underperforming retail group." An announcement is promised by March.

February 2000: Norman is appointed shadow environment secretary but refuses to relinquish his 10% stake in Knutsford. If he does become the part-owner of a supermarket chain, how will he be able to speak on such subjects as greenfield development without a conflict of interest? Answer comes there none.

May 2000: Hold the front page! "Knutsford is in talks to make its first acquisition, it emerged last night." The company says it is negotiating with "a privately owned investor-relations business operating in Europe and North America regarding a possible takeover".

June 2000: Last month's carefully worded statement neglected to mention who was taking over whom. Far from making its first acquisition, we now learn, Knutsford has reached its last gasp. It is disappearing into the small American company WILink.com, which is run by property tycoon Nigel Wray, a schoolfriend of one of the awesome foursome. Knutsford's share-price tumbles from 80p to 22p.

The awesome foursome, who until recently bestrode the City like a £690m colossus, have become the winsome losesome. Disgruntled investors who bought into the company at 200p recall what Norman said last November: "My whole track record is making money for people and I don't want to let them down." Having paid just 2p each for his own shares, he is still showing a handsome profit. Quite what he has done to earn it remains a mystery.

Mo, the Mail and palace poppycock
Hegel says somewhere that all important events and characters in world history occur twice. He forgot to add that the same is true of silly-season news in the Daily Mail. Hence the screaming front-page headline yesterday, "MO'S ATTACK ON THE QUEEN", which bears an uncanny resemblance to a story from August 1994. Then as now, Mo Mowlam didn't attack the Queen at all, suggesting merely that the royal family ought to abandon Buckingham Palace and move into a "good modern building".

The Mail, which describes Mowlam's interview with Saga magazine as a "constitutional bombshell", apparently regards royal residences as sacred relics. As it commented last time around, Buckingham Palace "is inseparable from our history, our nationhood and, most importantly, our constitution".

What poppycock. Like so much of the "historic" pageantry and paraphernalia that surround the royals, the palace is actually quite modern. The first monarch to live there was Queen Victoria - and she moved out again after the death of Prince Albert in 1861, leaving it empty for the next 40 years. (In 1864 a notice was pinned to the railings: "These commanding premises to be let or sold, in consequence of the late inhabitant's declining business.") Since then, several hideous additions - notably the Portland stone facade, which replaced John Nash's east front in 1913 - have made it the ugliest building in London. Like most of its occupants, Buckingham Palace is an undignified embarrassment.

Mowlam tells Saga magazine that although she's "not a great fan of the monarchy" she likes Prince Charles and finds the Queen "very pleasant". All this was known six years ago. So why the hysteria now? Allow the Mail to explain: "Yesterday's interview in Saga magazine indicates her views have not changed."

A politician who says the same when in government as in opposition, eh? No wonder Mo's cabinet colleagues are reported to be shocked and appalled by her "bombshell".

 Now that the first rough map of the human genome has been completed, I hope that a few Nobel-hungry scientists will take on the far more difficult project of mapping William Hague's brain.

Here's what we know so far. He has a low opinion of the government in which he served, so much so that his front bench now has only three people (himself included) who sat in the Major cabinet. Does he hark back to the Thatcher years? Not really: he is, for example, scathing about the Blessed Margaret's failure to "do anything" about law and order throughout the 1980s. His attitude towards asylum seekers leads one to wonder if he's a Powellite, but he is quick to deny any such allegiance.

What, then, do those Hagueite chromosomes add up to? He claims to be a cuddly, modern Conservative who approves of gay marriages; yet he sits respectfully at the feet of a loopy American creationist who regards homosexuality as the devil's own work. He is fervently opposed to the very principle of a European single currency, for all the usual reasons concerning loss of economic sovereignty; yet he leaves open the possibility that a Hague government might join the euro after the next election but one. He seems genuinely proud of his shadow ministers, apparently convinced that they have the same elegance and talent as the Dutch football side; yet a glance at the team-sheet reveals a shadow cabinet stuffed with no-hopers - Angela Browning, Gary Streeter, Theresa May, Andrew Mackay, Archie Norman - who would be lucky to make the Accrington Stanley 3rd XI.

To all appearances, the man is a hopelessly confused nitwit. Even among liberals and lefties, however, I now find more and more people arguing that he's an impressive figure who shouldn't be underestimated. The Tories' poll ratings suggest this opinion is widely held.

Why? Earlier this week, referring to the Human Genome Project, a Guardian editorial warned that "no one knows the language and no one has the dictionary. It will be many, many years before we have begun to understand..."

The same can be said of the attempt to explain the appeal of William Hague - or, as it will soon be known, the Inhuman Gnome Project.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
A Star Is Born
(George Cukor, 1954) 4pm, Sky Cinema

Lavish musical remake of the tearful 1937 drama about a rising singer's fraught marriage to a free-falling drunken movie star. James Mason seized the latter role after Cary Grant said no, and he's impressive, but it's tragic Judy Garland's show: a heartbreaking performance, even if the songs aren't so hot. Incredibly, Grace Kelly beat her to the best actress Oscar that year.

An Officer and a Gentleman
(Taylor Hackford, 1981) 10pm, 3.25am, Sky Cinema

Richard Gere saunters through gruelling training to fly Navy planes but is scared of being taken for a ride by Debra Winger's gutsy factory girl. Does she really love him, or would any immaculately uniformed superstar pilot do? Brushing the chips off his poor-boy shoulders (there's a wrong-side-of-the-tracks subplot) and squaring up to Oscar-winning Louis Gossett Jr's ramrod sergeant, Zack (yep, that's his name) finally sees sense in Hackford's smart-looking, posturing romance.

Rush Hour
(Brett Ratner, 1998) 10pm, FilmFour

The indestructible Jackie Chan bounces back for more martial arts mayhem. He plays a Hong Kong supercop arriving in LA to find the kidnapped daughter of an old pal; Chris Tucker is the local detective assigned to keep him out of trouble. Amid the usual frenetic, beautifully choreographed action scenes, Ken Leung makes a worthy, adversary, but the best of it is in the chalk-and-cheese pairing of Chan and Tucker.

Alien Resurrection
(Jean-Pierre Jeunet, 1997) 10.50pm, Sky Premier

Fourth of the Alien series, set 200 years on from Alien 3, with Sigourney Weaver's cloned Ripley back from the dead to face the creatures once more. True, the macabre ramifications of genetic mutation inherent in Ripley's rebirth give way to the usual mayhem; but Jeunet adds some ghoulish touches to the action and the humans - a band of space pirates; Winona Ryder's elfin Call, and particularly the enigmatic super-Ripley - are as freaky as the monsters.

fields.headline: More than a laughing matter
fields.standfirst: Dying can be an art, but you wouldn't know it from BAC's season of plays about mortality.  Lyn Gardner reports
fields.trailText: Dying can be an art, but you wouldn't know it from BAC's season of plays about mortality. Lyn Gardner reports
fields.body:
Death has been described as the last great taboo of our age. Yet it seems to me that death and dying have been well and truly outed. Open a newspaper and you'll find John Diamond facing the consequences of cancer. Turn on the TV and if Oprah isn't helping a studio of people overcome their grief, some soap opera will be showing an individual being snuffed out by a rare incurable disease that nobody has ever heard of, or an entire community rubbed out by a billion-to-one catastrophe.

Not since the 17th century and the Jacobean revenge playwrights has popular culture been quite so obsessed by death. Since Diana died and brought funerals back into fashion, we have all become death groupies.

In this context, Matters of Life and Death, a season of theatre about death and dying at London's BAC, seems slightly less essential, particularly since so few of the shows get to grips with the subject matter. There has been some terrific theatre work on the theme of dying: it recently proved good West End box office in Margaret Edson's Wit, about an American professor who dies of ovarian cancer. Frantic Assembly's immensely touching Hymns, about the rising toll of young male suicides (which had two performances in the BAC season), and Improbable's Coma have taken death to the cutting edge of performance.

But after a week at BAC I feel bombarded by statistics and jokes. Why do so many companies fail to take this subject seriously? Or simply treat it like an actuarial statement? Is it that many of the companies here are made up of young people who have not yet confronted their own mortality?

A work in progress, Entertaining Death's title is a giveaway. Theatre Edible's performers display a relentless need to make us laugh, as if they are embarrassed by their subject matter, and when they are not doing that the content is banal. We all know that death is a great leveller and that Princess Diana and Fred West are dead, but that is the only connection between them as far as I am aware.

Fevered Sleep's Exquisite Moments and Imperfect Endings is similarly afflicted, but at least it takes a more oblique and original view of the subject. The opening moments, with a performing space lit by naked bulbs and a flow of sand falling over a still performer, suggest gravity, but, alas, the need to crack jokes soon takes over. With a better script and much less self-consciousness about form, this company might come up with something interesting. In the meantime I'd advise them to stick to Sam Beckett, who wrote rather more eloquently about the fact that we are all dying from the moment we are born.

Winsomeness is another feature of many of these performances: Stacy Makishi's Suicide for Beginners and Kazuko Hohki's Toothless both fumble towards an unfettered simplicity but merely end up looking amateurish. Hohki's tale about her mother's death from mouth cancer has its moments of insight and - unlike other pieces in the season - doesn't so much laugh defensively at death as point up its absurdities. But life is too short for an evening in the theatre that only has moments.

In BAC's Old Bookshop the extraordinary and severely disabled actor Nabil Shaban has constructed an installation that he describes as Nab's Necrospace. Maybe because from the moment he was born Shaban has confronted death on a daily basis, there is something peaceful and moving about this quiet oasis with its jumble of skulls and everyday objects. It's a contemplation of death that is so natural and so seamlessly interconnected with life that it feels like a poem by John Donne.

In one corner is a computer on which you can record how you would like to die. I'd always thought it would be nice to go in the theatre. After this week I'm not so sure.

 The Matters of Life and Death season continues at BAC, London SW11 (020-7223 2223), till July 15.

fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
What exactly happens when two mutually attracted pairs of eyes meet across a crowded room - apart from the distant sound of throbbing violins and a feeling of excessive well-being? According to one American researcher, their brains get a jerk from a tiny cluster of cells known as the third interstitial nucleus of the anterior hypothalamus. In The Lover's Mind (9.0pm, Radio 4), Dee Palmer coolly investigates this and other dismal sounding mechanisms, hoping to establish whether love can ever be distinguished from lust.

Stuart Maconie wraps up his survey of Seven Days That Rocked The World (10.0pm, Radio 2) with the impact in 1977 of the film Saturday Night Fever (pictured). One critic commented that "all the characters seem to have crawled out from under stones", but they loosed disco on a waiting world, and a little-known group on the soundtrack took off like a rocket. The Bee Gees' eponymous album sold 30 million copies.

fields.headline: Get your kit on
fields.trailText: A Many Splintered Thing | Real Life
fields.body:
Any show that gives work to Josie Lawrence is good news, and every time she appeared in A Many Splintered Thing (BBC1) the screen seemed to become a few shades brighter. As Camilla, bohemian den-mother to the adulterous young things of Geoff Deane's comedy, she swanned around in brightly-coloured fabrics and delivered ball-breaking witticisms in a Fenella Fielding husk. Later in the proceedings, when she was revealed as her (female) lodger's probable lover, she sported animal-print pyjamas and a huge shaggy mane of hair, the nocturnal wardrobe of femmes fatales the world over.

It was when Lawrence was not there to vamp it up that the trouble began. Alan Davies, as accidental adulterer Russel, stumbled well-meaningly through the sex ual minefield, quietly proud of the fact that his mistress Elly (Kate Ashfield) and his wife Susanna (Simone Bendix) had coaxed four orgasms out of him in a day. He was surprised; the rest of us were incredulous. The entire show was predicated on the fact that you find Davies irresistible, and if you don't, Newsnight began to seem strangely appealing. For the first 10 minutes Davies was unable to keep his clothes on, hopping in and out of beds and showers, having sex in all the basic positions and even at one point receiving oral pleasure from his (male) agent in a dream sequence. This kind of behaviour is understandable in any drama starring Robson Green, Clive Owen or Gary Mavers, who really project better without clothes. In the case of Davies, however, each unrobing could only be greeted with hearty cries of "get 'em on!"

The subject matter was agreeably raunchy for BBC1, and it's always good to hear lines about ejaculation and cottaging, even if they're not terribly funny. And there was the rub: we waited in vain for the laughs to come. But instead of jokes there were remarks like "that is some scary shit" and "I may be married, but at least I've got a cock". At one point, Elly looked hard at Russel and said "That isn't funny", which was a risky move. Occasionally Russel had visions of the Ally McBeal variety, in which he imagined himself smashing his agent over the head with a giant hammer, a device which sat awkwardly with the rest of the fare.

Things perked up a bit when Russel went for dinner in a posh restaurant with his gay best friend Luis (Victor McGuire) and became convinced that the waiter thought he was "the bitch". Luis, as the gay best friend, should have provided some light relief, but bucked the trend of sitcom homosexuals by being dull and sensible. Russel ended the show lying semi-conscious in a stream of dog piss, and so we can only hope that things improve in the coming weeks.

ITV's Real Life strand returned with The Gay Dads, a warts-and-all portrait of Barrie Drewitt and Tony Barlow, the Essex millionaires who made headlines last year by becoming parents of twins through a surrogate mother. Andrew Webb's cameras were with them throughout the pregnancy and birth, and through the ghastly post-natal farce in which the Home Office attempted to prevent the babies from staying in Britain. After putting Drewitt and Barlow through hell and effectively souring the joy of fatherhood, the Home Secretary backed down just three days before the deadline and allowed little Aspen and Saffron to stay put.

More interesting than this well-documented political blunder, however, was the insight offered into the Drewitt-Barlow ménage. They came across at first as stock types: Barrie in his silly micro-fibre hat looking like a reject from East 17, Tony all inarticulate butchness and button-down collars. As the film wound on, however, they emerged from the façade as a serious-minded pair, hurt by the misrepresentation of their predicament and righteously angry at the way they were being criminalised. "People are saying the children will have no female influence in their lives", laughed Barlow, as he welcomed the extended family for a visit - seldom has such a collection of strong-minded women been seen in one place at the same time. Even the grandparents-to-be waxed lyrical about the love between their sons.

Ten years ago, this kind of sympathetic coverage on ITV would have been unthinkable. "A sign of the times, or a threat to the family as we know it?" asked the voice-over at the beginning of the film, but there was never any doubt as to the answer.

fields.headline: The last laugh
fields.standfirst: The critics raved but the viewers switched off in droves. So why is ITV giving Bob Martin - Michael's Barrymore's bid to reinvent himself as a proper actor - a second chance?  Matt Wells investigates
fields.trailText: The critics raved but the viewers switched off in droves. So why is ITV giving Bob Martin - Michael's Barrymore's bid to reinvent himself as a proper actor - a second chance? Matt Wells investigates
fields.body:
Michael Barrymore's success as a mass-appeal entertainer hangs on his image as a fun-loving clown who constantly acts the goat. So when salacious pictures of his antics with an apparently under-dressed Mary Nightingale were splashed across the tabloids recently, his showbiz entourage will have squealed with delight.

But across London, a newer set of professional colleagues descended into a mood of unrelenting gloom. For the production team at Bob Martin, the satirical showbiz send-up in which Barrymore stars, the renewed interest of the red-tops could not have come at a worse time.

"We were trying to get people like Stephen Fry and Alan Bennett to appear in this show", says Bob Mills, co-writer and producer of Bob Martin. "We had our heads in our hands."

The starkly different reactions illustrate the opposite strands of Barrymore's career: there's the matey, My Kind Of Music Barrymore which pulls in 15 million viewers on prime-time ITV; and the serious, considered Barrymore who gently satirises himself and gets just 3 million for Sunday night ITV. The conflict between the two is unresolved.

But it is clear that Barrymore's interest in the serious side of his career is growing. A new series of Bob Martin is now being filmed - and he's certainly not doing it for the money. "This is cab-fare stuff for him", says Mills.

The return of Bob Martin may come as a surprise to some. Any producer whose ITV show lost half its viewers between the first episode and the second, and settled at a paltry 3 million, would usually expect to suffer the cruel slice of the network axe pretty swiftly. That the weapon lay unbloodied in the drawer of network chief David Liddiment owes more to the power of the pen than the vagaries of the viewers: a favourable review in the Spectator allowed programme heads to tell their paymasters in advertising that while low, the ratings were made up of quality viewers who read erudite television reviews in weekly political journals.

Bob Mills, who co-writes Bob Martin with Jeff Pope, says that while the gloom of the ratings battle was depressing, it was not altogether unexpected: most Barrymore fans would have been perplexed by Bob Martin. "On week one, we got seven million viewers. We knew for a fact that they weren't coming back. What saved us was the press. That Spectator piece was the oxygen mask as we were plummeting."

Bob Martin is a crucial part of ITV's strategy to woo a younger audience, so it has got another chance. But key changes have been made: the writing is tighter and episodes shorter. Mills has made the show more accessible without turning it into a sitcom, and has retained the sense that viewers are in on the joke. If you laugh out loud when the acidly camp Scots producer (Dennis Lawson) berates Vince the warm-up man (Keith Allen) for hiding a camera in the shower of a celebrity guest with the rasping heterosexist put-down: "You people disgust me", you are just the sort of person who should be watching Bob Martin.

Barrymore himself is unperturbed by the lack of ratings. While his other shows Strike It Rich and My Kind Of Music can get anything up to 15 million viewers, he clearly believes that the kudos of Bob Martin is worth far more than the megabucks generated by his regular material.

"They are bloody good scripts, and they are even better this time", says Barrymore. Protected by the thin veil of fiction, he says that Bob Martin has allowed him to stick two fingers up at the kind of showbiz people satirised in the series. "What is great about it is that the script says a lot of things you would say to people in private that you want to say out loud."

Selecting Barrymore to play the lead role might have been a risk - his past battles with drink, drugs and his own sexuality are well-documented - but Mills says he has been the model actor. (It probably helps that he doesn't exactly have to dig deep for inspiration for the role: Martin is insecure, self-absorbed and displays signs of an uncertain sexuality.) Barrymore has only been late on set twice - both by a matter of minutes and through no fault of his - and has proved brilliantly successful at sending himself up.

Mills's take on Barrymore is that he is the victim of his own genuine personality. "Any problems that he has, all his problems, come from the fact that he is a decent, slightly naive and open man working in a business where they aren't the best qualities to have."

Once filming is over, Mills knows that the ratings battle will have to be fought out once more. "What we need to do with this series is get another 1.5m", he says. And if not? "We will have made 12 programmes that we're very proud of."

 The first series of Bob Martin is now available on Granada Video/VCI

fields.headline: No: 1665 Magaluf
fields.body:
Appearance: Concrete and neon tourist hell.

Can I have a room with a view? Only if you like watching posh boys getting bladdered.

So does one get a better class of lager lout in the Balearics? Apparently so. Peter Phillips, 22-year-old son of Princess Anne, has been spotted frolicking on the holiday isle of Majorca, enjoying a well-earned break after his final exams with a party of 50 university friends.

Does he really have 50 friends? When one's completed a rigorous sports science course, one has plenty of gripping conversational gambits.

So what did they do instead? Dwank and dwank and dwank in the Magaluf clubs until they fell over. Slept off their hangovers on the beach. Began again.

No day trips to sites of local historical interest? He did make it to the dolphinarium. And played some beach rugby. You can take the boy out of Gordonstoun...

Indeed. So was there any romance? Apparently he persuaded some topless birds to join in his sandy revels by flicking water at them.

How classy. I can't understand why Britney's not after him instead of Wills. Perhaps she's not so keen on his sartorials. The crazy gang wore matching white polo T-shirts with blue collars, emblazoned with the legend "Probably the best tour in the world", with the wearer's name and "squad number" on the back.

Handy for those drunken memory blackouts. Well, he was having Sex on the Beach.

Heavens to Betsy! I thought you said there was no romance. It's a cocktail. And it's not on the menu at Klosters.

That's because Klosters doesn't have a Caribbean Cocktail Bar. Perhaps it should. Let's start a chain... then Mustique, Balmoral, the world.

But Pete has no truck with posh fripperies. He even stayed in the two-star Hotel Don Bigote (Mr Moustache) in case one was thinking he wasn't sufficiently down with it.

Not to be confused with: Ibiza. At least he wasn't girning sweatily to the Venga Boys.

Do say: He's just a normal lad enjoying some innocent fun.

Don't say: Did you pay for that with your own money dear?

webTitle: Tate Modern gets a million visitors in just six weeks. Meanwhile, at poor old Tate Britain...

fields.headline: Tate Modern gets a million visitors in just six weeks. Meanwhile, at poor old Tate Britain...
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones  on an unfashionable national treasure
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones on an unfashionable national treasure
fields.body:
In 1941, with bombs falling on London and nation's survival looking doubtful, George Orwell sat down to write about gardening. His essay The Lion and the Unicorn is an analysis of the British national character - written at a time when Britain and England were considered to be one and the same - that concludes with a plea for socialists to love their country.

"Here are a couple of generalisations about England that would be accepted by just about everybody," noted Orwell without fear of contradiction. "One is that the English are not gifted artistically." Instead of great art they have "a love of flowers... We are a nation of flower-lovers, but also a nation of stamp collectors, pigeon fanciers, amateur carpenters, darts players, crossword puzzle fans."

Orwell's judgment on British art has finally been vindicated by an unlikely authority: Tate Britain. Flower arrangements by members of the Women's Institute are among the exhibits in Intelligence, a survey show of contemporary British art opening there next week that also features art stars such as Douglas Gordon, Tacita Dean and Susan Hiller. The flower arranging has been organised by artists Jeremy Deller and Alan Kane as part of their Folk Archive, a collection of folk art from around Britain that also includes images of a pipe-smoking competition at Egremont Crab Fair, gurning world champion Tommy Mattinson, Morris dancers, Diana tributes, obscene garden decorations and - displayed at the Tate in all its straw-stuffed glory - a scarecrow.

Folk Archive is a neat image of what this new museum of national British art feels like. Tate Britain feels like stepping into a folk song, an old ballad, and encountering homely images we thought we had left behind. Green hills and fairies, Stonehenge, the red-coated soldiers who hold the Union Jack aloft in John Singleton Copley's painting The Death of Major Peirson, 6 January 1781 - depicting the patriotic martyrdom of the young officer who liberated Jersey from a French invasion - are what you see in this museum. But do we want to see those things?

Some days are better than others, but Tate Britain's curators have had to endure a huge reduction in visitor figures since the opening of Tate Modern, which has already clocked up 1m visitors in only six weeks. When Tate Britain was launched in April it had 162,000 visitors in a month; when Tate Modern opened it sent the next month's figures plummeting to 99,000, and so far, virtually at the end of the month, the June figure is 60,000. When I met the museum's director, Stephen Deuchar, recently he made no secret of his anxieties about the museum's role.

Tate Britain has had vicious reviews for its opening displays, which reject chronology in favour of themes like Private and Public and Home and Abroad. It's true that some of the juxtapositions of artists from different periods are amazingly silly - do we really gain anything by seeing Gilbert and George in the same room as LS Lowry because they're both "urban"? - but it is not that badly curated. Lots of rooms, such as the one exploring images of war from The Death of Major Peirson to Jacob Epstein's The Rock Drill (1913-14), are fascinating. But this is not why people are not visiting the museum. This is not about individual works of art, but how we see ourselves.

It's incredibly hard to read the mood of Britain at the beginning of the 21st century. Tate Modern on the one hand, soccer violence on the other. We have certainly disproved the old stereotype of the British as moderate and dull. The sudden rush of visual images and visual pleasure in Britain, the total abandonment of our old staid "character", is full of violent contradictions. When George Orwell analysed the British character in The Lion and the Unicorn he said that, in compensation for our lack of artistic excellence, we had fortitude and loyalty and no real nationalist or racist hatred for others. Today we seem to have the capacity for both. So while it would be nice to say that our lack of interest in Tate Britain is a triumph of modernity over nationhood, things are not so clear. What does it mean that our national art heritage is being stepped around in the road like a dead bulldog?

Folk Archive's intervention makes the best argument I have seen so far for this museum. It's not just that getting the stripping, Blair-bashing cohorts of the WI to contribute to an exhibition of contemporary art will bring the beleaguered Tate Britain some press attention. Folk Archive is a reading of this institution, an interpretation of it. The artists hold up Tate Britain as an anthropological phenomenon and invite you to see our national collection of British painting and sculpture in the same way we see flower arranging when it is framed here - not ironically so much as ethnographically. What a strange activity it is to make a scarecrow, or gurn; what a strange activity to collect works of art that embody "Britishness".

Jeremy Deller, an artist who specialises in anthropological investigations of contemporary British culture, has touched on this stuff before. He once did an artwork collecting "middle-class hand signals" by which the middle class of the home counties purportedly know one another. This time he has excelled himself with a comprehensive anthology of everything that is archaic, unruly and plain odd in British culture. Folk Archive is a model for what Tate Britain might be. Artists, unlike the general public, are very interested in this museum precisely because it's a bit hard to get your head around, all this old British art. We're so far removed now from the rural culture that produced Stubbs's paintings of horses or Gainsborough's rustic portraits that they can be rediscovered as images of Britishness strangely at odds with how we now see ourselves.

At first sight, the unpopularity of Tate Britain looks like proof that we have become a modern European nation. We want all the cosmopolitan wonders at Tate Modern, and we couldn't give a damn, apparently, about all those old canvases by Hogarth and Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites and the Bloomsbury group. Just as it turned out that the famously pub-loving British were waiting for some nice continental-style bars to open so we could get out of those smelly old pubs, so it turns out we were just waiting for a decent modern art museum to open so we could get away from all those figurative paintings.

But it's one thing to reject conservative taste, quite another to forget your history. One of the feeblest attractions at the Dome is the Self-Portrait Zone, which is full of little homilies about how wonderful Britain is, saying things like "We have a good sense of humour", but without any sense of history or things British people might actually want to remember, like enduring the blitz, a history that is marked on the landscape beside the Thames yet finds no mention in the Dome.

Tate Britain is a necessary corrective to our infatuation with now. It has the makings of a really eccentric museum, and they are the best kind. What it contains is our folk art - our collective depository of myths and images, which we can all feed our imaginations on. Folk Archive is a key to this museum's strange, secret world of British cultural history. Tate Britain is full of images straight out of a folk song. Here is Richard Dadd's painting of the fairy folk, done when he was in Bedlam for murdering his father; here is William Hogarth's painting of the mythic highwayman Macheath, from John Gay's 18th-century play with ballads The Beggar's Opera. Visiting Tate Britain is like listening to folk music - you could start to enjoy it.

Folk art is politically ambiguous. British art from the past is fiercely patriotic, from the nobly shed blood of Major Peirson to William Hogarth's painting of starving Frenchies and Jacobites looking with longing at the Roast Beef of Old England. But there's also a savage satire in this art, that is not opposed to its patriotism but a part of it. Hogarth's love of Old England is a love of a plebeian, urban crowd exploited and manipulated by aristocracy and corrupt government: his relish of popular British habits - the boozing, whoring, rioting and fist-fighting that is "Hogarthian" - is a rejection of the narrower, politer, more restrained Englishness you get in Reynolds's portraits of the aristocracy. Hogarth's appetite for a robust, subversive popular culture runs through old British art: satirical printmakers like Gillray dredged up scabrous, ambivalent images straight from the national unconscious, again all patriotism as they attack the French Revolution but at the same time full of disgust at Britain's bloated, corrupt rulers.

"The genuinely popular culture of England is something that goes on beneath the surface, unofficially and more or less frowned on by the authorities," wrote Orwell in The Lion and the Unicorn, but it has surfaced time and again in British art. You can see it in William Blake's channelling of 18th-century sectarian beliefs into an alternative British cosmology - to be celebrated in a big Blake show at Tate Britain later this year. You can see it in Henry Fuseli's transformation of popular superstitions into his nightmarishly surreal painting of Titania and Bottom from A Midsummer Night's Dream, in which the fairy folk are not cute but sinister.

The danger with Britain's love affair with modern art is that we risk repressing all this. Tate Modern is an austerely seductive image of the new. But Tate Britain makes me think of "rough music", the aggressive rituals the rural poor used to perform to punish enemies of the people. This could mean an ugly assault on the different, those who disobey the community's rules. But it could also mean rioting against rulers. If a new, modern Britain represses the weirdness that still exists in our popular culture, it will haunt us in ugly and authoritarian ways. And we have no excuse for underestimating the savage strangeness of the British: the evidence is laid out for us to study at the museum of British folk art.
