fields.bodyText: In 1941, with bombs falling on London and nation's survival looking doubtful, George Orwell sat down to write about gardening. His essay The Lion and the Unicorn is an analysis of the British national character - written at a time when Britain and England were considered to be one and the same - that concludes with a plea for socialists to love their country. "Here are a couple of generalisations about England that would be accepted by just about everybody," noted Orwell without fear of contradiction. "One is that the English are not gifted artistically." Instead of great art they have "a love of flowers... We are a nation of flower-lovers, but also a nation of stamp collectors, pigeon fanciers, amateur carpenters, darts players, crossword puzzle fans." Orwell's judgment on British art has finally been vindicated by an unlikely authority: Tate Britain. Flower arrangements by members of the Women's Institute are among the exhibits in Intelligence, a survey show of contemporary British art opening there next week that also features art stars such as Douglas Gordon, Tacita Dean and Susan Hiller. The flower arranging has been organised by artists Jeremy Deller and Alan Kane as part of their Folk Archive, a collection of folk art from around Britain that also includes images of a pipe-smoking competition at Egremont Crab Fair, gurning world champion Tommy Mattinson, Morris dancers, Diana tributes, obscene garden decorations and - displayed at the Tate in all its straw-stuffed glory - a scarecrow. Folk Archive is a neat image of what this new museum of national British art feels like. Tate Britain feels like stepping into a folk song, an old ballad, and encountering homely images we thought we had left behind. Green hills and fairies, Stonehenge, the red-coated soldiers who hold the Union Jack aloft in John Singleton Copley's painting The Death of Major Peirson, 6 January 1781 - depicting the patriotic martyrdom of the young officer who liberated Jersey from a French invasion - are what you see in this museum. But do we want to see those things? Some days are better than others, but Tate Britain's curators have had to endure a huge reduction in visitor figures since the opening of Tate Modern, which has already clocked up 1m visitors in only six weeks. When Tate Britain was launched in April it had 162,000 visitors in a month; when Tate Modern opened it sent the next month's figures plummeting to 99,000, and so far, virtually at the end of the month, the June figure is 60,000. When I met the museum's director, Stephen Deuchar, recently he made no secret of his anxieties about the museum's role. Tate Britain has had vicious reviews for its opening displays, which reject chronology in favour of themes like Private and Public and Home and Abroad. It's true that some of the juxtapositions of artists from different periods are amazingly silly - do we really gain anything by seeing Gilbert and George in the same room as LS Lowry because they're both "urban"? - but it is not that badly curated. Lots of rooms, such as the one exploring images of war from The Death of Major Peirson to Jacob Epstein's The Rock Drill (1913-14), are fascinating. But this is not why people are not visiting the museum. This is not about individual works of art, but how we see ourselves. It's incredibly hard to read the mood of Britain at the beginning of the 21st century. Tate Modern on the one hand, soccer violence on the other. We have certainly disproved the old stereotype of the British as moderate and dull. The sudden rush of visual images and visual pleasure in Britain, the total abandonment of our old staid "character", is full of violent contradictions. When George Orwell analysed the British character in The Lion and the Unicorn he said that, in compensation for our lack of artistic excellence, we had fortitude and loyalty and no real nationalist or racist hatred for others. Today we seem to have the capacity for both. So while it would be nice to say that our lack of interest in Tate Britain is a triumph of modernity over nationhood, things are not so clear. What does it mean that our national art heritage is being stepped around in the road like a dead bulldog? Folk Archive's intervention makes the best argument I have seen so far for this museum. It's not just that getting the stripping, Blair-bashing cohorts of the WI to contribute to an exhibition of contemporary art will bring the beleaguered Tate Britain some press attention. Folk Archive is a reading of this institution, an interpretation of it. The artists hold up Tate Britain as an anthropological phenomenon and invite you to see our national collection of British painting and sculpture in the same way we see flower arranging when it is framed here - not ironically so much as ethnographically. What a strange activity it is to make a scarecrow, or gurn; what a strange activity to collect works of art that embody "Britishness". Jeremy Deller, an artist who specialises in anthropological investigations of contemporary British culture, has touched on this stuff before. He once did an artwork collecting "middle-class hand signals" by which the middle class of the home counties purportedly know one another. This time he has excelled himself with a comprehensive anthology of everything that is archaic, unruly and plain odd in British culture. Folk Archive is a model for what Tate Britain might be. Artists, unlike the general public, are very interested in this museum precisely because it's a bit hard to get your head around, all this old British art. We're so far removed now from the rural culture that produced Stubbs's paintings of horses or Gainsborough's rustic portraits that they can be rediscovered as images of Britishness strangely at odds with how we now see ourselves. At first sight, the unpopularity of Tate Britain looks like proof that we have become a modern European nation. We want all the cosmopolitan wonders at Tate Modern, and we couldn't give a damn, apparently, about all those old canvases by Hogarth and Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites and the Bloomsbury group. Just as it turned out that the famously pub-loving British were waiting for some nice continental-style bars to open so we could get out of those smelly old pubs, so it turns out we were just waiting for a decent modern art museum to open so we could get away from all those figurative paintings. But it's one thing to reject conservative taste, quite another to forget your history. One of the feeblest attractions at the Dome is the Self-Portrait Zone, which is full of little homilies about how wonderful Britain is, saying things like "We have a good sense of humour", but without any sense of history or things British people might actually want to remember, like enduring the blitz, a history that is marked on the landscape beside the Thames yet finds no mention in the Dome. Tate Britain is a necessary corrective to our infatuation with now. It has the makings of a really eccentric museum, and they are the best kind. What it contains is our folk art - our collective depository of myths and images, which we can all feed our imaginations on. Folk Archive is a key to this museum's strange, secret world of British cultural history. Tate Britain is full of images straight out of a folk song. Here is Richard Dadd's painting of the fairy folk, done when he was in Bedlam for murdering his father; here is William Hogarth's painting of the mythic highwayman Macheath, from John Gay's 18th-century play with ballads The Beggar's Opera. fields.headline: We will not be muzzled
fields.standfirst: Donald Sutherland has become the latest actor to hit out at the critics.  Michael Billington bites back
fields.trailText: Donald Sutherland has become the latest actor to hit out at the critics. Michael Billington bites back
fields.body:
Fame is no insulation against pain. Donald Sutherland last week wrote a wounded piece in the Times recording his personal devastation at the reviews for Enigmatic Variations, in which he is playing at the Savoy Theatre. Referring to one particularly cruel jibe, he invoked the grief of a bereaved father and the agony of Ethel Rosenberg in the electric chair before suggesting he had no desire to live. More philosophically, Kelsey Grammer - TV's Frasier - greeted the critical drubbing of his Broadway Macbeth, which closed after 10 days at a loss of $1.5m, by saying, "I'm not going to moan about it. I'll cram something else down their throats in another couple of years."

So are critics vindictive Torquemadas delighting in cruelty, as Sutherland would have us believe? Or are they simply plain-speakers who, in the course of their job, inevitably inflict pain? Before answering that, I would say I have some sympathy with the soul-scorched Sutherland.

Three years back I had the temerity to direct a couple of plays in Battersea as part of a critics' season. One evening I turned up at the theatre to find an actress, who had loyally followed my instructions, shell-shocked by a lacerating review from the RSC's Adrian Noble. She was - and is - an excellent actress. But it took a lot of persuasion to undo the damage inflicted by a piece of casual abuse. It also brought home to me - this was soon after Stephen Fry had taken flight to Bruges after bad reviews for Simon Gray's Cell Mates - the volatile precariousness of the performer.

For all that, I believe Sutherland's argument rests on a shaky premise. "Surely," he writes, "the responsibility of the theatre reviewer is to the theatre audience. To report how they responded to the play, to reflect the audience's reaction." Absolutely not. The critic's prime responsibility is to his or her conscience and vision of the truth. Indeed, I suspect Sutherland is being faux-naïf . He knows, as well as I do, that commercial managements pack first-night houses with backers, friends and claqueurs; to report their partial reaction would be pointless and counter-productive. What Sutherland may not know is that someone else once advocated criticism be replaced by reporting. Rather than be concerned with values, he said, "it should confine itself to description which would give the public the right to make up its own mind". His name, unfortunately, was Joseph Goebbels.

The critic is not a straw-poll merchant, a tipster or a second-guesser of audience taste, simply an individual paid to record his or her reaction. Throughout history this has been a source of creative tension between artists and critics. What I believe is distorting that relationship at present is the gradual shift towards a PR-led culture. Before any major film, play, musical or book is launched, there is now a barrage of pre-publicity in every available medium. Artists are wooed, cossetted, persuaded to bang the interview drum. Criticism, when it arrives, is consequently regarded as a form of belated impertinence, a spoiler at the publicity feast. I was amused, not long ago, to be introduced at a public forum as "the critic who didn't like The Lion King". I was made to feel like the man in a Bateman cartoon notorious for his solitary perversity.

Sutherland's notion of the critic as a neutral mediator between artist and public also ignores the economic factor. This surfaced some years back when Simon Gray and I were both on a radio programme after one of his plays had been harshly received. Gray, a civilised man, pointed out that a dramatist feels as protective towards a new play as a mother to her new-born child and is as fiercely resentful of criticism. "It's as if," he said, "you'd taken your baby out in the pram and people came along and poked their noses inside and asked why you couldn't have made the leg a bit longer or the arm a bit shorter." I couldn't help pointing out that mothers rarely charge people £30 a head to view their baby. A play is a public event that it costs money to attend - hence the need for external assessment.

But are critics out of touch with popular taste? Is there a growing gulf between opinion-mongers and audiences? Possibly so - especially in the field of musicals. No critic warmed to The Sound of Music; the rest is history. Les Misérables got tepid overnight reviews; the rest is hysteria. And, having trashed Notre-Dame de Paris, I was intrigued to get a letter inviting me to meet its composer and attend another performance where I would find it playing to a packed and ecstatic audience. I politely declined, not because I believe critics are invincibly right but simply because Notre-Dame represents a trend - towards the over-amplified, characterless musical - that I personally dislike. I've said my piece. The public is now free to make up its own mind.

Of course, critics can be blinkered, egotistic, smugly protective of their own prejudices; but so too can artists. What we all need is to be more open about our mistakes. Years ago I remember being wheeled out on television the day after the disastrous opening of Jeeves, the initial version of the Andrew Lloyd Webber-Alan Ayckbourn musical that got appalling reviews. The interviewer turned to Eric Thompson, who had directed it, and asked, "Did the critics kill the show?" With impeccable honesty, the saintly Thompson replied, "No, the show killed the show." It's the only time in my life I've ever heard anyone admit that.

What we need, if theatre is to survive, is not the kind of neutered-tom, reportorial criticism Sutherland advocates. I don't suppose he'd be any too pleased if one announced that one's own enthusiasm was clearly not shared by a restless, fidgety, bored-out-of-their-skull audience. What one needs is criticism that is lively, informed, impassioned and capable of measuring the theatre we have against a platonic ideal of the one we'd like to have. In the process one may cause pain. But, as Eric Bentley once said, that is the price one pays for the right to practise the profession: "For the journalist-critic the only alternative to a sharp tongue is a mealy mouth."

At the moment theatre criticism is not an easy occupation in Britain: it has to contend with the oily workings of the PR machine, an increasingly consumerist society and what Robert Hughes once called "the psychotic cult of celebrity". But at least things are infinitely better than in New York. We have a plurality of opinion and a diverse theatre; in New York there is a direct correlation between the awesome power of the New York Times and the bland sterility of Broadway. In New York Kelsey Grammer's Macbeth didn't stand a chance once it had been given the official thumbs-down. In London Donald Sutherland, however much he may despise us rude scribblers, is still in there fighting and proving the power of the critic is provisional rather than absolute. Instead of baring his wounds, perhaps he should count his blessings.

Some of the cruellest remarks about Donald Sutherland's play...

Financial Times: Everything about Enigmatic Variations is foolish: the ill-advised decision of the film actor Donald Sutherland to use this as the vehicle to bring him to the West End stage, the weak performance of his co-actor John Rubinstein, and - above all - the silly, silly play. It has a plot so stupid that you stretch your eyes in disbelief wondering whether you and it can both be awake in the West End at the same time. Sutherland is an awkward stage animal, with his muzzy consonants and his ill-tuned, foggily projected voice. He does nothing original or interesting with the role apart from varnishing it with an aura of craggy authority.

Independent on Sunday: Enigmatic Variations is built round twists. I wouldn't want to give anything away - least of all tickets.

Independent: Like Sleuth with intellectual pretensions. It is a mystery why a director as talented as Anthony Page has associated himself with such clunking material, weighed down by the hamfisted translation by the star's son, Roeg Sutherland. If there were Nobel prize for middlebrow reassurance, Enigmatic Variations would be a cert.

...and Kelsey Grammer's

New York Times: Who says they don't do Shakespeare like they used to? Terry Hands's staging suggests what the barnstorming American companies of the 19th century must have been like: potboiler productions emphasising melodrama over psychology, with a lot of stately actors planting themselves like trees at the edge of the stage and declaiming fiercely and nobly. Kelsey Grammer basically has two gears here - amoral, confident Macbeth and tender, contrite Macbeth - and he has pretty much worn them out by the end of his second monologue.

Financial Times: Judged on scene-by-scene comprehensibility, this must be one of the murkiest readings of Macbeth I have witnessed.

fields.headline: 2,000 soldiers sent to Ulster
fields.standfirst:
Security raised as Orangemen plan to defy Drumcree ban

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Up to 2,000 troops have been recalled to Northern Ireland as part of a huge security operation after this weekend's controversial Drumcree Orange Order parade was banned for the third year running.
fields.byline: Maggie O'Kane  in Belfast and  Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
Up to 2,000 troops have been recalled to Northern Ireland as part of a huge security operation after this weekend's controversial Drumcree Orange Order parade was banned for the third year running.

Army headquarters in Northern Ireland confirmed that three battalions of soldiers had been drafted in, with two more to arrive by Sunday morning when Orangemen will attempt to defy the ban on their march.

The return of the troops, who were withdrawn from the province as part of the peace process, underlined fears among security sources that violence could erupt at the weekend when police prevent the Orangemen from marching along the nationalist Garvaghy Road into Portadown. The Northern Ireland parades commission banned the march on Monday night, saying it could have an "adverse impact" on community relations.

Orangemen, who have held a year-long vigil at Drumcree parish church in protest at last year's ban, have underlined their determination to march this year by filing for two parades on consecutive Sundays.

The Drumcree parade - the biggest flashpoint in Northern Ireland's annual loyalist marching season - normally takes place on the last Sunday before the main July 12 Orange commemorations.

In the violent loyalist backlash which followed the decision to ban the march in 1998 three young children from one family were killed in a petrol bomb attack on their home.

An army spokesman yesterday described the temporary arrival of the troops as "prudent contingency plans". Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, insisted that the government was still committed to continuing to "scale down" the security presence in Northern Ireland following the IRA decision to open three arms dumps to international inspectors last week.

Tension at Drumcree this year is expected to be greater than last year, when the military were not called in. Many unionists feel betrayed by the resumption of the Northern Ireland assembly without the IRA being being forced to hand over arms.

Hardline unionists yesterday stepped up the pressure on David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, when they secured the support of 30 members of the Northern Ireland assembly to force a debate to exclude Sinn Fein from the power-sharing executive. But the motion, tabled by Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists, will not succeed because votes in Northern Ireland have to attract cross-community support to be passed. However, the DUP hopes to expose divisions within Mr Trimble's party by attracting the support of disgruntled Ulster Unionists.

Two UUP members who opposed Mr Trimble's decision to re-establish the executive, Peter Weir and Pauline Armitage, broke ranks yesterday to support the DUP motion, prompting the DUP deputy leader, Peter Robinson, to challenge others to support him.

Two DUP ministers are expected to resign if, as is almost certain, their proposal is rejected. Other members of their party will then fill their seats.

The renewed threat to Mr Trimble came as the government unveiled an important concession to nationalists in the police bill, which will set up the force to replace the RUC. At a hearing of the committee stage of the bill at Westminster, Adam Ingram, the Northern Ireland security minister, said the government would accept a key demand of the SDLP over the oath sworn by members of the new force.

The amendment will mean police recruits will swear to respect all "traditions and beliefs", seen by nationalists as recognition of their identity.

Tension at Drumcree this year is expected to be greater than last year, when the military were not called in. Many unionists feel betrayed by the resumption of the Northern Ireland assembly without the IRA being being forced to hand over arms. Hardline unionists yesterday stepped up the pressure on David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, when they secured the support of 30 members of the Northern Ireland assembly to force a debate to exclude Sinn Fein from the power-sharing executive. But the motion, tabled by Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists, will not succeed because votes in Northern Ireland have to attract cross-community support to be passed. However, the DUP hopes to expose divisions within Mr Trimble's party by attracting the support of disgruntled Ulster Unionists. Two UUP members who opposed Mr Trimble's decision to re-establish the executive, Peter Weir and Pauline Armitage, broke ranks yesterday to support the DUP motion, prompting the DUP deputy leader, Peter Robinson, to challenge others to support him. Two DUP ministers are expected to resign if, as is almost certain, their proposal is rejected. Other members of their party will then fill their seats. The renewed threat to Mr Trimble came as the government unveiled an important concession to nationalists in the police bill, which will set up the force to replace the RUC. At a hearing of the committee stage of the bill at Westminster, Adam Ingram, the Northern Ireland security minister, said the government would accept a key demand of the SDLP over the oath sworn by members of the new force. The amendment will mean police recruits will swear to respect all "traditions and beliefs", seen by nationalists as recognition of their identity.

webTitle: Voyeur vision puts contestants in focus

fields.headline: Voyeur vision puts contestants in focus
fields.standfirst: 40,000 apply to have every hour recorded for TV game show
fields.trailText: Owing more to Colditz than a Conran loft conversion, a purpose-built London home is about to become the centre of this year's biggest television phenomenon.
fields.body:
Owing more to Colditz than a Conran loft conversion, a purpose-built London home is about to become the centre of this year's biggest television phenomenon.

It needs to be well-protected. When its 10 occupants move in next month, they will become the focus of unrelenting interest, the target of commercial publicity stunts and an attraction for assorted oddballs.

The reason is that their every hour, waking and sleeping, is to be filmed for consumption on nightly television shows and 24-hour webcasts.

In Europe, where this social experiment was first aired, the broadcasts became compulsive viewing. Big Brother has been copied for Britain in a £5m show that broadcasters expect to become the most talked-about television event of the summer.

More than 40,000 applications from the public have been whittled down to 14, following psychological tests, interviews and auditions. Eight have been chosen, and producers are close to agreeing the final pair who will make up the family that is to take up residence next month.

Every week, viewers will vote to evict one participant, picked from a shortlist of two drawn up by the residents. At the end, the survivor will take home a prize of £70,000.

There will be plenty of viewing on which to judge the contestants. Two dozen cameras, some behind mirrors, cover every inch of the house; there is a camera trained on the kitchen sink, and another behind the bathroom washbasin mirror. Even the shower room and toilets are on camera - although certain private moments in these locations will not be broadcast.

There are microphones above the Ikea beds and behind the Habitat sofas. Each contestant will wear a radio mike, so there can be no whisperings out on the patio. Even fumblings under the duvet could be shown - subject to broadcasting regulations.

Security at the site in Plaistow, east London, is tight: guard dogs and razor wire protect the 15ft steel perimeter fence around the house.

Each night for 10 weeks at 10.30pm, Channel 4 will screen a half-hour programme based on the previous day. Every Friday, Davina McCall will host a live "eviction special", when the rejected contestant will walk what is termed the "bridge of shame" across a canal separating the house from a television studio. Viewers will watch as McCall takes each rejected contestant through their life in the Big Brother house.

The show has a psychologist from Oxford University, Peter Collett, to comment on events in the house. "It is going to be very revealing about how a group of strangers work together," said Peter Bazalgette of Bazal, the production company making the show.

The group's first task will be to decide the sleeping arrangements in the two bedrooms: mixed or same-sex? They will also need to settle on whether the house should be a non-smoking zone.

Provisions will be limited to flour, potatoes, pasta, rice and restricted amounts of fish and meat, locked in a larder to which participants will have an hour of access every day. They will each have a a £1.50 daily allowance with which to augment their supplies. If they want a more varied diet, they will have to tend the Big Brother garden: potatoes, tomatoes, celery, two varieties of runner beans, cabbage and strawberry plants have been planted. A chicken coop has been installed, and a handful of hens should provide (if they are tended properly) a supply of eggs.

The house is also equipped with a so-called confession room where occupants can speak directly to the audience, and where anyone who needs a respite can consult a resident psychotherapist. Occupants will be given daily tasks to explore aspects of their personalities: leadership skills, cooperation and so on. If a mood sets in and the producers want to change the atmosphere, they might demand team work; or if people sleep too late, hot water might only be available up to 8.30 in the morning.

The participants' success in completing tasks will be rewarded with points to increase their food supplies or give them luxuries such as alcohol. While viewers will be able to suggest possible challenges, the producers and the show's psychological consultants will have the final say.

Success on the show guarantees instant fame: one German participant drives around in a Mercedes with two bodyguards, while a Dutch contestant ended up modelling for Playboy.

fields.headline: Unilever finally clears EU hurdle
fields.trailText: Market Forces
fields.body:
Anglo-Dutch consumer products group, Unilever, received long-awaited European Union approval yesterday for the launch of its cholesterol-lowering margarine, Becel pro activ.

The EU standing committee for foodstuffs gave the go-ahead months after Finnish rival Raisio beat Unilever to market with a similar product, Benecol.

Benecol first launched in Finland in 1995, and was not subject to the new committee's 1997 regulations which were responsible for Unilever's delay.

Last year judges dismissed an appeal from Unilever that they would be disadvantaged in Europe because consumers would confuse Becel pro activ with Raisio's simi larly-named brand. The Unilever margarine uses a derivative of soybeans to reduce the absorption of harmful LDL cholesterol, and will be sold as Becel pro activ in continental Europe and Flora pro activ in Britain.

The product has already launched in a number of countries including Australia, Brazil and the United States (where it is known as Take Control) with the claim that it can reduce cholesterol by 10-15% in a matter of weeks.

Christiaan Brakman, a spokesman for Unilever Europe, said the company was disappointed that the approval procedure had taken so long but indicators from the US and Australian launches last year were encouraging. He said: "US sales have been in line with expectations and the Australian launch has exceeded all our expectations."

Unilever, whose brands range from Calvin Klein to Findus, view the Becel pro activ launch as integral to securing a slice of the rapidly expanding health-promotion foods sector which, according to Dutch Rabobank, could see global sales grow by 62% from $32bn (£21bn) last year to $52bn in 2004.

Mr Brakman said the company anticipate Becel pro activ starting as a niche product for consumers with cholesterol problems, but eventually broadening out as, they believe, it becomes a recommended product.

Foods Director at Unilever, Lex Kemner, said in a statement: "We are confident that this independent scientific assessment will contribute substantially to consumers' and health professionals' trust."

Final preparations to roll out the product across Europe will follow a European Commission rubber stamp in four weeks.

Shares in Unilever fell recently when the company issued reduced sales forecasts of 2%-3% growth having previously forecast 3%-4% in February. Half-year results are due on August 4.Unilever shares closed yesterday at 416.25p down 0.75p.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Market Forces
fields.body:
Freeserve took another tumble yesterday as the market decided that life without T-Online was worth less than originally thought. The shares fell 45.5p, after a fraught Monday when they dropped 73.75p, to hit a six-month low of 318p.

In thin trading, the fading star of Britain's most valuable ISP dragged down the FTSE and Techmark, which finished 0.5% down at 3414.

At the close, the FTSE 100 index was 29.9 points lower at 6,375.3, just off its afternoon low of 6,365.6, and staying well below its early peak of 6,428.4.

Many dealers were content to sit on their hands and wait for today's Fed decision on US interest rates. British blue chips had managed to sport solid early gains, boosted by overnight gains on Wall Street which saw the Dow Jones power forward, and the Nasdaq index recover from recent profit-taking falls. Shares in Freeserve's parent, Dixons, managed to rally and ended up 5.5p at 269p. Psion was also up, gaining 30p at 690p following news of plans to supply Compaq with Bluetooth wireless software.

Telewest , down 32p at 267p, ran into profit-taking after Monday's strong gains on the back of news that Dutch-listed UPC has taken a 25% stake in the group. Other telecom issues also suffered again, with Energis losing 120p at 2,675p and Colt Telecom shedding 69p at 2,361p. BT, off 10p at 905p, reflected news that the government has sold its remaining holding of 11m shares in the firm to Schroder Salomon Smith Barney for onward sale to institutional clients, following a competitive auction for the stake.

Also on the downside, National Grid shed 5.5p at 516p after regulator Ofgem disclosed plans to raise the group's RPI-x control period to five years.

Granada Group - off 30.5p at 620p - and Compass Group , down 24.5p at 813p, suffered after news of Morgan Stanley's downgrades to ratings to "neutral" from "outperform" for the soon-to-merge firms.

BAE Systems , which hit 280p in January, has seen a steady recovery in sentiment to take the shares back up to 429p. The deal struck with Airbus whereby it becomes a 20% shareholder and offloads much of its liabilities to the company pleased Schroder Salomon Smith Barney among others. Salomons set a price target of 585p, which BAe took a step nearer yesterday, edging up 3p.

Banks did not fare so well. Legal & General shed 7.5p to 160p on reports of a downgrade by Cazenove. Alliance & Leicester was off 4p to 560p, Lloyds dipped 6p to 624p.

fields.headline: Berkeley Group
fields.trailText: Focus: Property group Berkeley is in the middle of a good run. And the more pessimistic view of the property price boom is not going to upset that.
fields.body:
Property group Berkeley is in the middle of a good run. And the more pessimistic view of the property price boom is not going to upset that.

Berkeley Group denies that yesterday's report from the Royal Chartered Institute of Surveyors, which reported a slowdown in house prices, will have a negative effect on the year ahead.

Chairman Roger Lewis said: "The market needs a period of stabilisation and we do better during such times. A lot of rubbish was sold at inflated prices last year and stabilisation means this is put to an end."

Britain's housing boom triggered better than forecast annual results for Berkeley Group. Pre-tax profits for the year to April 30 rose from £110.2m in 1999 to £143.2m - an increase of 30%. Analysts had expected £138m.

Turnover was up £102m to £799m and the number of units sold went from 2,825 to 2,915, with the average price per property up £20,000 to £251,000. A final dividend of 9.8p is expected. Combined with February's interim dividend of 3.1p, the total payment to shareholders will be 12.9, up 15.2% year on year.

Mr Lewis attributed the profit growth to rising house values, particularly in the south-east which accounts for around 70% of the company's income. The group has advance bookings for the coming year of £400m and expects the profits from its 1,665-unit development in Chelsea Harbour to come in during 2001-02.

UBS Warburg adjusted profit forecasts for 2000-01 yesterday to £157.5m following the results announcement.

Shares closed up 13p yesterday at 623.5p

fields.headline: Power gap swallows peace summit
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, flew into the Middle East last night and straight into a blazing row between Israel and the Palestinians on plans for a peace summit.
fields.body:
The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, flew into the Middle East last night and straight into a blazing row between Israel and the Palestinians on plans for a peace summit.

Insecurities are hampering all three leadership camps involved in trying to get some sort of deal between the Israelis and Palestinians before September 13 - the latest notional deadline for a final peace agreement after nearly seven tortuous years of negotiation..

As Bill Clinton works out his last few months as US president, his ability to act as a power broker is shrinking. So too, by extension, is Mrs Albright's as mediator.

Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, is lobbying hard for President Clinton to host a three-way summit in Washington at the beginning of next month to force through a deal.

But Mr Barak has been weakened by coalition quarrels. Some in his cabinet are balking after recent press reports of possible concessions that would see Israel ceding control of 90% of the West Bank.

The officials around the ailing Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, fear Mr Barak lacks the power to marshall his coalition behind a viable peace deal. "We want to avoid going to a summit that is not prepared very well," Saeb Erakat, a lead negotiator, told Israel Radio.

But Haim Ramon, an Israeli minister seen as a Barak spokesman, said: "The only chance is through a summit in which chairman Arafat makes the necessary concessions. Sure it is a risk but without it the peace process will fail."

webTitle: Video Networks set to announce £100m private deal

fields.headline: Video Networks set to announce £100m private deal
fields.standfirst: Cash will enable company to offer hundreds of films, TV programmes and sport on demand
fields.trailText: Video Networks, the video- on-demand company that had been tipped for a £1bn stock market flotation, is close to securing its next set of financing through a private placing instead.
fields.body:
Video Networks, the video- on-demand company that had been tipped for a £1bn stock market flotation, is close to securing its next set of financing through a private placing instead.

The company, which is currently running a commercial pilot of its service in 2,000 homes in west London, is expected to announce a £100m-plus agreement later this week.

The deal with a private equity firm should be enough to finance the business for at least the next 18 months.

Video Networks was actively considering plans for a stock market flotation, but will have been chilled by the experiences of fellow video-on- demand companies Yes Television and Filmgroup.

Both Yes TV and Filmgroup pulled their floats at the eleventh hour earlier this year in the face of market turmoil. The aborted plans will have had a damaging effect on the prospects of any similar business keen to join the market, at least in the short term.

The new cash raised will be a step change for Video Networks and fund the start of its roll out of a national service, due to begin in the next few months.

It is not known which company Video Networks has secured backing from although previous investors in the business include Bernard Arnault's luxury goods empire LVMH, GE Equity, SanPaolo Imi of Italy and investment company Digital Explosion LLC. The total amount raised previously was around £70m.

Video Networks employs ADSL technology which enables existing copper telephone wires to be upgraded for high bandwidth applications such as video and high speed internet.

The company aims to offer households hundreds of Hollywood films and television programmes and sporting events on demand under the HomeChoice brand. The technology allows viewers to not only watch programmes when they want but has the functionality of a video recorder - allowing fast forward, pause and rewind.

It has signed licensing deals with, among others, Warner Brothers, Buena Vista and Columbia TriStar.

Video Networks also recently applied for a broadcasting licence which will, in effect, allow it to become a direct competitor to the cable and satellite pay-TV businesses when the broadcasting ban on British Telecom's network is lifted next year. Filmgroup abandoned its flotation plans earlier this month after the company failed to generate the interest in its shares that it had hoped. Yes TV failed in two attempts to join the market.

Video Networks also has content deals to screen Wimbledon tennis, the Euro 2000 football tournament, ITN news programmes and BBC nature series including Walking With Dinosaurs.

Video Networks declined to comment.

fields.headline: Littlewoods ends pools era
fields.standfirst: Blackpool Tower tycoon masterminds £160m deal to buy family business
fields.trailText: The Moores family drew the curtain on more than 75 years of history yesterday by selling its Littlewoods pools empire for £160m in a deal led by leisure tycoon Trevor Hemmings.
fields.body:
The Moores family drew the curtain on more than 75 years of history yesterday by selling its Littlewoods pools empire for £160m in a deal led by leisure tycoon Trevor Hemmings.

Under the new plans to develop the business, which has been hurt by the advent of the lottery, pools coupons might soon be extended outside the UK and Australian football to major championships such as the World Cup and league matches in Europe.

The Liverpool-based business is to be reversed into the much smaller Rodime, essentially a £40m shell company in which Bank of Scotland has a 49% stake.

Mr Hemmings, who has stakes in the Blackpool Tower, 800 pubs and racecourses through Arena Leisure, masterminded the deal and was the successful bidder against 12 others. He has promised to keep the 750 jobs in the pools operation.

The sale leaves Littlewoods, founded by Sir John Moores in the 1920s, with a retail business which yesterday admitted it was having a "tough time" in its home shopping areas.

With its customer base in the "middle market", Littlewoods' retailing plight is similar to that of C&A, which is pulling the plug on its 109 stores, and rival catalogue firm GUS. The businesses are being squeezed by discount retailers.

However, Barry Gibson, chief executive of Littlewoods, said yesterday that he had put in a bid for up to 30 of the C&A stores.

Littlewoods, still owned by more than 30 members of the Moores family, tried to demonstrate that its performance on the high street had not been as bad as its home shopping area, where its catalogues had featured over-priced clothes.

fields.headline: Reclusive dealmaker with common touch
fields.trailText: Trevor Hemmings is an old fashioned kind of tycoon. Not for him the internet goldrush or the hi-tech road to riches but the more traditional pursuits of racecourses, casinos, pubs, pleasure beaches, oh and wallpaper, after he made a successful bid for Vymura last year.
fields.body:
Trevor Hemmings is an old fashioned kind of tycoon. Not for him the internet goldrush or the hi-tech road to riches but the more traditional pursuits of racecourses, casinos, pubs, pleasure beaches, oh and wallpaper, after he made a successful bid for Vymura last year.

Mr Hemmings began his working life at 15 after leaving his secondary modern school to wipe grease from diesel trains. He then became an apprentice bricklayer in his native Lancashire and within five years had his own business. That was sold to Christian Salvesen for £1.5m in the 1970s. A second building company was sold to Barratts for £5.7m a few years later.

By this year, a career built on shrewd deal-making had gained him 54th place in the Sunday Times rich list which estimated his worth at £450m. He clearly had a good year, climbing from 64th in 1999.

At the age of 64, Mr Hemmings remains a virtual recluse as far as the press is concerned. His deals are largely done through private companies which does not expose the entrepreneur to the gaze of either the City at large or the business pages.

He does not appear, however, to have lost any of his appetite for deal-making, despite the advancing years. Nor has he lost his grit after taking Vymura for £29m in a hostile bid. His other recent deals included the acquisition of Blackpool Tower and a number of piers from First Leisure for £73m and a string of buys which took his pub estate to some 900.

Mr Hemmings made his name in the holiday camp business. In 1987 he led the £57m management buyout of the Pontins group from Bass and later sold it to Scottish & Newcastle for a sizeable profit after turn ing the fortunes of the business round. He became a director at S&N and engineered the acquisition of the more upmarket Center Parcs holiday destinations.

The key to his success, he has claimed, is mingling with the people. "You will not see me in the restaurants at Lingfield [racecourse] or Ayr," he once said. "I queue up at the chippy with the real people. You have to learn about the real people and understand their requirements."

Mr Hemmings owns around half of Arena Leisure the quoted racecourse owner which, among others, owns Lingfield Park. At Arena, however, the internet has played its part in Mr Hemming's recent gains in wealth. Hopes of online betting profits from Arena Leisure have caused shares in the company to soar.

webTitle: Israel hounds the Jew who spied for the KGB

fields.headline: Israel hounds the Jew who spied for the KGB
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: At 8am precisely, a stooped man with a halo of white hair emerged with his walking stick from an unremarkable block of flats in central Tel Aviv and mingled with the crowd.
fields.body:
At 8am precisely, a stooped man with a halo of white hair emerged with his walking stick from an unremarkable block of flats in central Tel Aviv and mingled with the crowd.

He is Israel's walking nightmare: a Jew who spied for the former Soviet Union for nearly 20 years, and from an exceedingly privileged vantage point: deputy director of the top-secret institute that is reported to be the hub of Israel's chemical and biological warfare programme.

Dr Marcus Klingberg was released from prison nearly two years ago, after serving 16 years of a life term, but he remains under constant surveillance because, at the age of 81, and two decades after his days as a KGB agent, Israel still considers him a threat to its security.

A burly minder with a pistol at his hip followed his every move as he tapped his way to a nearby clinic yesterday. Dr Klingberg is locked into his flat at night, and allowed contact with only a handful of people.

Today his lawyers await a ruling from a court in the southern city of Beer Sheva which could finally free the man blamed for inflicting the most serious damage ever to Israel's clandestine weapons programme. It would also release him from the financial burden of a surveillance apparatus for which Dr Klingberg is forced to pay more than £2,000 a month.

That prospect is being fiercely contested by the Israeli government, which accuses Dr Klingberg of compounding his crimes by writing a book about his experiences with the KGB. His lawyer denies the claim.

Most Israelis can barely remember Dr Klingberg, so great are the government's efforts to expunge his name from living memory.

His trial in 1983 was held in camera; even Dr Klingberg's late wife was banned from attending the case of State of Israel vs "X", and even from telling friends of his arrest.

He was held at Ashqelon prison under the false name of Abraham Greenberg and for 10 years military censors forbade Israeli newspapers from printing his name. In effect, the doctor with an international reputation for his research on congenital abnormalities had ceased to exist.

For the security establishment, Dr Klingberg's betrayal is enormous. As deputy director of the Israel Institute for Biological Research, he was essential to a chemical and biological weapons programme that Israel has refused to acknowledge.

Even after his release, his punishment continues. He lives a lonely existence, confined to a fourth floor flat with barred windows. He is allowed out for only a few hours a day, and his every contact with the outside world is vetted by a special branch of the intelligence services.

He is banned from owning a computer or fax machine, or dialling his own phone. A few months ago, he was barred from speaking Yiddish to an old friend because his minder could not understand.

His only child, Sylvia, argues that her father has paid for his crime, and that requiring him to shoulder the costs of his security is vindictive.

"For me, it is rather odd that he should remain under house arrest because it is 10 years since the Soviet Union ceased to exist," she said from Paris, where she now lives. "It is an old story of an old world. It really is a part of history, and of a particular generation."

In the hazy realms of anti-Israeli espionage, Dr Klingberg has little in common with Mordechai Vanunu, who was jailed for 18 years in 1986 for revealing Israeli nuclear secrets to a British newspaper.

Unlike Vanunu, Klingberg divulged his secrets to the KGB in a calculated manner. According to his daughter, he admitted at his trial to spying, and is believed to have met his controllers regularly from 1957 to 1975. But by the time of his arrest, on his way to a scientific conference in Switzerland, he had broken off contact with the KGB for seven years.

He also occupied a much more privileged position in Israeli society. He rose to the rank of lieutenant-colonel in the army medical corps and still receives a military pension. He had many academic publications to his credit, and spent a sabbatical at Oxford.

But as a Polish-born Jew who lost his family in the Holocaust, he always believed he owed a debt to the Soviet Union, and to the Red Army in which he served, for allowing him a chance to avenge that loss, his daughter says.

For others, the passage of time has done nothing to erase Dr Klingberg's betrayal.

"I never thought a Jew could do such a thing to our state," said a woman who has lived downstairs from Dr Klingberg for 25 years. "You can't be sympathetic to a man like this. You can't forgive him."

fields.headline: Birth of a football dynasty
fields.trailText: Sir John Moores was the brain behind the Littlewoods pools business, which he started in the 1920s. He began by selling coupons outside Manchester United's ground.
fields.body:
Sir John Moores was the brain behind the Littlewoods pools business, which he started in the 1920s. He began by selling coupons outside Manchester United's ground.

Within 10 years, and with the help of his brother, Cecil, he had expanded the business into home shopping and had begun to establish its high street presence.

But while Old Trafford was the birthplace of the Littlewoods' business, Liverpool is where the family's football connections survive; some members of the family took stakes in both Everton and Liverpool football clubs in the 1960s. The family retains its stake in Liverpool, where Cecil's son David is chairman.

More than 30 members of the Moores family still own Littlewoods, one the largest privately owned businesses in the country. Their managerial connections have faded in recent years after internal squabbles and the appointment of James Ross, a former chief executive of Cable & Wireless, as chairman, four years ago.

Only one member of the wealthy clan remains on the board; James Suenson-Taylor, the son of Sir John's daughter Lady Grantchester.

Speculation about the sale of the pools business, hurt by the birth of the National Lottery, first began just over a year ago when the operation was given a separate management board.

The family shareholders will now have to decide whether to take the £160m proceeds in cash or reinvest it in the struggling retail business, which will be the next part of the operation to be subjected to fresh rumours of an impending stock market flotation.

fields.headline: Enrico Cuccia
fields.standfirst: Secret hand behind Italian banking power
fields.trailText: Enrico Cuccia, who has died aged 92, was the grand old strategist of Italian capitalism. His immense power as a financier at the head of Mediobanca, the merchant bank set up in 1946 to grant loans to Italy's war-ravaged industry, prompted the former prime minister, Giulio Andreotti, to remark: "At times, Cuccia was more important than the government."
fields.body:
Enrico Cuccia, who has died aged 92, was the grand old strategist of Italian capitalism. His immense power as a financier at the head of Mediobanca, the merchant bank set up in 1946 to grant loans to Italy's war-ravaged industry, prompted the former prime minister, Giulio Andreotti, to remark: "At times, Cuccia was more important than the government."

Cuccia linked enterprises to enterprises, not enterprises to banks and politics. But there was a paradox about his leadership of an institution whose main shareholder, until the end of the 1980s, was the state: he invariably championed the interests of the big, historical Italian business families over those of the smaller industrialists. Over the years, that led to accusations that he favoured "capitalism for the chosen few".

The Agnellis picked him as their personal adviser, and Leopoldo Pirelli was quoted as saying: "What Cuccia wants, God wants." Another financier, Giampiero Pesenti, noted that "Cuccia is the only one in Italy who can reach the world's most important bankers within five minutes."

Cuccia was born in Rome of Sicilian origin, the son of a senior civil servant at the finance ministry. He graduated in jurisprudence in 1930 and, after a brief foray into journalism, joined the Bank of Italy and worked in Ethiopia. Then he joined the Banca Commerciale Italiana (Comit), part of IRI, the state holding company set up to help Italy out of the depression. He married Idea Nuova Beneduce, a daughter of the IRI founder, Alberto Beneduce, then left when Raffaele Mattioli, a key figure in postwar finance, tapped him to start Mediobanca.

In order to underpin a system that often ran short by billions of lire, Cuccia financed big sums at favourable rates. At every critical point in postwar Italian history, he was there, masterminding something.

He created the merger of Montecatini and Edison (into Montedison) in 1966, which marked the first reorganisation of the chemical industry; the marriage between Pirelli and Dunlop, and the rescue of Fiat in 1972, when he helped the Agnellis retain the control of the group by selling a 10% stake in Fiat to the Libyan Arab Investment Bank - and then, some 10 years later, by helping Fiat to buy it back.

His alliance with the Agnelli family remained, for years, the bulwark of financial power in Italy, although, according to some analysts, it cooled towards the end of the 1990s. His seemingly omnipotent influence, as head of IRI, also brought him into conflict with Romano Prodi. Cuccia looked increasingly like the great pessimist who, in good faith, wanted to defend the status quo, while Prodi wanted to open up the system and extend the help that banks could give to business.

In 1994, Cuccia was one of four Mediobanca executives investigated for alleged accounting irregularities. But he was never charged, and nothing dimmed his star status. He remained the last of Italy's old-style bankers, who pulled the strings with a word in the ear at the right moment, or a phone call to the right person.

Despite growing demands for globalisation in international finance, his influence was a determining factor until the end. His last coup, in 1999, was the successful backing of Olivetti in the hostile takeover bid for Telecom Italia.

Cucci retained an almost sacred sense of secrecy, an inheritance, perhaps, from his Sicilian origins. He used to say: "Financiers can commit two sins. The venial sin is to flee with the coffers; the deadly sin is to speak." In an unusual move aimed at preserving the independence of Mediobanca, he recently went to Rome to court the then prime minister, Massimo D'Alema. The former communist was sufficiently impressed that he was moved to declare that, for Cuccia, power was "a sort of priesthood".

Cuccia is survived by his wife, a son and two daughters.

Enrico Cuccia, banker, born November 24 1907; died June 23 2000

fields.headline: Pierre Pflimlin
fields.standfirst: French prime minister and champion of Europe whose discretion saved his country from civil war over Algeria
fields.trailText: French prime minister and champion of Europe whose discretion saved his country from civil war over Algeria
fields.body:
In February 1999, the political party known as the Union Démocratique Française, usually described as "centriste", decided in Bordeaux that, in the forthcoming European elections, they would stand as an independent party. Most people thought the finest speech made on this occasion came from Pierre Pflimlin, who has died aged 93, eloquent and incisive as ever, in spite of his years.

He stood then, as he always had, for three great causes: Europe, Alsace and Social Catholicism. But for many listening, the most prominent episode in his long career was his appointment as prime minister in May 1958, which precipitated the demise of the fourth republic, and which, without Pflimlin's skill and honesty, could have led to civil war in France.

At that time, internal divisions and the repercussions of the Algerian war had made government in France impossible. When President Coty invited Pflimlin to form a government on May 8, the country had been without a premier for 38 days.

In Algeria, the reaction to his appointment was violent. Pflimlin had earlier, in the Strasbourg newspaper, Le Nouvel Alsacien, suggested a ceasefire and negotiations among all parties. The army rejected this. Crowds demonstrated on both sides of the Mediterranean, declaiming that Algeria was French. Pflimlin's summer house, in the south of France, was bombed. On May 13, as he was asking the national assembly for a vote of confidence, insurgents seized power in Algiers.

The immediate result was a clear vote of confidence in Pflimlin, since most deputies felt that there had to be a government in power to face up to the crisis. But the situation worsened; Corsica was invaded, and it seemed that the mainland would be attacked, with parachutists landing in Paris.

General de Gaulle was the unknown factor. Was he in favour of the insurrection or waiting for the right moment to install himself at the head of a military dictatorship? Pflimlin met de Gaulle secretly during the night of May 26 and asked him to condemn the insurgents, but the general refused. The meeting ended at 2am and, at midday, Pflimlin was astonished to learn of de Gaulle's communiqué stating that he had begun the regu lar process necessary for the establishment of a republican government. This was not true - but should Pflimlin say so?

Had Pflimlin denounced de Gaulle's statement, some sort of military action would certainly have followed. In spite of much pressure, especially from François Mitterrand and the communists, Pflimlin remained discreet. At 3am on May 29, after a long series of meetings, he went to Coty with his resignation.

He had been prime minister for only 21 days - but they had been crucial. Coty said that the French people did not realise how much he had done for them, and de Gaulle seemed to have been sincere when he praised Pflimlin's courage and coolness. Earlier, by contrast, he had been dismissive, including Pflimlin among those devoted to the hopeless task of saving the fourth republic. "Pflimlin?" he said, "it's a name that makes me want to sneeze."

Pflimlin had entered politics by chance. In 1945, he had been appointed to organise a special court in Metz, which would try Vichy collaborators. This was not a job to his liking, and he found it difficult to accommodate himself and his young family in a town that had suffered intense destruction.

He therefore returned to his old job in the appeal court in Strasbourg, and to the house that he had left when he joined the army in September 1939. In Strasbourg, he found an interest ing political situation. The new Social Catholic party, the Mouvement Républicain Populaire, had been formed in Paris in November 1944 as the party of the resistance. By 1945, it was in process of creating itself in Strasbourg, but it had a rival, a Catholic party, linked with the resistance - but also seeking autonomy for Alsace.

Pflimlin chose the former, and was rapidly elected municipal councillor, and, in October 1945, deputy. He then became minister for agriculture, minister for overseas France, and finance minister. From 1956-59, he was the MRP's national president and, from 1959-83, mayor of Strasbourg. Always an ardent supporter of Europe, he backed all the measures for the creation of a European identity, including the proposal for a European defence community.

He stayed in de Gaulle's governments until May 15 1962, when the general mocked the idea of European integration. Pflimlin resigned, devoting himself from then on to Alsace and Europe, especially to Strasbourg as the site of the European parliament, and to relations with Germany. He was a member of the European parliament from 1979 and its president from 1984-89.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Mortgage lending up
fields.body:
Mortgage lending up

Gross mortgage lending by leading British banks rose in May to £6.5bn from £5.8bn the previous month, according to the British Bankers' Association. The BBA said new mortgage approvals totalled 144,000 loans with a value of £7.6bn, up from 63,270 and £4.3bn, respectively in April.

There were also 33,803 re-mortgages approved during the month with a value of £1.97bn - both record figures. The value of gross lending on personal loans rose to £3bn May, up from April's figure of £2.5bn.

JJB sees sales rise

JJB Sports total stores sales for the 21 weeks ended June 25 were up 17% over the corresponding period the previous year. The increase in like-for-like turnover during the first eight weeks of this financial year was 26%. It is continuing its policy of opening superstores while closing a number of smaller high street stores.

Executive chairman David Whelan will sell up to 4.5m shares in connection with the funding of the new JJB stadium, which is the home of Wigan Athletic and Wigan Rugby league clubs.

Lamy calls for new trade talks

A new round of trade talks is urgently needed to set the rules for governing the global economy, the EU's top trade negotiator, Pascal Lamy said yesterday.

Mr Lamy's call came as the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development pledged to work towards restarting the negotiations which collapsed in Seattle in December amid public protests against globalisation.

"There is a clear consensus here that time is running out," said Mr Lamy, who is campaigning for the World Trade Organisation to launch a new trade round this year, despite gloomy predictions that the process is effectively stalled until after the US elections this November.

Lower pound brings relief

The recent slide in the pound's external exchange rate, notably against the euro, has been "of considerable relief", according to Ian Plenderleith, one of the members of the interest rate setting monetary policy committee.

Mr Plenderleith said while some of the appreciation of the pound against the euro prior to mid-1998 was readily explainable by fundamental factors, the further rise in sterling since that time was somewhat harder to explain.

He refused to say whether or not the pound's recent decline has left it at a sustainable level.

BG finds Gaza holds oil fields

BG Group has discovered two oil fields off Gaza able to satisfy Palestinian needs, said Abdelrahman Hamad, housing minister and president of the Palestinian ministry of energy.

The discovery would also release a small amount for exportation after five months of prospecting, he said.

fields.headline: Beauty is a mole
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

Just as dusk is settling in the woods a darker thing lies across the path - a creature of darkness, an underworlder. The mole is stiff and dead. For all its five-inch length, this is a heroic corpse. Great clawed, shovel-feet which can propel the mole at three miles per hour through tunnels a mile long, are open to the sky. The mouth, with tiny needle teeth which can gobble up 80 pounds of worms a year, is gaping. The nose, which images its subterranean world much more than the pin-head eyes or invisible ears can, is bloody.

The soil in this part of the woods has all the consistency of a brick; it's a clay dried harder than in a kiln, and may have forced the mole above ground in a desperate scramble to leave the woods and get into fields. Bad luck. The soft, smoky blackness of its fur won't last the night.

Out in the warm summer evening there is a white pulse in the hedges and edges of the wood. Bramble, elderflower, dogwood and, more spectacularly, roses cast a ghostly light at dusk. The field or trailing rose with purple stems, white petals with gold centres is intense. Many of the larger dogroses are brilliant white and even those which are pink are a kind of white, rather than a kind of red. Even though the dogrose was grown in the Minoan palace gardens of Knossos, it and the field rose have been defined by their wildness and commonness as flowers of boundary and territory - hedgeroses, never quite accepted in the inner sanctum of the garden proper.

Because of their mixture of the wild and vernacular, the hedgeroses have largely escaped the obsessive meddling of horticulture. But at this time in the evening, as the sun sets behind the woods, the hedgeroses seem to give off a pale, ethereal light of their own, so much more atmospheric and moody than their cultivated counterparts. It's like the Sleeping Beauty story with the briars and hedgeroses enclosing the sleeping princess/goddess, except that tonight Beauty is a mole.

fields.headline: Alan Hovhaness
fields.standfirst: American composer synthesising music from east and west
fields.trailText: The American composer Alan Hovhaness, who has died aged 89, achieved and refined a striking synthesis between eastern and western musical cultures. Mainstream 20th-century music was of almost no concern to him; nearly every piece was spiritually rooted in ancient, and often remote, mysticism.
fields.body:
The American composer Alan Hovhaness, who has died aged 89, achieved and refined a striking synthesis between eastern and western musical cultures. Mainstream 20th-century music was of almost no concern to him; nearly every piece was spiritually rooted in ancient, and often remote, mysticism. The result was that his music was not taken seriously by the fashionable avant-garde, but nonetheless had many devotees.

The sheer scale of his output - well over 400 numbered works, including 67 symphonies - reflects a huge range of oriental, middle and near-eastern material. The titles of his works - such as Men Are Brothers (Symphony no 11), Compassion (Symphony no 26), Love Songs Of Hafiz, City Of Light (Symphony no 22) - point to a man with an inwardly peaceful spirit, drawing strength from his fellow creatures and their creator, and glorifying them in music.

The natural world of mighty rivers, lofty mountains, distant temples, mist-shrouded forests and myriad stars is evoked by his endless tapestries of tintinnabulation, woven with figures, canons and chorales.

Hovhaness was born in Somerville, Massachusetts, to a Scottish mother and Armenian father. He took an early interest in the piano and, before commencing lessons at the age of nine with Adelaide Proctor, learned to improvise and compose using a homemade musical notation method. Soon after entering Tufts University in 1929, he won a scholarship to the New England Conservatory of Music , studying with Frederick Converse, a significant composer and musical figure of his day .

Captivated by his Armenian heritage, he began voraciously exploring Armenian liturgical music, as well as that of the composer Komitas Vartabed (1869-1936), who was virtually unknown outside Armenia. Hovhaness's Symphony No 1, Exile (1936) had some Siberian overtones, but it is a strikingly original testimony to the plight of the Armenian nation during the Turkish persecution of the first world war. It was given a BBC performance under Leslie Heward in 1939.

Meanwhile, Hovhaness's interest in other eastern cultures was expanding and , in 1940, he decided to destroy a whole host of earlier works with which he was dissatisfied. H e began to adapt an increasingly improvisatory, seamless Byzantine musical language, overlaid with neo- baroque fugal structures. At about this time, he also introduced a technique he called "spirit murmur", whereby instruments, mainly strings, would improvise freely within defined limits, often using modal or whole-tone scales and glissandi, as in his piano concerto Lousadzak (The Coming Of Light, 1944).

By now, Hovhaness was living in Boston, supporting himself by teaching music, and playing the organ at the Armenian church. In 1942, he went on a scholarship to the Tanglewood music centre, but came away disappointed; Lukas Foss and Aaron Copland had criticised his music. From then on, he became his own man musically.

A chance attendance at a concert in Boston, given by a visiting group of Indian musicians, gave further impetus to his eastern interests and, by 1950, after a two-year spell on the staff at Boston Conservatory, Hovhaness left to become a fulltime composer. The following year, he moved to New York after the award of his first Guggenheim fellowship.

H e conducted the New York Philharmonic in the first performance of his St Vartan symphony, written in memory of the 5th-century Armenian martyr and consisting of a long series of short, embellished tableaux.

Shortly afterwards, he found a supporter in Leopold Stokowski, who was also based in New York , where he had established his own orchestra. I n 1955, Stokowski was appointed conductor of the Houston Symphony, and asked Hovhaness for a new piece for his opening concert.

The result, Mysterious Mountain, has become enduringly popular: Hovhaness always imagined it as what the earliest American music may have sounded like. "Mountains," he said, "represent symbols, like pyramids, of man's attempt to know God. They are symbolic meeting places between the mundane and spiritual worlds. " Many other "mountain" pieces followed.

In 1959, Hovhaness went to India on a Fulbright fellowship, where he directed the premiere of his Arjuna Symphony (No 8) , which features jhalas and other unusual Indian ostinati. He was accorded celebrity status the next year in Japan, where he immersed himself in gagaku (ancient Japanese court music) and noh drama, which led to several operas. It was thus inevitable that when he visited Korea, he should be drawn to ah-ak (old Korean court music) and, in 1963, his Symphony No 16 was scored for both western and Korean instruments (a further symphony for this combination followed in 1978). In 1962, he spent a year as composer-in-residence in Hawaii.

Travel fascinated Hovhan- ess, and many pieces cast their eye towards journeys both ancient and modern, such as Symphony No 15 (Silver Pilgrimage, 1963), another Stokowski commission, replete with lavish parts for gongs, bells and brass, Odysseus Symphony (1973) and Journey to Vega (1982).

In the late 1960s, Hovhaness settled in Lucerne, Switzerland, from where he visited London for concerts and to undertake recordings of his orchestral music for issue on his personal record label. One of his really big tunes can be found in the orchestral portrait Fra Angelico (1968), written in homage to the artist who painted in an oriental style.

His own music began to evolve towards a fusion of the many influences he had absorbed, but he lost no enthusiasm for experimentation: the large tone poem, And God Created Great Whales (1970), combines orchestra with the sound of hump-backed whales on tape. By the mid-1970s, he had moved permanently to Seattle, and his prolific work rate stood up until he was well into his 70s: more than 40 symphonies appeared between 1972 and 1992, though there was latterly a drift towards predictabilty.

He was a gracious and hospitable host at his idyllic home in the Cascade mountains. A tall, charismatic man, with kindly eyes and sage-like beard, he exuded an aura of timelessness. When asked for his view as to the path modern music was taking, he replied: "To me, atonality is against nature. In nature, everything has a centre: the planets, the sun, the moon and the earth." As to the place of his own music: "Well, it will all be sorted out in a few hundred years."

Hovhaness married Elizabeth Whittington in 1959. After their divorce he married, in 1977, the singer Hinako Fujihara, for whom many of his later pieces were written. His huge legacy seems set for a fair wind in the new age of eclecticism and romanticism.

fields.headline: Wall Street sheds its old threads
fields.standfirst: New York's business fashion undergoes a casual revolution
fields.trailText: New York's business fashion undergoes a casual revolution
fields.body:
Gone are the days when the easy part about going to work on Wall Street involved putting on a suit, a pressed white shirt, designer tie and neat black, lace-up shoes - the Wall Street so famously described by Brett Easton Ellis in American Psycho.

Instead, Wall Street's finest, and to a lesser extent those in London's financial district, the City, now face a new daily dilemma: what to wear.

They find themselves rummaging through their wardrobes to unearth khaki trousers, an open-neck, bright shirt and once-ridiculed suede shoes.

For women, twin-sets are becoming more common than a two-piece suit with knee-length skirt. Even sandals are considered to be acceptable in an environment where court shoes and tights were once the only footwear allowed.

The dress code is all part of a new language evolving on Wall Street. It is not the impenetrable jargon used by the young men, and sometimes women, who earn a healthy living by conducting multi-million dollar deals each day. But the new terminology and etiquette associated with "business casual" is proving just as mind-blowing for the uninitiated: attire for the internet age and the death-knell of the classic suit.

On a busy, hot and humid lunchtime near Wall Street, there are few signs of the corporate suit. It is a trend that can be traced back five years when many of the big Wall Street firms started allowing "dress-down Fridays", particularly in the summer when many New Yorkers try to slip off after lunch.

Then, about three months ago, the move to ditch the suit in favour of more casual wear exploded on Wall Street. It is the young internet entrepreneurs - the millionaires of the coming decade - behind the trend. Bankers turning up at their clients' offices in Silicon Valley or the heart of Manhattan felt out of place in their Wall Street attire.

One banker's interpretation of events reverses the impetus: "We're a service industry and the idea is that we want to make our clients feel comfortable."

Salomon Smith Barney, one of the big Wall Street firms, now owned by the Citigroup conglomerate, estimates that up to 95% of its employees, from the secretaries up to the chief executive, have embraced the idea of business casual.

"It's not mandatory. Most people are easing into it. It wasn't like there was one day that it happened," a Salomon spokesman said, adding that just in case a suit was usually hanging on the back of the office door.

Trickle-down effect

While the move to more casual attire is filtering through to the big American firms in London, it has yet to catch on to the same extent in the more conservative City environment that it has in Manhattan, even though the move in London has already started to have an impact on well-known formal retailers such as Moss Bros. It is a far cry from the days when London's bankers wore bowler hats and starched collars.

Three months into the transformation on Wall Street, the big firms are hastily setting the boundaries for what is suitable and what is not.

One clear messages is that business casual is fine but the dressing down of the old Fridays is not. This is a fine line, and big and the small firms alike are calling in help.

At increasingly frequent presentations to newly dressed-down bankers, lawyers or accountants, she says: "Don't lose your style. Keep looking clean and well presented."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Waiters serve fraud rings
fields.body:
Waiters serve fraud rings

Waiters working for criminals helped to push the cost of credit-card fraud to a record £189m last year, the Home Office said. Staff at Italian, Chinese and east European restaurants in Britain were passing customers' bank details on to counterfeiters.

Japan's dolphin kill close to 1/2m

More than 400,000 whales, dolphins, and porpoises have been killed in hunts around Japan in the past 20 years, says a report by the London-based Environmental Investigation Agency, marking the start this week of the International Whaling Commission meeting in Adelaide, Australia.

Drink-drive ban for pub officer

Philip Toulson, 40, a police officer who ran a pubwatch scheme to stamp out drunken behaviour, was yesterday banned from driving for 18 months and fined more than £1,000 by South Tyneside magistrates for crashing his car while over the limit.

Man choked on drug condom

A driver choked while swallowing a condom full of heroin - the size of a chicken leg - when police stopped his car, an inquest heard. Paramedics attended Peter Williams, 41, at the scene, but he died a week later at the Royal Cornwall hospital. A verdict of accidental death was recorded.

Barn storm for De Bono

The lateral thinking proponent Edward de Bono is fighting a barn conversion project near his 18th-century home in Norfolk. He says its use as a house would affect his privacy.

fields.headline: Cork farmers attack supermarket 'lies'
fields.trailText: Leading British supermarkets and wine retailers have been accused of "black propaganda" which could threaten the livelihoods of farmers involved in the cork industry.
fields.byline: John Vidal  and Eduardo Goncalves in Lisbon
fields.body:
Leading British supermarkets and wine retailers have been accused of "black propaganda" which could threaten the livelihoods of farmers involved in the cork industry.

The accusations by Portuguese politicians, academics and environmentalists follow the change by many leading wine retailers to plastic corks.

Marks and Spencer, which now sells millions of bottles a year with synthetic stoppers, has written to those complaining about the switch saying it is environmentally beneficial to use plastic because it saves cork trees being felled.

Safeway has claimed cork growers are damaging forests, the farmers are greedy and that they are driving out wildlife.

Portugal produces over half the world's cork and many farmers live at a subsistence level.

Paulo Portas, leader of the country's opposition Popular party, said campaigning against cork had been unremitting.

"First the supermarkets said that cork was overpriced. Then they said it spoilt wine. Now they say cork-stripping is an environmental hazard. This is a campaign based on falsehoods," he said.

Maria Teresa Correia, a cork forest specialist at Portugal's Evora University, said: "Everything the supermarkets are saying is untrue. They claim the cork farmers are endangering the wild boar, for example, when in fact this animal is thriving because of traditional forest management techniques."

Marks and Spencer has been criticised for claiming forests are being cut down to harvest cork for wine bottles.

Helena Freitas, president of LPN, Portugal's oldest conservation group, said: "The trees are never cut down. The bark of the cork oak is carefully stripped by hand, just as it has been for hundreds of years. "

Yesterday Marks and Spencer admitted its information was "incorrect" and Safeway said that it was ready to be corrected.
