fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: China opposes foreign visit
fields.body:
China opposes foreign visit

China has reacted angrily to the news that Britain is allowing the former Taiwan president Lee Teng-hui to pay a private visit.

"We strongly oppose Lee Teng-hui's visit to Britain," said a foreign ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, yesterday.

The Foreign Office said the trip by Mr Lee, who is regarded by Beijing as still exerting separatist influence, was a "private visit by a private citizen".
John Gittings, Hong Kong

Dealers vow to act on diamonds

Antwerp diamond dealers pledged yesterday to strengthen controls in concert with war-torn countries like Sierra Leone and Angola.

Peter Meuss, director-general of the Belgian city's Diamond High Council, said members would cooperate with a strict certification system and expel anyone found flouting it. Britain is leading a drive to help curb African wars sparked by rebel groups in control of diamond areas.
Ian Black, Brussels

Mermaid lures tourists

A bare-breasted blonde mermaid perched on a rock is surprising tourists along a Norwegian fjord.

"One man jumped off a boat and swam over to me," Line Oexnevad, 37, said of her job as a siren. "Most people just look and cheer."

Ms Oexnevad, naked except for a blonde wig and a fish-tail, was hired to sit on a rock along the Lyse fjord as a tourist attraction.
Reuters, Oslo

webTitle: Skydiver proves Da Vinci chute works

fields.headline: Skydiver proves Da Vinci chute works
fields.trailText: More than 500 years after Leonardo da Vinci sketched his design, a Briton has proved that the renaissance genius was indeed the inventor of the first working parachute.
fields.body:
More than 500 years after Leonardo da Vinci sketched his design, a Briton has proved that the renaissance genius was indeed the inventor of the first working parachute.

Adrian Nicholas, a 38-year-old skydiver from London, fulfilled his life's ambition to prove the aerodynamics experts wrong when he used a parachute based on Da Vinci's design to float almost one and a half miles down from a hot air balloon. Ignoring warnings that it would never work, he built the 187lb contraption of wooden poles, canvas and ropes from a simple sketch that Da Vinci had scribbled in a notebook in 1485.

And at 7am on Monday, over the Mpumalanga province of South Africa, Mr Nicholas proved in a 7,000ft descent that the design could indeed be looked upon as a prototype for the modern parachute.

Yesterday he said: "It took one of the greatest minds who ever lived to design it, but it took 500 years to find a man with a brain small enough to actually go and fly it.

"All the experts agreed it wouldn't work - it would tip over or fall apart or spin around and make you sick - but Leonardo was right all along. It's just that no one else has ever bothered trying to build it before."

Mr Nicholas, who holds the world record for the longest free fall at just under five minutes, was strapped into a harness attached by four thick ropes to a 70ft square frame of nine pine poles covered in canvas. He was then hoisted by a hot air balloon to 10,000ft above ground level.

The balloon dropped altitude for a few seconds, to enable the parachute to fill with air, and the harness was released, allowing the parachute to float free.

Surrounded by two helicopters and two parachutists, Mr Nicholas fell for five minutes as a black box recorder measured the 7,000ft descent, before he cut himself free and released a conventional parachute. The Da Vinci model, which has more in common with sail technology than with the modern-day parachute, made such a smooth and slow descent that the two accompanying parachutists had to brake twice to stay level with it. It had none of the sudden plunges and swinging associated with modern parachutes.

After being cut free, the contraption floated to the ground with only minor damage on impact.

Mr Nicholas, a former broadcaster who has made 6,500 skydives, said: "The whole experience was incredibly moving, like one of those great English boy's own adventures. I had a feeling of gentle elation and celebration. It was like floating under a balloon.

"I was able to stare out at the river below, with the wind rattling through my ears. As I landed, I thanked Leonardo for a wonderful ride."

The contraption, which has seen two aborted attempts to fly over Salisbury plain in Wiltshire earlier this year, was built by Katarina Ollikainen, Mr Nicholas's Swedish girlfriend.

Following Da Vinci's design for a four-sided pyramid covered in linen and measuring 24ft square at the base, Ms Ollikainen used only tools and materials that would have been available in the 15th century, apart from some thick balloon tapes to stop the canvas tearing.

Although there was little demand for parachutes in the 15th century - and it was the Frenchman Louis-Sebastien Lenormand who was always credited with the first parachute jump after he leapt from a tree with the help of two parasols - Da Vinci gave specific instructions for his design.

He wrote beside his sketch: "If a man is provided with a length of gummed linen cloth, with a length of 12 yards on each side and 12 yards high, he can jump from any great height whatsoever without any injury."

Leonardo's inventions
By Helen Morris

Aeroplane Numerous machines using bird-like wings which could be flapped by a man using his arms and legs - although most were too heavy to get off the ground using manpower alone. Encompassed retractable landing gear and crash safety systems using shock absorbers

Helicopter Prototype featured a rotating airscrew or propeller powered by a wound-up spring

Armoured car/tank Powered by four soldiers sitting inside. Problems included its thin wheels and large weight, which would make it hard to move

Diving Several different suits, most with a diver breathing air from the surface through long hoses. One imagined a crush-proof air chamber on the diver's chest to allow free swimming without any link to the surface

Robot First humanoid robot drawn in about 1495, and designed to sit up, wave its arms and move its head via a flexible neck while moving its jaw

Machine gun His innovations to create rapid fire led to the Gatling gun and the machine gun

webTitle: From Bleadon Man to digital man

fields.headline: From Bleadon Man to digital man
fields.trailText: In a demonstration of the power of human genetic research, the Queen yesterday met the relatives of the Unknown Soldier of Vietnam and the descendants of Jesse James.
fields.body:
In a demonstration of the power of human genetic research, the Queen yesterday met the relatives of the Unknown Soldier of Vietnam and the descendants of Jesse James.

She did so as she opened the Wellcome Wing of the Science Museum in London, designed to display up-to-the minute science.

The £50m wing tells the story of the discovery of the power of DNA and the deciphering of the human genome, unveiled on Monday.

The US government chose one unidentified casualty of the war it fought in Vietnam as a symbol of all its servicemen who died or went missing, and placed his remains in Arlington cemetery, Virginia. In 1998, the cemetery released his remains for identification by comparison of mitochondrial DNA, which is inherited from the mother. He was quickly found to be Michael Blassie, a pilot from St Louis, Missouri.

The wing also tells the story of Jesse James, reportedly shot in Missouri in 1882 for a $10,000 reward. But, historians began to ask, was the dead man really Jesse James? A US geneticist collected mitochondrial DNA from known descendants of the outlaw's mother, and compared them with the bones of the mystery man. The DNA matched, and science closed a chapter in the history of the American West.

"The opening of the Wellcome Wing is the biggest development of the Science Museum in its 140-year history," said Graham Farmelo, of the museum, yesterday. "From now on we can not just record history, we can make news and look to the future. For example, we have in the gallery a piece of equipment that was used last week to finish the first draft of the human genome project."

The wing contains a seven-story Imax cinema, a gallery called Digitopolis exploring the astonishing explosion of information technology, and six exhibitions. It tells the story of past, modern and future science in 2,700 exhibits, and a showcase - the making of the modern world - contains 1,800 iconic objects that chart the history of science and technology since 1750, from Puffing Billy, the oldest surviving steam engine, to a solar-powered car.

When it opens on July 3, visitors will see slices of a "digital human" in an electronic anatomy lesson. They will learn about Bleadon Man, one of Britain's oldest unearthed skeletons, and look at DNA matches with his surviving relatives near Bleadon, Somerset.

They will take their own fingerprints and create their own websites, storing information about themselves learned from interactive exhibits. They will get a sneak preview of the technology that will replace PIN numbers, signatures and passwords - when the blink of an eye will reveal the telltale pattern of the iris and identify the visitor, when the distinctive sound of an individual voice will open doors.

webTitle: One birth in 80 from a test tube

fields.headline: One birth in 80 from a test tube
fields.trailText: Nearly one child in 80 born in Britain today is a test-tube baby, according to figures compiled by Europe's fertility specialists.
fields.body:
Nearly one child in 80 born in Britain today is a test-tube baby, according to figures compiled by Europe's fertility specialists.

Just 22 years after British doctors astonished the world with the birth of Louise Brown, the first test-tube baby, more than 200,000 treatment cycles a year are being carried out in Europe.

France leads with 45,000, followed by Britain with 34,000 and Germany on more than 28,000. The three leaders account for half of all fertility provision in Europe.

The statistics from 18 countries, compiled for the first time by fertility specialists around Europe, were revealed yesterday at the annual conference of the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology in Bologna, Italy.

They show that 1.3% of all births in Europe are the result of either the standard test-tube baby technique IVF (in vitro fertilisation) or ICSI - where a single sperm is injected into the egg. In Britain, the proportion is 1.2%.

Britain has the second highest number of IVF and ICSI children, at 8,727 in the year 1997-98, just below France at 8,762.

Unlike France, however, where the state will pay for four attempts at IVF, the NHS will fund only one or two attempts for most couples and in some areas long waiting lists mean private treatment is virtually the only option.

Francoise Shenfield of the reproductive medicine unit of University College London, said: "The inequality of access in the UK is outrageous."

Karl Nygren, from the Sofia hospital in Stockholm, presenting the statistics, said Britain and France were doing well in terms of their success in achieving live births. In Britain 27.5% of fertilised eggs returned to the womb resulted in a live birth, while France achieved 25.6%.

Those countries with higher figures - such as Spain on 45.5% and the Czech Republic on 38.9% - achieved them only by returning a large number of embryos to the womb each time, which results in high rates of multiple births - twins, triplets, quads and even more.

Most fertility specialists agree that multiple births, which risk complications such as cerebral palsy as well as stress, are undesirable.

"That is a very strong message, that they are having a good success rate but running the risk of the dire consequences that are not talked about enough," Professor Nygren said.

"The couples who are in grief and depression with children who are mentally handicapped do not want to talk about it. How can you say you regret having a child?"

Scandinavia has the lowest incidence of multiple births from fertility treatment, because of a consensus among clinics that no more than two embryos should be replaced in the womb. There is growing pressure, he said, to return one.

The European average for births per treatment cycle is around 20%, which compares with 26% in the United States, where there are high rates of multiple births.

Private clinics put back large numbers of embryos to maximise women's chances of becoming pregnant, both to optimise their own success rates and because the couple can often not afford to return for further treatment for future babies.

Just 22 years after British doctors astonished the world with the birth of Louise Brown, the first test-tube baby, more than 200,000 treatment cycles a year are being carried out in Europe. France leads with 45,000, followed by Britain with 34,000 and Germany on more than 28,000. The three leaders account for half of all fertility provision in Europe. The statistics from 18 countries, compiled for the first time by fertility specialists around Europe, were revealed yesterday at the annual conference of the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology in Bologna, Italy. They show that 1.3% of all births in Europe are the result of either the standard test-tube baby technique IVF (in vitro fertilisation) or ICSI - where a single sperm is injected into the egg. In Britain, the proportion is 1.2%. Britain has the second highest number of IVF and ICSI children, at 8,727 in the year 1997-98, just below France at 8,762. Unlike France, however, where the state will pay for four attempts at IVF, the NHS will fund only one or two attempts for most couples and in some areas long waiting lists mean private treatment is virtually the only option. Francoise Shenfield of the reproductive medicine unit of University College London, said: "The inequality of access in the UK is outrageous." Karl Nygren, from the Sofia hospital in Stockholm, presenting the statistics, said Britain and France were doing well in terms of their success in achieving live births. In Britain 27.5% of fertilised eggs returned to the womb resulted in a live birth, while France achieved 25.6%. Those countries with higher figures - such as Spain on 45.5% and the Czech Republic on 38.9% - achieved them only by returning a large number of embryos to the womb each time, which results in high rates of multiple births - twins, triplets, quads and even more. Most fertility specialists agree that multiple births, which risk complications such as cerebral palsy as well as stress, are undesirable. "That is a very strong message, that they are having a good success rate but running the risk of the dire consequences that are not talked about enough," Professor Nygren said. "The couples who are in grief and depression with children who are mentally handicapped do not want to talk about it. How can you say you regret having a child?" Scandinavia has the lowest incidence of multiple births from fertility treatment, because of a consensus among clinics that no more than two embryos should be replaced in the womb. There is growing pressure, he said, to return one. The European average for births per treatment cycle is around 20%, which compares with 26% in the United States, where there are high rates of multiple births. Private clinics put back large numbers of embryos to maximise women's chances of becoming pregnant, both to optimise their own success rates and because the couple can often not afford to return for further treatment for future babies.

fields.headline: IVF laser technique performs well
fields.trailText: The use of lasers to drill a hole in a fertilised egg - a technique banned in the US - is safe and successful in helping older women with fertility problems to have babies, according to new research.
fields.body:
The use of lasers to drill a hole in a fertilised egg - a technique banned in the US - is safe and successful in helping older women with fertility problems to have babies, according to new research.

Yesterday two Hungarian doctors reported that babies born to 96 women in the St John hospital in Budapest using the technique showed no higher rate of birth defects than usual.

Increasingly women over the age of 35, when fertility goes into decline, are seeking IVF (test tube baby treatment) because they have left it late to have a family.

But although they produce eggs and those eggs can be fertilised outside the womb, often the egg will not implant in the wall of the uterus.

The shell of the egg, called the zona pellucida, gets thicker and harder with age and will not burst under pressure from multiplying cells inside, as it should.

Katalin Kanyo and Janos Konc are using lasers to help the egg while it is still in the petri dish.

"We look through the microscope and measure the zona pellucida," said Dr Kanyo, "and then, with a surgical laser, we give two tiny bursts of energy."

The result is not so much a hole as a tunnel at the very edge of the shell with a diameter between 4.5 and 20 millionths of a metre. The egg, primed to hatch, is then placed in the uterus.

The Hungarian team focused on the safety of the technique, looking at 134 babies, now aged between six and 18 months, born to 96 women and found the malformation rate was just 2%.

In the study group were 32 patients over 35 and 11 over the age of 40. Dr Kanyo said the women had a 22% chance of taking home a baby - compared with just 4% or 5% normally.

webTitle: Postal workers fight sacking for delaying junk mail

fields.headline: Postal workers fight sacking for delaying junk mail
fields.trailText: It was snowy, slippery and raining hard when postmen David Hopkins and Alan Arthur decided their village could do without junk mail for a day.
fields.body:
It was snowy, slippery and raining hard when postmen David Hopkins and Alan Arthur decided their village could do without junk mail for a day.

Delivering the circulars would have meant visiting all 490 homes in Egerton, Kent, so they decided just to carry personal letters and packages.

Unfortunately for them, inspectors carrying out a spot check discovered what had happened and the pair were sacked.

On the same day, 16 miles away in Brabourne, Kent, postwoman Jean Wratten, 62, took the same decision with the same consequences.

Mrs Wratten, a postwoman for 29 years, said: "It was a terrible day, it had snowed overnight and the ground was a mixture of ice and slush."

She left the direct mail behind on April 4, intending to deliver it the next day, but slipped and fell on her round.

Laid up for three days, she returned to find her dismissal under way.

Now Egerton villagers have raised a petition with 473 signatures - nearly half the 1,000 residents - in support of Mr Hopkins, 50, whose father did the job before him, and Mr Arthur, 49, a postman for 25 years, who are appealing against their sacking. Mrs Wratten has also been flooded with letters of support.

Direct mail may be profitable for the Royal Mail and valued by businesses but Egerton villagers do not like it.

Susan Palmer, clerk to the parish council, said: "They have been dismissed for failing to deliver something no one wants."

Timothy Oliver, the parish council chairman, said: "The weather was very poor and they appear to have taken a decision which ensured all the important letters were delivered quickly and efficiently."

While both men admit holding back the circulars, their alleged offence is not telling head office in Ashford. They say they rang the office but received no answer.

The Royal Mail declined to comment yesterday. A decision on their appeal is expected next week. Mrs Wratten's appeal was being heard yesterday.

webTitle: Genome quiz: have you been paying attention?

fields.headline: Genome quiz: have you been paying attention?
fields.standfirst: You've probably heard that there has been a major scientific breakthrough this week. But do you really know what it's all about? Try our special genome quiz
fields.trailText: You've probably heard that there has been a major scientific breakthrough this week. But do you really know what it's all about? Try our special genome quiz.
fields.body:
1: What is a gene?

a: A length of DNA, contained in the nucleus of cells, which receives and issues chemical instructions regulating bodily functions
b: An unpleasant personal characteristic which can be blamed on your parents
c: A pleasing personal characteristic which surely couldn't have come from your parents
d: One leg of a pair of denim trousers

2: What is a genome?

a: The new Volkswagen people- carrier
b: The complement of haploid chromosomes contained in a single gamete or nucleus
c: A diminutive figurine for the garden

3: According to president Clinton, the decoding of the human genome could extend the life of Leo Blair by around:

a: 100 years
b: 50 years
c: 25 years
d: 10 years

4: To which two of the following landmarks in human achievement has the genome project not yet been compared by leading scientists and commentators?

a: The invention of the wheel
b: The Apollo moon landings
c: The Gutenberg printing press
d: The building of Noah's ark
e: The splitting of the atom
f: The discovery of antibiotics
g: The publication of the latest Harry Potter book

5: Which of the following has Craig Venter, the brilliant US scientist and rapacious capitalist who led the commercial bid to crack the genome, not been called?

a: Darth Venter
b: The Alan Turing of his generation
c: An asshole, an idiot and an egomaniac
d: Doctor Evil

6: What do the initials A, T, C and G stand for?

a: Adenine, thymine, cytosine and guanine
b: Anger, tearfulness, churlishness and greed
c: Allspice, thyme, cinnamon and garlic
d: Aren't they the singers in Steps?

7: The cost of the human genome project was equivalent to:

a: Five millennium domes, costing £758m apiece
b: One millennium dome
c: Around a quarter of a millennium dome

8: Celera is:

a: A new salt substitute recently endorsed by Jamie Oliver
b: A genetically modified celery seed unsuccessfully marketed by Monsanto
c: An Italian government funded project to isolate the genes which make men want to drive fast cars
d: The company founded by brilliant US scientist and rapacious capitalist Craig Venter

9: Written out in its entirety, the deciphered genome would fill

a: A telephone directory
b: 200 telephone directories
c: Enough telephone directories to fill the British Library

10: Who is most likely to win a Nobel Prize for sequencing the human genome?

a: Frances Collins, head of the International Human Genome Project
b: No one
c: Bill Clinton
d: Tony Blair

11: The finished human genome sequence will be

a: Available free of charge on the internet
b: Available for a fee on the internet as an insomnia treatment
c: Read out by the BBC on Saturday afternoons in place of Grandstand
d: Serialised in the Daily Telegraph

12: What is c elegans?

a: A new leisurewear range from Calvin Klein
b: A part of the male reproductive system
c: A species of worm on which altruistic and brilliant British scientist John Sulston, who led the project in Britain, did much of his early work
d: Iceland's top boy band

13: What outcome of genetics research is likely to have the biggest impact on society in the near future?

a: Most diseases will be curable
b: Doctors will be able to tell healthy people what diseases they are likely to get in future and whether specific drugs will work on them or not
c: FIFA will permit the FA to graft skill genes from European and South American footballers on to native players
d: The wealthy will be able to give birth to "designer children" - but the only designs available will be an Arnold Schwarzenegger/ Bill Gates hybrid (boys) and a Pamela Anderson/ Susan Sontag genotype (girls)

14: Which of the following is not true of John Sulston, the altruistic and brilliant British scientist?

a: He grows runner beans
b: He wears old leather sandals
c: He drives a secondhand car
d: He makes his own ginger beer

15: Sulston described the worm whose genetic map he produced as:

a: "A nice little mover"
b: "A nice little earner"
c: "Really quite sweet, once you get to know it"

16: What causes many diseases?

a: Tiny mutations in our genes
b: Stress
c: Supermodels
d: Overdose of hyperbole from politicians

17: Brilliant US scientist and rapacious capitalist Venter is a former:

a: Joy rider
b: Crack dealer
c: Professional surfer

18: Who are Crick and Watson?

a: A firm of lawyers specialising in gene patenting
b: The Anglo-American scientific team who discovered the structure of DNA
c: The British family firm which invented the first gene sequencing machine in 1924 but failed to exploit it
d: A popular singing duo from the 90s whose naïve ballads briefly entered the charts

19: The 82ft yacht belonging to the brilliant US scientist and rapacious capitalist Craig Venter is called:

a: The Sorcerer
b: The Schemer
c: The Schmoozer
d: The Egomaniac

20: If you unravelled the DNA in a single human cell, how long would it be?

a: Long enough to reach the moon and back
b: Exactly one furlong
c: Roughly the height of Craig Venter
d: How long is a piece of string?

Answers: 1,a; 2,b; 3,c; 4,d&g; 5,d; 6,a; 7,c; 8,d; 9,b; 10,b; 11,a; 12,c; 13,b; 14,d; 15,a; 16,a; 17,c; 18,b; 19, a; 20, c.

How do you rate?

16-20 Superhuman
11-15 Designer baby
6-10 Genetically modified
1-5 Evolutionary throwback

fields.headline: Council of war
fields.standfirst: The honeymoon between Whitehall and town hall is over.  Peter Hetherington  meets the reformer and assesses the changes
fields.trailText: The honeymoon between Whitehall and town hall is over. Peter Hetherington meets the reformer and assesses the changes.
fields.body:
Outwardly, the minister is bullish. Hilary Armstrong, after all, has quietly driven through potentially far-reaching changes in the government of England and Wales over the past three years by dragging - as she would put it - some tired old councils kicking and screaming into the 21st century.

Yet she still finds it hard to hide her frustration at the slow pace of change and the growing resistance of Labour councillors and backbenchers to reforms which are sweeping aside old committees in favour of town hall "cabinets". Many councillors feel they have now been pushed to the sidelines, relegated to scrutiny committees meant to monitor the executive, while an elite, usually about 10, makes key decisions behind closed doors.

Looking over her shoulder, Armstrong must know that some key Labour councillors, fed up with what they regard as Whitehall's centralising tendency riding roughshod over local democracy, are close to revolt. What's more, the Local Government Association (LGA), which begins its annual conference in Bournemouth today, has all but accused ministers of treating councils with contempt and, implicitly, undermining local democracy.

On the surface, at least, councils are being given more freedoms. Indeed, next year should herald a bright new dawn. Town hall modernisers in the Blairite New Local Government Network, which has strong links with the minister, are planning a "democracy day" in May with referendums in big cities (maybe Birmingham and Newcastle) and boroughs (like Watford and Lewisham) to further test the concept of elected executive mayors. Armstrong is pushing the idea, while others have raised the prospect of a government advertising blitz pushing for a "yes" vote.

"Despite the debacle in London, there is clear evidence that people out there are interested... and at least want to have a say about it," she says. "And, of course, a mayor in a borough will have very different powers, much stronger, than the mayor of London."

That's because big councils, unlike the new, slimline Greater London Authority, have unitary status, providing a full range of services, from education to social services, refuse collection, housing, planning and even economic development. Blessed with all these powers, a provincial mayor should be a far bigger-hitter than Ken Livingstone, who will frequently have to defer to 33 London councils.

But below the surface, the modernising agenda is murkier. It's one thing to lay the framework for cabinet-style government and elected mayors; quite another to give go-ahead councils the freedom they need, the ability to be more self-sustaining and, crucially, to raise more of their own cash (currently Whitehall provides three-quarters of town hall funding, council tax meets the rest).

While the government is prepared to give with one hand, councils fear ministers are preparing to take away with the other - gradually transferring key elements of local government, such as education, social services and housing provision, to central control, new partnerships with health authorities or, in the case of housing, arms-length companies and housing associations with powers to borrow on the open market.

"Frontline-first" is the much-vaunted agenda of David Blunkett, education secretary, and Alan Milburn, health secretary, to hop over councils and health authorities and direct money straight to schools and hospitals. With education and social services by far the biggest spending departments in local government, the agenda is sending shock waves through towns halls. Power, influence and - the LGA would say - local democracy is at stake. That's why delegates at Bournemouth this week will hear that the Labour-led association is preparing to fight as never before.

But if that wasn't bad enough, the government's attitude towards local government generally is far from clear. Will town halls, for instance, in future merely become a focus for local partnerships - covering areas from housing to urban regeneration, education and welfare - with less emphasis on direct control if Labour is re-elected for a second term?

With all sorts of initiatives being pushed down from Whitehall, from the New Deal for communities to a national strategy for neighbourhood renewal, just where do councils fit in? Different ministers give differing theories. Armstrong says that new legislation giving councils powers to promote social and economic well-being holds the key for ambitious town halls. "We see them as the key partner," she insists. "We are saying that where they become that key partner, where they demonstrate that level of leadership, then they will get the ability to really get new flexibilities and freedoms, too. If you look at some councils, they are the driving force for regeneration, for economic development, and they have the trust and the support of the business community, the voluntary sector and so on..."

But here's the threat. "If they're not," says the minister, "we're going to have to make sure that other people are taking the lead."

She seems to be offering a carrot and wielding a stick. Extolling the virtues of "strategic partnerships", embracing business and other stakeholders across authorities, she insists again: "We're saying they should really be the key to identifying priorities, but that then those priorities need to have their own neighbourhood focus... that has to involve local people in a very strong way." She adds: "The authority really ought to be the organisation leading that, but if they're not up to it, we would want to make sure that somebody [else] actually did it."

That takes us right back to the mayoral debate. A local government finance white paper, due shortly, will propose giving councils greater powers to borrow money for big capital projects without getting prior approval from Whitehall.

On the revenue side, Armstrong hints at the possibility of other freedoms - but falls well short of promising to give councils the power to set business rates (removed when the poll tax was briefly introduced eight years ago and distributed nationally by Whitehall). Councils might eventually be allowed to get 5% of that rate, with some who are granted "beacon" status getting 10%, but that's all.

"I don't want to over-egg the pudding," Armstrong cautions. "We're not going down the American route of not much national tax and more local tax. But there are some freedoms we're looking at. We always had a much greater principle in this country, one I want to uphold, of redistribution. Because we're a smaller country, that needs to be on a national level".

But there still remains the small matter of getting a new local government bill through parliament in the face of opposition from Lib-Dems and Tories as well as Labour backbenchers. They don't like the idea of new council cabinets - although one in three councils in England and Wales have now adopted this system - meeting in private and excluding the press and public.

Although draft guidance on the new bill now requires council cabinets to publish papers in advance of private meetings, 200 MPs - many of them Labour - have signed a commons motion urging the government to maintain "open" cabinet meetings.

Many councillors outside the charmed cabinet circle, who once played a key role in the old committee system, are now fuming on the sidelines, with little power and a lot of time on their hands. Their protests will ring out from Bournemouth this week. And much as ministers might dismiss them, many believe some concessions will have to be thrown their way if Labour is to avoid a messy internal battle.

The reform jargon and what it means

 Best value: new system for "continuous improvement" of all council services, replacing the Conservatives' regime of compulsory competitive tendering, policed by new 500-strong inspectorate at cost of £50m.

 Performance indicators: complex audit commission system of monitoring best value with hundreds of pre-determined minimum standards from street cleaning to refuse collection.

 Frontline first: new policy of directing Whitehall cash directly to schools, by-passing town halls. Could social services be next?

 Strategic partnerships : new agencies embracing councils, business and other local stake holders. Led to new regeneration companies being set up in Liverpool, east Manchester and Sheffield.

 Environmental, economic and social well-being: additional power recently granted to councils, allowing them to take wider role in creating jobs and improving local economies, ideally in partnership with others.

 Cabinet-style governance: ministers encouraged creation of town hall cabinets (145 now operating), modelled on Downing Street, in advance of new local government bill which gives go-ahead for elected mayors. Bill getting bogged down in parliament, but should receive royal assent next month.

Will town halls, for instance, in future merely become a focus for local partnerships - covering areas from housing to urban regeneration, education and welfare - with less emphasis on direct control if Labour is re-elected for a second term? With all sorts of initiatives being pushed down from Whitehall, from the New Deal for communities to a national strategy for neighbourhood renewal, just where do councils fit in? Different ministers give differing theories. Armstrong says that new legislation giving councils powers to promote social and economic well-being holds the key for ambitious town halls. "We see them as the key partner," she insists. "We are saying that where they become that key partner, where they demonstrate that level of leadership, then they will get the ability to really get new flexibilities and freedoms, too. If you look at some councils, they are the driving force for regeneration, for economic development, and they have the trust and the support of the business community, the voluntary sector and so on..." But here's the threat. "If they're not," says the minister, "we're going to have to make sure that other people are taking the lead." She seems to be offering a carrot and wielding a stick. Extolling the virtues of "strategic partnerships", embracing business and other stakeholders across authorities, she insists again: "We're saying they should really be the key to identifying priorities, but that then those priorities need to have their own neighbourhood focus... that has to involve local people in a very strong way." She adds: "The authority really ought to be the organisation leading that, but if they're not up to it, we would want to make sure that somebody [else] actually did it." That takes us right back to the mayoral debate. A local government finance white paper, due shortly, will propose giving councils greater powers to borrow money for big capital projects without getting prior approval from Whitehall. On the revenue side, Armstrong hints at the possibility of other freedoms - but falls well short of promising to give councils the power to set business rates (removed when the poll tax was briefly introduced eight years ago and distributed nationally by Whitehall). Councils might eventually be allowed to get 5% of that rate, with some who are granted "beacon" status getting 10%, but that's all. "I don't want to over-egg the pudding," Armstrong cautions. "We're not going down the American route of not much national tax and more local tax. But there are some freedoms we're looking at. We always had a much greater principle in this country, one I want to uphold, of redistribution. Because we're a smaller country, that needs to be on a national level". But there still remains the small matter of getting a new local government bill through parliament in the face of opposition from Lib-Dems and Tories as well as Labour backbenchers. They don't like the idea of new council cabinets - although one in three councils in England and Wales have now adopted this system - meeting in private and excluding the press and public. Although draft guidance on the new bill now requires council cabinets to publish papers in advance of private meetings, 200 MPs - many of them Labour - have signed a commons motion urging the government to maintain "open" cabinet meetings. Many councillors outside the charmed cabinet circle, who once played a key role in the old committee system, are now fuming on the sidelines, with little power and a lot of time on their hands. Their protests will ring out from Bournemouth this week. And much as ministers might dismiss them, many believe some concessions will have to be thrown their way if Labour is to avoid a messy internal battle. The reform jargon and what it means  Best value: new system for "continuous improvement" of all council services, replacing the Conservatives' regime of compulsory competitive tendering, policed by new 500-strong inspectorate at cost of £50m.  Performance indicators: complex audit commission system of monitoring best value with hundreds of pre-determined minimum standards from street cleaning to refuse collection.  Frontline first: new policy of directing Whitehall cash directly to schools, by-passing town halls. Could social services be next?  Strategic partnerships : new agencies embracing councils, business and other local stake holders. Led to new regeneration companies being set up in Liverpool, east Manchester and Sheffield.  Environmental, economic and social well-being: additional power recently granted to councils, allowing them to take wider role in creating jobs and improving local economies, ideally in partnership with others.  Cabinet-style governance: ministers encouraged creation of town hall cabinets (145 now operating), modelled on Downing Street, in advance of new local government bill which gives go-ahead for elected mayors. Bill getting bogged down in parliament, but should receive royal assent next month.

fields.headline: A helping hand
fields.standfirst: The care sector needs standards, says Melanie Henwood
fields.trailText: The care sector needs standards, says Melanie Henwood.
fields.body:
Among the one million strong social care workforce, 80% have no formal qualifications or training for the job. The care standards bill, currently before parliament, will begin to address this yawning gap and establish mechanisms for regulating training and setting practice standards.

Such changes are to be welcomed, but are they enough? This is the central question being addressed by a national inquiry established by the King's Fund, the independent health think tank.

Many people need help to maintain their independence in the community, whether because of ageing, physical impairment, chronic ill health, learning disability or mental health problems. Help takes different forms. For some, support is needed in the most basic (and intensely personal) areas of care: getting in and out of bed, using the toilet, having a bath or shower and getting dressed. For others, support may be needed in other aspects of daily life, from everyday tasks of shopping, cooking and cleaning, to help with medication.

It is the very diversity of these needs which indicates the potential complexity of the challenge. The people likely to be engaged in providing paid support are found not only in the social care arena, but also in health care and in the field of housing associations and supported housing. What links them is that they are all engaged in some way in assisting people to retain, regain, or strive towards a measure of independence - though the way in which they do so will look very different in different situations, precisely because their role is (or should be) tailored to the needs of the individual.

Setting standards for such diversity is problematic. It is easier in some fields than others and any standards which could operate across the board would be a blunt instrument indeed.

Concerns arise in two main and inter-related areas. The first stems from the vulnerability of people receiving these services. There are potential risks of neglect, of incompetent care and treatment and, at worst, of actual abuse (especially where support is provided in people's own homes). The second relates to the welfare and safety of the workforce. Of particular concern is the increasing substitution of support workers for more highly trained - and expensive - staff. With little training, and often next to no supervision, support workers find themselves undertaking demanding tasks for which they are ill-equipped.

Other concerns must also be addressed. Research among people who use support services shows time and again that "good" workers are seen as those who are personable and kind, who treat them with respect and dignity, who turn up when expected and who are responsive to changing needs. Staff who are unreliable, unsympathetic, disinterested, or worse, are viewed less positively. But how likely is it that a consistently competent and committed workforce can be recruited and retained under condi tions of low pay, lack of training and poor career prospects, or where there is an exploitative over-reliance on individual goodwill?

There is little opportunity to progress from care worker to professional or managerial positions. Expectations of employees are low and the largely female workforce continues, in the main, to be treated as part-time, unskilled manual labour, rather than as the most essential components of the flexible "high touch" service sector of the 21st century. Instead of a culture which encourages and rewards initiative, there is a rigid adherence to rules and procedures.

It is little wonder that many staff do not regard their employment as a vocation; that it is not a career path which young people aspire to follow; that turnover and discontent are high; or that the opening of a local supermarket can see a haemorrhage of care staff to take up the new jobs.

The planned general social care council will begin to address some of these vital issues. Codes of conduct for staff and codes of practice for employers will help to raise standards. So too, will the new national training organisations, promoting opportunities for learning and development of standards and core competencies. But there needs also to be recognition of the practical life skills which many care staff bring - skills which can never be taught and are rarely acknowledged.

A well-trained and qualified workforce will not be delivered overnight and it is likely to take a decade or more to transform the care sector. The King's Fund inquiry will map the problems and assess how far they are likely to be resolved by new arrangements. It will identify good practice, and the skills and characteristics of staff associated with such practice. It intends to report early in 2001 with practical and realistic recommendations for moving on the agenda.

 Melanie Henwood is an independent health and social care analyst, and secretary to the King's Fund inquiry.

webTitle: Venables - I would take over if Keegan quits

fields.headline: Venables - I would take over if Keegan quits
fields.trailText: Terry Venables has revealed that if Kevin Keegan quits the England manager's job he would be willing to take over - provided he was given the full backing of the Football Association hierarchy.
fields.body:
Terry Venables has revealed that if Kevin Keegan quits the England manager's job he would be willing to take over - provided he was given the full backing of the Football Association hierarchy.

Venables told the Daily Mail: "A lot of people keep telling me that I should re-open the door to an approach if Kevin walks away. They say a lot of people would want me back, especially the professionals in the game.

"But there would have to be a condition on my part: I would want to be sure I had the backing of everyone at the FA.

"This is a demanding job, which is even more difficult without that support.

"This does not imply any criticism whatsoever of Kevin on my part. Let's be clear about this.

"He is the man in the hot seat and he's doing his very best to make it all work."
